('28', 0, 1, 2, 40) 1. MY JAIL EXPERIENCE VI
('28', 0, 2, 3, 65) ETHICS OF FASTING
('28', 0, 3, 4, 83) When the incidents related in the Last chapter took place, my cell was situated in a triangular block containing eleven tells.
('28', 0, 3, 5, 210) They were also part of the separate division, but the block was separated from the other separate blocks by a high massive wall.
('28', 0, 3, 6, 339) The base of the triangle lay alongside the road leading to the other separate blocks.
('28', 0, 3, 7, 425) Hence, I was able to watch and see the prisoners that passed to and fro.
('28', 0, 3, 8, 498) In fact, there was constant traffic along the road.
('28', 0, 3, 9, 550) Communication with the prisoners was therefore easy.
('28', 0, 3, 10, 603) Some time after the flogging inci dent, we were removed to the European yard.
('28', 0, 3, 11, 681) The cells were better ventilated and more roomy.
('28', 0, 3, 12, 730) There was a pleasant garden in front.
('28', 0, 3, 13, 768) But we were more secluded and cut off from all contact with the prisoners whom we used to see whilst we were in the separate.
('28', 0, 3, 14, 894) I did not mind it.
('28', 0, 3, 15, 913) On the contrary, the greater seclusion gave me more time for contemplation and study.
('28', 0, 3, 16, 999) And the wireless remained intact.
('28', 0, 3, 17, 1033) It was impossible to prevent it so long as it was necessary for a single other prisoner or official to see us.
('28', 0, 3, 18, 1144) In spite of effort to the contrary, someone of them would drop a remark resulting in our knowing the happenings in the jail.
('28', 0, 3, 19, 1269) So one fine morning we heard that several Mulshi Peta prisoners were flogged for short task and that, as a protest against the punishment, many other Mulshi Peta prisoners had commenced a hunger strike.
('28', 0, 3, 20, 1472) Two of these were well known to me.
('28', 0, 3, 21, 1508) One was Devi and the other Dastane.
('28', 0, 3, 22, 1544) Mr. Dev had worked with me in Champaran, and had proved one of the most conscientious, sober and honest among the co workers whom I had the privilege of having in Champaran.
('28', 0, 3, 23, 1718) Dastane of Bhusaval is known to everybody.
('28', 0, 3, 24, 1761) The reader may therefore imagine my pain when I heard that Dev was among the party flogged and that he was also one of the hunger strikers.
('28', 0, 3, 25, 1901) Messrs Indulal Yagnik 1 and Manzar Ali Sokta were at this time my fellow prisoners.
('28', 0, 3, 26, 1985) They were agitated equally with me.
('28', 0, 3, 27, 2021) Their first thought was to declare a sympathetic hunger strike.
('28', 0, 3, 28, 2085) We discussed the propriety of such a strike and came to the conclusion that it would be wrong to do so.
('28', 0, 3, 29, 2189) We were neither morally nor in any other way responsible for the floggings or the subsequent hunger strike.
('28', 0, 4, 30, 2297) 1 Then secretary, Gujarat Provincial Congress Committee
('28', 1, 0, 1, 2353) 2 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 1, 1, 2, 2393) satyagrahis we were to be prepared for and to suffer cheerfully the rigours of jail life and even injustices including flogging.
('28', 1, 1, 3, 2522) Such hunger strike, therefore, with a view to preventing future punishment would be a species of violence done to the jail officials.
('28', 1, 1, 4, 2656) Moreover, we had no right to sit in judgment upon the action of the authorities.
('28', 1, 1, 5, 2737) That would be an end to all prison discipline.
('28', 1, 1, 6, 2784) And even if we wished to judge the authorities, we had not and could not get sufficient data to warrant an impartial judgment.
('28', 1, 1, 7, 2911) If the fast was to be out of sympathy with the hunger strikers, we had no data to enable us to judge whether their action was justified or not.
('28', 1, 1, 8, 3055) Any one of these grounds was sufficient to show that the proposed fast would be wholly premature.
('28', 1, 1, 9, 3153) But I suggested to my friends that I should try to find out the true facts through the Superintendent, and endeavour as before to get into touch with the hunger strikers.
('28', 1, 1, 10, 3324) I felt that we as human beings could not possibly remain uninterested in such matters although we were prisoners, and that under certain circumstances even a prisoner was entitled to claim a hearing in the matter of general jail administration when it was likely to result in the perpetration of gross injustice bordering on inhumanity.
('28', 1, 1, 11, 3661) So we all decided that I should approach the authorities in the matter.
('28', 1, 1, 12, 3733) The letter of 29th June, 1923 1, published in Young India of March 6, 1924, will give the reader further details about the matter.
('28', 1, 1, 13, 3864) There was a great deal of correspondence and negotiation which, being of a confidential nature, I do not wish to publish.
('28', 1, 1, 14, 3986) I can however say that the Government recognized that I had no desire to interfere with the prison administration and that my proposal to be permitted to see the two leaders among the hun ger strikers was dictated by purely humanitarian motives.
('28', 1, 1, 15, 4232) They, there fore, permitted me to see Messrs Dastane and Dev in the presence of the Superintendent and Mr. Griffiths, the Inspector General of Police.
('28', 1, 1, 16, 4383) It was to me a rare pleasure and a matter of pride to see these two friends walking unaided and with a steady step after full thirteen days unbroken fast.
('28', 1, 1, 17, 4538) They were as cheerful as they were brave.
('28', 1, 1, 18, 4580) I could see that they were terribly reduced in body, but their spirit had waxed strong in exact proportion to the reduction of the body.
('28', 1, 1, 19, 4717) As I hugged them and greeted them with the question, Are you nearly dead? they rang out, Certainly not, and Dastane added, We are able to prolong the fast indefinitely, if need be, for we are in the right.But if you are in the wrong? I asked.
('28', 1, 1, 20, 4960) We shall then like men admit our
('28', 1, 2, 21, 4993) 1 Vide Letter To Jail Superintendent, Yeravda, 29 6 1923.
('28', 2, 0, 1, 5051) VOL. 28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15AUGUST, 1924 3
('28', 2, 1, 2, 5091) mistake and abandon the fast, was the reply.
('28', 2, 1, 3, 5136) By their brightness they made me forget that they were suffering from pangs of hunger.
('28', 2, 1, 4, 5223) I wish I had leisure to reproduce the whole of the ethical discourse we held.
('28', 2, 1, 5, 5301) Their ground for fasting was that the punishment inflicted by the Superintendent was unjust and that, therefore, unless the Superin tendent admitted his mistake and apologized, they must go on with the fast.
('28', 2, 1, 6, 5509) I pleaded that this was not a correct attitude.
('28', 2, 1, 7, 5557) Whilst I was discuss ing the moral basis of their action, the Superintendent voluntarily and out of his usual good nature intervened and said, I tell you, if I felt that I had done wrong, I should surely apologize.
('28', 2, 1, 8, 5772) I know that I do make mistakes.
('28', 2, 1, 9, 5804) We all do.
('28', 2, 1, 10, 5815) I may have erred even in this case, but I am not conscious of it. I continued my pleading.
('28', 2, 1, 11, 5906) I told my friends that it was improper to expect an apology from the Superintendent unless he could be convinced that he was wrong.
('28', 2, 1, 12, 6038) Their fast could carry no conviction to him of the wrongness of the punishment.
('28', 2, 1, 13, 6118) Such convic tion could be brought about only by reasoning.
('28', 2, 1, 14, 6177) And, in any case, as satyagrahis who were out for suffering, how could they fast against injustices whether done to them or their co prisoners?
('28', 2, 1, 15, 6321) My friends appreciated the force of my argument and Major Joness generous statement did the rest.
('28', 2, 1, 16, 6419) They agreed to break the fast and to persuade the others to do likewise.
('28', 2, 1, 17, 6492) I asked for the Majors permission to give them a portion of my milk which he readily granted.
('28', 2, 1, 18, 6586) They accepted the milk but said they would first take their bath and then take the milk in the company of the other hunger strikers.
('28', 2, 1, 19, 6719) The Major ordered milk and fruit diet for the strikers during the period of recuperation.
('28', 2, 1, 20, 6809) A hearty handshake between us all terminated the meeting.
('28', 2, 1, 21, 6867) For the moment the officials were not officials and we were not prisoners.
('28', 2, 1, 22, 6942) We were all friends engaged in solving a knotty problem and glad that it was solved.
('28', 2, 1, 23, 7027) Thus ended this eventful hunger strike.
('28', 2, 1, 24, 7067) The Major admitted that this was the cleanest hunger strike he had witnessed.
('28', 2, 1, 25, 7145) He had taken extraordinary pre cautions to see that no food was passed to the prisoners surreptitiously and he was satisfied that none was passed.
('28', 2, 1, 26, 7292) Had he known the stuff of which these strikers were made, he need not have taken any precautions at all.
('28', 2, 1, 27, 7397) One permanent result of the incident was that the Government passed orders that, except in cases of the gravest provocation and insult offered to the officials, flogging should not be administered without the previous sanction of the superior authority.The precaution was undoubtedly necessary.
('28', 2, 1, 28, 7692) Whilst, in some matters, widest discretion must be given to the Superintendents of Jails, in matters such as
('28', 3, 0, 1, 7801) 4 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 3, 1, 2, 7841) punishments which cannot be recalled, the wisest of Superintendents must be subject to salutary checks.
('28', 3, 1, 3, 7945) There can be no doubt that the hunger strike of Messrs Dastane and Dev and the other satyagrahis produced startling results of a beneficial character.
('28', 3, 1, 4, 8096) For the motive, though mistaken, was excellent and the action itself purely innocent.
('28', 3, 1, 5, 8182) But though the result attained was good, the fast must be condemned.
('28', 3, 1, 6, 8251) The good result was not a direct result of the fast but of repentance and admission of mistaken motive and consequent abandonment of the fast.
('28', 3, 1, 7, 8394) Fasting by a satyagrahi can only be justified when it is a shame to eat and live.
('28', 3, 1, 8, 8476) Thus, still confining my attention to a prisoners conduct, it would be a shame to eat and live if I was deprived of religious liberty or degraded as a human being, as when food is thrown at me instead of being given to me in a courteous manner.
('28', 3, 1, 9, 8721) It should be unnecessary to say that religious objection should be really so and discourtesy should be such as would be felt by an ordinary prisoner.
('28', 3, 1, 10, 8871) The caution is necessary because a religious necessity is often pretended merely in order to embarrass, and discourtesy is often felt where none is meant.
('28', 3, 1, 11, 9026) I may not insist on keeping or bringing the Bhagavad Gita for the purpose of stealing in prohibited correspondence.
('28', 3, 1, 12, 9142) I may not resent as discourtesy the ordinary search which every prisoner must undergo.
('28', 3, 1, 13, 9229) In satyagraha there is no room for shams.
('28', 3, 1, 14, 9271) But I would have been bound to fast, say, if the Government had not given me the oppor tunity of seeing the hunger strikers merely with a view to understand their view point and dissuade them from their error, if I found them to be erring.
('28', 3, 1, 15, 9511) I could not afford to eat to live, when I knew that it was possible to prevent starvation if my keepers recognized the ordinary rules of humanity.
('28', 3, 1, 16, 9658) But, say some friends,why should you draw these fine distinctions?
('28', 3, 1, 17, 9725) Why should we not embarrass the jail officials as we embarrass officials outside?
('28', 3, 1, 18, 9807) Why should we co operate as you co operated with the jail authorities?
('28', 3, 1, 19, 9878) Why should we not non violently resist them?
('28', 3, 1, 20, 9923) Why should we obey any regulations at all, save for our own convenience?
('28', 3, 1, 21, 9996) Have we not a perfect right, is it not our duty, to paralyse the prison administration?
('28', 3, 1, 22, 10084) If we make the officials position uncomfortable without using any violence, the Government will find it difficult to arrest a large number and will thus be obliged to sue for
('28', 4, 0, 1, 10259) VOL. 28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15AUGUST, 1924 5
('28', 4, 1, 2, 10299) peace. This argument has been seriously advanced.
('28', 4, 1, 3, 10349) I must therefore devote the next chapter to its consideration.
('28', 4, 1, 4, 10412) Young India, 22 5 1924
('28', 4, 2, 5, 10435) 2. BOYCOTT FOREIGN CLOTH
('28', 4, 3, 6, 10460) Last week I endeavoured to show the futility of the boycott of Empire goods campaign.
('28', 4, 3, 7, 10546) I submit that it is even harmful in that it distracts the countrys attention from the only effective and indis pensable boycott.
('28', 4, 3, 8, 10675) I have admitted more than once that, if we eliminate non violence from our consideration, those who do not believe with me that non violence in politics is the only remedy for achieving our goal and are satisfied that non violent methods have failed, are not only justified in applying other remedies if they find them more effective, but are bound to do so.
('28', 4, 3, 9, 11034) My point, however, is that boycott of Empire goods is not at all feasible so long as the present system is in existence.
('28', 4, 3, 10, 11155) So far as I can sec.
('28', 4, 3, 11, 11176) the only alternative to non violence and all it implies is an armed rebellion.
('28', 4, 3, 12, 11255) If we wish to make preparations for it, boycott of Empire goods has not only a legitimate but it has a necessary place in the national programme.
('28', 4, 3, 13, 11401) Its retention and a fierce propaganda in its favour must increasingly heat our blood as we realize our impotence.
('28', 4, 3, 14, 11515) The natural consequence of such propaganda must there fore result in [sic] undisciplined violence all round.
('28', 4, 3, 15, 11624) It would not then matter that it is crushed.
('28', 4, 3, 16, 11669) It will still be considered a training in armed rebellion.
('28', 4, 3, 17, 11728) Each crushing will certainly bring demoralization among many but will bring increased determination among a few.
('28', 4, 3, 18, 11841) And out of that small determined band may arise an army of soldiers such as William the Silent 1 surrounded himself with.
('28', 4, 3, 19, 11963) If the national workers have come to the conclusion that India cannot write new history, but must do as the European countries have done, I would understand and appreciate their campaign of boycott of Empire goods.
('28', 4, 3, 20, 12178) Even though it may never succeed, it must be kept up as an ideal, because it would be regarded as one of the factories for generating the necessary steam.
('28', 4, 3, 21, 12333) India has a right to adopt the time worn method if she chooses to, and no power on earth can deprive her of that right.
('28', 4, 4, 22, 12453) 1 William I (1533 84); founder of the Dutch Republic; opposed Philip II in his persecution of Protestants and led a War of Liberation against Spanish armies and succeeded in gaining independence for a number of provinces of Holland.
('28', 5, 0, 1, 12686) 6 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 5, 1, 2, 12726) But I venture to say, with confidence, that the way of the sword is not open to India.
('28', 5, 1, 3, 12813) I dare to prophesy that if India chooses that way, she must be prepared: (1) either to submit to foreign rule for generations to come; (2) or to submit to exclusively Hindu or exclusively Mussalman rule almost in perpetuity.
('28', 5, 1, 4, 13038) I know that there are Hindus who, if they cannot have a purely Hindu India, are prepared to make the best terms with the Englishmen, and I know, too, that there arc Mussalmans who, till they arc able to impose a purely Mussalman rule on India, are prepared to resign themselves to the English domination.
('28', 5, 1, 5, 13343) To this minority I have no argument to address.
('28', 5, 1, 6, 13391) They must continue to plough the sands.
('28', 5, 1, 7, 13431) But I know that there is a very large majority that is impatient of foreign domination and is anxious to find an effective method of ridding India of it.
('28', 5, 1, 8, 13585) I do not despair of convincing them that swaraj in which Hindus, Mussalmans and all others professing different creeds can participate on equal terms is attainable in a much shorter time than they can imagine possible if the thinking portion adopts means that are strictly non violent, and of further convincing them that attain ment of such swaraj is impossible through any other means.
('28', 5, 1, 9, 13973) For the time being, however, I propose to assume that the Con gress creed being what it is, Congressmen are precluded from creating an atmosphere predisposed to violence.
('28', 5, 1, 10, 14144) Ineffective boycott of Empire goods must create such an atmosphere and, therefore, I go so far as to say that the boycott resolution was ultra vires of the Congress creed.
('28', 5, 1, 11, 14316) But this point can only be decided by the Congress.
('28', 5, 1, 12, 14368) Let me, therefore, confine the readers attention to the alter native boycott of foreign cloth.
('28', 5, 1, 13, 14463) I suggest to the Liberals, Nationalists and Congressmen that, if they will all adopt the hand spun khaddar for their own personal use to the exclusion of all foreign or Indian mill cloth and if they will themselves religiously spin for a definite period every day and persuade every member of their family to do likewise, and if they will to the extent of their ability introduce the wheel and the use of khaddar among their neighbours, the nation can bring about the boycott of foreign cloth even in a years time.
('28', 5, 1, 14, 14978) Even as they may not, on any pretext whatsoever, use foreign cloth, they may not use cloth manufactured in our mills.
('28', 5, 1, 15, 15096) I must distinguish bet ween the two prohibitions.
('28', 5, 1, 16, 15146) Boycott of foreign cloth is a vital necessity for all time.
('28', 5, 1, 17, 15206) There is no question of a permanent national boycott of
('28', 6, 0, 1, 15262) VOL. 28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15AUGUST, 1924 7
('28', 6, 1, 2, 15302) mill cloth.
('28', 6, 1, 3, 15314) But Indian mills alone can never supply the present demand for cloth, whereas the charkha and the hand loom can.
('28', 6, 1, 4, 15427) But the khaddar, the product of the charkha, has yet to become popular and universal.
('28', 6, 1, 5, 15513) It can only be so if the thinking portion of India will make the commencement.
('28', 6, 1, 6, 15592) They must, therefore, restrict their use of cloth to khaddar only.
('28', 6, 1, 7, 15659) Our mills need no patronage from us.
('28', 6, 1, 8, 15696) Their goods are popular enough.
('28', 6, 1, 9, 15728) Moreover, the nation has no control over the mills.
('28', 6, 1, 10, 15780) They are not philanthropic institutions.
('28', 6, 1, 11, 15821) They are frankly selfish.
('28', 6, 1, 12, 15847) They have their own propaganda.
('28', 6, 1, 13, 15879) If they recognize the signs of the times, they will help the foreign cloth boycott movement by cheapening their cloth and taking to areas not served at present by khaddar.
('28', 6, 1, 14, 16051) They can, if they will, avoid competition with khaddar and be satisfied with supplementing it.
('28', 6, 1, 15, 16146) Boycott of foreign cloth cannot be immediately accomplished unless every national worker religiously avoids the use of mill made cloth.
('28', 6, 1, 16, 16282) Surely, the proposition is too simple to need any argument.
('28', 6, 1, 17, 16342) Khaddar, which has to find a market, must command preference among enlightened men.
('28', 6, 1, 18, 16426) I have hitherto examined the use of khaddar as the only effec tive and speedy means of bringing about a successful boycott of foreign cloth as distinguished from and as an alternative to that of Empire goods.
('28', 6, 1, 19, 16635) But when to this potency of khaddar is added its power to feed the starving millions, the case becomes irresistible.
('28', 6, 1, 20, 16752) It is perhaps now easy to understand why a charkha atmosphere has to be created and why every man and woman and child who understands the necessity of the charkha for the national well being must religiously spin for some time every day.
('28', 6, 1, 21, 16990) The peasantry of India is among the most industrious in the world as it is perhaps also the idlest.
('28', 6, 1, 22, 17090) Both its industry and idleness are imposed upon it.
('28', 6, 1, 23, 17142) It must work to make its fields yield their harvest.
('28', 6, 1, 24, 17195) The East India Company by killing hand spinning made it idle when it had no full labour to do.
('28', 6, 1, 25, 17290) The peasantry will now return to the charkha only when we set the example.
('28', 6, 1, 26, 17365) Mere precept will produce little impression upon it.
('28', 6, 1, 27, 17418) And when thousands spin for love, it is possible to give higher wages for spinning if we would keep the same price for khaddar.
('28', 6, 1, 28, 17546) I have myself been able to sell khaddar manufactured at the Satyagraha Ashram cheaper because I had maunds of yarn lovingly thrown to me by the Punjabi sisters during my tour in the Punjab in 1919. It was possible for me, if I had liked, to pay their wages to professional spinners, and not reduce the price of khaddar.
('28', 6, 1, 29, 17866) I (lid not do so because, at that early
('28', 7, 0, 1, 17906) 8 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 7, 1, 2, 17946) stage of the khaddar movement, I was paying so high a price as 4 annas for one pound of yarn indifferently spun.
('28', 7, 1, 3, 18059) If the Liberals and the Congressmen, stung by the Kenya decision, hurled the ineffective boycott of Empire goods at the heads of the white Colonists of Kenya, why will they not, in their cooler moments, concentrate their effort upon the complete success of the khaddar movement and thereby ensure the boycott of all foreign cloth?
('28', 7, 1, 4, 18390) Need I prove that the boycott of foreign cloth will not only bring relief to the Kenya Indians, but it will also bring swaraj?

('28', 7, 3, 7, 18549) TO A MOHAMMEDAN, A HINDU
('28', 7, 4, 8, 18574) A correspondent or correspondents sent some time ago a question of importance for answer in these columns.
('28', 7, 4, 9, 18681) As the letter was unsigned and as I do not wish to encourage anonymous correspon dence, I consigned it to the waste paper basket.
('28', 7, 4, 10, 18811) If the correspondent (for I suspect one writer has assumed two names) is serious about his question, he must disclose his identity not for publication but as an earnest of his own bona fides.
('28', 7, 5, 11, 19003) PANDIT MALAVIYAJI ON MOPLAH RELIEF

('28', 7, 6, 13, 19128) The following is the translation of what he says in a letter written to me in Hindi: I agree with every word of what you have written about helping Moplah women and children.
('28', 7, 6, 14, 19303) Where is the merit in a man who returns good for good?
('28', 7, 6, 15, 19358) The wise call him only good who does good to the evil doer.
('28', 7, 6, 16, 19418) They alone arc good who do good to those that do harm to them and these good souls adorn the earth; for it is the better for their birth. Please do not infer from the verse quoted by me that in my opinion all Moplahs have injured Hindus.
('28', 7, 6, 17, 19656) But even assuming that all the Moplahs have done us an injury, even then must we serve them in

('28', 8, 2, 6, 20160) PRINCIPAL GIDWANI
('28', 8, 3, 7, 20178) In reply to my inquiry, the Administrator of Nabha State has favoured me with the following reply which is dated 12th May 1 924.
('28', 8, 4, 8, 20307) DEAR SIR,
('28', 8, 5, 9, 20317) I am in receipt of your letter of the 5th of May.
('28', 8, 5, 10, 20367) I instituted enquiries with regard to Principal Gidwanis condition in jail, with the following results:
('28', 8, 6, 11, 20471) Mr. Gidwani is wearing jail clothes, but these are clean, and he is allowed soap to wash them when he desires.
('28', 8, 6, 12, 20582) He has never fasted since 2 21st March, 1924. He is in a good state of health, and his wright is I maund 38 seers.
('28', 8, 6, 13, 20697) Up to the present he has received the same food as other convicts in the jail but has been allowed milk on certain occasions on medical grounds.
('28', 8, 6, 14, 20842) I understand that no difficulties are presented to his receiving visitors, and that only recently he was allowed to receive his wife and brother, and that every facility was provided on that occasion.
('28', 8, 6, 15, 21043) Under the Jail Rules, visitors can only be received once in six months.
('28', 8, 7, 16, 21115) I have personally visited the jail and satisfied myself as to the above facts.
('28', 8, 7, 17, 21194) Mr. Gidwani asked me for certain facilities, such as the cooking of his own food, provision of vegetables and some ghee, and permission to take exercise.
('28', 8, 7, 18, 21348) These requests were granted by me.
('28', 8, 7, 19, 21383) He made no complaints to me as to any rough treatment by the jail authorities or anybody else, although he had an opportunity of doing so as I interviewed him alone.
('28', 8, 8, 20, 21549) You seem to be under some misapprehension as to the conditions under which Principal Gidwani is imprisoned.
('28', 8, 8, 21, 21657) He was sentenced under Sections 188 and 145 of the Indian Penal Code in October last together with Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru and Mr. Santanam.
('28', 8, 8, 22, 21798) I, as Administrator, suspended the sentences passed in those cases on condition that these gentlemen left the State and did not return thereto without permission.
('28', 8, 8, 23, 21961) Mr. Gidwani broke the conditions of the suspension of the sentences when he returned to Nabha State on February the 21st.
('28', 8, 8, 24, 22083) He is now in jail undergoing the sentences that were passed upon him in the first instance.
('28', 8, 8, 25, 22175) There is no intention of trying Mr. Gidwani upon any further charge.
('28', 8, 8, 26, 22244) Thus Principal Gidwani is to suffer the original into years imprisonment for having crossed to the Nabha State border, in Mr. Zimands opinion, in the interest of humanity.
('28', 8, 8, 27, 22416) Principal Gidwani does
('28', 9, 0, 1, 22439) 10 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 9, 1, 2, 22480) not complain because he never asked for his release in the first instance.
('28', 9, 1, 3, 22555) Rut what is the public to think of an administration under which a man is imprisoned for doing what he considered was an act of humanity, and which, as a matter of fact, too, resulted in no injury to anybody?
('28', 9, 1, 4, 22764) If Mr. Zimand is to believed, Principal Gidwani had no intention of entering the State in the company of the Jatha.
('28', 9, 1, 5, 22880) I do not suppose it is contended that Principal Gidwani insists upon remaining in the State limits if he is left free.
('28', 9, 1, 6, 22999) It would, therefore, seem that he is being made to serve the sentence without any just cause whatsoever.
('28', 9, 2, 7, 23104) ARE SIKHS HINDUS?
('28', 9, 3, 8, 23122) A friend from the Punjab writes:
('28', 9, 4, 9, 23155) The Akalis here are more or less enraged at your note about Vaikom in which you class them with Mussalmans and Christians as non Hindus.
('28', 9, 4, 10, 23292) I have had many people complaining to me that the Sikhs never formally dissociated themselves from Hinduism.
('28', 9, 4, 11, 23401) And as for some people refusing to be called Hindus, it is pointed out that Swami Shraddhanand 1 himself some time ago look strong exception to be called a Hindu.
('28', 9, 4, 12, 23564) Several prominent members of the S.G.P.C. are members of the Hindu Sabha; and though, undoubtedly, there is a feeling among one section of Akalis that it is better to disclaim all connection with Hinduism, there is an equally strong section which is conservative on this matter.
('28', 9, 4, 13, 23843) Of course, they want their temples separated from general Hindu temples and to be under their own control.
('28', 9, 4, 14, 23950) But this is the case with all Hindu sects.
('28', 9, 4, 15, 23993) The Jains, so far as I am told, have the same right; and it is pointed out to me that the Sikhs are claiming no more than the Aryas, Brahmos and others not belonging to the orthodox Hindu traditions claim.
('28', 9, 4, 16, 24199) After close acquain tance with the Sikh leaders here and with some study of the Sikh movement, I myself feel that to class Akalis as non Hindus is not entirely fair to them.
('28', 9, 4, 17, 24373) I am very glad to find that Sikh friends resent my classing them with non Hindus.
('28', 9, 4, 18, 24455) I assure them that I had no such intention whatsoever.
('28', 9, 4, 19, 24510) During my first tour in the Punjab I happened to say in speaking of the Sikhs that, in my opinion, they were a part of the Hindu community.
('28', 9, 4, 20, 24650) I did so because I knew that millions of Hindus believed in Guru Nanak and that the Granth Saheb was filled with the Hindu spirit and Hindu legends.
('28', 9, 4, 21, 24799) But a Sikh friend who was present at the meeting took me aside and said with the gravest concern that my inclusion of the Sikhs in the Hindu community had given offence, and the friend advised me in future never to speak of the Sikhs in the same breath as Hindus.
('28', 9, 4, 22, 25063) During my tour in the Punjab, I found that the
('28', 9, 5, 23, 25110) 1 1856 1926; nationalist leader of the Arya Samaj
('28', 10, 0, 1, 25160) VOL. 28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15AUGUST, 1924 11
('28', 10, 1, 2, 25201) caution given by the friend was well given.
('28', 10, 1, 3, 25245) For I noticed that many Sikhs regarded themselves as belonging to a religion distinct from Hinduism.
('28', 10, 1, 4, 25346) I promised the friend never again to refer to the Sikhs as Hindus.
('28', 10, 1, 5, 25413) Nothing would, therefore, please me better than to find that the separatist tendency is confined only to a very few Sikhs and that the general body regard themselves as Hindus.
('28', 10, 1, 6, 25590) I have met with the same fate from Arya Samajists.
('28', 10, 1, 7, 25641) An innocent reference to them as being part of Hindus was also resented.
('28', 10, 1, 8, 25714) One gentleman felt insulted when, without the slightest intention of hurting his feelings, I referred to him as a Hindu.
('28', 10, 1, 9, 25835) I soothed him by immediate apology.
('28', 10, 1, 10, 25871) I have not fared much better with some Jains.
('28', 10, 1, 11, 25917) During my tour in Maharashtra I found many Jains telling me that they were a community apart from Hindus.
('28', 10, 1, 12, 26023) I have never understood the Jain objection, because there is so much in common between Jainism, Buddhism and Hinduism.
('28', 10, 1, 13, 26142) I could somewhat understand the Arya Samaj objection, because the Samajists are, if one may say so without giving offence, fanatically hostile to idol worship and Pauranic literature and everything outside the Vedas and the Upanishads.
('28', 10, 1, 14, 26378) But Jainism and Buddhism have, so far as I know, no such quarrels with Hinduism.
('28', 10, 1, 15, 26459) Indeed, Buddhism and Jainism are mighty reforms in Hinduism.
('28', 10, 1, 16, 26520) Buddhism rightly insisted on internal purity.
('28', 10, 1, 17, 26566) Its appeal went straight to the heart.
('28', 10, 1, 18, 26605) It broke down arrogant assumption of superiority.
('28', 10, 1, 19, 26655) Jainism represents the highest flight of logic.
('28', 10, 1, 20, 26703) It has taken nothing for granted and has endeavoured to prove metaphysical truth by challenging the intellect.
('28', 10, 1, 21, 26814) In my opinion, we have hardly touched the vast literature that these two reform movements have produced.
('28', 10, 2, 22, 26919) Holding the views I do, I hope my Sikh friends will appreciate the fact that, if I have classed them as non Hindus, it is out of delicate regard for their feelings and against my own inclination.
('28', 10, 2, 23, 27115) So far as the Sikh kitchen is concerned, it is a menace whether the Sikhs may be regarded as Hindus or non Hindus.
('28', 10, 2, 24, 27230) All this outside intrusionfor I cannot call it anything elsetakes no note of the orthodox sensitiveness or the difficulty of the Durbar And now that I have learnt the facts more fully about the Sikh kitchen, I cannot help saying that it compromises the self respect of the Kerala people.
('28', 10, 2, 25, 27518) They are not living in starvation.
('28', 10, 2, 26, 27553) If I was a volunteer, I would rather starve than be fed by outside charity, whether Hindu or non Hindu Surely, the Kerala people must be trusted to see to the feeding of their volunteers.

('28', 11, 1, 2, 27782) VIRTUE PENALIZED
('28', 11, 2, 3, 27799) The renters explanation for not working the shop and for not tapping and drawing toddy from the trees for the shop unsatisfactory.
('28', 11, 2, 4, 27930) He is fined Rs. 50. Such is the entry in the proceedings of the Revenue Divisional Officer of Namakal in the Madras Presidency.
('28', 11, 2, 5, 28058) The reader knows that the shop is a drink shop.
('28', 11, 2, 6, 28106) The renters explanation was that the drinkers had decided not to drink and, therefore, he saw no use in keeping the shop open.
('28', 11, 2, 7, 28233) He was, however, willing to pay the rent.
('28', 11, 2, 8, 28275) This explanation was not satisfactory.
('28', 11, 2, 9, 28314) Nor was it enough that the abstaining villagers were ready to pay the Government the whole years stipulated profits from the drink traffic for the luxury of indulging in their newly acquired virtue of abstinence.
('28', 11, 2, 10, 28527) That was not to be, for the law was against them.
('28', 11, 2, 11, 28577) If the whole of the proceedings were legally examined, it would probably be found that the officials concerned could give no other decision.
('28', 11, 2, 12, 28718) They arc not at fault.
('28', 11, 2, 13, 28741) It is the system that is bad, for in that system revenue is the primary consideration, not the health of the soul or the body.
('28', 11, 2, 14, 28868) Had it been otherwise, the drink and the opium traffic would have gone long ago.
('28', 11, 2, 15, 28949) One blessing conferred upon the people by the reforms is that the drink and the drug revenue is earmarked for the education of our children.
('28', 11, 2, 16, 29090) I do hope that the villagers and the poor renter will have the strength to withstand all fines and other penalties for the reform they have inau gurated.
('28', 11, 3, 17, 29244) KHADI UMBRELLAS
('28', 11, 4, 18, 29260) A correspondent who is a thorough believer in khaddar asks what one should do for umbrellas.
('28', 11, 4, 19, 29353) I do not regard umbrellas as clothing and personally I should not hesitate to use a foreign umbrella.
('28', 11, 4, 20, 29455) But I have seen umbrellas covered with khaddar.
('28', 11, 4, 21, 29503) I know too that it is possible by smearing khaddar with water proof composition to make it water proof.
('28', 11, 4, 22, 29607) It may be an expensive process but a deter mined man will not count the cost.
('28', 11, 4, 23, 29685) I know also a poor mans um brella.
('28', 11, 4, 24, 29720) Prisoners arc not allowed the use of umbrellas except con vict warders on out door duty.
('28', 11, 4, 25, 29809) We had in Yeravda Very useful and more effective protection against rain by lucking one corner into another of a gunny bag and hanging it loosely on the head.
('28', 11, 4, 26, 29968) The correspondent is also puzzled over the use of silk dhotis for sacred wear.
('28', 11, 4, 27, 30047) For me khadi is more sacred than silk, foreign or homespun, for the simple reason that silk manufacture is confined to a
('28', 12, 0, 1, 30168) VOL. 28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15AUGUST, 1924 13
('28', 12, 1, 2, 30209) few thousands; yarn manufacture extends to millions But the move ment does permit one to use homespun khaddar.
('28', 12, 1, 3, 30320) Here again coarse woollen dhotis are suggested as a perfect substitute for silk.
('28', 12, 1, 4, 30401) It is not without difficulty that one can procure hand spun silk and then there is always doubt whether the silk yarn is foreign or home spun.
('28', 12, 2, 5, 30544) PARODY OF RELIGION
('28', 12, 3, 6, 30563) A Delhi correspondent writes:
('28', 12, 4, 7, 30593) There are about sixty houses of Chamars in Rohed in the district of Rohtak.
('28', 12, 4, 8, 30669) These are all labourers and have no property rights in the village land.
('28', 12, 4, 9, 30742) They used to take water from the village pond so long as it was available.
('28', 12, 4, 10, 30817) But after that supply failed they were at the mercy of the zemindars for the well water.
('28', 12, 4, 11, 30906) The latter would keep them waiting for hours before condescending to issue it to the poor untouchables.
('28', 12, 4, 12, 31010) Latterly in order to avoid this delay a com mittee was appointed with a view to devise a remedy.
('28', 12, 4, 13, 31107) This committee con tained one Chamar.
('28', 12, 4, 14, 31145) It decided that the Chamars should appoint a member of the Mali (gardener) caste to draw water for them and pay him Rs. 15 per month.
('28', 12, 4, 15, 31279) Ale Chamars were disposed to agree but now they feel that they ought not to pay what is after all a heavy and iniquitous monthly tax upon them.
('28', 12, 4, 16, 31423) What is one to do?
('28', 12, 4, 17, 31442) Should the Chamars approach the Government officials for a piece Of land to dig their own well?
('28', 12, 4, 18, 31538) Will it not be in conflict with Non co opera tion?
('28', 12, 4, 19, 31589) The answer to the question asked is exceedingly simple.
('28', 12, 4, 20, 31645) The Chamars are non co operators.
('28', 12, 4, 21, 31679) They have no polities.
('28', 12, 4, 22, 31702) But the staunchest non co operator is not precluded from buying or getting land from the Government for necessary purposes.
('28', 12, 4, 23, 31826) The less he does so undoubtedly the better.
('28', 12, 4, 24, 31870) But there is no bar against it in the Congress resolution.
('28', 12, 4, 25, 31929) A non co operator who understands the spirit of the resolution will certainly not buy land from the Government for profit.
('28', 12, 4, 26, 32052) In the case in point the land is required for the necessaries that nature has imposed upon us.
('28', 12, 4, 27, 32147) And if the Chamars can get land from the Government for digging a well, the staunchest non co operator, in my opinion, need not hesitate to assist them to get it.
('28', 12, 4, 28, 32310) But the answer to the question is the least difficult part of my task.
('28', 12, 4, 29, 32381) What is to be said of the Hindu zemindars who would not have the decency and the ordinary humanity to issue water in due time to men who belong to their own religion and who serve them in hundreds of ways?
('28', 12, 4, 30, 32587) And all this callousness in the name of religion?
('28', 12, 4, 31, 32637) If their well is likely to be polluted by the Chamars using them, why will they not pay the gardener for the luxury of enjoying their exclusive ness?
('28', 12, 4, 32, 32787) Why will they not give them a plot of land for digging a well in
('28', 13, 0, 1, 32852) 14 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 13, 1, 2, 32893) Does my correspondent know whether the zemindars have been approached for a plot of land?
('28', 13, 1, 3, 32983) If a deputation waits on them, they will perhaps not only grant a plot, but have a well dug at their expense.
('28', 13, 1, 4, 33093) If the attempt has not been made, it should be made.
('28', 13, 1, 5, 33146) Immediate relief may be obtained by securing a piece of land from the Government.
('28', 13, 1, 6, 33228) But the campaign against untouchability is an attempt to blot it out from Hinduism.
('28', 13, 1, 7, 33312) No numbers of separate wells will do it.
('28', 13, 1, 8, 33353) Hindu reformers have, therefore, a double task before them to secure relief for the suffering brethren, and to change, by a proper appeal to them, the hearts of those who believe in the evil and savage custom of regarding our own kith and kin as untouchables.

('28', 13, 4, 13, 33854) 5. STATEMENT TO ASSOCIATED PRESS OF INDIA
('28', 13, 5, 14, 33896) [BOMBAY,] May 22, 1924 After having discussed with the Swarajist friends the vexed question of entry into the Legislative Assembly and the Councils by the Congressmen, 2 I am sorry to have to say that I have not been able to see eye to eye with the Swarajists.
('28', 13, 5, 15, 34157) I assure the public that there has been no lack of willingness or effort on my part to accept the Swarajist position.
('28', 13, 5, 16, 34275) My task would be much simpler if I could identify myself with it.
('28', 13, 5, 17, 34341) It can be no pleasure to me to oppose even in thought
('28', 13, 6, 18, 34395) 1 In her speech, Sarojini Naidu had advised the children to be good to each other irrespective of the race they might belong to.
('28', 13, 6, 19, 34524) Her concluding words were: You are going to say: We will not live in a country where there is division between race and race, where there is hatred and selfishness. When you love the whole world, the whole world will he full of peace and joy. 2 The week long consultations between Gandhiji, Motilal Nehru and C. R. Das had proved inconclusive.
('28', 13, 6, 20, 34868) For the Swarajists statement, vide Appendix Swarajists Statement on Council Entry, 22 5 1924.
('28', 14, 0, 1, 34962) VOL. 28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15AUGUST, 1924 15
('28', 14, 1, 2, 35003) the most valued and respected leaders, some of whom have made great sacrifices in the cause of the country and who yield to no one in their love of freedom of the motherland, but, in spite of my effort and willingness, I have failed to be convinced by their argument.
('28', 14, 1, 3, 35271) Nor is the difference between them and myself one of mere detail.
('28', 14, 1, 4, 35337) There is an honest and fundamental difference.
('28', 14, 1, 5, 35384) I retain the opinion that Council entry is inconsistent with non co operation as I conceive it.
('28', 14, 1, 6, 35480) Nor is this difference a mere matter of interpretation of the word non co operation, but relates to the essential mental attitude resulting in different treatment of vital problems.
('28', 14, 1, 7, 35662) It is with reference to such mental attitude that the success or the failure of the triple boycott is to be judged and not merely by a reference to the actual results attained.
('28', 14, 1, 8, 35839) It is from that point of view that I say that to be out of the legislative bodies is far more advantageous to the country than to be in them.
('28', 14, 1, 9, 35981) I have, however, failed to convince my Swarajist friends.
('28', 14, 1, 10, 36039) But I recognize that, so long as they think otherwise, their place is undoubtedly in the Councils.
('28', 14, 1, 11, 36138) It is the best for us all.
('28', 14, 1, 12, 36165) It was hardly to be expected that the Swarajists could be convinced by the arguments I advanced in the course of the conversations.
('28', 14, 1, 13, 36297) They are many of them amongst the ablest, most experienced and honest patriots.
('28', 14, 1, 14, 36377) They have not entered the legislative bodies without full deliberation and they must not be expected to retire from the position until experience has convinced them of the futility of their methods.
('28', 14, 1, 15, 36576) The question, therefore, before the country is not an exami nation and determination of the merits of the Swarajist view and mine.
('28', 14, 1, 16, 36707) The question is: what is to be done now regarding Council entry as a settled fact?
('28', 14, 1, 17, 36790) Are the Non co operators to keep up their hostility against the Swarajists method or are they to remain neutral and even help, whenever it is possible or consistent with their principles?
('28', 14, 1, 18, 36978) The Delhi and Cocanada resolutions have permitted those Con gressmen who have no conscientious scruples to enter the Councils and the Assembly, if they want to do so .
('28', 14, 1, 19, 37146) In my opinion, the Swarajists are therefore justified in entering the legislative bodies and expecting perfect neutrality on the part of the No changers.
('28', 14, 1, 20, 37300) They are also justified in resorting to obstruction, because such was their policy and the Congress laid down no conditions as to their entry.
('28', 14, 1, 21, 37443) If the work of the Swarajists prospers and the country benefits, such an ocular demonstration cannot but convince honest sceptics like me of our
('28', 15, 0, 1, 37588) 16 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 15, 1, 2, 37629) error, and I know the Swarajists to be patriotic enough to retrace their steps when experience has disillusioned them.
('28', 15, 1, 3, 37748) I would, therefore, be no party to putting any obstacles in their way or to carrying on any propaganda against the Swarajists entry into the Legislatures, though I cannot actively help them in a project in which I do not believe.
('28', 15, 1, 4, 37978) The purpose of the Delhi and Cocanada resolutions was to allow the Swarajists a Chance of trying the method of Council entry and that purpose can be served only if the No changers, with scrupulous honesty, allow the Swarajists full liberty to pursue their programme in the Councils, unfettered by any obstruction from them.
('28', 15, 1, 5, 38302) With regard to the method of work in the Councils, I will say that I would enter a legislative body if only I found that I could at all use it to advantage.
('28', 15, 1, 6, 38459) If, therefore, I enter the Councils, I should, without following a general policy of obstruction, endeavour to give strength to the Constructive Programme of the Congress.
('28', 15, 1, 7, 38631) I should, therefore, move resolutions requiring the Central or the Provincial Government, as the case may be, (1) To make all their cloth purchases in hand spun and hand woven khaddar; (2) To impose a prohibitive duty on foreign cloth, (3) To abolish the drink and drug revenue, and (4) At least correspondingly reduce the army expenditure.
('28', 15, 1, 8, 38972) If the Government refuses to enforce such resolutions when carried in the Legislatures, I should invite them to dissolve them and take the vote of the electors on the specific points.
('28', 15, 1, 9, 39156) If the Government would not dissolve, I should resign my seat and prepare the country for civil disobedience.
('28', 15, 1, 10, 39266) When that stage is reached, the Swarajists will find me ready to work with and under them.
('28', 15, 1, 11, 39357) My test of fitness for civil disobedience remains the same as before.
('28', 15, 1, 12, 39427) During the state of probation, I should advise the No chan gers not to worry about what the Swarajists are doing or saying and to prove their own faith by prosecuting the Constructive Programme with undivided energy and concentration.The khaddar and the national schools are enough to occupy every available worker who believes in quiet, honest and undemonstrative work.
('28', 15, 1, 13, 39798) Tile Hindu Mus lim problem too will tax the best energy and faith or the workers.
('28', 15, 1, 14, 39880) The No changers can justify their opposition to Council entry only by
('28', 16, 0, 1, 39950) VOL. 28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15AUGUST, 1924 17
('28', 16, 1, 2, 39991) showing the results of their application though the Constructive Pro gramme even as the Pro changers must justify their entry by results.
('28', 16, 1, 3, 40129) TheNo changers are in one respect in an advantageous posi tion; for they can secure the co operation of the Pro changers.
('28', 16, 1, 4, 40251) The latter have declared their faith in the Constructive Programme, but their contention is that by itself, the Constructive Programme cannot enable the country to reach the goal.
('28', 16, 1, 5, 40431) In the prosecution, however, of the Constructive Programme outside the Legislatures, all No chan gers, Pro changers and others can, if they will, work in unison through their respective organizations if necessary.
('28', 16, 1, 6, 40645) The statement is incomplete without an examination of the working of the Congress organization.
('28', 16, 1, 7, 40741) I hold drastic and definite views in the matter, but I must reserve their expression for a future, though early, occasion.

('28', 20, 1, 2, 45943) 13. MY REQUEST
('28', 20, 2, 3, 45958) I shall have reached Satyagraha Ashram some time next week.
('28', 20, 2, 4, 46018) 1 I have to say regretfully that I have not yet recovered sufficient strength to be able to tolerate noise, attend meetings or make speeches.
('28', 20, 2, 5, 46160) Even moving about is only possible to a certain extent.
('28', 20, 2, 6, 46216) In my present state, the hope that I shall be able to see many men and women should be given up both by them and me.
('28', 20, 2, 7, 46333) I know that many are anxious to meet me.
('28', 20, 2, 8, 46374) I am as eager for such meeting as they are.
('28', 20, 2, 9, 46418) For the time being, however, we both must restrain our desire.
('28', 20, 2, 10, 46481) Everyone, therefore, should for the present assume that I have not yet entered Gujarat at all.
('28', 20, 2, 11, 46576) Let everyone take it that I have gone to the Ashram for change of air as I had gone to Juhu.
('28', 20, 2, 12, 46669) 2 If all brothers and sisters oblige me to this extent, I shall have some peace and be ableto carry the burden of work I have to.
('28', 20, 2, 13, 46799) Almost all the energy I have is spent in running Navajivan and Young India.
('28', 20, 2, 14, 46875) 3 With what is left I can just cope with my correspon dence.
('28', 20, 2, 15, 46936) I am, of course, continuing to observe silence on Mondays and Wednesdays.
('28', 20, 2, 16, 47010) 4 I utilize those days for writing for my papers.
('28', 20, 2, 17, 47060) On those days, therefore, I would not desire to see anyone.
('28', 20, 2, 18, 47120) On the other days, I intend to see visitors from 4 to 6 in the evening, as I do in Juhu.
('28', 20, 2, 19, 47209) On these days, too, I intend to observe silence in the morning.
('28', 20, 2, 20, 47273) If I do not observe this rule, I cannot avoid meeting people who turn up unex pectedly to see me and, if I see them, I cannot cope with my work.
('28', 20, 2, 21, 47418) I desire to observe this rule scrupulously till the end of July at any rate.
('28', 20, 2, 22, 47495) What I shall do thereafter will depend on the state of my health and the volume of work.
('28', 20, 2, 23, 47584) This, then, is my request for the sake of my physical well being.
('28', 20, 2, 24, 47650) The second request concerns our national work.
('28', 20, 2, 25, 47697) There is a lot to be done, about which I have been giving my views through the pages of Navajivan.
('28', 20, 2, 26, 47796) But may I ask for one favour?
('28', 20, 2, 27, 47826) Am I fated to see

('28', 21, 0, 1, 48349) 22 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 21, 1, 2, 48390) Gujaratis still wearing foreign cloth?
('28', 21, 1, 3, 48429) Will the time never come when I shall see Gujarat clothed exclusively in khadi?
('28', 21, 1, 4, 48509) Vallabhbhai has planned to raise a purse of Rs. 10 lakhs.
('28', 21, 1, 5, 48567) Will he not plan to make Gujarat completely khadi minded?
('28', 21, 1, 6, 48625) If anyone asked me whether I would have from Gujarat a crore of rupees or that it should become completely khadi minded, I would say at once, without the slightest hesitation, that I would rather see Gujarat become khadi minded than give me a crore of rupees.
('28', 21, 1, 7, 48885) I do not wish to announce the day of my departure from Bombay.
('28', 21, 1, 8, 48948) Let no one be curious to find out.
('28', 21, 1, 9, 48983) I desire that even those who come to know it do not crowd at the station.
('28', 21, 1, 10, 49057) How much yarn could those people produce if they spent the time in spinning instead of coming to the station?
('28', 21, 1, 11, 49167) If we devote half of our spare time to spinning, we can easily produce all.
('28', 21, 1, 12, 49243) the yarn needed by the country.
('28', 21, 2, 13, 49275) SIMPLE CALCULATION
('28', 21, 3, 14, 49294) The average annual per capita requirement of cloth comes to 13 yards.
('28', 21, 3, 15, 49364) Let us assume that this quantity of cloth weighs three seers.
('28', 21, 3, 16, 49426) So much can be easily produced by one person if he spins no more than half an hour daily.
('28', 21, 3, 17, 49516) That is to say, if half the population spins only for one hour a day it can supply the yarn needs of the entire country.
('28', 21, 3, 18, 49637) May I hope that, instead of taking the trouble to come to the station, my brothers and sisters will restrain their eagerness and give that time to spinning?

('28', 21, 4, 20, 49831) 14. BRAHMACHARYA
('28', 21, 5, 21, 49848) It is not easy to write on this subject.
('28', 21, 5, 22, 49889) But my own experience is so wide that I always wish to give some of it to the reader.
('28', 21, 5, 23, 49975) Many letters which I have received have strengthened that wish.
('28', 21, 5, 24, 50039) A friend asks: What is brahmacharya?
('28', 21, 5, 25, 50076) Is perfect observance of brahmacharya possible?
('28', 21, 5, 26, 50124) If it is, do you observe it so?
('28', 21, 5, 27, 50156) The full and correct meaning of brahmacharya is search for the brahman.
('28', 21, 5, 28, 50228) As the brahman is immanent in everyone, it can be known through contemplation and the inner illumination resulting from it.
('28', 21, 5, 29, 50352) This illumination is not possible without complete control over the senses.
('28', 21, 5, 30, 50428) Hence, brahmacharya means control in thought,
('28', 22, 0, 1, 50474) VOL. 28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15AUGUST, 1924 23
('28', 22, 1, 2, 50515) speech and action of all senses, at all places and at all times.
('28', 22, 1, 3, 50580) The man or woman who observes such perfect brahmacharya is totally free from disease and, therefore, he or she lives ever in the presence of God, is like God.
('28', 22, 1, 4, 50739) I have no doubt that complete observance of such brahmacharya in thought, speech and action is possible.
('28', 22, 1, 5, 50844) I regret to say that I have not attained to the state of such perfect brahmacharya.
('28', 22, 1, 6, 50928) I am striving every moment to reach it.
('28', 22, 1, 7, 50968) I have not given up the hope of attaining that state in this very life.
('28', 22, 1, 8, 51040) I have acquired control over my body.
('28', 22, 1, 9, 51078) I can guard myself during the waking state.
('28', 22, 1, 10, 51122) I have acquired fairly good control over speech.
('28', 22, 1, 11, 51171) I have yet to gain good enough control over my thoughts.
('28', 22, 1, 12, 51228) When I begin to think about a certain matter, I may have thoughts about other matters too, resulting in a constant clashing of thoughts.
('28', 22, 1, 13, 51365) Even so, in my waking moments I am able to stop such clash of thoughts.
('28', 22, 1, 14, 51437) I have attained a state, it can be claimed, in which ugly thoughts at any rate do not trouble me.
('28', 22, 1, 15, 51535) But I have less control over my thoughts during sleep.
('28', 22, 1, 16, 51590) In that state, all manner of thoughts come to me, even strange dreams, and sometimes desire for indulgences familiar to the body also wakes up in me.
('28', 22, 1, 17, 51740) When the thoughts are unclean, there may be involuntary discharge too.
('28', 22, 1, 18, 51811) This condition is possible only in a life troubled by desire.
('28', 22, 1, 19, 51873) The disturbances in my thoughts are becoming weaker, but I have not ceased altogether.
('28', 22, 1, 20, 51960) Had I acquired complete mastery over my thoughts, I would not have been, during the last ten years, afflicted with the three diseases of pleurisy, dysentery and appendicitis.
('28', 22, 1, 21, 52135) 1 I believe that the body encasing a healthy atman is bound to be healthy Hence, as the atman becomes healthieris less and less troubled by desirethe body too becomes healthier.
('28', 22, 1, 22, 52313) This does not mean that a healthy body is necessarily a strong body.
('28', 22, 1, 23, 52382) It is only in a lean body that a strong atman lives.
('28', 22, 1, 24, 52435) As the atman grows in strength, the body becomes leaner.
('28', 22, 1, 25, 52492) A perfectly healthy body can be very lean.
('28', 22, 1, 26, 52535) A strong body usually suffers from some disease.
('28', 22, 1, 27, 52584) Even if it has no disease, it is quick to catch infection or contract a disease, whereas a perfectly healthy body will never catch an infection.
('28', 22, 1, 28, 52729) Pure blood has the pro perty of keeping off destructive germs of infection.
('28', 22, 2, 29, 52805) 1 Gandhiji had an attack of pleurisy in October 1914, of dysentery in August 1918 and of appendicitis in January 1924.
('28', 23, 0, 1, 52924) 24 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 23, 1, 2, 52965) Such a wonderful state is certainly difficult to attain.
('28', 23, 1, 3, 53022) Else I would have reached it, for, as my atman testifies, I would not be remiss in taking all measures necessary for attaining it.
('28', 23, 1, 4, 53153) There is nothing in this world which can keep me from striving for it.
('28', 23, 1, 5, 53224) But it is not easy for everyone to undo the accumulated effects of his past.
('28', 23, 1, 6, 53301) Despite this delay, however, I have not been in the least disheartened, for I am able to visualize the desireless state, am able to glimpse it faintly, and the progress I have made makes me hopeful rather than otherwise.
('28', 23, 1, 7, 53522) More over, even if I should die without realizing my hope, I do not believe that I would have failed in my striving.
('28', 23, 1, 8, 53639) I am as certain of rebirth as that this body exists.
('28', 23, 1, 9, 53692) I am sure, therefore, that even a modest effort does not go in vain.
('28', 23, 1, 10, 53761) I have given this account of my experiences only in order that my correspondents and others in the same position may have patience and self confidence.
('28', 23, 1, 11, 53913) All have the same atman.
('28', 23, 1, 12, 53938) The power of the atman is the same in all.
('28', 23, 1, 13, 53981) Only, it has been manifested in some and in others it is still to be manifested.
('28', 23, 1, 14, 54062) They too, if they try, will have like experience.
('28', 23, 1, 15, 54112) So far I have discussed brahmacharya in its comprehensive meaning.
('28', 23, 1, 16, 54179) The conventional and commonly accepted meaning of brahmacharya is, simply, control of the sex impulse in thought, speech and action.
('28', 23, 1, 17, 54312) This view of it is realistic, for observance of brahmacharya in this sense is believed to be very difficult.
('28', 23, 1, 18, 54421) Control over the palate has not been equally emphasized, and that has made control of the sex impulse more difficult.
('28', 23, 1, 19, 54539) It has become almost impossible.
('28', 23, 1, 20, 54572) Again, the experience of doctors tells us that a person whose body is weakened by disease is more troubled by sex desire and this is an additional reason why observance of brahmacharya seems difficult to our disease ridden people.
('28', 23, 1, 21, 54803) I have referred above to a body being lean but healthy.
('28', 23, 1, 22, 54859) No one should take me to mean that one need not develop physical strength.
('28', 23, 1, 23, 54934) I have merely expressed, in my imperfect language, my idea about brahmacharya in its finest aspect.
('28', 23, 1, 24, 55034) What I have said may possibly be misunderstood.
('28', 23, 1, 25, 55082) Anyone who wishes to acquire complete control over all the senses has no choice, ultimately, but to welcome his body becoming lean.
('28', 23, 1, 26, 55214) When blind love of the body and attachment for it decline, no desire for physical strength will be left.
('28', 23, 1, 27, 55319) But the body of a brahmachari who has conquered sex desire ought to be strong and glowing with vigour.
('28', 23, 1, 28, 55422) Even the observance of
('28', 24, 0, 1, 55445) VOL. 28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15AUGUST, 1924 25
('28', 24, 1, 2, 55486) this brahmacharya raises one above the common level.
('28', 24, 1, 3, 55539) He who does not feel physical urge even in a dream deserves to be honoured by the world.
('28', 24, 1, 4, 55628) There is little doubt that it is easy for such a one to exercise self control in other matters.
('28', 24, 1, 5, 55724) About brahmacharya in this sense, another friend writes:
('28', 24, 2, 6, 55781) My condition is pitiable.
('28', 24, 2, 7, 55807) Whether I am chanting the name of God, whether I am in the office or walking in the street, whether I am reading at night or working, I get those very thoughts.
('28', 24, 2, 8, 55968) What should I do to control my thoughts?
('28', 24, 2, 9, 56009) How can one develop the same regard for every woman as one has for ones mother?
('28', 24, 2, 10, 56089) What should be done so that the eyes will shine with nothing but pure affection?
('28', 24, 2, 11, 56170) What is the way to be free from evil thoughts?
('28', 24, 2, 12, 56217) I have preserved with me your article 1 on brahmacharya, but in this place it is of no help to me at all.
('28', 24, 2, 13, 56323) This is a touching plight.
('28', 24, 2, 14, 56350) Many find themselves in such a con dition.
('28', 24, 2, 15, 56393) But there is no cause for apprehension as long as ones mind wrestles with thoughts of that kind.
('28', 24, 2, 16, 56490) If the eyes offend, they should be closed.
('28', 24, 2, 17, 56533) If the ears offend, they should be plugged with cottonwool.
('28', 24, 2, 18, 56593) It is a good habit to walk with ones eyes always on the ground.
('28', 24, 2, 19, 56657) They will, then, get no opportunity at all to see anything else; One should run away from a place where people are talking obscene things or singing obscene songs.
('28', 24, 2, 20, 56821) One must acquire control over the palate.
('28', 24, 2, 21, 56863) It is my experience that anyone who has not conquered the palate cannot conquer the sex impulse.
('28', 24, 2, 22, 56960) It is very difficult to conquer the palate.
('28', 24, 2, 23, 57004) But victory over it is essential for the other victory.
('28', 24, 2, 24, 57060) One way to conquer the palace is to give up condiments wholly or as far as possible, and another effective way is to keep thinking that we eat merely to keep the body and soul together, and that we would never indulge the palate.
('28', 24, 2, 25, 57290) We breathe not for the pleasure of breathing, but for taking in air.
('28', 24, 2, 26, 57359) We drink water to slake thirst and, likewise, we should eat only to satisfy hunger.
('28', 24, 2, 27, 57443) Right from childhood, our parents develop in us the opposite habit.
('28', 24, 2, 28, 57511) They spoil us by teaching us to enjoy all manner of delicacies, which they do, not for our nourishment, but to show their love for us.
('28', 24, 2, 29, 57646) We have to fight such tendencies.
('28', 24, 2, 30, 57680) But the golden rule for conquering the sex impulse is to keep repeating the magic name of Rama or some such holy word.
('28', 24, 2, 31, 57799) Even the Dwadash mantra 2 serves the same purpose.
('28', 24, 2, 32, 57850) One may choose the
('28', 24, 3, 33, 57869) 1 Presumably, How Celibacy Can Be Observed, 10 11 1921; vide How Celibacy can be Observed?, 10 11 1921. 2 Om Namo Bhagavate Vasudevaya: Salutation to Lord Vasudeva; this

('28', 25, 1, 2, 58080) mantra to be chanted as prompted by ones faith.
('28', 25, 1, 3, 58128) I have suggested the name of Rama because I was initiated into it from my childhood and have always found support in it.
('28', 25, 1, 4, 58249) Whichever mantra we choose, we must become one with it.
('28', 25, 1, 5, 58305) Even if other thoughts distract us while we repeat the mantra, I have no doubt at all that anyone who keeps repeating it with faith will succeed ultimately.
('28', 25, 1, 6, 58462) The mantra will come to be the support of ones life and save one from all dangers.

('28', 25, 3, 14, 59248) One learns from it that some workers have resolved to wear khadi exclusively and some others to have the spinning wheel and the loom in their homes.
('28', 25, 3, 15, 59397) The workers are running twenty schools and eight hundred children study: in them.
('28', 25, 3, 16, 59479) ALL of them wear khadi.
('28', 25, 3, 17, 59503) To supply their needs, the organizers have got stitched long shirts, caps, etc., and as these were mass produced, the stitching costs of the long shirt and the cap came to no more than two annas and nine pies for the former and six pies for the latter.

('28', 25, 4, 19, 59817) If you buy a pound of khadi: Ten annas will go to one of our peasants.

('28', 25, 4, 21, 59952) Four to six annas will go to some poor woman who spun the yarn.

('28', 28, 1, 2, 64675) 18. KATHIAWAR RAJPUT CONFERENCE 1
('28', 28, 2, 3, 64709) I wish very much to attend this Conference which is about to meet, but that seems quite impossible.
('28', 28, 2, 4, 64809) Kathiawar was a land of warriors.
('28', 28, 2, 5, 64843) The valour of the Rajputs is world renowned.
('28', 28, 2, 6, 64888) But the Rajputs of today are not likely to become brave by singing praises of their valour in the past.
('28', 28, 2, 7, 64992) When the Brahmin gave up pursuit of higher knowledge, the Rajput became commerce minded, forsaking his traditional duty of defending people, and the Vania 2 took to paid service, who can blame the Sudra if he ceased to be a servant?
('28', 28, 2, 8, 65225) When the four castes fell, they gave rise, against the spirit of religion, to a fifth one and this came to be looked upon as a class of untouchables.
('28', 28, 2, 9, 65375) Having created this fifth class, the four castes kept it in suppression and, in consequence, they themselves came to be suppressed and fell.
('28', 28, 2, 10, 65516) Who will rescue the Hindus from this plight?
('28', 28, 2, 11, 65561) If the Hindus are not saved, the Muslims also cannot escape the same fate.
('28', 28, 2, 12, 65636) If twenty two crores fall, surely the other seven crores cannot survive.
('28', 28, 2, 13, 65709) When a train is in motion, we cannot stand close to it because its velocity is likely to drag us along.
('28', 28, 2, 14, 65813) Indias freedom thus lies in the regeneration of the Hindus.
('28', 28, 2, 15, 65873) The country can be saved only if this regeneration is religious in character.
('28', 28, 2, 16, 65951) If the Hindus try to imitate the West in order to acquire its physical strength, they will themselves fall and bring down others as well.
('28', 28, 2, 17, 66089) Who will save this fallen Hindu society?
('28', 28, 2, 18, 66130) Who will inspire courage in the timid?
('28', 28, 2, 19, 66169) Surely, this duty belongs to the Kshatriya.
('28', 28, 2, 20, 66213) If, therefore, the Rajput Conference wants to understand its duty and discharge it, the Rajputs will have to consider what their dharma is.
('28', 28, 2, 21, 66353) For protecting others, it is not necessary to possess the strength of the sword.
('28', 28, 2, 22, 66434) The age of such strength has passed, or is passing.
('28', 28, 2, 23, 66486) The world has had plenty of experience of the sword and has had enough of it.
('28', 28, 2, 24, 66564) Even the West seems to have tired of it.
('28', 28, 2, 25, 66605) He who protects others by killing the enemy is no Kshatriya; he is a true Kshatriya who protects others by laying down his own life.
('28', 28, 2, 26, 66738) He is no brave man who runs away from danger; one who stands firm, chest forward, and bears blows without striking back is a Kshatriya.
('28', 28, 3, 27, 66874) 1 Held, presumably, in June 1924; vide The Purdah and the Pledge, 22 6 1924. 2 Member of mercantile community
('28', 29, 0, 1, 66984) 30 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 29, 1, 2, 67025) But let us suppose for a moment that the sword is necessary.
('28', 29, 1, 3, 67086) What then?
('28', 29, 1, 4, 67097) If Rama used it, it was after he had purified himself through tapascharya by living in the forest for fourteen years.
('28', 29, 1, 5, 67215) The Pandavas, too, lived in the forest.
('28', 29, 1, 6, 67255) Arjuna 1 went to god Indra 2 himself and obtained divine weapons.
('28', 29, 1, 7, 67321) One must get the power which comes through tapas 3 before acquiring the strength of arms.
('28', 29, 1, 8, 67411) If this is not done, the result would be senseless fighting as among the Yadavas 4
('28', 29, 2, 9, 67494) and, just as the latter destroyed themselves with their own arms, our weapons would kill us.
('28', 29, 2, 10, 67587) Hence the first task before the Rajput Conference is to raise the Rajputs.
('28', 29, 2, 11, 67662) A Rajput may talk of his rights, but he should first talk of his duty.
('28', 29, 2, 12, 67733) He should give up addictions, adopt simplicity, befriend the poorest among Kathiawaris, share his sufferings and serve him.
('28', 29, 2, 13, 67857) No one can deprive him of this right to serve.
('28', 29, 2, 14, 67904) If anyone in Kathiawar is forced to leave it, a Raiput should feel ashamed of it.
('28', 29, 2, 15, 67986) Theres the wherewithal of life where there are the spinning wheel, the carding bow and the loom.
('28', 29, 2, 16, 68083) Why do Kathiawaris leave the heavenly climate of the region for the foul air of Bombay?
('28', 29, 2, 17, 68171) It is for the Rajputs, more than for others, to answer this question.
('28', 29, 2, 18, 68241) The discredit for this should certainly go to the rulers.
('28', 29, 2, 19, 68299) If the rulers of Kathiawar concern themsel ves only with the well being of their subjects, why should the latter have to leave their land?
('28', 29, 2, 20, 68438) The rulers will not, of course, be present at the Rajput Conference but, if the Rajputs mean it, even they will understand.
('28', 29, 2, 21, 68562) This is an age of democracy and so the rulers will become what the subjects are and remain so.
('28', 29, 2, 22, 68657) The Rajputs are in a position to make a worthy contribution to the national awakening.
('28', 29, 2, 23, 68744) If the members of the Conference spend more time examining their own shortcomings than spotting out those of others, they will be showing the way on the royal road.
('28', 29, 2, 24, 68909) Nowadays we blame others for our sufferings; we forget or wish to forget that we ourselves are responsible for them.
('28', 29, 2, 25, 69026) If there is none to tolerate tyranny, what can the tyrant do?
('28', 29, 2, 26, 69088) So long as we remain weak enough to be enslaved, there will be people who will seek to enslave us.
('28', 29, 2, 27, 69187) It is an easy, though useless,
('28', 29, 3, 28, 69218) 1 The most valiant of the five Pandavas in the Mahabharata
('28', 29, 4, 29, 69277) 2 King of the gods 3 Austerities 4 Shri Krishnas kinsmen; with the advent of the Age of Strife, they were possessed by the spirit of evil and, after an orgy of drinking, destroyed themselves by fighting against one another.

('28', 30, 1, 2, 69542) exercise to abuse such people.
('28', 30, 1, 3, 69573) It is certainly difficult to understand our own weakness and remove it, but that is the only course which will yield results.
('28', 30, 1, 4, 69699) And since the means of removing it is in our own hands, no one can deprive us of it.
('28', 30, 2, 5, 69784) It is my earnest appeal to the members of the Rajput Conference that they give their most serious attention to this suggestion and do some self examination.
('28', 30, 3, 6, 69941) Finally, let me give them a little advice from experience.
('28', 30, 3, 7, 70000) Let them beware of speeches and speech makers.
('28', 30, 3, 8, 70047) They would do well to keep away from these.
('28', 30, 3, 9, 70091) Work will be done better if it is done in silence.
('28', 30, 3, 10, 70142) One who goes on shouting about his hunger will not satisfy the hunger of the hungry, but a good man, dumb from birth, taking a handful of bajra 1 to them, will bring light to their eyes, colour to their cheeks and a smile to their lips.
('28', 30, 3, 11, 70379) They will bless the dumb man from the depth of their hearts.
('28', 30, 3, 12, 70440) God does not teach us through speeches, but He ever remains active.
('28', 30, 3, 13, 70508) He is awake even when we are asleep.
('28', 30, 3, 14, 70545) He can spare no time from His work to make speeches.
('28', 30, 3, 15, 70598) I request the Rajputs to devote themselves exclusively to work, and thus set an example to other workers of Kathiawar who are all too ready with the tongue, but in action are clever diplomats.

('28', 31, 3, 6, 71216) 20. TRIUMPH OF SPRING May 25, 1924 The poet 1 killed Pandu and burnt Madri and thus celebrated the triumph of spring.
('28', 31, 3, 7, 71334) In the Chaitra issue of Vasant, Shri Anandshan karbhai 2 has tried to celebrate a somewhat similar triumph of a violent nature.
('28', 31, 3, 8, 71462) He has attempted to do so by attributing to me certain views about mill cloth.
('28', 31, 3, 9, 71541) If he succeeds in his attempt, the cause of poor khadi would be completely ruined.
('28', 31, 3, 10, 71624) Hence, we deem it our duty to prevent the success of this violent attack.
('28', 31, 3, 11, 71698) The reader is well aware that I seldom interest myself in criticizing any newspaper or individual.
('28', 31, 3, 12, 71797) Such criticism seems pointless to me; it gives rise to unnecessary controversy and sometimes even ill feeling.
('28', 31, 3, 13, 71908) I have no cause for fear in regard to Shri Anandshankars articles.
('28', 31, 3, 14, 71975) Between us there may be differences of opinion, but there can be no misunderstanding.
('28', 31, 3, 15, 72061) As I write this, a co worker puts in my hand the note in Vasant which I have referred to.
('28', 31, 3, 16, 72151) I do not, therefore, wish to check the desire to reply to it.
('28', 31, 3, 17, 72213) However, readers should not hope that I shall always be ready to enter into such friendly controversies even with Vasant.
('28', 31, 3, 18, 72335) My duty is to place my ideas before the public and, if
('28', 31, 4, 19, 72390) 1 Manishankar Bhatt, who wrote a poem entitled Vasant Vijaya, Triumph of Spring, on the Mahabharata story of how Panda, father of the Pandava heroes, met his death.
('28', 31, 4, 20, 72555) Yielding to the influence of spring, Pandu disregarded the curse on him and sought union with his wife, Madri, and died in consequence.
('28', 31, 4, 21, 72691) Madri, too, immolated herself on the funeral pyre.
('28', 31, 4, 22, 72742) 2 Anandshankar Bapubhai Dhruva (1869 1942); Sanskrit scholar and Gujarati writer, Pro Vice Chancellor of the Banaras Hindu University, 1920 37; founded and edited Vasant, a Gujarati journal

('28', 32, 1, 2, 72973) any issues arise, to solve them from a distance.
('28', 32, 1, 3, 73022) I always regard myself as vanquished by everyone.
('28', 32, 1, 4, 73072) I am never keen to convince people thro ugh arguments, and I have often found that the imperfect language in which the imperfect thoughts of an imperfect man are expressed cannot explain his meaning fully.
('28', 32, 1, 5, 73278) Moreover, if the readers impati ence and opposition to the authors views are added to the threefold imperfection, they would further diminish his capacity to understand the argument.
('28', 32, 1, 6, 73461) It is because I believe that, in such circumstances, the proper thing is to say little and let work speak for itself, that I do not enter into argument and, in consequence, do not need to read many newspapers.
('28', 32, 1, 7, 73671) The note in Vasant is itself a good instance of what I have said.
('28', 32, 1, 8, 73737) Had Anandshankarbhai fully understood my views, he would have found nothing to say against them, or, if he had thought it necessary to write anything, it would have been to welcome the movement to popularize the exclusive use of khadi and this would have made my task and that of Gujarat, as also the path of swaraj, easy.
('28', 32, 1, 9, 74060) But how can I expect that he would understand them?
('28', 32, 1, 10, 74112) Why should he or anyone else read what I have written elsewhere in this connection?
('28', 32, 1, 11, 74196) They naturally form their opinions on the basis of what they happen to read or see.
('28', 32, 1, 12, 74280) I am certainly to blame for going on writing on the subject though aware of this difficulty.
('28', 32, 1, 13, 74373) If one must write, one should use such langu age as will admit of no misconstruction.
('28', 32, 1, 14, 74459) But, then, if one can com mand such language, need one write?
('28', 32, 1, 15, 74521) Only an imperfect person reso rts to writing.
('28', 32, 1, 16, 74567) Hence, we have no choice but to tolerate each others failings.
('28', 32, 1, 17, 74630) If we keep trying to overcome our failings and in the mean time maintain cordial relations with others, we may not reach perfec tion, but we shall certainly make some progress towards our goal.
('28', 32, 1, 18, 74824) It would be simpler for me and the reader if I re state my ideas rather than try to reply to Anandshankarbhais criticism: 1. I have no particular love or dislike for the textile industry.
('28', 32, 1, 19, 75012) 2. Even if there were no textile mills, India could meet its require ment of cloth by means of the spinning wheel and the handloom.
('28', 32, 1, 20, 75144) There is enough evidence to prove this.
('28', 32, 1, 21, 75184) 3. Mill made cloth requires no encouragement, as that industry faces no risks.
('28', 32, 1, 22, 75263) 4. There is, for the seven lakh villages of India, only one possible cottage industry to supplement agriculture, and that is spinning and weaving.
