('28', 33, 1, 2, 75451) 5. The use of khadi is still new.
('28', 33, 1, 3, 75485) It has not yet gained a permanent place and has to make its way against foreign and mill made cloth.
('28', 33, 1, 4, 75586) 6. Only a small section of the public is within the reach of the present movement; if even this section is permitted to wear mill made cloth, who will be left to use khadi and when will the come to use it?
('28', 33, 1, 5, 75792) If it is possible to popularize khadi even in some measure, that can be done only when this small section of society learns to regard the use of khadi as a religious duty and insists on wearing it.
('28', 33, 1, 6, 75990) 7. It is essential to boycott foreign cloth.
('28', 33, 1, 7, 76035) It is a threat to the interests of the textile mills in India.
('28', 33, 1, 8, 76098) I see no happy signs of Indians taking to the use of khadi immediately; hence, Indian mill made cloth has ample scope.
('28', 33, 1, 9, 76217) It has reason to fear not khadi but foreign cloth.
('28', 33, 1, 10, 76268) Hence, I should certainly like to see sufficient import duties levied to save the textile industry from this danger.
('28', 33, 1, 11, 76385) 8. I believe that even the spinning wheel and the hammer are machines.
('28', 33, 1, 12, 76456) I have always accepted, and still accept, the principle that external machinery is unnecessary.
('28', 33, 1, 13, 76552) I believe likewise in the need for self control in regard to outward possessions.
('28', 33, 1, 14, 76634) The West believes in just the opposite.
('28', 33, 1, 15, 76674) In other words, from its point of view, progress consists in increasing use of machines.
('28', 33, 1, 16, 76763) Believers in both these principles give importance to machinery.
('28', 33, 1, 17, 76828) Ancient civilization regards it as a necessary evil and assigns it a secondary place; modern civilization welcomes it as something desirable.
('28', 33, 1, 18, 76970) 9. History does not tell us that khadi went out of use because foreign cloth was better and cheaper.
('28', 33, 1, 19, 77071) Even today, foreign cloth cannot compete with the better sort of khadi.
('28', 33, 1, 20, 77143) Cloth like the shabnam 1 muslin of Dacca has disappeared for ever.
('28', 33, 1, 21, 77210) When foreign cloth was first introduced, it was not even cheap.
('28', 33, 1, 22, 77274) History tells us, on the contrary, that the East India Company deliberately destroyed the spinning and weaving industries and, by securing various forms of protection, made us accept foreign cloth.
('28', 33, 1, 23, 77472) I have not invented this history out of my ignorance.
('28', 33, 1, 24, 77526) I have gathered it from Shri Romesh Chandra Dutts 2 vast storehouse of knowledge.
('28', 33, 1, 25, 77608) I am not aware of these assertions having been disputed to this day; if this belief of mine is erroneous, I shall certainly be ready to revise it.
('28', 33, 2, 26, 77755) 1 Literally, dew; hence exquisitely delicate 2 1848 1909; member of Indian Civil Service, author of The Economic History of India since the Advent of the East India Company; President of the Indian National Congress, 1899; later Chief Minister of Baroda State

('28', 34, 1, 2, 78056) 10. The power of khadi is immeasurable.
('28', 34, 1, 3, 78096) It need not compete with mill made cloth in order to increase it.
('28', 34, 1, 4, 78162) It is always increasing.
('28', 34, 1, 5, 78187) Whoever wishes to examine this can compare the fine khadi that is being produced today with what little was produced four years ago.
('28', 34, 1, 6, 78320) I was surprised even by the change that I saw when I came out after two years of imprisonment.
('28', 34, 1, 7, 78415) Today, khadi is produced in every home.

('28', 34, 1, 9, 78618) It is only the craze for mill made cloth which impedes its progress.

('28', 34, 2, 12, 78927) 21. MY NOTES
('28', 34, 3, 13, 78940) DIRTY HABITS OF PASSENGERS
('28', 34, 4, 14, 78967) A gentleman who usually travels third on railways, writes to say that travelling by this class becomes intolerable because of the dirty habits of passengers and that, to save oneself the suffering on the journey, one should carry a small broom and a spittoon with a lid.
('28', 34, 4, 15, 79238) The compartment should be periodically swept with the broom and, whenever anyone wishes to spit, the spittle should be collected in the spittoon.
('28', 34, 4, 16, 79384) In this way, one would be spared some suffering at any rate.
('28', 34, 4, 17, 79445) There is no doubt that such filth is intolerable to anyone who cares for cleanliness.
('28', 34, 4, 18, 79531) Nevertheless, we cannot choose but travel third class.
('28', 34, 4, 19, 79586) When I used to travel only third class, I had leaflets printed 1 and had even started distributing them among the travelling public.
('28', 34, 4, 20, 79719) When the nature of my work changed, I left off this propaganda through leaflets.
('28', 34, 4, 21, 79800) Later on, I suffered in health, and had to give up both the privilege and the hardships of third class travel.
('28', 34, 4, 22, 79911) But its sweet memories are still fresh in my mind and I hope to describe them again some time.
('28', 34, 4, 23, 80006) Every volunteer should read out the leaflet as he distributes
('28', 34, 5, 24, 80068) 1 During 1916 17, these were distributed in Gujarat; vide also Railway Passengers, before 26 7 1916.

('28', 35, 1, 2, 80210) copies of it.
('28', 35, 1, 3, 80224) Simultaneously, the experiment of using a broom should also be tried.
('28', 35, 1, 4, 80294) The suggestion about the spittoon is difficult to carry out.
('28', 35, 1, 5, 80355) In acting upon it, there is a risk of ones being beaten up and, even so, the passengers may refuse to spit into it.
('28', 35, 1, 6, 80471) But the use of the broom is very necessary.
('28', 35, 1, 7, 80515) We may politely request passengers not to throw rubbish in the compartment and, at the same time, ungrud gingly sweep away the dirt which may be thrown despite our pleas.
('28', 35, 1, 8, 80686) In trying to use the spittoon, there is the danger, while trying to avoid one kind of uncleanliness, of inviting another.
('28', 35, 1, 9, 80808) It should be properly cleaned after use every time.
('28', 35, 1, 10, 80860) The spittoon, too, should have no joints, should not corrode and should be large enough in size.
('28', 35, 1, 11, 80957) On such occasions I used large quantities of paper.
('28', 35, 1, 12, 81009) By using paper to clean the spot where anyone has spat, one does not soil ones hands and can yet clean the place properly.
('28', 35, 1, 13, 81132) Later, one can wash the hands, if one feels like doing so.
('28', 35, 1, 14, 81191) If we do all this, others who are inclined to spit will feel ashamed and restrain themselves.
('28', 35, 1, 15, 81285) What really makes one sad is that volunteers do not themselves always observe the rules of tidiness and cleanliness.
('28', 35, 1, 16, 81402) Generally, we seem to have little consideration for others.
('28', 35, 1, 17, 81462) This is the reason for the excessive filthiness one finds on trains and ships, in fact, wherever one goes.
('28', 35, 1, 18, 81569) Improvement in this matter can be brought about only if teaching habits of cleanliness and tidiness is part of childrens education and if we realize that the rules taught are meant to be followed.
('28', 35, 1, 19, 81766) Perhaps, the reader does not know that to make railway compartments dirty in the manner described above is an offence under the Railways Act.
('28', 35, 1, 20, 81908) But no one is prosecuted since the majority of people are guilty of this offence and only a few are innocent.
('28', 35, 1, 21, 82018) It is a maxim that only a law which the majority obeys can be enforced against a few.
('28', 35, 1, 22, 82104) In other words, the atmosphere must be favourable if such laws are to be enforced.
('28', 35, 1, 23, 82187) This further means that, in practice, many laws serve no useful purpose.
('28', 35, 1, 24, 82260) Once the necessary atmosphere has been created, the minority conforms of its own accord to the general practice.

('28', 36, 1, 2, 82664) views in keeping with my principles and, consistently with them, we should not have schools in villages which do not favour them.
('28', 36, 1, 3, 82794) If at all we have them, we should not call them popular.

('28', 36, 1, 23, 84861) In this context, popularity must be understood in a different sense.
('28', 36, 1, 24, 84930) It is only in such perplexing situations that moral dilemmas arise.
('28', 36, 1, 25, 84998) On such occasions, the test of our good sense consists in reconciling diverse principles and working accordingly.

('28', 37, 1, 2, 85190) 22. DAILY PLYING OF THE SPINNING WHEEL
('28', 37, 2, 3, 85229) A Jain friend writes to me to say that the women in his family have stopped spinning because some monks have told them that the Jain religion forbids the plying of the spinning wheel as it kills the invisible germs living in the air!
('28', 37, 2, 4, 85463) If the song below 1 dates back to 300 years, that itself will answer those monks.
('28', 37, 2, 5, 85545) Moreover, common sense will not at all accept their argument.
('28', 37, 2, 6, 85607) There is violence in every deed and in every bodily function.
('28', 37, 2, 7, 85669) There is violence certainly in eating, drinking and dressing How, then, can we help taking up those activi ties which are necessary for producing clothing for us?
('28', 37, 2, 8, 85832) If others draw water, cook, spin and weave and we utilize the fruits of their labour, we naturally share their sin.
('28', 37, 2, 9, 85948) If, therefore, we ourselves do the three things with our own hands, we can limit their extent and reduce our burden of sins.
('28', 37, 2, 10, 86073) He who draws water with his own hands will use it econo mically.
('28', 37, 2, 11, 86138) But does anyone using tap water exercise any restraint on himself?
('28', 37, 2, 12, 86205) The same is true of all activities.
('28', 37, 2, 13, 86241) Personally, I consider spinning to be an activity which serves the cause of non violence in every respect.
('28', 37, 2, 14, 86348) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 25 5 1924

('28', 42, 5, 10, 94225) 30. HINDU MUSLIM TENSION: ITS CAUSE AND CURE 3
('28', 42, 6, 11, 94272) HINDU INDICTMENT
('28', 42, 7, 12, 94289) Pandit Banarsidas Chaturvedi brought a message from a Hindu residing in Tanganyika to the following effect: Tell Gandhi he is responsible for the Muslim atrocities in Multan. 4 I did not print the message before, as I was not ready to write then upon the question of questions.
('28', 42, 7, 13, 94567) But many letters have since been received by me, some from well known friends telling one that I was responsible even for the alleged Moplah atrocities, in fact for all the riots in which Hindus have or are said to have suffered since the Khilafat agitation.
('28', 42, 7, 14, 94826) The argument is somewhat this: You asked the Hindus to make common cause with the Mussalmans in the Khilafat question.
('28', 42, 7, 15, 94945) Your being identified with it gave it an importance it would never have otherwise received.
('28', 42, 7, 16, 95037) It unified and awakened the Mussalmans.
('28', 42, 7, 17, 95077) It gave a prestige to the Maulvis which they never had before.
('28', 42, 7, 18, 95140) And now that the Khilafat question is over, the awakened Mussalmans have proclaimed a kind of jehad against us Hindus. I have given the purport of the charge in readable language.
('28', 42, 7, 19, 95320) Some letters contain unprintable abuse.
('28', 42, 7, 20, 95360) So much for the Hindu part of the indictment against me.
('28', 42, 8, 21, 95417) 1 Kedarnath Kulkarni, spiritual seeker and frequent visitor to the Ashram 2 Kishorelal Mashruwala 3 A reprint of this article was later issued in the form of a pamphlet.
('28', 42, 8, 22, 95587) 4 In March April 1923
('28', 43, 0, 1, 95609) 44 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 43, 1, 2, 95650) MUSSALMAN INDICTMENT
('28', 43, 2, 3, 95671) A Mussalman friend says:
('28', 43, 3, 4, 95696) The Muslim community being a very simple and religious community were led to believe that the Khilafat was in danger and that it could be saved by the united voice of Hindus and Mohammedans; these innocent people, believing your very eloquent words, showed great enthusiasm, with the result that they were the first to boycott schools, law courts, Councils, etc.
('28', 43, 3, 5, 96059) The most famous institution of Aligarh, which Sir Syed had built by the labour of his lifetime and which was justly the first institution of its kind, was utterly spoilt.
('28', 43, 3, 6, 96230) I shall be very much obliged if you will kindly point out that the Hindu community had a similar institution, and it met with the same fate.
('28', 43, 3, 7, 96371) I know of scores of boys who could have taken the University degree with credit to themselves and the community to which they belonged, but they were induced to leave studies on religious grounds, with the result that they were utterly ruined.
('28', 43, 3, 8, 96615) On the contrary very few Hindu boys left, and those who did so for the time beinginstantly joined, as soon as they found that the movement was tottering to pieces.
('28', 43, 3, 9, 96779) Similar was the case with lawyers.
('28', 43, 3, 10, 96814) In those days, you brought about a sort of unity between the two communities and advertised it far and near that it was a solid one.
('28', 43, 3, 11, 96947) The simple minded Mohammedans again beli eved it, with the result that they were brutally treated at Ajmer, Lucknow, Meerut, Agra, Saharanpur, Lahore and other places.
('28', 43, 3, 12, 97115) Mr. Mahomed Ali, who was a born journalist of a very high type, and whose wonderful paper The Comrade was doing such solid work for the Muslim community, was won over to your side, and he is now a loss to the community.
('28', 43, 3, 13, 97335) Your Hindu leaders in the guise of shuddhi and sangathan are trying to weaken the Muslim community.
('28', 43, 3, 14, 97435) Your short sighted decision to prevent people from entering the Councils has acted most unfairly on this community as the majority of able men refrain from entering the Councils because of the so called fatwa.
('28', 43, 3, 15, 97645) Under the circums tances, do you not honestly think that you are doing a great harm to this community by keeping the Mohammedans, a few of them of course, still in your camp.
('28', 43, 3, 16, 97820) I have not given the whole of the letter.
('28', 43, 3, 17, 97862) But the extract represents the gist of the Muslim indictment against me.
('28', 43, 4, 18, 97935) NOT GUILTY
('28', 43, 5, 19, 97946) I must plead not guilty to both the charges, and add that I am totally unrepentant.
('28', 43, 5, 20, 98030) Had I been a prophet and foreseen all that has happened, I should have still thrown myself into the Khilafat agitation.
('28', 43, 5, 21, 98150) In spite of the present strained relations between the two communities, both have gained.
('28', 43, 5, 22, 98240) The awakening among the masses was a necessary part of the training.
('28', 43, 5, 23, 98309) It is itself a tremendous gain.
('28', 43, 5, 24, 98341) I would do nothing
('28', 44, 0, 1, 98360) VOL. 28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15AUGUST, 1924 45
('28', 44, 1, 2, 98401) to put the people to sleep again.
('28', 44, 1, 3, 98435) Our wisdom consists now in directing the awakening in the proper channel.
('28', 44, 1, 4, 98509) What we see before us is sad but not disheartening, if we have faith in ourselves.
('28', 44, 1, 5, 98592) The storm is but the forerunner of the coming calm that comes from a consciousness of strength, not from the stupor of exhaustion and disappointment.
('28', 44, 1, 6, 98742) The public will not expect me to give judgment upon the riots in the different places.
('28', 44, 1, 7, 98829) I have no desire for giving judgment.
('28', 44, 1, 8, 98867) And even if I had, I have not the facts before me.
('28', 44, 2, 9, 98918) MOPLAHS
('28', 44, 3, 10, 98926) I will say a word as to the causes.
('28', 44, 3, 11, 98962) The Malabar happenings undoubtedly disquieted the Hindu mind.
('28', 44, 3, 12, 99024) What the truth is no one knows.
('28', 44, 3, 13, 99056) The Hindus say that the Moplah atrocities were indescribable.
('28', 44, 3, 14, 99118) Dr. Mahmud tells me that these have been grossly exaggerated, that the Moplahs too had a grievance aga inst the Hindus, and that he could find no cases of forcible conver sions.
('28', 44, 3, 15, 99296) The one case that was reported to him was at least non proven.
('28', 44, 3, 16, 99359) In his findings, Dr. Mahmud says, he is supported by Hindu testimony.
('28', 44, 3, 17, 99429) I merely mention the two versions to ask the public to con clude with me that it is impossible to arrive at the exact truth, and that it is unnecessary for the purpose of regulating Our future conduct.
('28', 44, 4, 18, 99631) MULTAN, ETC.
('28', 44, 5, 19, 99644) In Multan, Saharanpur, Agra, Ajmer etc., it is agreed that the Hindus suffered most.
('28', 44, 5, 20, 99729) In Palwal it is stated that Hindus have prevented Mussalmans from turning a kachcha mosque into a pukka one.
('28', 44, 5, 21, 99838) They are said to have pulled down part of the pukka wall, driven the Muslims out of the village, and stated that the Muslims could not live in the village unless they promised not to build any mosque and say azan.
('28', 44, 5, 22, 100052) This state of things is said to have continued for over a year.
('28', 44, 5, 23, 100116) The driven Mussalmans are said to be living in temporary huts near Rohtak.
('28', 44, 5, 24, 100191) In Byade in Dharwar district, my informant tells me, on Muslims objecting to music being played before their mosque, the Hindu desecrated the mosque, beat the Mussalmans, and then got them persecuted.
('28', 44, 5, 25, 100392) Here again I cite these two instances, not as proved facts, but to show that the Mussalmans too claim to have much to complain of against Hindus.
('28', 44, 5, 26, 100538) And it can certainly be fairly added that where they were manifestly weak and Hindus strong, as in Katarpur and Arrah years
('28', 45, 0, 1, 100662) 46 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 45, 1, 2, 100703) ago, they were mercilessly treated by their Hindu neighbours.
('28', 45, 1, 3, 100765) The fact is that when blood boils, prejudice reigns supreme; man, whether he labels himself Hindu, Mussalman, Christian or what not, becomes a beast and acts as such.
('28', 45, 2, 4, 100932) THE SEAT OF THE TROUBLE
('28', 45, 3, 5, 100956) The seat of the trouble, however, is in the Punjab.
('28', 45, 3, 6, 101008) The Mussal mans complain that the Hindus have raised a storm of protest on Mr. Fazal Hussain trying very timidly to give a fair proportion of Govern ment employment to Mussalmans.
('28', 45, 3, 7, 101188) The letter from which I have already quoted complains bitterly that, wherever a Hindu has been the head of a department, he has carefully excluded Mussalmans from Government posts.
('28', 45, 3, 8, 101369) The causes for the tension are thus more than merely religious.
('28', 45, 3, 9, 101433) The charges I have quoted are individual.
('28', 45, 3, 10, 101475) But the mass mind is a reflection of individual opinion.
('28', 45, 4, 11, 101532) TIRED OF NON VIOLENCE
('28', 45, 5, 12, 101554) The immediate cause is the most dangerous.
('28', 45, 5, 13, 101597) The thinking por tion seems to be tired of non violence.
('28', 45, 5, 14, 101654) It has not as yet understood my suspension of Satyagraha after Ahmedabad and Viramgam trage dies, then after the Bombay rowdyism, and, Lastly, after the Chauri Chaura outrage.
('28', 45, 5, 15, 101830) The last was the last straw.
('28', 45, 5, 16, 101859) The thinking men imagined that all hope of Satyagraha, and therefore of swaraj too in the near future, was at an end.
('28', 45, 5, 17, 101977) Their faith in non violence was skin deep.
('28', 45, 5, 18, 102020) Two years ago, a Mussalman friend said to me in all sincerity, I do not believe [in] your non violence.
('28', 45, 5, 19, 102124) At least, I would not have my Mussalmans to learn it.
('28', 45, 5, 20, 102178) Violence is the law of life.
('28', 45, 5, 21, 102207) I would not have swaraj by non violence as you define the latter.
('28', 45, 5, 22, 102273) I must hate my enemy. This friend is an honest man.
('28', 45, 5, 23, 102325) I entertain great regard for him.
('28', 45, 5, 24, 102359) Much the same has been reported of another very great Mussalman friend of mine.
('28', 45, 5, 25, 102439) The report may be untrue, but the reporter himself is not an untrue man.
('28', 45, 6, 26, 102512) HINDU REPUGNANCE
('28', 45, 7, 27, 102529) Nor is this repugnance to non violence confined to Mussalmans.
('28', 45, 7, 28, 102592) Hindu friends have said the same thing, if possible, with greater vehemence.
('28', 45, 7, 29, 102669) My claim to Hinduism has been rejected by some, because I believe [in] and advocate non violence in its extreme form.
('28', 45, 7, 30, 102787) They say that I am a Christian in disguise.
('28', 45, 7, 31, 102831) I have been even seriously
('28', 46, 0, 1, 102858) VOL. 28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15AUGUST, 1924 47
('28', 46, 1, 2, 102899) told that I am distorting the meaning of the Gita when I ascribe to that great poem the teaching of unadulterated non violence.
('28', 46, 1, 3, 103027) Some of my Hindu friends tell me that killing is a duty enjoined by the Gita under certain circumstances.
('28', 46, 1, 4, 103133) A very learned Shastri only the other day scornfully rejected my interpretation of the Gita and said that there was no warrant for the opinion held by some commentators that the Gita represented the eternal duel between forces of evil and good, and inculcated the duty of eradicating evil within us without hesitation, without tenderness.
('28', 46, 1, 5, 103472) I state these opinions against non violence in detail, because it is necessary to understand them if we would understand the solution I have to offer.
('28', 46, 1, 6, 103623) What I see around me today is, therefore, a reaction against the spread of non violence.
('28', 46, 1, 7, 103712) I feel the wave of violence coming.
('28', 46, 1, 8, 103748) The Hindu Muslim tension is an acute phase of this tiredness.
('28', 46, 1, 9, 103810) I must be dismissed out of consideration.
('28', 46, 1, 10, 103852) My religion is a matter solely between my Maker and myself.
('28', 46, 1, 11, 103912) If I am a Hindu, I cannot cease to be one even though I may be disowned by the whole of the Hindu population.
('28', 46, 1, 12, 104022) I do, however, suggest that non violence is the end of all religions.
('28', 46, 2, 13, 104092) LIMITED NON VIOLENCE
('28', 46, 3, 14, 104113) But I have never presented to India that extreme form of non violence, if only because I do not regard myself fit enough to re deliver that ancient message.
('28', 46, 3, 15, 104270) Though my intellect has fully under stood and grasped it, it has not as yet become part of my whole being.
('28', 46, 3, 16, 104377) My strength lies in my asking people to do nothing that I have not tried repeatedly in my own life.
('28', 46, 3, 17, 104477) I am then asking my countrymen today to adopt non violence as their final creed, only for the purpose of regulating the relations between the different races, and for the purpose of attaining swaraj.
('28', 46, 3, 18, 104677) Hindus and Mussalmans, Christians, Sikhs and Parsis must not settle their differences by resort to violence, and the means for the attainment of swaraj must be non violent.
('28', 46, 3, 19, 104850) This I venture to place before India, not as a weapon of the weak, but of the strong.
('28', 46, 3, 20, 104936) Hindus and Mussalmans prate about no compulsion in religion.
('28', 46, 3, 21, 104997) What is it but compulsion if Hindus will kill a Mussalman for saving a cow?
('28', 46, 3, 22, 105073) It is like wanting to convert a Mussalman to Hinduism by force.
('28', 46, 3, 23, 105137) And similarly, what is it but compulsion if Mussalmans seek to prevent by force Hindus from playing music before mosques?
('28', 46, 3, 24, 105259) Virtue lies in being absorbed in ones prayers in the presence of din and noise.
('28', 46, 3, 25, 105339) We shall both be voted irreligious savages by posterity if we

('28', 64, 1, 2, 148292) unaided to secure swaraj, and if they really voice the feelings of their electors, I would not hesitate to advise the Committee even to take the risk of revising and radically altering the programme in anticipation of endorsement next year.

('28', 68, 5, 12, 156839) 36. INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS OF INDIA
('28', 68, 6, 13, 156882) AHMEDABAD, May 31, 1924
('28', 68, 7, 14, 156906) Questioned if, in view of his article in the Young India on the Congress
('28', 68, 8, 15, 156979) organization, 2 a split in the Congress was not a certainty, Mr. Gandhi replied: It all depends on what you mean by split.
('28', 68, 8, 16, 157102) If you mean parties, yes.
('28', 68, 8, 17, 157128) Both parties came into being at the Gaya Congress.
('28', 68, 8, 18, 157179) The House of Commons contains many parties, but you do not call their existence a split in the English nation.
('28', 68, 8, 19, 157290) Congress will now contain two parties, but will have no split, I hope.
('28', 68, 8, 20, 157361) Just as the popular party in the House of Commons is always in power, so should the most popular Congress party be in power in the national organization.
('28', 68, 8, 21, 157515) Just as Liberals do not and dare not regard Conservatives or Labourites as their inferiors, so may the No changers and vice versa.
('28', 68, 8, 22, 157646) My suggestion attempts at least to avoid a split and provides the most favourable atmosphere for efficiency, even if it does not ensure it.
('28', 68, 8, 23, 157786) I do not believe in coalition government at any time, but certainly not when there are vital differences of opinion or, if you will, different mentalities, making for different and diametrically opposite courses of action.
('28', 68, 9, 24, 158009) Asked what he thought would be its effect upon the Government and whether it
('28', 68, 10, 25, 158086) 1 The sentence abruptly ends here.
('28', 68, 10, 26, 158121) 2 Vide Congress Organization, 29 5 1924.
('28', 69, 0, 1, 158162) 70 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 69, 1, 2, 158203) was likely to destroy all chances of expected advance in Reforms, Mr. Gandhi said: I do not think it will.
('28', 69, 1, 3, 158310) I know it has been suggested that the Government would have trembled if I had made common cause with the Pro changers.
('28', 69, 1, 4, 158429) I hold a totally opposite view.
('28', 69, 1, 5, 158461) Those who are responsible for the conduct of the Government of India are not fools.
('28', 69, 1, 6, 158545) They are clever and wide awake.
('28', 69, 1, 7, 158577) They know that all real pressure that is exerted upon them is from No changers, because they dread civil disobedience.
('28', 69, 1, 8, 158696) The organization for civil disobedience is possible only by those who devote their whole time and attention to it.
('28', 69, 1, 9, 158811) The Govern ment will certainly chuckle if the No changers and Pro changers obstruct one another.
('28', 69, 1, 10, 158908) I shall be no party to any such thing and I do not think the two parties will [be] either.
('28', 69, 1, 11, 158999) They both want swaraj and that at the earliest possible moment.

('28', 69, 3, 20, 159917) 37. HINDUS AND MUSLIMS OF VISNAGAR
('28', 69, 4, 21, 159952) I have received a whole heap of letters on this subject.
('28', 69, 4, 22, 160009) The fact that the correspondents themselves do not expect these letters to be published proves their generosity, and also their approval of the policy I have adopted in running Navajivan.
('28', 69, 4, 23, 160197) I would certainly not publish letters attacking anyone.
('28', 69, 4, 24, 160253) I would also not publish anything which would create bitterness between the two communities.
('28', 69, 4, 25, 160346) I could not set down even a single word in hatred.
('28', 69, 4, 26, 160397) If I wrote about the communal disharmony in Visnagar, it was only to try and pacify the two communities and to point out to them what their dharma towards each other should be.
('28', 70, 0, 1, 160574) VOL. 28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15AUGUST, 1924 71
('28', 70, 1, 2, 160615) If we look at the matter from this point of view, it is not at all necessary to publish any of the letters which I have received.
('28', 70, 1, 3, 160745) I had one from Shri Mahasukhbhai many days ago and did not publish it, as I did not like to do so.
('28', 70, 1, 4, 160844) However, I had agreed to publish it if there was the slightest feeling that I had been unjust intentionally or other wise.
('28', 70, 1, 5, 160967) Meanwhile, I find from other letters and from replies to Shri Mahasukhbhais letter which I have received that the letter in question has been published in other newspapers.
('28', 70, 1, 6, 161140) This being so, it is not necessary to publish it here even in order to be fair to him.
('28', 70, 1, 7, 161227) To do justice to the correspondent who had informed me, I should mention that it was I who used the word beast instead of cows and bulls.
('28', 70, 1, 8, 161365) The correspondent himself had used these words.
('28', 70, 1, 9, 161413) Thinking that there might be some exaggeration, I used the more general term instead of a more specific word.
('28', 70, 1, 10, 161523) The latter was not necessary for my argument.
('28', 70, 1, 11, 161569) From other letters which I have received, I find that Shri Mahasukhbhai is on good terms with the Muslims.
('28', 70, 1, 12, 161676) Let us all hope that utilizing that friendly relation, he will bring about harmony between the two communities and end the discord in Visnagar I have, before me, letters bywhite capped gentry in which they defend them selves.
('28', 70, 1, 13, 161902) I also have letters accusing them.
('28', 70, 1, 14, 161937) The white capped gentry or others who have done nothing wrong have no need to defend themselves.
('28', 70, 1, 15, 162034) Ones actions are ones defence.
('28', 70, 1, 16, 162065) one whose actions are blameless puts up with accusations, as he has faith in the truth that the light shed by good actions cannot be hidden for long by the cloud of accusations.
('28', 70, 1, 17, 162243) Hence the white capped gentry should have no fear if they have indeed done nothing unworthy; if, however, they have done some wrong thing, they should frankly admit the fact and, by way of atonement, refrain from acting in such manner in future.
('28', 70, 1, 18, 162489) I have never believed that all who wear white caps are good men.
('28', 70, 1, 19, 162554) Moreover, people have not yet come to love khadi well enough.
('28', 70, 1, 20, 162616) When the use of khadi becomes universal and people using mill made cloth are a rare sight, both the millionaire and the thief will be in white caps.
('28', 70, 1, 21, 162765) Eating, drinking and wearing clothes are common to both the saint and the sinner.
('28', 70, 1, 22, 162847) It is desirable, therefore, that those who wear white caps and society in general stop believing that the former have a monopoly of virtue.

('28', 72, 3, 5, 165664) 38. MY NOTES
('28', 72, 4, 6, 165677) YOUNG OLD MAN
('28', 72, 5, 7, 165691) The reader will be glad to know that Abbas Saheb is not the person to remain unmoved by my pleasant digs at him.
('28', 72, 5, 8, 165804) All Gujaratis know that he knows Gujarati.
('28', 72, 5, 9, 165847) He has now started writing letters to me in Gujarati.
('28', 72, 5, 10, 165901) I give below a specimen of his writing.
('28', 72, 6, 11, 165941) I have put his Gujarati before readers without any corrections.
('28', 72, 6, 12, 166005) The reader knows that I myself commit many mistakes.
('28', 72, 6, 13, 166058) Summit dweller points out that I commit them still.
('28', 72, 6, 14, 166110) I feel ashamed when I see some of them.
('28', 72, 6, 15, 166150) However, as I myself commit plenty of mistakes, Abbas Sahebs Gujarati, full of mistakes as it is, is very much dearer to me than his faultless English.
('28', 72, 6, 16, 166302) Just as I do not intend to give up writing in Gujarati because of my mistakes, similarly, Abbas Saheb may, if he wishes, learn to avoid the mistakes which he makes, but should continue to write in Gujarati and so awaken in other Gujaratis pride in their own language.
('28', 72, 6, 17, 166570) The word pustak 2 used by him sounds very sweet to me.
('28', 72, 6, 18, 166625) However, even if he does not read other Gujarati books, we hope that henceforth he will certainly read Navajivan.
('28', 72, 6, 19, 166739) I intend to publish in Navajivan in a few days the list of my mistakes prepared by that Summit dweller, mistakes which make me feel ashamed of myself, and then Abbas Saheb will have no reason to feel ashamed of his mistakes.
('28', 72, 6, 20, 166964) He will, moreover, read Navajivan, correcting my mistakes as he reads on, and so will learn to write relatively correct Gujarati.
('28', 72, 6, 21, 167094) The persons who attend on Abbas Saheb should persuade him to let them read out Navajivan to him.
('28', 72, 6, 22, 167191) He has also mentioned another thing which should be a source of inspiration to Gujaratis and to all Indians.
('28', 72, 6, 23, 167300) Dear Sir, you have spread my fame throughout India as an old man.
('28', 72, 6, 24, 167366) I look upon myself as a young man. This old man will not concede that he is old even if he is given a mirror to look into, for he is young at heart.
('28', 72, 7, 25, 167515) 1 The passage is not translated here.

('28', 73, 1, 3, 167683) Abbas Saheb does not!
('28', 73, 1, 4, 167705) A person who can work harder than a young man is young indeed, though he may be advanced in years.

('28', 82, 1, 7, 188651) Only a person who has renounced the idea of a career for himself should seek admission to the Vidyapith.
('28', 82, 1, 8, 188756) Since this ideal has not yet taken hold of the minds of people either in Gujarat or in the rest of the country, it is not surprising that Vidyapiths dedicated to this ideal should have only a few students in the first few years.
('28', 82, 1, 9, 188985) In fact, it is a pleasant surprise that thousands of students are having their literary education under the inspiring guidance of the Vidyapith and, at the same time, are acquiring the spirit of patriotic service.
('28', 82, 1, 10, 189199) [From Gujarati]

('28', 83, 1, 2, 190290) 43. A HINT TO ORGANIZERS OF CONFERENCES
('28', 83, 2, 3, 190330) People say that the days of big public meetings, processions and speeches are past, that the time has come to work while keeping the mouth shut.
('28', 83, 2, 4, 190475) But the organizers of conferences and public meetings are always anxious to make great shows of them.
('28', 83, 2, 5, 190577) In their zeal, many times they forget the truth and practise deception on the innocent public while making preparations for conferences.
('28', 83, 2, 6, 190714) A notice about some conference says:
('28', 83, 3, 7, 190751) It is a matter of great pleasure that the conference is going to take place in a big way.
('28', 83, 3, 8, 190841) Important leaders such as Mahatma Gandhi, the Ali Brothers, Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, Dr. Kitchlew 1, Maulana Abul Kalam Azad 2, Devdas Gandhi, Shankerlal Banker 3, Rajagopalachari 4, Seth Jamnalal Bajaj 5, Maulana A. Jafar Khan, Shrimati Gandhi, Bi Amma Sahiba, Tapasvi Sunderlal, Makhanlal Chaturvedi 6, Shrimati Subhadra Kumari, etc., are expected to come.
('28', 83, 3, 9, 191200) It is possible that the reception committee has sent invitations to these leaders.
('28', 83, 3, 10, 191283) But till replies have been received from them saying that they will try to come, it is not true to say that they are expected to come.
('28', 83, 3, 11, 191418) However commendable the intention may be, it is improper to mislead people.
('28', 83, 3, 12, 191494) Once or twice people may be deceived, but very soon the workers lose their prestige as well as the I trust of the people.
('28', 83, 3, 13, 191616) Abraham Lincoln has rightly said: You can fool all the people some of the time, and some of the people all the time, but you cannot fool all the people all the time. [From Hindi]

('28', 85, 6, 13, 194520) 47. INTERVIEW TO  SWATANTRYA
('28', 85, 7, 14, 194549) [SABARMATI, June 3, 1924] 2
('28', 85, 8, 15, 194577) Q. Since your release from Yeravda Jail, do you think that there is some change in your writing?
('28', 85, 9, 16, 194674) A. Yes, there is.
('28', 85, 10, 17, 194692) Q. Because of your too much stress on non violence as a religion, the Congress had to pass a resolution of self defence as regards Congress volunteers.
('28', 85, 11, 18, 194844) A. It was not right for the Congress to pass such a resolution.
('28', 85, 11, 19, 194908) The same meaning was already included in my definition of non violence.
('28', 85, 12, 20, 194980) Q. Do you not think, Mahatmaji, that Congress leaders at least found your defini tion rather vague?
('28', 85, 13, 21, 195080) A. Yes, you are right.
('28', 85, 13, 22, 195103) Every religionist should try to find out autho rities on non violence in his own religious books.
('28', 85, 13, 23, 195201) I am preaching non violence so that people may be induced to find out the real meaning of non violence according to their religious texts.
('28', 85, 14, 24, 195340) The correspondent then asked Mahatmaji to explain the limits of non vio lence against a thief, dacoit or foreign invasion.
('28', 85, 14, 25, 195463) He [Gandhiji] narrated the story of a great saint, Eknath Maharaj [who] having found his house attacked by thieves, prayed to God lest the robbers might go away without finding any booty.
('28', 85, 15, 26, 195651) 1 The postmark bears this date.
('28', 85, 15, 27, 195683) 2 Vide 1st footnote to Interview to Swatantrya, 30 5 1924.
('28', 86, 0, 1, 195742) VOL. 28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15AUGUST, 1924 87
('28', 86, 1, 2, 195783) Q. This is possible for a mahatma, but not for ordinary people.
('28', 86, 1, 3, 195847) What do you advise people to do under such circumstances?
('28', 86, 2, 4, 195905) A. We must protect ourselves from thieves, etc.
('28', 86, 2, 5, 195953) The difference you have shown is quite correct.
('28', 86, 3, 6, 196001) Q. Dont you think that Englishmen also fall under this category?
('28', 86, 4, 7, 196066) A. No, the present day Englishmen are not so.
('28', 86, 4, 8, 196112) The East India Company may be regarded as such.
('28', 86, 4, 9, 196160) But are you going to call robbers sons also as robbers?
('28', 86, 5, 10, 196216) Q. If such sons are also following their fathers vocation, we must call them thieves.
('28', 86, 6, 11, 196302) A. No, no.
('28', 86, 6, 12, 196313) The English people of the present day are not such, hence we must remain non violent.
('28', 86, 6, 13, 196399) To dispossess the English of their power, we need the will and not the arms and, moreover, so long as the Congress has adopted non violence as its policy, we must be non violent.
('28', 86, 6, 14, 196578) I have illustrated my meaning in my article headed My Mission, 1 by taking the illustration of a prisoner at the gallows and a jailor.
('28', 86, 6, 15, 196713) This whole question I shall have to get settled finally in the coming Congress.
('28', 86, 7, 16, 196793) Q. Mahatmaji, have you read the evidence which Mohammedans gave before the Government enquiry committee regarding the Hindu Muslim disputes at Nagpur?
('28', 86, 7, 17, 196944) The Mohammedan witnesses said that Lokamanya Tilak was responsible for fostering such quarrels among the Hindus and Mohammedans, and that every Mohammedan has a right to convert, at any time, his house into a masjid.
('28', 86, 8, 18, 197161) A. No, I have not read that.
('28', 86, 8, 19, 197190) 2 I shall certainly read that.
('28', 86, 8, 20, 197221) It is simply ungratefulness to accuse the Lokamanya of having given rise to such communal feuds.
('28', 86, 8, 21, 197318) It was Lokamanya Tilak himself who personally told me that, if by giving cent per cent representation to Mohammedans, swaraj would be attained, he ( Lokamanya Tilak) was willing to sign such a pact.
('28', 86, 8, 22, 197517) Dr. Moonje has specially requested me not to write anything about Nagpur.
('28', 86, 9, 23, 197591) Mahatmaji further said that the people must find out their own way for their liberation, and expressed regret that the leaders Of the country have not very seriously considered the utility of his own method Of non violent non co operation.

('28', 87, 1, 2, 198022) 48. NOTES
('28', 87, 2, 3, 198032) TARKESHWAR SATYAGRAHA
('28', 87, 3, 4, 198054) I have received various telegrams on the situation in Tarkeshwar.
('28', 87, 3, 5, 198120) Two of them invite me to go there and advise.
('28', 87, 3, 6, 198166) My going is out of the question, if only because I am too weak yet to undertake fatiguing journeys.
('28', 87, 3, 7, 198266) But what I have said generally about Vaikom applies to Tarkeshwar.
('28', 87, 3, 8, 198333) There should be no force nor show of it for the purpose of taking possession.
('28', 87, 3, 9, 198411) The rush of railwaymen and their blocking the progress of the train (if the facts reported are true) was not only not Satyagraha, but the blocking was, to say the least, discreditable.
('28', 87, 3, 10, 198596) Not even a mahant reported to be immoral may be summarily and forcibly dismissed from his possession.
('28', 87, 4, 11, 198698) DIGGING MY OWN GRAVE
('28', 87, 5, 12, 198719) This is the expression that has been used about my article on Congress organization.
('28', 87, 5, 13, 198804) 1 I like it.
('28', 87, 5, 14, 198817) For nothing will please me more than to dig my own grave [rather] than that I should dig that of Truth for which and which alone I want to live.
('28', 87, 5, 15, 198962) An esteemed English friend who helped me in South Africa once told me: Do you know that I have thrown myself heart and soul into your movement because you represent a minority?
('28', 87, 5, 16, 199139) For I believe that truth always lies with mino rities.
('28', 87, 5, 17, 199194) You should not therefore be surprised at my opposing you, friends though we are, if I ever find you representing a majority. I have often wondered, and never more so than now, whether the friend was not right and whether he would not have come to the conclusion that I must be in the wrong as I am at present supposed to be repre senting a majority.
('28', 87, 5, 18, 199544) But whether the friend was right or wrong, I hope that the A.I.C.C. will not hesitate to put me in a minority and I shall also hope that I shall not be found untrue to my faith.
('28', 87, 5, 19, 199722) I assure them that I shall work as zealously under defeat as, perhaps, I have worked with the tide flowing with me.
('28', 87, 5, 20, 199838) If we want to serve India, we must put measures before men.
('28', 87, 5, 21, 199898) The latter come and go, but causes must survive even the greatest of them.
('28', 87, 6, 22, 199973) AN ARYA SAMAJ PROTEST
('28', 87, 7, 23, 199995) I have received the following wire from Agra Arya Samaj:
('28', 87, 8, 24, 200052) 1 Vide Congress Organization, 29 5 1924.
('28', 88, 0, 1, 200093) VOL. 28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15AUGUST, 1924 89
('28', 88, 1, 2, 200134) Agra enters emphatic protest against strictures made by you regarding Arya Samaj, Rishi Dayanand, Swami Shraddhanandji, Satyarth Prakash and shuddhi movement, which it trusts have been made unconsciously because of lack of full acquaintance with Arya Samaj teachings.
('28', 88, 1, 3, 200402) 1 Respectfully prays you to reconsider your views and remove misgivings likely to be produced.
('28', 88, 1, 4, 200497) I publish the telegram, as I am sure the Agra Samaj represents a considerable body of Arya Samaj opinion.
('28', 88, 1, 5, 200603) All I can say in reply is that I have not written a single word in the reference to the Samaj or Rishi Dayanand or Swami Shraddhanandji without deep considera tion.
('28', 88, 1, 6, 200768) It was easy enough for me to suppress my opinion.
('28', 88, 1, 7, 200818) But, consis tently with truth, I could not do so when it became relevant.
('28', 88, 1, 8, 200892) Hindu Muslim tension is a grim reality.
('28', 88, 1, 9, 200932) Removal of it is a stern national nec essity.
('28', 88, 1, 10, 200978) It cannot be brought about by ignoring or suppressing facts.
('28', 88, 1, 11, 201039) Truth on such occasions must be told, no matter how unpalatable it may be.
('28', 88, 1, 12, 201114) But I claim no infallibility.
('28', 88, 1, 13, 201144) As yet I have seen nothing to revise my views.
('28', 88, 1, 14, 201191) I cannot plead ignorance.
('28', 88, 1, 15, 201217) I claim to have read Saty arth Prakash.
('28', 88, 1, 16, 201257) I have the privilege of knowing Shraddhanandji intima tely.
('28', 88, 1, 17, 201317) My writing therefore is deliberate.
('28', 88, 1, 18, 201353) But if any Arya Samajist can convince me that I have erred in any single particular, I shall gladly confess my error, apologize and withdraw the erroneous statement.
('28', 88, 2, 19, 201519) PUNISHMENT OR REWARD
('28', 88, 3, 20, 201540) Thoreau has said that, under a despotic government, plenty is a crime and poverty a merit.
('28', 88, 3, 21, 201631) In other words, the frowns of such a government are any day welcome.
('28', 88, 3, 22, 201700) One has to be cautious about its smiles.
('28', 88, 3, 23, 201741) Taken in this light, the punishment of the Swarajya of Madras may be treated as a reward for public services rendered.
('28', 88, 3, 24, 201860) I can therefore only congratulate Mr. Prakasam 2 upon his paper being the first to be on the black list of the Madras Government.
('28', 88, 3, 25, 201990) That the Indian members of that Government are responsible for this reward does not surprise me.
('28', 88, 3, 26, 202087) They could do no better.
('28', 88, 3, 27, 202112) They must either sustain that Government or resign.
('28', 88, 3, 28, 202164) They believe in that Government being for the good of the country.
('28', 88, 3, 29, 202231) Non violent non co operation is intended to quicken the process of disillusionment.
('28', 88, 3, 30, 202315) That process has been slow

('28', 89, 2, 3, 202790) LUXURY NOT POWER
('28', 89, 3, 4, 202807) Borodada writes thus from Shantiniketan:
('28', 89, 4, 5, 202848) The reason why you exhort us to concentrate all our energy on the constructive programme is simply this.
('28', 89, 4, 6, 202953) You want us to produce by our own hands the necessaries of life, arid thereby gain power.
('28', 89, 4, 7, 203043) If we once get the initial power simply to live, we can gradually gain more power to live comfortably afterwards.
('28', 89, 4, 8, 203157) But if we take only that which Government pleases to give us, we will get something no doubt but will not gain power, and thus will become weaker and weaker every day.
('28', 89, 4, 9, 203325) For, as long as power remains with the Government, we will be at its mercy.
('28', 89, 4, 10, 203401) It is natural that the Government will look after its own interest and we will look after our own.
('28', 89, 4, 11, 203500) It is foolish to expect that the Government will give us power to nullify its own power of doing anything it likes It is ready to give us the materials of luxury when the great masses are suffering from want of food and clothing It will not part with the least of its power, unless forced by circumstances That power is exerted mainly for its own interest and by no means for the real well being of the Indian masses Is it not only too true that the towns buy their luxuries at the expense of the poor, whilst all the power resides in the hands of a Government totally irresponsible and irresponsive to the people?
('28', 89, 5, 12, 204115) THE WHEEL TO THE RESCUE
('28', 89, 6, 13, 204139) The following letter from Babu Bhupendra Narayan Sen cannot fail to interest the reader:
('28', 89, 7, 14, 204228) Duadonda is a village in the sub division of Arambagh, district Hooghly and is about 7 miles west of Raja Ram Mohun Roys 1 birthplace, Radhanagar.
('28', 89, 7, 15, 204375) In June 1922, there occurred a severe flood in the river Darakeshwar and my friend Sj.
('28', 89, 7, 16, 204462) Prafulla Chandra Sen was deputed by the Hooghly District Congress Committee for relief work in the flooded area.
('28', 89, 7, 17, 204575) When Prafulla proposed to distribute the charkha to insure againt famine which generally attends such flood, he was ridiculed by the Flood Relief Committee.
('28', 89, 7, 18, 204732) Undaunted, my friend promised that he would make the charkha a success even in such a backward N.C.O. district as Hooghly.
('28', 89, 7, 19, 204855) With only three co workers, he began to tramp from villagers door to door with a bag of cotton, with some charkhas and
('28', 89, 8, 20, 204974) 1 1774 1833; scholar, social reformer and founder of Brahmo Samaj; worked for the abolition of sati
('28', 90, 0, 1, 205074) VOL. 28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15AUGUST, 1924 91
('28', 90, 1, 2, 205115) other implements The younger generation laughed to his face, the older people wisely shook their heads and remarked that there was a time when the charkhas musical hum was a feature of village life At last, they succeeded in introducing a dozen charkhas and began to feed the spinners regularly with cotton and wagas.
('28', 90, 1, 3, 205433) In order that the spinners might store sufficient yarn for weaving their own clothes, Prafulla used to give them cotton instead of wagas, i.e., for 5 tolas of yarn given by a spinner, he gave 10 tolas of cotton in return and to the needy he gave spinning wagas @ 3 pies per tola of yarn spun,
('28', 90, 2, 4, 205726) carding being done by the spinners themselves The earnest and steady spinning by the aid twelve spinners drew the attention of young and old alike.
('28', 90, 2, 5, 205874) The people who scoffed at charkha now wondered at the beautiful khaddar saris which the spinners had woven out of their own hand spun yarn and began to envy the spinners who earned such wages They now began to request my friend for charkhas, promising that they would ply them regularly The number increased and in 3 or 4 months the number of spinners was a hundred, and my friends abilities were put to severe test to keep them all going and the nucleus of our organization was thus established.
('28', 90, 2, 6, 206371) The Mohammedan ladies were the first to revive this charkha culture and their Hindu sisters are also following in their wake.
('28', 90, 2, 7, 206497) The present number of spinners is more than two hundred.
('28', 90, 3, 8, 206554) My own conversion to this khadi programme, i.e., village work, may interest you a little.
('28', 90, 3, 9, 206644) I was working as secretary, Jorabagan Congress Committee, Calcutta.
('28', 90, 3, 10, 206712) At the invitation of my friend Prafulla, I came to this place to see him working and it is here and here alone I became convinced of the potentialities of the charkha in the building up of our national life.
('28', 90, 3, 11, 206920) From daybreak to sunset, people old and young came with yarn to get double quantity of slivers or to sell it for meeting the weaver demand.
('28', 90, 3, 12, 207060) Old spinners were all clad in khaddar saris woven out of their own yarn.
('28', 90, 3, 13, 207133) Their hunger stricken faces had now sparks of joy.
('28', 90, 3, 14, 207184) I began to chat with them and learnt that my friends work had kept the wolf from their doors; that women, who used to beg for their sustenance, were now well off; that they no longer quarrelled among themselves because they had now no idle time left after carding and spinning; that their husbands could not now ill treat them as they were contributing considerably to the family fund; and lastly, but not the least, their izzat was saved.
('28', 90, 3, 15, 207624) I could learn all these things because I was introduced to them as a khadi worker; otherwise, nothing on earth could have moved these purdahnashin ladies to talk so intimately with a stranger.
('28', 90, 3, 16, 207817) Near about sunset,
('28', 90, 4, 17, 207836) the male population of the village began to arrive at our centre and they came daily to hear my friends conversation on various topics.
('28', 90, 4, 18, 207972) They all expressed their deepest sympathy for our work and anxiously prayed that it might conti nue for ever.
('28', 90, 4, 19, 208082) This evenings gathering made me at once remember one of your
('28', 91, 0, 1, 208143) 92 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 91, 1, 2, 208184) beautiful sayings: Non co operation with the Government for more co opera tion with the people, and I thought that this was the rightest way to do it.
('28', 91, 1, 3, 208335) In short, I could not resist myself the temptation of serving these poor innocent people; I gave up my town Congress work and came down here.
('28', 91, 1, 4, 208477) The more we are becoming familiar with the village life, the more convinced we become of the truth of the Bardoli programme and we now believe that we shall want nothing more if we can only work out this programme for the rest of our lives.
('28', 91, 2, 5, 208718) Along with khadi work there has begun national education, arbitra tion, and social service.
('28', 91, 2, 6, 208810) We have now a separate propaganda department which publishes a litho weekly, namely, Congress Sambad, containing exposition
('28', 91, 3, 7, 208934) on non violent non co operation, khaddar, untouchability etc.
('28', 91, 3, 8, 208996) We have named this organization as Satyagraha Sangh, and it has under its control:
('28', 91, 4, 9, 209079) 1. One spinning centre at Duadonda.
('28', 91, 4, 10, 209115) 2. One weaving centre at Baradongal, 7 miles north of Duadonda.
('28', 91, 4, 11, 209179) 3. One national school at Bandar, 4 miles south of Duadonda.
('28', 91, 4, 12, 209240) We received help from the following sources mainly:

('28', 92, 2, 3, 210548) The following is Mahadev Desais translation of an article 1 I wrote on this delicate subject in Navajivan of 25th May 1924. I gladly publish it in Young India as I have before me many letters from the other parts of India on the same subject.
('28', 92, 2, 4, 210791) The stray thoughts collected together in the article might be of some help to those who are earnestly striving for a pure life.

('28', 92, 3, 11, 211282) ABOUT PRINCIPAL GIDWANI
('28', 92, 4, 12, 211306) Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru has sent a letter in the following terms to the Administrator of Nabha:
('28', 92, 5, 13, 211402) I have just read in Young India of the 92nd a letter dated 12th May
('28', 92, 6, 14, 211470) written by you to Mr. M. K. Gandhi in regard to Mr. Gidwanis imprisonment.
('28', 92, 7, 15, 211545) It is stated in this letter that you suspended the sentences passed against Principal Gidwani, Mr. K. Santanam and me on condition that we left the State and did not return thereto without permission.
('28', 92, 7, 16, 211746) My recollection of this episode is entirely at variance with this.
('28', 92, 7, 17, 211813) I was and still am under the impression that our sentences were suspended unconditionally.
('28', 92, 7, 18, 211904) There wag no reference, so far as I can remember, in the order of suspension urder sec.
('28', 92, 7, 19, 211992) 407 C.P.C. or even on the piece of paper containing this order, to any condition, or to our returning to Nabha with or without permission.
('28', 92, 7, 20, 212131) This point was further cleared up by our conversation with the Superintendent of the Jail and the Chief of Police who were present.
('28', 92, 7, 21, 212263) Subsequently, we were informed of another orderstyled an executive orderon another piece of paper, wherein we were asked to leave the State and not to return without permission.
('28', 92, 7, 22, 212441) In this second paper there was no mention of our sentences or suspensions.
('28', 92, 7, 23, 212516) My request for copies of the orders was not granted nor was I allowed to copy them myself.
('28', 92, 7, 24, 212607) I was told that you had expressly forbidden copies.
('28', 92, 7, 25, 212659) I shall be glad if you will kindly let me know if the facts I have stated above about the suspension order are correct.
('28', 92, 7, 26, 212779) I shall also be obliged if you will also send me copies of the suspension order and the executive order.
('28', 92, 7, 27, 212884) You will admit, I hope, that it is only fair to me to supply me with these copies so that I may know where I stand.

('28', 93, 2, 7, 213607) LUXURY AND LAZINESS
('28', 93, 3, 8, 213627) A gentleman has sent me a long letter on the difficulties surro unding khaddar propaganda.
('28', 93, 3, 9, 213718) I copy the relevant parts of that letter.
('28', 93, 4, 10, 213760) These is much spinning in our province.
('28', 93, 4, 11, 213800) It is no exaggeration when I say that every lady in our villages is a spinner.
('28', 93, 4, 12, 213879) Even little girls know and practise the art.
('28', 93, 4, 13, 213924) Weavers are in abundance in this province.
('28', 93, 4, 14, 213967) A large quantity of khaddar can be produced in this province.
('28', 93, 4, 15, 214029) When I see the vast field of work for khaddar production, I feel that I should work and work hard.
('28', 93, 4, 16, 214128) But when I come to the Khaddar Depot of our Congress Committee, I find very few people buying our cloth.
('28', 93, 4, 17, 214233) People who had begun weaving khaddar have begun to use mill yarn cloth or some even foreign cloth.
('28', 93, 5, 18, 214332) The Congress appealed to the sentiments of the people.
('28', 93, 5, 19, 214387) They discarded foreign cloth and some even burnt it.
('28', 93, 5, 20, 214440) They adopted khaddar.
('28', 93, 5, 21, 214462) But its inherent defects became apparent.
('28', 93, 5, 22, 214504) The result is that they do not like to wear it now.
('28', 93, 5, 23, 214556) The defects are:
('28', 93, 6, 24, 214573) 1. The stuff is very heavy; the ladies do not tolerate it.
('28', 93, 7, 25, 214632) 2. On account of its weight, it is not easy to wash.
('28', 93, 8, 26, 214685) 3. It is not a childrens cloth, for their clothing requires constant washing and it is very difficult to do so in case of khaddar.
('28', 93, 9, 27, 214816) 4. It has got no variety and we cannot give fast colours to it.
('28', 93, 10, 28, 214880) 5. It catches dust.
('28', 93, 11, 29, 214900) 6. It is dearer than the mill cloth.
('28', 93, 11, 30, 214937) We purchase hand spun yarn one pound in a rupee, while Indian mill cloth is sold at Amritsar at the same rate, that is one pound per rupee.
('28', 93, 12, 31, 215077) The rich people do not like to wear this cloth as it does not satisfy their tastes, while the poor cannot afford to wear it, considering its price, washing charges, and other expenses.
('28', 93, 13, 32, 215262) Only the agricultural class in the villages uses it.
('28', 93, 13, 33, 215315) They get cotton from their fields.
('28', 93, 13, 34, 215350) Their ladies do the ginning and the spinning.
('28', 93, 13, 35, 215396) They have to pay for the carding and weaving which is not much as the labour it very cheap in the
('28', 94, 0, 1, 215494) VOL. 28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15AUGUST, 1924 95
('28', 94, 1, 2, 215535) villages.
('28', 94, 1, 3, 215545) It is a bye product for them.
('28', 94, 1, 4, 215575) By using it they save money which they do not get so easily as the people in the towns do.
('28', 94, 1, 5, 215666) The writer is connected with the khaddar movement and believes in it.
('28', 94, 1, 6, 215736) It is clear, however, that his argument is an argument of luxury and laziness.
('28', 94, 1, 7, 215815) Khadi propaganda certainly cannot succeed where they reign supreme.
('28', 94, 1, 8, 215883) If we desire swaraj, we must be prepared to work and give up luxurious tastes, at least for the time being.
('28', 94, 1, 9, 215991) A soldier who is unwilling to give up conveniences cannot fight.
('28', 94, 1, 10, 216056) India, if it cannot part with the soft and cheap calico in favour of rough khadi, will certainly not get swaraj.
('28', 94, 1, 11, 216169) The Punjab is the best province immediately to dis place all mill cloth.
('28', 94, 1, 12, 216242) But that the difficulties come from the Punjabis shows how we have fallen.
('28', 94, 1, 13, 216317) If the Punjabis want fine cloth, the remedy is not to buy mill cloth but for the Punjabi sisters to spin even as fine yarn as the Andhra sisters.
('28', 94, 1, 14, 216463) The Andhra spinning gives one all the fineness one can expect.
('28', 94, 1, 15, 216526) Nor is it a difficult thing to accomplish.
('28', 94, 1, 16, 216569) Just as, if we want fine chapatis, we must roll them fine and not go elsewhere in search of fine ones, so should we spin fine yarn, if we want fine cloth.
('28', 94, 1, 17, 216724) The ladies have no right to grumble at the heaviness of their khaddar if they are too lazy to spin fine.
('28', 94, 1, 18, 216829) Khaddar is eminently childrens cloth, if we would clothe them for protection and not for show.
('28', 94, 1, 19, 216924) Khaddar is capable of giving as much variety as mill cloth.
('28', 94, 1, 20, 216984) But it requires revival of the original skill of our forefathers.
('28', 94, 1, 21, 217050) Khaddar is today dearer than mill cloth because we have not yet put this national cottage industry on a sound basis.
('28', 94, 1, 22, 217167) But surely we cannot count the cost if we will be free.
('28', 94, 1, 23, 217223) Experience of hundreds of khaddar wearers is that it having simplified their taste, though it is dearer yard for yard, the quantity required being much less than before, khaddar wear is undoubtedly cheaper.
('28', 94, 1, 24, 217430) For the poor people khaddar need not be dearer, because they can grow their own cotton and gin, card, spin and weave it themselves.
('28', 94, 1, 25, 217562) Closely examined, the argument is answered by carrying on a ceaseless propaganda among the Punjabi sisters asking them to spin not below 20 counts.
('28', 94, 1, 26, 217710) An expert spinner can readjust their spindles so as to enable them to Spill higher counts without much extra energy or time being required.
('28', 94, 2, 27, 217850) WHAT IS A SPINNER ?
('28', 94, 3, 28, 217870) People often say that they can spin only because they are able to draw the thread.
('28', 94, 3, 29, 217953) This is, however, a false notion A baker is one who bakes bread that can be eaten and digested.
('28', 94, 3, 30, 218049) And it is not enough if he only knows how to bake.
('28', 94, 3, 31, 218100) He must know, as he does know, all the
('28', 95, 0, 1, 218139) 96 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 95, 1, 2, 218180) processes that flour has to go through and know also its different varieties.
('28', 95, 1, 3, 218258) Similarly, a spinner is one who draws an even and well twisted thread that can be woven without difficulty.
('28', 95, 1, 4, 218366) If the thread is under twisted or over twisted, it is of no use for weaving purposes.
('28', 95, 1, 5, 218452) And since it is not possible to spin well without good slivers, a spinner ought to know carding and sliver making.
('28', 95, 1, 6, 218567) He ought also to tell the staples of different varieties of cotton and be able to spin a given count, to, say, 30 counts.
('28', 95, 1, 7, 218689) And just as a carpenter who cannot sharpen or mend his tools is worthless, so is a spinner worthless who cannot mend his bow or the wheel or who cannot tell a crooked from a straight spindle and who cannot straighten a crooked one.
('28', 95, 1, 8, 218921) Many leave off spinning because their wheel has got out of order.
('28', 95, 1, 9, 218987) A spinning examination, therefore, should, in my opinion, cover all the points I have raised.
('28', 95, 1, 10, 219081) The course need not frighten the reader.
('28', 95, 1, 11, 219122) It is easy enough for those who would apply themselves to the work.
('28', 95, 1, 12, 219190) The thing is to treat it seriously.
('28', 95, 2, 13, 219226) One who has faith can secure everything and everything appears easy to him.
('28', 95, 2, 14, 219302) One who is without faith finds everything difficult.
('28', 95, 2, 15, 219355) To learn spinning is to cease to be indolent and become industrious.
('28', 95, 2, 16, 219424) One should practise rather than preach.
('28', 95, 2, 17, 219464) Swaraj can never be won by speeches; it will be secured only through action.
('28', 95, 2, 18, 219541) Spinning is the only activity which all people can undertake.
('28', 95, 2, 19, 219603) India became dependent and impoverished when the spinning wheel came to be discarded.
('28', 95, 2, 20, 219689) Her prosperity lies in its revival.

('28', 100, 1, 8, 229891) The charge that the programme is uninspiring or that a nation of spinners cannot achieve swaraj does not frighten me, because I know nothing so inspiring as a programme of solid work and I am convinced that we have to become once again a nation of carders, spinners and weavers if we are ever to banish starvation from the land and become economically indepen dent.

('28', 100, 4, 11, 230307) SATYAGRAHI PRISONERS CONDUCT
('28', 100, 5, 12, 230336) The argument advanced by some friends and put by me at the end of the last chapter 1 deserves consideration if only because so many honestly believe in it and so many followed it out consistently in their conduct in 1921 and 1922, when thousands went to jail.
('28', 100, 5, 13, 230596) In the first instance, even outside the jails, embarrassment of the Government is not our goal.
('28', 100, 5, 14, 230692) We are indifferent if the Government is embarrassed so long as our conduct is right.
('28', 100, 5, 15, 230777) Our non co operation embarrasses the Government as nothing else can.
('28', 100, 5, 16, 230846) But we non co ope rate as lawyers or Councillors because it is our duty.
('28', 100, 5, 17, 230919) That is to say, we will not cease to non co operate if we discovered that our non co op eration pleased the rulers.
('28', 100, 5, 18, 231035) And we are so indifferent because we beli eve that, by non co operation, we must ultimately benefit ourselves.
('28', 100, 5, 19, 231146) But there cannot be any such non co operation in the jails.
('28', 100, 5, 20, 231206) We do not enter them to serve a selfish end.
('28', 100, 5, 21, 231251) We are taken there by the Govern ment as criminals according so their estimation.
('28', 100, 5, 22, 231333) Our business, there fore, is to disillusion them by acting in an exemplary (and by them
('28', 100, 6, 23, 231421) 1 Vide My Jail Experiences VI, 22 5 1924.
('28', 101, 0, 1, 231463) 102 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 101, 1, 2, 231505) expected) manner, just as our business outside is to disillusion them by avoiding, say, their law courts, schools or Councils or titles and by showing that we are prepared to do without their doubtful benefits.
('28', 101, 1, 3, 231716) Whether all of us realize it or not the method of non co oper ation is a process of touching the heart and appealing to reason, not one of frightening by rowdyism.
('28', 101, 1, 4, 231880) Rowdyism has no place in a non violent movement.
('28', 101, 1, 5, 231929) I have often likened satyagrahi prisoners to prisoners of war.
('28', 101, 1, 6, 231992) Once caught by the enemy, prisoners of war act towards the enemy as friends.
('28', 101, 1, 7, 232069) It will be considered dishonourable on the part of a soldier as a prisoner of war to deceive the enemy.
('28', 101, 1, 8, 232173) It does not affect my argu ment that the Government does not regard satyagrahi prisoners as prisoners of war.
('28', 101, 1, 9, 232283) If we act as such, we shall soon command respect.
('28', 101, 1, 10, 232333) We must make the prisons a neutral institution in which we may, nay, must co operate to a certain extent.
('28', 101, 1, 11, 232439) We would be highly inconsistent and hardly self respecting if, on the one hand, we deliberately break prison rules and, in the same breath, complain of punishment and strictness.
('28', 101, 1, 12, 232618) We may not, for instance, resist and complain of search and, at the same time, conceal prohibited things in our blankets or our clothes.
('28', 101, 1, 13, 232755) There is nothing in satyagraha that I know whereby we may, under certain circumstances, tell untruths or practise other deception.
('28', 101, 1, 14, 232886) When we say that, if we make the lives of prison officials uncomfortable, the Government will he obliged to sue for peace, we either pay them a subtle compliment or regard them as simpletons.
('28', 101, 1, 15, 233078) We pay a subtle compliment when we consider that, even though we may make prison officials lives uncomfortable, the Government will look on in silence and hesitate to award us condign punishment so as utterly to break our spirit.
('28', 101, 1, 16, 233308) That is to say, we regard the administrators to be so considerate and humane that they will not severely punish us even though we give them sufficient cause.
('28', 101, 1, 17, 233466) As a matter of fact, they will not and do not hesitate to throw overboard all idea of decency and award not only authotized but even unauthorized punishments on given occasions.
('28', 101, 1, 18, 233644) But it is my deliberate conviction that, had we but acted with uniform honesty and dignity behoving satyagrahis, we should have disarmed all opposition on the part of the Government, and such strictly honourable behaviour on the part of so many prisoners would have at least shamed the Government into confessing their error in
('28', 102, 0, 1, 233972) VOL. 28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15AUGUST, 1924 103
('28', 102, 1, 2, 234014) imprisoning so many honourable and innocent men.
('28', 102, 1, 3, 234063) For, is it not their case that our non violence is but a cloak for our violence?
('28', 102, 1, 4, 234144) Do we not, therefore, play into their hands every time we are rowdy?
('28', 102, 1, 5, 234213) In my opinion, therefore, as satyagrahis we are bound, when we become prisoners: 1. to act with the most scrupulous honesty; 2. to co operate with the prison officials in their administration; 3. to set, by our obedience to all reasonable discipline, an example to co prisoners; 4. to ask for no favours and claim no privileges which the meanest of prisoners do not get and which we do not need strictly for reasons of health; 5. not to fail to ask what we do so need and not to get irritated if we do not obtain it; 6. to do all the tasks allotted, to the utmost of our ability.
('28', 102, 1, 6, 234793) It is such conduct which will make the Government position uncom fortable and untenable.
('28', 102, 1, 7, 234882) It is difficult for them to meet honesty with honesty for their want of faith and unpreparedness for such a rare eventuality.
('28', 102, 1, 8, 235008) Rowdyism they expect and meet with a double dose of it.
('28', 102, 1, 9, 235064) They were able to deal with anarchical crime, but they havenot yet found out any way of dealing with non violence save by yielding to it.
('28', 102, 1, 10, 235202) The idea behind the imprisonment of a satyagrahi is that he expects relief through humble submission to suffering.
('28', 102, 1, 11, 235317) He believes that meek suffering for a just cause has a virtue all its own and infinitely greater than the virtue of the sword.
('28', 102, 1, 12, 235444) This does not mean that we may not resist when the treatment touches our self respect.
('28', 102, 1, 13, 235531) Thus, for instance, we must resist to the point of death the use of abusive language by officials or if they were to throw our food at us which is often done.
('28', 102, 1, 14, 235690) Insult and abuse are no part of an officials duty.
('28', 102, 1, 15, 235741) Therefore, we must resist them.
('28', 102, 1, 16, 235773) But we may not resist search because it is part of prison regulations.
('28', 102, 1, 17, 235844) Nor are my remarks about mute suffering to be construed to mean that there should be no agitation against putting innocent priso ners like satyagrahis in the same class as confirmed criminals.
('28', 102, 1, 18, 236037) Only as prisoners we may not ask for favours.
('28', 102, 1, 19, 236083) We must be content to live with the confirmed criminals and even welcome the opportunity of work ing moral reform in them.
('28', 102, 1, 20, 236206) It is however expected of a Government

('28', 103, 1, 2, 236287) that calls itself civilized to recognize the most natural divisions.

('28', 104, 2, 3, 238387) A Vaishnava gentleman has lovingly chided me for having used the singular number while referring to Rama, Shankar 1, Bharat and other incarnations of God.

('28', 104, 2, 6, 238894) Perhaps, the friend who has written to me does not know that I myself am a Vaishnava and that Shri Ramachandra Prabhu is the ishtadevata 3 worshipped in my family.

('28', 106, 5, 6, 243204) I stated in a previous issue that all pupils in the schools for workers children exclusively wore khadi.

('28', 106, 5, 8, 243410) The mistake was mine.

('28', 106, 5, 10, 243555) The editor of the Majoor Sandesh expects nothing by making exaggerated statements.
('28', 106, 5, 11, 243638) Exaggeration does not advance a cause, but actually obstructs it.
('28', 106, 5, 12, 243704) When the desired state of affairs does not in fact exist, it cannot be brought into being by trying to prove that it does exist.
('28', 106, 5, 13, 243833) The starvation in India is a real fact, and not merely a tragedy on the stage.
('28', 106, 5, 14, 243912) The hundreds of thousands of skeletons we see in India are the very images of pity.
