('28', 107, 6, 16, 246270) 56. INTERVIEW TO  THE TIMES OF INDIA
('28', 107, 7, 17, 246307) [SABARMATI ASHRAM, June 5, 1924]
('28', 107, 8, 18, 246340) Mr. Gandhi was good enough to give an interview to the special correspondent of The Times of India this afternoon at the Sabarmati Ashram, with reference to the
('28', 107, 9, 19, 246501) amazing resolution passed at the Bengal Provincial Conference paying homage to the patriotism of Gopinath Saha, the murderer of Mr. Ernest Day 2. Mr. Gandhi had no hesitation in condemning in the severest terms the purport of the resolution to which Mr. Das and his followers are reported to have given their support, but he was not prepared to pass any opinion on Mr. Dass action unless he knew from him personally what his views were.
('28', 107, 10, 20, 246938) My first question to Mr. Gandhi was: I suppose you have read the Calcutta telegram regarding the attitude of Mr. Das at the Bengal Provincial Conference with reference to the murder of Mr. Ernest Day.
('28', 107, 10, 21, 247139) There it is stated that Mr. Das and his party,
('28', 107, 11, 22, 247186) 1 Held in December 1920 2 An Englishman who had connections with the Government and, being mistaken for a high police official, was murdered
('28', 108, 0, 1, 247327) VOL. 28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15AUGUST, 1924 109
('28', 108, 1, 2, 247369) while condemning the action of Gopinath Saha in murdering Mr. Day, paid homage to his patriotism and admired his object which they considered noble and praiseworthy.
('28', 108, 1, 3, 247535) May I ask if you take the same view of the matter as Mr. Dass?
('28', 108, 2, 4, 247598) Mr. Gandhi replied: I dont know what view Mr. Das takes.
('28', 108, 2, 5, 247655) I have seen nothing beyond the Associated Press telegram which you have shown me.
('28', 108, 2, 6, 247737) I can, therefore, give you my own opinion upon the hypothetical ques tion whether I would approve of the murder by one person of another, no matter how laudable the object of the murderer may be.
('28', 108, 2, 7, 247933) My answer would be emphatically, no.
('28', 108, 2, 8, 247970) I purposely refrain from giving you a direct reply to the question put, because I distrust telegraphic summaries of the proceedings of big conferences, even when they are sent by parties who are not prejudiced one way or the other.
('28', 108, 2, 9, 248202) Unless, therefore, I know what the Bengal Conference has done and what Mr. Das has said, I must decline to give any opinion whatever upon his action.
('28', 108, 2, 10, 248352) Indeed, when I met him at Juhu he warned me against belie ving anything that might be said against him, because he said there was a conspiracy against him designed to undermine his influence.
('28', 108, 3, 11, 248544) Do you think the Bengal resolution could be justified morally or politically, or by your non violent creed?
('28', 108, 4, 12, 248652) MR. GANDHI: In my opinion, no murder can be consistent with my own personal creed of non violence.
('28', 108, 4, 13, 248751) Whether political murder can be justified morally or politically is a question which everybody must answer for himself.
('28', 108, 4, 14, 248871) I know many persons, Indian as well as European, who consider that taking the life of a person from political motives is justified on the highest principle of morality.
('28', 108, 4, 15, 249040) Needless to say, I totally dissent from that view.
('28', 108, 5, 16, 249091) What do you think would be the effect of the resolution on the popular mind, particularly on the mind of the illiterate and ignorant classes?
('28', 108, 6, 17, 249233) Mr. Gandhi could say nothing about Mr. Dass view unless he knew personally from him what his view was, but if the text of the resolution was as the one shown to him, Mr. Gandhi certainly considered it to be unfortunate and inconsistent with the Congress creed.
('28', 108, 6, 18, 249494) He agreed also that such a resolution could not but mislead ignorant people.
('28', 108, 7, 19, 249571) Do you think the moral underlying the resolution of the Bengal Provincial Conference, if accepted by any political party in India, would be conducive to the interests of the country?
('28', 109, 0, 1, 249754) 110 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 109, 1, 2, 249796) MR. GANDHI: I am totally in the dark as to what the resolution is.
('28', 109, 1, 3, 249863) The telegram that you have shown me does not give the text of the resolution, but, if the purport given in the telegram is correct, I find it difficult to understand its meaning, because if the action of Gopinath Saha was worthy of condemnation, as in my humble opinion it was, what was the patriotism apart from the action for which the homage was deserved?
('28', 109, 1, 4, 250222) I cannot, therefore, conceive the possibility of any political party subscribing to the moral underlying the homage paid to Gopinath Saha.
('28', 109, 2, 5, 250361) Do you think that the Congress as at present constituted would sanction such a doctrine?
('28', 109, 3, 6, 250450) MR. GANDHI: No.
('28', 109, 4, 7, 250466) Would you call murderers like Gopinath Saha patriots?
('28', 109, 5, 8, 250520) MR. GANDHI: I would call murderers like Gopinath Saha patriots, but not without an indispensable adjective, namely, misleading.
('28', 109, 5, 9, 250648) Their selflessness, defiance of death and love of the country I think must be held to be unquestionable, but on that very account, whilst I would call them misleading patriots, I would condemn their actions in the severest terms possible and I would be no party to resolutions praising their motives.
('28', 109, 5, 10, 250949) We can only judge peoples actions and, if they are bad and harmful to society, we cannot afford to pay them homage for their motives.
('28', 109, 5, 11, 251083) In my humble opinion, the largest amount of harm done in this world is by people who have good motives, but who do not hesitate to resort to acts that are bad.
('28', 109, 5, 12, 251243) It is the age long superstition that the end justifies the means and it is because I see as clear as daylight that there can be no dividing line between the end and the means and that the end is, always the direct consequence of the means, that I am resisting with my whole soul the present system of Govern ment as well as activities designed to beat the system with its own wea pons, namely, by means fair or foul.
('28', 109, 6, 13, 251660) May I take you back to the days when the political crimes commenced in Bengal?
('28', 109, 6, 14, 251739) There is an impression abroad that the activities of the Bengal anarchists would have continued but for the inauguration of your non violent Non co operation movement.
('28', 109, 6, 15, 251907) Those activities, it is said, were suspended on account of this movement, but that since your imprisonment the influence of the N.C.O. movement had diminished to such an extent that the Bengal revolutionaries had recommenced their activities.
('28', 109, 6, 16, 252150) May I ask if that is, in your opinion, a correct view of the situation?
('28', 109, 7, 17, 252222) MR. GANDHI: I do believe that anarchism in Bengal became dor mant because of the advent of non violent Non co operation which required just as much sacrifice as any anarchist was capable of offer ing.
('28', 109, 7, 18, 252423) I also believe that the signs that we see of a revival of violent revolutionary activities are due to the belief that non violence has
('28', 110, 0, 1, 252558) VOL. 28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15AUGUST, 1924 111
('28', 110, 1, 2, 252600) failed.
('28', 110, 2, 3, 252608) Have you in contemplation, Mr. Gandhi, any practical measures for checking political crimes in Bengal and converting the youth of the province to your doctrine of non violence in thought and in action?
('28', 110, 3, 4, 252810) MR. GANDHI: I do, indeed, contemplate measures for checking the activities of these misguided friends of mine.
('28', 110, 3, 5, 252921) I use the word friends purposely, because I yield to no one in my admiration for the spirit of self sacrifice that actuates them, but I know that their activity does immense harm to the country.
('28', 110, 3, 6, 253116) It can never give swaraj to India even if it succeeds in making English rule impossible.
('28', 110, 3, 7, 253205) I am convinced that the spirit of India is essentially non violent and gentle.
('28', 110, 3, 8, 253284) Violence has, therefore, no atmosphere to thrive in and if God grants me health, I hope to be able to overtake the anarchical activities and show to the anarchists that there is more than ample scope for pure and exacting sacrifice in my scheme for achieving swaraj and that, if they will only give me their enthusiastic support, they will deserve homage not merely for their motives, but also for their acts which can be emulated by the least of their countrymen without the slightest hesitation and without any danger to anybody else.
('28', 110, 4, 9, 253821) The interviewer then passed on to another subject, namely, the revolt of the C. P. ('28', 110, 5, 12, 254481) MR. GANDHI: I am unable to say whether Dr. Moonjes views are shared by many other Swarajists, but whether they are or not, I remain unperturbed, because there will be no loss of prestige of either of the parties if only because I do not propose to take part in any fratri cidal struggle.
('28', 110, 5, 13, 254769) After all, it requires two parties to carry on a struggle of that character, and my scheme of carrying on political work always avoids such friction.
('28', 110, 5, 14, 254919) I literally mean what I have said, namely, that I have advocated exclusive control of the Congress executives in the interests of both parties and, if I see the slightest desire on the part of the Swarajists to take over the Congress executives, I for one shall not resist the attempt, but let them take charge of the Congress executives.
('28', 110, 5, 15, 255258) I would then form an organization outside the Congress and invite those who believe in the Congress programme to work it outside the

('28', 111, 1, 3, 255443) Thus, in any event I shall avoid a brush with the Swarajists.
('28', 111, 1, 4, 255505) I shall not need to carry on any propaganda against the Swarajists.

('28', 112, 6, 19, 257768) 60. AIM OF KATHIAWAR POLITICAL CONFERENCE
('28', 112, 7, 20, 257810) I quote the following 4 from a long letter which a friend has written about the Kathiawar Political Conference: In my opinion, the aim of the Kathiawar Political Conference should be as follows: 1. To take steps in every State to make the relationship between the Ruler and the ruled beneficial to the latter.
('28', 112, 7, 21, 258120) 2. To take steps which would lead to a closer and mutually beneficial relationship among the States as also among their subjects.
('28', 112, 8, 22, 258250) 1 The reference in the letter to the health of Mani, Radha and Kikibehn suggests that the letter was written in 1924. Similar references are found in some of the letters written during March April, 1924. That year Jeth Sud 5 fell on June 7.
('28', 112, 9, 23, 258491) 2 Manibehn Patel 3 Son of Chhanganlal Gandhi 4 Not translated here
('28', 113, 0, 1, 258558) 114 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 113, 1, 2, 258600) 3. To take steps for the economic, political and moral progress of the entire population of Kathiawar.
('28', 113, 1, 3, 258703) In all its activities, the Conference should follow the path of peace.
('28', 113, 1, 4, 258774) The Conference cannot undertake the burden of freeing the Princes from the control of British Government; if it aims at doing so, the interests of both the Rulers and the subjects will suffer.
('28', 113, 1, 5, 258967) The Rulers are subservient to the British and cannot permit the holding of a Conference with such an aim, even if they approved of the movement for their freedom, they would have to oppose it.
('28', 113, 1, 6, 259160) I, therefore, think that all efforts by the people to that end will prove both futile and harmful so long as the Rulers themselves do not desire their freedom and [are not ready to] work publicly for it.
('28', 113, 1, 7, 259364) It should certainly be one of the functions of the Conference to create public opinion against the tyranny of the Rulers, and this is included in the first clause.
('28', 113, 1, 8, 259528) Let the people of each State solve their own local problems.
('28', 113, 1, 9, 259589) But Kathiawaris are all one people and as such have a right to hold a Conference on behalf of the entire population; in fact, they have a duty to do so.
('28', 113, 1, 10, 259742) Not only can such a Conference discuss problems common to all, it can also interest itself in local issues, form a collective public opinion on them and bring it to bear on the solution of local problems.
('28', 113, 1, 11, 259947) I have explained in earlier issues the wider meaning of the word political, and that, I believe, is the true meaning.
('28', 113, 1, 12, 260065) The task of making the Conference popular has yet to be taken up.
('28', 113, 1, 13, 260131) Making it popular does not mean only that people start attending its meetings; it means that they should work for redress of their grievances through the Conference and follow its advice.
('28', 113, 1, 14, 260319) Before this could happen, the workers of the Conference should serve the people, go into the villages and make themselves as poor and simple as the masses.
('28', 113, 1, 15, 260475) We should not be hostile to Indian States.
('28', 113, 1, 16, 260518) We are not offering non co operation against the Rulers.
('28', 113, 1, 17, 260575) We have not given up the latter as hopeless; I, at any rate, have not done so.
('28', 113, 1, 18, 260654) I am not ignorant of the tyranny of some of the Rulers.
('28', 113, 1, 19, 260710) I am disgusted by their uncontrolled and excessive spending.
('28', 113, 1, 20, 260771) It is shocking that they prefer to live in Europe rather than in their own country.
('28', 113, 1, 21, 260855) However, I do not blame them for this.
('28', 113, 1, 22, 260894) This state of affairs is one of the results of the British system.
('28', 113, 1, 23, 260961) From their childhood, the Rulers grow up dependent on others.
('28', 113, 1, 24, 261023) They are watched over by British tutors and others, who have
('28', 114, 0, 1, 261084) VOL. 28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15AUGUST, 1924 115
('28', 114, 1, 2, 261126) orders to train the Princes to behave like the British, create in them admiration for British rule and educate them to like all things British.
('28', 114, 1, 3, 261270) We see this preference for European ways among the well to do also, and find the same thing on a greater scale among the Rulers.
('28', 114, 1, 4, 261399) The reason for this love of foreign ways in both is the same.
('28', 114, 1, 5, 261461) I am sure that if public opinion in Kathiawar, i.e., Indian States, is properly educated, if it becomes strong and fearless, the Rulers will immediately bow to it.
('28', 114, 1, 6, 261625) In spite of their many failings, I believe the Princes to be simple hearted men.
('28', 114, 1, 7, 261706) They are godfearing, and are much afraid, indeed, of public opinion.
('28', 114, 1, 8, 261775) I know both these things from personal experience.
('28', 114, 1, 9, 261826) However, what can the poor Rulers do where there is no public opinion or there arc only flatterers among their subjects?
('28', 114, 1, 10, 261947) As there is no one to point out their failings and criticize them, they give up all self restraint; they arc, moreover, encouraged by the British] Govern ment in this.
('28', 114, 1, 11, 262115) Thus, the circumstances conspire against them and bring about their degradation.
('28', 114, 1, 12, 262196) True, their oppression is sometimes crude and we feel it to be unbearably cruel.
('28', 114, 1, 13, 262277) On the other hand, the Govern ments oppression is civilized and is not felt to be unbearable in the same measure.
('28', 114, 1, 14, 262391) Moreover, in the part of the country directly ruled by the British, one feels secure in the support of public opinion and numerous co workers, whereas in the Indian States only a few brave men come forward as yet for public work and so it is easy for the Rulers to suppress them.
('28', 114, 1, 15, 262671) Nevertheless, if a few polite, humble, well behaved and discriminating men come forward as public workers, the Rulers will yield to them, and they will do this not so much through fear of them as because of their own virtues.
('28', 114, 1, 16, 262897) If we start by being suspicious of the Rulers, are determined to speak ill of them and refuse to see any good in them, we will, from the outset, be set down in the debit column of their books.
('28', 114, 1, 17, 263090) It would then be very hard to get oneself brought over to the credit side.
('28', 114, 1, 18, 263165) Let no one conclude from this that I am encouraging cowardice.
('28', 114, 1, 19, 263228) I am pointing out the difference between arrogance and fearlessness which is at the same time humble.
('28', 114, 1, 20, 263330) The mango tree as it grows and spreads bends lower.
('28', 114, 1, 21, 263382) Similarly, as the strength of the strong increases, he should become progressively more humble; he should become more and more godfearing.
('28', 114, 1, 22, 263521) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 8 6 1924

('28', 115, 1, 2, 263599) 61. MY VIEWS
('28', 115, 2, 3, 263612) A gentleman has sent me the opinions of a Jain muni 1 on my views, and wishes me to comment on them.
('28', 115, 2, 4, 263713) I give below the munis opinions and my comments on each: I. If Gandhis ideas are fully carried out, they will do harm to Jainism.
('28', 115, 2, 5, 263843) I am certain that, if my ideas are carried out, they will do only good to the world, and what benefits the world as a whole cannot possibly harm Jainism or any other religion.
('28', 115, 2, 6, 264019) Non violence is love.
('28', 115, 2, 7, 264041) How can a method of bringing about reform through love do any harm?
('28', 115, 2, 8, 264109) 2. Khadi will benefit the Antyajas, but will harm the interests of the Jains very much.
('28', 115, 2, 9, 264197) This opinion is difficult to understand.
('28', 115, 2, 10, 264238) Can there be no Antyaja who is a shravak 2?
('28', 115, 2, 11, 264282) Moreover, the only sense in which the interest of the Jains can suffer is that the business of those of them who deal in foreign cloth may be ruined.
('28', 115, 2, 12, 264432) If that happens, however, Jains can start some other business.
('28', 115, 2, 13, 264495) Why cannot they deal in khadi?
('28', 115, 2, 14, 264526) There are others besides Jains who also trade in foreign cloth.
('28', 115, 2, 15, 264590) In the last analysis, it is desirable, from a religious standpoint, that a business which is morally tainted should come to a stop.
('28', 115, 2, 16, 264722) 3. A businessman commits no sin, whatever he does.
('28', 115, 2, 17, 264773) This cannot be Jainism.
('28', 115, 2, 18, 264797) I have not come across such ideas in any religion.
('28', 115, 2, 19, 264848) 4. There is much exaggeration in the praises showered on Gandhi.
('28', 115, 2, 20, 264913) It is not proper to attribute to him the virtues of one like Mahavira 3. I entirely agree.
('28', 115, 2, 21, 265004) Those who sing my praises would show their admiration for me better if they stopped praising me and got absorbed in doing their own duty.
('28', 115, 2, 22, 265142) Such praise will not suffer from exaggeration or any other fault.
('28', 115, 2, 23, 265208) 5. An Antyaja remains an Antyaja, however much he purifies himself.
('28', 115, 3, 24, 265276) 1 Monk 2 Follower of the Jain religion 3 Founder of the Jain religion

('28', 116, 1, 2, 265388) This idea has neither religion nor reason in it.
('28', 116, 1, 3, 265437) 6. Gandhi describes himself as a staunch Vaishnava for a reason of his own.
('28', 116, 1, 4, 265513) All the religions would perish if every one of Gandhis ideas was carried out.

('28', 116, 1, 12, 266154) In refraining from doing so, they would be putting those ideas into action.
('28', 116, 1, 13, 266230) Those who accept my ideas and carry them out should keep in mind our rustic saying: Our interest is in the oil, not in the sound which the drops make as they fall. Moreover, by replying to accusa tions, we generate ill feeling, waste our time and arouse passions.
('28', 116, 1, 14, 266494) We should also understand that we have no reason to believe that the accusations are inspired merely by malice.
('28', 116, 1, 15, 266606) A good number of those who criticize me believe in all sincerity that many of my actions only harm the country.
('28', 116, 1, 16, 266718) The right way is to think carefully over the charges made against a friend of ours and tell him what truth we find in them.
('28', 116, 1, 17, 266842) Generally, a person does not attend to what is said by his opponents but, when his friends point out his failings, he will, if there is any measure of sincerity in him, take prompt note and examine himself.

('28', 119, 1, 2, 272384) 63. MY NOTES
('28', 119, 2, 3, 272397) THE AGA KHANI BROTHERS
('28', 119, 3, 4, 272420) My article 1 on Hindu Muslim unity has called forth an endless stream of comment.
('28', 119, 3, 5, 272502) Some have liked it, while others have been incensed by it.
('28', 119, 3, 6, 272561) From time to time, I shall publish in Navajivan extracts from these comments, whenever necessary.
('28', 119, 3, 7, 272659) The Khoja friends have been hurt and perhaps enraged by what I said about their activities.
('28', 119, 3, 8, 272751) They preferred to come and see me instead of writing to me.
('28', 119, 3, 9, 272811) This, of course, pleased me very much.
('28', 119, 3, 10, 272850) I could thus get to know their point of view also.
('28', 119, 3, 11, 272901) They feel that I should have made no comment without having first met them.
('28', 119, 3, 12, 272977) I explained to them that, in my statement taken as a whole, I had presented both the sides, as was but proper, and, concerning matter about which I had no positive knowledge, I had said that certain allegations were made in regard to some activities.
('28', 119, 3, 13, 273228) I told them that I would certainly go through the books which I had received and give my opinion on them.
('28', 119, 3, 14, 273334) If I feel that my informants had misled me, I would admit the fact and also apologize.
('28', 119, 3, 15, 273421) If, however, I form from these writings the same impression as my informants and I agree with their views, the Khoja friends should not feel hurt.
('28', 119, 3, 16, 273568) I also told them that I could not accept the view that the Hon.
('28', 119, 3, 17, 273632) Aga Khan is an incarnation in the sense recognized in Hinduism.
('28', 119, 3, 18, 273696) Moreover, the way in which they use the word Om and the shape they have given to it is, in my opinion, taking liberties with concepts which belong to Hinduism.
('28', 119, 3, 19, 273856) They asked me, however, what they should do if they felt about the matter as they said they did.
('28', 119, 3, 20, 273953) I told them that in that case they should adhere to their views and accept my right to express my views in oral discussions and in my writings.
('28', 119, 3, 21, 274097) Moreover, they assured me that no one is ever offered material inducement to become a Khoja.
('28', 119, 3, 22, 274190) I was very glad to hear this and assured them that I would repeat this to my informants and, if they failed to prove their charge, I would state that, too, in Navajivan.
('28', 119, 3, 23, 274360) Finally, they also said that readers of Navajivan were likely to get the impression that the Khojas belief in a perfect incarnation was of recent origin.
('28', 119, 3, 24, 274514) The truth of the matter according to them is that this
('28', 119, 4, 25, 274569) 1 Vide Hindu Muslim Tension: Its Cause and Cure, 29 5 1924.
('28', 120, 0, 1, 274629) VOL. 28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15AUGUST, 1924 121
('28', 120, 1, 2, 274671) belief of theirs, as also their belief about Om, dates back to very ancient times and that they have proof in support of this.
('28', 120, 2, 3, 274798) SELFISHNESS
('28', 120, 3, 4, 274810) After reading the note 2 in Navajivan on the dirty habits of many third class passengers, a gentleman writes to say: 3
('28', 120, 4, 5, 274929) I congratulate him on refusing to accept the seat belatedly offered to him as a favour and, not minding the inconvenience, remaining where he was in the narrow passage.
('28', 120, 4, 6, 275098) If those who offered him the seat wished to display the smallest measure of courtesy, they could have offered him a seat as soon as he entered the compartment.
('28', 120, 4, 7, 275258) Courtesy demands that, even if there is no room, we should offer a seat to a passenger who boards the train.
('28', 120, 4, 8, 275367) The fact is that we have not yet gone much beyond regard for family relationships.
('28', 120, 4, 9, 275450) We know the duty of sacrifice for the sake of kinsfolk.
('28', 120, 4, 10, 275506) We may also do something for acquaintances.
('28', 120, 4, 11, 275550) There is nothing at all in either of these.
('28', 120, 4, 12, 275594) We also suffer inconvenience for a third category, that of the strong and the powerful.
('28', 120, 4, 13, 275682) This is unworthy, of course.
('28', 120, 4, 14, 275711) As for passengers who may be poor, we would even go to the length of pushing them away from the seats already occupied by them.
('28', 120, 4, 15, 275839) If we wish to cultivate the feeling of being one people, it is our duty to be ready to make room especially for the poor.
('28', 120, 4, 16, 275961) If our neighbour (particularly if he is a stranger) is hungry, we should give him food to eat and water to drink before we attend to ourselves and we should suffer discomfort ourselves to make him comfortable.
('28', 120, 4, 17, 276171) Such an attitude, if adopted towards our own people, means patriotic unity and, if towards the whole of mankind, means a religious spirit.
('28', 120, 4, 18, 276310) Even if we do not wish to cultivate the religious spirit, we should cultivate patriotic unity.

('28', 122, 1, 2, 278521) 65. INTERVIEW TO  THE HINDU
('28', 122, 2, 3, 278549) AHMEDABAD, June 8, 1924
('28', 122, 3, 4, 278573) Mahatmaji asked me to sit near to him and asked me the purpose of my visit.
('28', 122, 3, 5, 278649) I joined my hands as I went near him with reverence to which he replied with his characteristic bowing and smiling.
('28', 122, 3, 6, 278765) Then I told him that I had come for his darshan and also for an interview.
('28', 122, 3, 7, 278840) He gladly consented to give me an interview.
('28', 122, 3, 8, 278885) The following are the questions put by me and answered by Mahatmaji:
('28', 122, 4, 9, 278954) At the outset I enquired of his health, to which he replied that he was getting better.
('28', 122, 4, 10, 279042) After talking a while on other matters, the conversation turned to the interview itself.
('28', 122, 5, 11, 279131) You did not give your rigid interpretation to the peaceful and legitimate, to be non violent and truthful, as you did after the Delhi A.I.C.C.? I asked.
('28', 122, 5, 12, 279284) I may not have made my meaning clear at the Calcutta Con gress, as there could not be any interpretation but that, and as I thought everybody understood that meaning.
('28', 122, 6, 13, 279451) But then, why do you force that interpretation on others now?
('28', 122, 6, 14, 279513) He answered: I do not want to force on others my interpretation of the words peaceful and legitimateas non violent and truthful.
('28', 122, 6, 15, 279642) To do so would be inconsistent with my dharma.
('28', 122, 6, 16, 279689) I had to make my meaning subsequently clear, as I thought it was misunderstood.
('28', 122, 7, 17, 279769) In your recent statement, you lay greater stress on the mental attitude and not on the actual results attained, but at the Calcutta Congress you started N.C.O. to achieve definite ends, viz., Khilafat and Punjab wrongs, and at that time, you never laid more stress on the mental attitude.
('28', 122, 7, 18, 280058) Is this consistent?
('28', 122, 7, 19, 280078) I do not attach much importance to mental attitude, except in so far as it would affect the treatment of the different problems.
('28', 122, 8, 20, 280207) As regards the Congress machinery, you know that it lays down its policy and chooses its own executives to carry and supervise the carrying out of its policy.
('28', 122, 8, 21, 280366) If in the discretion vested in the Congress, it chooses Swarajists to carry out its policy, will you still think that the Swarajist position is not consistent with its policy, especially when the Congress knows better than anybody else?
('28', 122, 8, 22, 280603) This also is a misunderstanding of the position I have taken.
('28', 122, 8, 23, 280665) I know it is open to Congress voters to elect whom they choose, but as a humble worker in the Congress and a voter myself, I am exercising right of free opinion and trying to guide the voters consistently with their programme to choose only such representatives as have pledged themselves to fulfil the programme in its entirety.
('28', 122, 8, 24, 280995) My appeal is
('28', 123, 0, 1, 281008) 124 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 123, 1, 2, 281050) similarly addressed to the present representatives of the voters that, whilst they abide by the N.C.O. resolution, it is their duty either to carry out that programme in its entirety or to resign and ask the electors to choose those who believe in that programme.
('28', 123, 2, 3, 281314) If the Swarajist programme is altogether inconsistent with the mental attitude essential to N.C.O., how do you approve of its programme by its success, as measured by its results?
('28', 123, 2, 4, 281494) Mahatmaji laughed and said: If the Swarajist programme is successful, I wish to be the first to join the party and congratulate them, and then, I shall pocket all my pride and my mental attitude.
('28', 123, 3, 5, 281690) The conversation next turned to Hindu Muslim questions.
('28', 123, 3, 6, 281746) I asked: In your recent article 1 on Hindu Muslim tension, many Hindus think that injustice is being done to them at your hands as you demand more sacrifices from them than their Muslim brothers.
('28', 123, 3, 7, 281942) In the first instance, I have not demanded sufficient sacrifices from Hindus.
('28', 123, 3, 8, 282020) But if they will only sacrifice to their utmost, I would promise not only swaraj within a day, but promise that Hindus will always be in the ascendent and hold the Muslims in the palm of their hands.
('28', 123, 4, 9, 282220) But what have you to say to those Arya Samajists who say that injustice is also being done them in your article?
('28', 123, 4, 10, 282333) They think you have petted and defended Maulana Abdul Bari and Maulana Mahomed Ali and you could have done the same to Dayanand Saraswati and Shraddhanandji.
('28', 123, 4, 11, 282491) Any special motive in condemning the Arya Samaj deliberately, will you clear your position?
('28', 123, 4, 12, 282583) Surely.
('28', 123, 4, 13, 282591) But I have not defended either of the Maulanas at all; I have said plainly that the reference in Mahomed Alis Congress speech to division of untouchables was wrong, and it is to his credit that he has made the admission.
('28', 123, 4, 14, 282812) I have also said that Abdul Bari is betrayed into making statements which cannot be explained, and I have therefore called him a dangerous friend.
('28', 123, 4, 15, 282959) I am unable to say anything more against either of these friends, because I know nothing more.
('28', 123, 4, 16, 283054) Similarly, I know about the Arya Samajists illustrious founder and Shraddhanandji and I have also not hesitated to draw their attention to what I have considered to be their weaknesses.
('28', 123, 4, 17, 283240) The motive is obvious.
('28', 123, 4, 18, 283263) I would be untrue to myself and to the cause if I did not say all that I have felt regarding the principal actors, and regarding the principal religions which came into conflict with one another.
('28', 123, 4, 19, 283459) I am anxious that the Arya Samaj and Shraddhanandji should do much
('28', 123, 5, 20, 283526) 1 Vide Hindu Muslim Tension: Its Cause and Cure, 29 5 1924.
('28', 124, 0, 1, 283586) VOL. 28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15AUGUST, 1924 125
('28', 124, 1, 2, 283628) more good than they have already done and, therefore, I have drawn attention to their limitations a friend and a well wisher and by no means as a critic.
('28', 124, 1, 3, 283782) But in spite of this, there is a good deal of pertur bation in the Arya Samaj circles throughout India over my remarks.
('28', 124, 1, 4, 283902) I can quite understand we have all, at the present moment, become very touchy and, therefore, impatient of criticism as intolerance.
('28', 124, 1, 5, 284035) We have become intolerant of any criticism that might be levelled against us, even though it may be of very friendly character.
('28', 124, 1, 6, 284163) I have, however, no doubt whatsoever that the storm will subside if I keep myself cool and, as there is no danger of my losing my head yet for a while, I am not affected by all the furious criticism that is directed against me.
('28', 124, 2, 7, 284391) One more question about khaddar and I have done (I told Mahatmaji as it was getting late): Is your khaddar programme meant to bring about economic salvation of India, or is it meant to change the mental attitude of the people towards nationalism?
('28', 124, 2, 8, 284638) If it is the former, then how do you expect swarajya without concerted action for creating nationalism among the people, and, if it is the latter, will the present khaddar programme be sufficient to rouse that feeling among the masses?
('28', 124, 2, 9, 284874) The khaddar programme undoubtedly will bring about the economic salvation of India, if it succeeds.
('28', 124, 2, 10, 284974) In my opinion, no concerted action is possible for the masses without their realizing their economic salvation.
('28', 124, 2, 11, 285086) Moreover, the khaddar programme is impossible without concerted action.
('28', 124, 2, 12, 285158) Thirdly, a successful khaddar programme necessarily means the conversion of Englishmen themselves into nationalists, or, at least, impartial spectators of the Indian movement.
('28', 124, 2, 13, 285334) They will no longer succeed in holding India under subjection for the purpose of her exploitation.
('28', 124, 3, 14, 285433) Do you expect, Mahatmaji, that the A.I.C.C. that will meet here shortly would endorse your views as embodied in your two statements and the drastic tests for office bearers?
('28', 124, 3, 15, 285607) It is very difficult for me to say what the members of the A.I.C.C. will do at its forthcoming session.
('28', 124, 3, 16, 285711) But it will not surprise me in the least if all the drastic tests I have suggested are rejected by an overwhelming majority.
('28', 124, 3, 17, 285836) I either want a clear cut majority, which implicitly believes in the programme and is determined to carry it out at any cost, or a microscopic minority.
('28', 124, 3, 18, 285989) What is intolerable to me is the extreme indefiniteness that overwhelms us at the present moment and makes all real progress utterly impossible.
('28', 124, 4, 19, 286134) But in case the opinions of the peoples representatives are nicely balanced, for and against your programme, what do you intend doing?
('28', 124, 4, 20, 286269) In the first instance, I do not consider it possible that there
('28', 125, 0, 1, 286333) 126 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 125, 1, 2, 286375) would be a balance of voting on either side.
('28', 125, 1, 3, 286420) As a matter of fact, we shall come to a clear understanding without the necessity of voting.
('28', 125, 1, 4, 286513) But if it does come to voting, and the parties are nicely balanced, I dare say God will give us something or other which will enable us to divide the parties sharply.

('28', 126, 2, 3, 287766) June 10, 1924
('28', 126, 3, 4, 287780) SHR I KRI PALAN I 2, STU DENT FRI ENDS, SIST ERS AND BRO THERS , This morning, I saw three letters addressed to me.
('28', 126, 3, 5, 287896) 3 One of them advised me to burn the Vidyapith, if possible.
('28', 126, 3, 6, 287957) The Vidyapith, the letter said, had done no good in all these years.
('28', 126, 3, 7, 288026) The correspondent himself had been once its student.
('28', 126, 3, 8, 288079) The second letter tells me that the students are pleasure loving and indulge their palate in all manner of ways.
('28', 126, 3, 9, 288192) The correspondent had sent his sons to the Vidyapith in the belief that the students there led simple lives and developed strength of character.
('28', 126, 3, 10, 288337) What should he do, he asks.
('28', 126, 3, 11, 288365) The third letter, from a friend in Madras, suggests that in my speech today I ought to give a lead to the whole nation.
('28', 126, 3, 12, 288485) Well, what should I do?
('28', 126, 3, 13, 288509) Which of the three suggestions should I follow?
('28', 126, 3, 14, 288557) I wish to act upon none of them.
('28', 126, 3, 15, 288590) Why should I burn the Vidyapith, in the establishment of which I have had some share, however small?
('28', 126, 3, 16, 288691) There is a story told by an English painter.
('28', 126, 3, 17, 288736) Once, by way of joke, he hung up one of his paintings in the market place and wrote below it that anyone who saw any fault in it should mark it with a dot.
('28', 126, 3, 18, 288892) The next day there was not an inch on the surface of the painting which was without a mark.
('28', 126, 3, 19, 288984) But the artist said that he would not burn the painting so long as he was himself satisfied with it.
('28', 126, 3, 20, 289085) I remembered the painter this morning and felt that he was right.
('28', 126, 3, 21, 289151) There would be no end to criticisms if we paid attention to all of them.
('28', 126, 3, 22, 289224) God has made man a creature of attachment.
('28', 126, 3, 23, 289267) We carry on our work driven by our attachments.
('28', 126, 3, 24, 289315) On your part, however, you should draw your lesson from all three of these suggestions.
('28', 126, 3, 25, 289403) The corres pondent who has been bitter in his remarks says that neither the students nor the teachers have anything in them.
('28', 126, 3, 26, 289528) He desires that I should publish his letter in Navajivan and also comment on it.

('28', 128, 1, 2, 292806) The other story which I remembered was one written by Sir Narayan Chandavarkar 1, and which I read while in jail.
('28', 128, 1, 3, 292920) He had once gone out for a walk in Poona.

('28', 133, 1, 2, 304759) 70. MY JAIL EXPERIENCES VIII
('28', 133, 2, 3, 304788) JAIL ECONOMICS
('28', 133, 3, 4, 304803) Everyone who has any experience of jails knowbs that they are the most starved of all departments.
('28', 133, 3, 5, 304902) The hospitals are comparatively the most expensive of public institutions.
('28', 133, 3, 6, 304977) In the jails everything is of the simplest and the crudest type.
('28', 133, 3, 7, 305042) In them there is extravagance in the spending of human labour, there is miserliness in the spending of money and materials.
('28', 133, 3, 8, 305166) In hospitals it is just the reverse.
('28', 133, 3, 9, 305203) And yet both are institutions designed to deal with human diseasesjails for mental and hospitals for physical.
('28', 133, 3, 10, 305314) Mental diseases are regarded as a crime and therefore punishable; physical diseases are regarded as unfore seen visitations of nature to be indulgently treated.
('28', 133, 3, 11, 305475) As a matter of fact, there is no reason for any such distinction.
('28', 133, 3, 12, 305541) Mental as well as physical diseases are traceable to the same causes.
('28', 133, 3, 13, 305611) If I steal, I commit a breach of laws governing healthy society.
('28', 133, 3, 14, 305676) If I suffer from stomach ache, I still commit a breach of laws governing a healthy society.
('28', 133, 3, 15, 305768) One reason why physical diseases are treated lightly is because the so called higher classes break the laws of physical healthperhaps more frequently than the lower classes.
('28', 133, 3, 16, 305942) The higher classes have no occasion for committing crude thefts and, as their lives would be disturbed if thefts continued, they being generally law givers, polish gross stealing, knowing all the while that their swindles which pass muster are far more harmful to society than the crude thefts.
('28', 133, 3, 17, 306237) It is curious, too, that both institutions flourish because of wrong treatment.
('28', 133, 3, 18, 306317) Hospitals flourish because patients are indulged and humoured, jails flourish because the prisoners are punished as if they were beyond recall.
('28', 133, 3, 19, 306461) If every disease, mental or physical, were regarded as a lapse, but every patient or prisoner were to be treated kindly and sympathetically, not severely or indulgently, both jails and hospitals would show a tendency to decrease.
('28', 133, 3, 20, 306691) A hospital no more than a jail is a necessity for a healthy society.
('28', 133, 3, 21, 306760) Every patient and every prisoner should come out of his hospital or jail as a missionary to preach the gospel of mental and physical health.
('28', 133, 3, 22, 306901) But I must stop the comparison at this stage.
('28', 133, 3, 23, 306947) The reader will be surprised to learn that the parsimony in prisons is exercised on the ground of economy.
('28', 133, 3, 24, 307054) Although all labour is taken from prisoners, e.g., drawing water, grinding flour, cleaning roads and closets, cooking
('28', 134, 0, 1, 307172) VOL. 28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15AUGUST, 1924 135
('28', 134, 1, 2, 307214) food, the prisoners are not only not self supporting, but they do not even pay for their own food.
('28', 134, 1, 3, 307313) And in spite of all their labour, the prisoners do not get the food they would like nor the manner of cooking they would appreciate; this for the simple reason that the prisoners who do the cooking, etc., are not as a rule interested in their work.
('28', 134, 1, 4, 307562) It is for them a task to be performed under unsympathetic supervision.
('28', 134, 1, 5, 307633) It is easy enough to see that, if the prisoners were philan thropists and, therefore, felt interested in the welfare of their fellow prisoners, they would not find themselves in prisons.
('28', 134, 1, 6, 307820) If, therefore, a more rational and more moral system of administration was adopted, the prisons would easily become self supporting reformatories instead of, as they are now, expensive penal settlements.
('28', 134, 1, 7, 308024) I would save the terrible waste of labour in drawing water, grinding flour, etc.
('28', 134, 1, 8, 308105) If I was in charge, I would buy flour from outside, I would draw water by machinery and, instead of having all kinds of odd jobs, I would devote the prisons to agriculture, hand spinning and hand weaving.

('28', 134, 1, 13, 308652) The labour of all the prisoners will be utilized for remunerative and yet not for competitive purposes, as is now the case in some respects.
('28', 134, 1, 14, 308793) There is a printing press attached to the Yeravda Jail.
('28', 134, 1, 15, 308849) Now this press is largely worked by convict labour.
('28', 134, 1, 16, 308901) I regard this as unfair competition with the general printing presses.
('28', 134, 1, 17, 308972) If the prisons were to run competitive indus tries, they would easily be made even profitable.
('28', 134, 1, 18, 309067) But my purpose is to show that they can be made self supporting without entering into such competition and, at the same time, teach the inmates a home industry which on their discharge would give them an independent calling, thus providing for them every incentive to live as respectable citizens.
('28', 134, 1, 19, 309365) I would moreover provide for the prisoners as homely an atmosphere as is consistent with public safety.
('28', 134, 1, 20, 309469) I would thus give them all facility for seeing their relatives, getting books and even tuition.

('28', 135, 1, 2, 309886) the protection of society and for his own reform.

('28', 135, 2, 12, 311013) 71. UNTOUCHABILITY AND SWARAJ
('28', 135, 3, 13, 311043) A correspondent gravely writes:
('28', 135, 4, 14, 311075) The very term untouchability seems to my mind to be an anomaly, because there generally does not exist any particular class of people called touchables.
('28', 135, 4, 15, 311228) It is very rarely that one actually and physically touches another, unless necessity demands it.
('28', 135, 4, 16, 311325) What is usually obtaining in case of those other than the so called untouchables is that one does not mind the approach of another, one does not mind another passing by his side.
('28', 135, 4, 17, 311504) That is all and the one does not literally and voluntarily touch another.
('28', 135, 4, 18, 311578) In the same way, if one minds his own business, allowing the untouchable to mind his own, is not the vexed problem solved?
('28', 135, 5, 19, 311701) I am sure you do not want me to go and actually touch the untouchable in order to remove the sin and, if you concede that actual touching is not necessary, what is the purpose in characterizing the evil as untouchability?
('28', 135, 5, 20, 311923) Your use of the term untouchability does imply that its removal consists in physical touching and I am afraid that orthodox objection to the movement is partly due to this.
('28', 135, 5, 21, 312096) I do not think that I often touch my own brother and as such it is neither necessary nor expedient that I should touch another man, even if I want to solve the problem; and hence, I think,
('28', 136, 0, 1, 312285) VOL. 28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15AUGUST, 1924 137
('28', 136, 1, 2, 312327) unapproachability better connotes the state of things relating tothat community.
('28', 136, 1, 3, 312408) No amount of external embracing will case the situation, unless the spirit of toleration exists within.
('28', 136, 2, 4, 312512) Next, I am unable to understand the relation between the existence of this evil and the establishment of swaraj.
('28', 136, 2, 5, 312625) After all, 'unapproachability' is only one of the many evils of the Hindu societyperhaps a greater eviland as long as society exists similar evils do exist, as no society is free from evils.
('28', 136, 2, 6, 312816) How is this an impediment to the obtaining of swaraj and why do you make its removal a condition precedent to our fitness for swaraj?
('28', 136, 2, 7, 312950) Is it not possible for this to be set right when swaraj is obtained, if not voluntarily, at least by legislation?
('28', 136, 3, 8, 313064) I can very well understand the imperative necessity for permanent
('28', 136, 4, 9, 313130) Hindu Muslim unity, as dissensions between these two large communities may
('28', 136, 5, 10, 313205) be taken advantage of by the Government, who may therefore indefinitely put
('28', 136, 6, 11, 313281) off granting our demands.

('28', 139, 3, 12, 320653) RABBI MAY
('28', 139, 4, 13, 320663) A most intimate Jewish friend often used the expression Rabbi may, to signify that the highest in the land may commit most atroci ous crimes, not only with impunity, but may even carry with them popular congratulations for those crimes.

('28', 140, 2, 6, 322505) THE WRONG WAY
('28', 140, 3, 7, 322519) But let us not lose patience because we fancy we are helpless.
('28', 140, 3, 8, 322582) The Serajganj Conference has given us the wrong lead.
('28', 140, 3, 9, 322636) I have not got before me the text of its resolution regarding Gopinath Saha.

('28', 140, 3, 11, 322808) Here is the text.
('28', 140, 3, 12, 322826) I copy from the Forward (4th June).
('28', 140, 4, 13, 322862) While adhering to the policy of non violence, this conference pays its respectful homage to patriotism of Gopinath Saha who suffered capital punishment in connection with Mr. Days murder.
('28', 140, 4, 14, 323050) I cannot but regard the resolution as a travesty of non violence.
('28', 140, 4, 15, 323116) It would have been less undignified if non violence had not been dragged in at all.
('28', 140, 4, 16, 323200) The patriotism of Gopinath Saha could only consist in the murder and not in the capital punishment which was the consequence of the murder.
('28', 140, 4, 17, 323340) He was not out to die, but to murder one who was odious to him.
('28', 140, 4, 18, 323404) The knowledge that he ran the risk of being hanged made him brave, but not necessarily patriotic.
('28', 140, 4, 19, 323502) For every murderer knows that he runs such risk and may, therefore, be called brave.
('28', 140, 4, 20, 323587) The patriotism, if any, therefore, consisted in the act of murder.
('28', 140, 4, 21, 323654) Now murder is inconsistent with non violence even when regarded purely as a policy.
('28', 140, 4, 22, 323738) Non violent suffering in ones person and violent injury to another cannot both be patriotic at the same time.
('28', 140, 4, 23, 323848) The patriotism of every lover of his country demands that, whilst the country pursues a policy of non violence, he does not disturb it by committing murder.
('28', 140, 4, 24, 324005) And if anybody does, those who are pledged to the policy of non violence are in duty bound not only to dissociate themselves from such acts, but to condemn them in unmeasured terms, if only because they must, by thus cultivating public opinion against them, discourage such murder.
('28', 140, 4, 25, 324287) And this condemnation is necessary even though the motive is the purest imaginable.
('28', 140, 4, 26, 324371) In practical politics, actions count and not mere motives or mental attitudes bereft of acts or results.
('28', 140, 4, 27, 324476) Had the belief in the policy of non violence not been reiterated, much of my argument would no doubt lose its force.
('28', 140, 4, 28, 324593) But I do submit that, so long as the Congress creed stands as it is, every
('28', 141, 0, 1, 324668) 142 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('28', 144, 5, 23, 333953) Lala Lajpat Rai stands in the [same] category with Pandit Malaviyaji.
('28', 144, 5, 24, 334023) Jeramdas and Choithram you are doing only injustice to yourself.
('28', 144, 5, 25, 334088) Their conduct towards the Mussalmans is as clear as daylight to every reader of newspapers.
('28', 144, 5, 26, 334180) Let me assure you that you will not advance the Hindu Muslim problem by all inch by praising these Hindu leaders and condemning the Muslim leaders.
('28', 144, 5, 27, 334328) The Hindu friends tell me that unity is impossible so long as I trust the Ali Brothers and Maulana Bari Saheb.
('28', 144, 5, 28, 334439) All these friends should know that, if neither the present Hindu nor the present Mussal man leaders are to be trusted, unity can be achieved, if at all, only after their death.
('28', 144, 5, 29, 334616) The friend proceeds:

('28', 144, 6, 31, 334694) No harm, not a bit, is done by them to the national movement.

('28', 145, 0, 1, 335063) 146 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 145, 1, 2, 335105) unconsciously attacked a Muslim State.
('28', 145, 1, 3, 335144) This writers is an attitude typical of a growing class of workers, namely, that we should not speak as we think, but hush up everything.
('28', 145, 1, 4, 335281) I can understand the necessity of not washing every rag of dirty linen in the open, but we cannot afford to slur over things that stare us in the face and of which everybody thinks.
('28', 145, 1, 5, 335463) In the heat of his passion, the writer has forgotten to note that I have delivered no attack upon a Muslim State.
('28', 145, 1, 6, 335577) I have said I am told that the questionable tabligh referred to in my statement is extensively practised in the Nizams dominions.
('28', 145, 1, 7, 335707) The writer says further:
('28', 145, 2, 8, 335732) I cannot understand how cow slaughter and music stand on the same platform.
('28', 145, 2, 9, 335808) Mussalmans are enjoined by the Quran to sacrifice cows whereas Hindus are not enjoined to play music before a mosque.
('28', 145, 2, 10, 335926) Hindus have to stop their music before Government hospitals and offices, but their obduracy does not allow them to do the same before a mosque.
('28', 145, 2, 11, 336070) The writer should know that Mussalmans are not enjoined by the Quran to sacrifice a cow.
('28', 145, 2, 12, 336159) They are said to be enjoined to sacrifice certain animals including the cow on stated occasions.
('28', 145, 2, 13, 336256) The sacrifice of a cow is not therefore obligatory.
('28', 145, 2, 14, 336308) But seeing that it is permissible, it becomes obligatory when a third party claims to force a Mussalman to refrain from cow slaughter.
('28', 145, 2, 15, 336443) Similarly, while there is no obligation upon a Hindu to play music before a mosque it does become an obligation immediately Mussalmans claim to stop Hindu music before mosques by force of arms.
('28', 145, 2, 16, 336637) Both these things must, therefore, be left to voluntary adjustment.
('28', 145, 3, 17, 336705) THE BHOPAL APOSTACY CIRCULAR Friends sent me a copy of the apostacy law of the Bhopal State now over a month ago.
('28', 145, 3, 18, 336819) I purposely refrained from dealing with it, because I was not then ready to publish my views on Hindu Muslim tension and because I wanted to make further inquiries into the matter.
('28', 145, 3, 19, 337000) Meanwhile, I have seen Dr. Ansaris note upon it.

('28', 145, 4, 21, 337088) Copy of Jaridah, dated, 7th July 1920, Resolution No.
('28', 145, 4, 22, 337142) 17, dated 5th July 1920. Her Highness the Ruler of Bhopal has been pleased to order that, in pursuance of section 300 of the Shahjehani Penal Code, Rule No.
('28', 145, 4, 23, 337299) 1, 1912, that is in the Compiled Penal Code of Bhopal, section 393, after section 393 A, the following be added, which after the date of publication will be in force and enforced:
('28', 146, 0, 1, 337479) VOL. 28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15AUGUST, 1924 147
('28', 146, 1, 2, 337521) APOSTACY AFTER EMBRACING ISLAM
('28', 146, 2, 3, 337552) Section 393A.
('28', 146, 2, 4, 337566) Any person renouncing his faith after once embracing Islam shall be liable to be sentenced to punishment of either description extending to three years imprisonment or to fine, or both.
('28', 146, 3, 5, 337752) This order is published for general information and observance.
('28', 146, 3, 6, 337816) I do not know whether the dates are accurately given.
('28', 146, 3, 7, 337870) But assuming the correctness, the law is of a fairly recent date.
('28', 146, 3, 8, 337936) But whether it is recent or ancient does not much matter.
('28', 146, 3, 9, 337994) The question is whether it is good law or whether it is bad law according to pure Islam.
('28', 146, 3, 10, 338083) The ideal before us is that the two, and for that matter, all religions should live in peace and that there may be free interchange among them if the people so desire; in other words, there should be no compulsion in religion.
('28', 146, 3, 11, 338310) Some of us Hindus and Mussalmans are endeavouring to bring up the practice to the level of that ideal.
('28', 146, 3, 12, 338413) If, therefore, Islam does not make it penal for one who has embraced it to go back to ones own faith, the law in question must be considered to be against the spirit of Islam and, therefore, it should be abrogated at the earliest moment.
('28', 146, 3, 13, 338651) I hope that, if the position is as I have stated, the Mussalman leaders will request Her Highness the Begum Saheba of Bhopal to repeal the law.
('28', 146, 4, 14, 338795) LIBERALS AND KHADDAR
('28', 146, 5, 15, 338816) A friend belonging to the Liberal Party writes:
('28', 146, 6, 16, 338864) I have been thinking and discussing the question of khaddar with my colleagues.
('28', 146, 6, 17, 338944) I find that there is no difference Of opinion as regards the merit of khaddar, but the hitch arises the moment they associate the movement for the spread of khaddar with your declaration that it is a preparation for civil disobe dience.
('28', 146, 6, 18, 339181) If it stood apart and did not form an item of the Non co operation movement, I think that the support to this propaganda will become wider and more universal.
('28', 146, 6, 19, 339340) The prejudice referred to by the writer is as old as non co operation.
('28', 146, 6, 20, 339411) I have tried to show times without number that no one save civil resisters need think of civil disobedience in connection with khaddar.
('28', 146, 6, 21, 339547) Civil disobedience has no direct connection with khaddar.
('28', 146, 6, 22, 339605) I have led many a battle of civil disobedience before khaddar was reborn.
('28', 146, 6, 23, 339679) The civil resisters (say) in the Kaira campaign knew nothing of khaddar.
('28', 146, 6, 24, 339752) Even Vallabhbhais band at Borsad were not pledged to khaddar.
('28', 146, 6, 25, 339814) Apart from the Congress volunteers, nobody in Borsad was obliged to wear it before he could be enlisted as a civil resister.
('28', 146, 6, 26, 339939) The reason was obvious.
('28', 146, 6, 27, 339963) It was not a campaign to establish swaraj.
('28', 147, 0, 1, 340006) 148 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 147, 1, 2, 340048) suggested khaddar as indispensable for civil disobedience or swaraj for two reasons.
('28', 147, 1, 3, 340133) The first is that swaraj I hold to be an impossibility without khaddar becoming universal in our country.
('28', 147, 1, 4, 340239) Secondly, it is the most efficient aid to mass discipline without which mass civil disobedience is impossible.
('28', 147, 1, 5, 340350) Liberals and others should realize that the best way to avert civil disobedience is for everybody to take up the constructive programme of the Congress; especially three items.
('28', 147, 1, 6, 340527) If all of us worked with one mind to achieve Hindu Muslim unity and universalize hand spun khaddar and if all Hindus united to remove the curse of untouchability, swaraj will be within sight.
('28', 147, 1, 7, 340719) There are some Englishmen who use khaddar but they will naturally repudiate even a suggestion of sympathy with civil disobedience or non co operation.
('28', 147, 2, 8, 340870) NARAYANAVARAM AND UNTOUCHABILITY
('28', 147, 3, 9, 340903) The following touching account shows the need for a vigorous campaign against the curse of untouchability:
('28', 147, 4, 10, 341010) With the exception of three streets, Panchamas (the depressed classes) were allowed to pass by the pubic streets.
('28', 147, 4, 11, 341124) The three streets are the north and the south Mada streets and the eastern street in front of the Kalyana Venkateswara temple.
('28', 147, 4, 12, 341251) Most of the inhabitants in these streets are Brahmins.
('28', 147, 4, 13, 341306) The temple lands were cultivated mostly by the Panchamas.
('28', 147, 4, 14, 341364) As the temple authorities could not remove the paddy brought by the Panchamas and left at a distant place, they allowed the Panchamas to carry the paddy through the above streets and place in front of the main gate of the temple.
('28', 147, 4, 15, 341594) Then came the informal Panchayat into the village.
('28', 147, 4, 16, 341645) The Brahmin Chairman cannot but engage Panchama sweepers.
('28', 147, 4, 17, 341703) He even allowed them to remain in the village to cook their food and sleep during nights.
('28', 147, 4, 18, 341793) One Brahmin gentleman engaged Panchama servants to protect him against his enemies, day and night.
('28', 147, 4, 19, 341892) They were allowed to take their meals and sleep in the Brahmin street during nights.
('28', 147, 4, 20, 341977) This innovation is highly objectionable from an orthodox point of view.
('28', 147, 4, 21, 342049) Still no one objected.
('28', 147, 5, 22, 342072) Then Mr. C. V. Rangam Chetty opened a Weaving School for Panchamas on 9 4 1924 on the main street near Taluq Board school in Sjt.
('28', 147, 5, 23, 342202) M. Rangaswamy Iyengars house who very kindly and boldly gave permission.
('28', 147, 5, 24, 342275) Mr. C. Doraiswamy Iyengar, M.L.A., did the opening ceremony.
('28', 147, 5, 25, 342336) Two Brahmins who are the personal enemies of Mr. Rangam Chetty started the opposition, engaged touts and organized the meeting of the villagers.
('28', 147, 5, 26, 342481) In one of their public meetings, they demanded Mr. Rangam Chetty to remove the Panchama Weaving School from the village as it is against Shastras for Panchamas to live in the village.
('28', 147, 5, 27, 342665) When questioned why the Panchamas were allowed on three previous occasions, they replied they did not see Shastras then.
('28', 147, 5, 28, 342786) As Mr. Rangam Chetty refused to remove the School, most of the

('28', 148, 1, 4, 343021) None complied with their requests.
('28', 148, 1, 5, 343056) The Brahmins then refused to take the god round the streets.

('28', 149, 1, 2, 345507) HANDLOOM AND HEIRLOOM
('28', 149, 2, 3, 345529) In sending me some beautiful hand spun yarn from Assam Mr. Andrews writes:
('28', 149, 3, 4, 345604) This is given to you by the little children of an ashram that I have just been visiting; it is being conducted by Mr. Phookan and his workers, near his own beautiful house.
('28', 149, 3, 5, 345777) His sister is in charge, and little children are the handi workers.
('28', 149, 3, 6, 345845) I wish you could have seen with your own eyes how happy they all were!
('28', 149, 4, 7, 345916) There is one striking factor here in Assam, which you most probably know.
('28', 149, 4, 8, 345990) Every girl who is married is expected to be able to weave with her own hands.
('28', 149, 4, 9, 346068) That is why you called this land beautiful Assam.
('28', 149, 4, 10, 346118) In every house there is a household loom.
('28', 149, 4, 11, 346160) These looms are frequently heirlooms, using the old English word in its literal sense, which reminds one of the days when in England also spinning and weaving were fine arts.
('28', 149, 4, 12, 346335) Now they have been banished to the Hebrides, where still the cottage looms produce the strongest and most durable cloth known in the West, called the Lewis Tweeds.
('28', 149, 4, 13, 346499) The spinning wheel there is worked by the foot, as both hands are needed for the wool; and the spinner sits on a three legged stool.
('28', 149, 4, 14, 346632) On my last visit to England, I found one of these old spinning wheels in a house at Sally Oak, in my own city of Birmingham, still being used by the spinster,only in this case the: spinster was not unmarried, as the old English word usually implied, but a housewife.
('28', 149, 4, 15, 346899) I believe the days are coming when these forgotten arts will again be renewed in the West, wherever objects of beauty and durability are demanded, just as the hand press can still produce the most beautiful printing that no machine can rival.
('28', 149, 6, 16, 347142) Of opium in Assam Mr. Andrews writes:
('28', 149, 7, 17, 347180) The curse of opium is very deep on this fair land, and l trust that a full Congress enquiry will now be made into its ravages, so that the facts about the Government of Indias opium revenue policy may be placed before the Geneva Convention.
('28', 149, 7, 18, 347421) Here, when I spoke last night at the meeting, and told the audience that the Government of India declared that the Indian opium consumption was legitimate, there rose a laugh of derision from the audience which I wish the Opium Convention at Geneva could have heard.
('28', 149, 7, 19, 347688) It alone would have convinced them concerning Indian public opinion on this subject.
('28', 149, 7, 20, 347773) I am quite certain now that we shall have some thorough work done here in Assam towards opium prohibition.
('28', 149, 8, 21, 347880) Young India, 12 6 1924

('28', 150, 1, 2, 347945) 74. CHHOP OR SPINNING COMPETITION
('28', 150, 2, 3, 347979) A Punjabi friend writes thus about spinning competitions that once were universal in the Punjab and which, let us hope, will not be allowed to die out.
('28', 150, 2, 4, 348131) The gentleman sends with it a drawing, made by himself, of sisters at their wheels taking part in one such competition.
('28', 150, 3, 5, 348251) About twenty or twenty five years ago, it was a very common practice in the Punjab among women, in villages as well as in towns, to hold spinning competitions called chhops.
('28', 150, 3, 6, 348425) Women of all ages participated in the general
('28', 150, 4, 7, 348471) competition.
('28', 150, 4, 8, 348484) Even small girls with their little charkhas joined as auxiliary forces.
('28', 150, 4, 9, 348556) The competitors would get up so early as 2 oclock in the morning and, taking an equal weight of carded cotton done into punish, they all sat to work
('28', 150, 5, 10, 348705) in right earnest, the competition generally coming to an end at seven or eight to enable them to attend to duties personal and domestic.
('28', 150, 5, 11, 348842) While working the machines with their hands, they sung happy and sacred songs such as the exile of Rama, virag 1 of Gopi Chand, virtuous life of Puran Bhagat, the melodious
('28', 150, 6, 12, 349015) hum of the charkha supplying the music.
('28', 150, 6, 13, 349055) The healthy and pure atmosphere surrounding the chhops can be better imagined than described.
('28', 150, 6, 14, 349149) Alas, such
('28', 150, 7, 15, 349160) happy scenes have become now very rare and it is very seldom that one witnesses them.

('28', 152, 1, 2, 351170) 78. LETTER TO ANASUYABEHN SARABHAI Thursday, [June12, 1924] 1
('28', 152, 2, 3, 351232) RESPECTED ANASUYABEHN, Received both your letters.
('28', 152, 2, 4, 351283) I tore up your second letter soon after reading it.
('28', 152, 2, 5, 351335) Do not hesitate to write anything you want to.
('28', 152, 2, 6, 351382) No one reads personal letters written by you.
('28', 152, 2, 7, 351428) They are passed on to me intact as they come.
('28', 152, 2, 8, 351474) If I put them in a file either by mistake or intentionally, they may be read by others as access to files is not restricted.
('28', 152, 2, 9, 351599) But I shall tear up the letters marked personal after reading them and as for my letters to you, I shall write them myself.
('28', 152, 2, 10, 351723) I do not like it at all that Bhai Shankerlal has some new ailment now.
('28', 152, 2, 11, 351794) He appears to be brooding over something.
('28', 152, 2, 12, 351836) I cant even ask him to come and stay with me because my entire life is led in the open.
('28', 152, 2, 13, 351924) There is no such thing as privacy for me.
('28', 152, 2, 14, 351966) What else can I do when persons who are more ill than I am, expect my help?
('28', 152, 2, 15, 352042) Even as I try to help them, I become unhappy.
('28', 152, 2, 16, 352088) So in spite of having an intense desire to help delicate flowers that you and Shankerlal are, I have become unfit for the task.
('28', 152, 2, 17, 352216) What can I do?

('28', 157, 2, 3, 361862) A correspondent writes: 1
('28', 157, 3, 4, 361888) I am sorry if my articles have given such an impression.
('28', 157, 3, 5, 361945) Satyagraha can be circumscribed only by truth and non violence.
('28', 157, 3, 6, 362009) Wherever the two are to be found, satyagraha can always be launched.
('28', 157, 3, 7, 362078) Considered thus, I believe no contradiction will be found in my writings.
('28', 157, 3, 8, 362152) There can be no satyagraha in the princely States in order to win swaraj for India.
('28', 157, 3, 9, 362236) It can be in respect of local problems.
('28', 157, 3, 10, 362276) But if there exists even the slightest element of untruth, satyagraha cannot be offered there or in any other place.
('28', 157, 3, 11, 362393) Even though a cause may be truthful, a person who cannot observe non violence, who is irascible, who hesitates to tell the truth and who is not ready to suffer, is not qualified to launch satyagraha.
('28', 157, 3, 12, 362593) By and large I see that the present atmosphere in the entire country is unfavourable to satyagraha.
('28', 157, 3, 13, 362693) Jealousy, untruth, violence, etc., have grown rife.
('28', 157, 3, 14, 362745) Satyagraha has been misconstrued as harassment of opponents.
('28', 157, 3, 15, 362806) One sees duragraha masquerading as satyagraha.
('28', 157, 3, 16, 362853) In this situation, even when a matter calls for satyagraha, a satyagrahi should act with caution.
('28', 157, 3, 17, 362951) But in spite of being cautious, if he finds that things have reached a state when satyagraha becomes inevitable, nothing and no one can hold back a satyagrahi.

('28', 158, 3, 12, 364252) For example, the Ahmedabad session of the Congress 2 laid down that non violence should be observed in thought, word and deed.
('28', 158, 3, 13, 364379) That certainly was not a new condition.
('28', 158, 3, 14, 364419) When it was found that people harboured violence in their hearts and merely refrained from overt acts of violence, then it became necessary to make it clear that a person could be regarded as non violent only if he was so in thought, speech and action.
('28', 158, 3, 15, 364672) In other words, if people were told that non violence for show was not non violence, this cannot be regarded as something new.

('28', 162, 1, 2, 373106) times, against such molestation.

('28', 162, 1, 4, 373157) That is, to lay down ones life, without killing others in defending ourselves.
('28', 162, 1, 5, 373236) Even a woman child can do this.
('28', 162, 1, 6, 373268) Why do all Hindus not take such training?
('28', 162, 1, 7, 373310) In acquiring the power to kill one has to cultivate physical strength, while in acquiring the strength to lay down ones life, one has to cultivate spiritual strength.
('28', 162, 1, 8, 373477) If only one sees the way, it is comparatively easy to cultivate this.
('28', 162, 1, 9, 373547) Is it possible for anyone physi cally maimed to acquire physical strength?
('28', 162, 1, 10, 373622) Nobodys soul is ever maimed.
('28', 162, 1, 11, 373651) I can, by calm reflection, acquire the strength to lay down my life if someone attacks my dear ones.
('28', 162, 1, 12, 373752) But I certainly must cultivate a peace loving temper in order to prepare myself to do this.
('28', 162, 1, 13, 373844) I must control my anger and convert it into strength.
('28', 162, 1, 14, 373898) If I wish to develop such strength, I should not get agitated by newspaper reports.
('28', 162, 1, 15, 373982) I must go wherever I desire to give protection to people, and be ready to die.
('28', 162, 1, 16, 374061) As there can be an army of soldiers, there can be an organi zation of satyagrahis too.
('28', 162, 1, 17, 374148) One Ravishankar suffices for dealing with thousands of Dharalas.
('28', 162, 1, 18, 374213) He is still living.
('28', 162, 1, 19, 374233) If hundreds of men be come Ravishankars, they save the weak Hindus from attacks and, in the process, also make the weak strong.
('28', 162, 1, 20, 374361) So much against physical attacks.
('28', 162, 1, 21, 374395) For saving cows, Hindus should never use force against Muslims.
('28', 162, 1, 22, 374459) They should try to save them only by winning over their heart.

('28', 163, 1, 2, 375245) 86. VALLABHBHAIS DIFFICULTY
('28', 163, 2, 3, 375273) Vallabhbhai is up against a serious difficulty ever since I took charge of Navajivan.
('28', 163, 2, 4, 375359) In order to serve Gujarat, he wishes to collect from it Rs. 10 lakhs in my name.
('28', 163, 2, 5, 375440) He used to take the help of Navajivan in this selfless work.
('28', 163, 2, 6, 375501) Now that I have become its editor, how can I be so brazen as to print in my own paper anything about raising funds for myself?
('28', 163, 2, 7, 375628) Because of this scruple of mine, Vallabhbhais appeals have ceased appearing in Navajivan.
('28', 163, 2, 8, 375718) The problem, now, is this: If Vallabhbhai does not get his Rs. 10 lakhs, he will drive me out and snatch the editorship.
('28', 163, 2, 9, 375839) If, on the other hand, I publish his appeals out of such fear, I shall prove not only shameless but also cowardly.
('28', 163, 2, 10, 375954) I cannot afford to give up the editorship, nor to be brazenly shameless.
('28', 163, 2, 11, 376027) And so I have thought of a middle way.
('28', 163, 2, 12, 376066) This is that I should clear Vallabhbhais confusion.
('28', 163, 2, 13, 376118) The simple thing is that, if Gujarat wants constructive work, Vallabhbhai must certainly have the money.
('28', 163, 2, 14, 376223) Some will be ready to pay, if not for the sake of the constructive programme, at least for my name.
('28', 163, 2, 15, 376323) With that expectation, my name was attached to the appeal for funds.
('28', 163, 2, 16, 376392) Vallabhbhai needs money, and he does not mind in whose name he gets it.
('28', 163, 2, 17, 376464) If Gujarat believes that Vallabhbhai has served it well, if it believes that he has embraced poverty for the sake of Gujarat and made others also follow suit, if it moreover believes that funds are not being misused, that accounts are maintained and published, if it believes that, however difficult the task which the Gujarat Vidyapith has undertaken, the work it is doing is valuable and also that, through it, thousands of children are being trained for swaraj, that khadi is being popularized and the cause of the Antyajas is being servedif the Gujaratis believe all this, they will put Rs. 10 lakhs into the Gandhi purse, that is, the Swaraj purse or the purse for the poor.
('28', 163, 2, 18, 377144) According to the saying, A dancer who does not wish to dance finds fault with the floor, anyone can trot out the excuse of trade being bad, etc., etc.
('28', 163, 2, 19, 377295) Despite poor business, we do eat and drink, celebrate weddings, and so on; let us, then, help this essential national work as well.
('28', 163, 2, 20, 377427) If every Gujarati understands that it is his job to steer the Congress ship in Gujarat, he should donate a petal if not a flower to the purse and help Vallabhbhai out of his difficulty.

('28', 166, 2, 13, 383210) 89. A NOTE
('28', 166, 3, 14, 383221) FALSE NOTION You and I have had our pleasure of wearing fine clothes and now wear khadi; if, however, we clothe these delicate children in khadi, the poor things will never know the pleasure of wearing other clothes. This is what many elderly persons, looking at their grandsons, say to the latters father and this is their way of showing their love for the little ones.
('28', 166, 3, 15, 383592) Writing in this strain, a gentleman asks what he should do in this predicament.
('28', 166, 3, 16, 383672) I for one see no great difficulty here at all.
('28', 166, 3, 17, 383719) By surrendering ourselves to such inordinate love of our elders, why should we compromise the future of our children or harm the great fight to banish starvation from India?
('28', 166, 3, 18, 383893) How can we, succumbing to such sentiment, give up what we consider to be our duty?
('28', 166, 3, 19, 383976) Moreover, it is merely a false notion that mill cloth, whether foreign or Indian, is better than other cloth because it is fine!
('28', 166, 3, 20, 384105) Today there are many child ren who will not touch fine cloth and will wear only khadi.
('28', 166, 3, 21, 384192) Children form such habits as we let them form.
('28', 166, 3, 22, 384239) It is difficult to understand what pleasure there is in wearing mill cloth.
('28', 166, 3, 23, 384315) After some years, when everyone will be wearing khadi and nothing else, we shall come to believe that there is pleasure in khadi.
('28', 166, 3, 24, 384445) On the little bodies of innocent children dyed clothes which stick to the body and which are often
('28', 167, 0, 1, 384544) 168 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 167, 1, 2, 384586) dirty never look so well as milk white khadi.
('28', 167, 1, 3, 384632) Moreover, in the climatic conditions of our country, the fewest clothes are best for us.
('28', 167, 1, 4, 384721) For our children, shoes, socks, and too many clothes are a source of disease.
('28', 167, 1, 5, 384799) To make them wear these things is the surest way of making them delicate and is needless expenditure besides.
('28', 167, 1, 6, 384909) How strange it is that we shower the wrong kind of love on our children and, right from the beginning, give them wrong education!

('28', 170, 3, 9, 390266) 96. NOTES
('28', 170, 4, 10, 390276) VAIKOM SATYAGRAHA
('28', 170, 5, 11, 390294) His Holiness Sri Narayan Guru, spiritual leader of the Tiyas 1, is reported to have disapproved of the present methods of satyagraha at Vaikom.
('28', 170, 5, 12, 390438) He suggests that volunteers should advance along barricaded roads and scale the barricades.
('28', 170, 5, 13, 390530) They should enter temples and sit with others to dine.
('28', 170, 5, 14, 390585) Though I have compressed the interview.
('28', 170, 5, 15, 390625) I have reproduced almost the exact words.
('28', 170, 5, 16, 390667) Now the action proposed is not satyagraha.
('28', 170, 5, 17, 390710) For scaling barri cades is open violence.
('28', 170, 5, 18, 390752) If you may scale barricades, why not break open temple doors and even pierce through temple walls?
('28', 170, 5, 19, 390851) How are volunteers to pierce through a row of policemen except by using physical force?
('28', 170, 5, 20, 390939) I. do not for one moment suggest that by the methods proposed the Tiyas, if they are strong and are willing to die in sufficient numbers, cannot gain their point.
('28', 170, 5, 21, 391102) All I submit is that they will have gained it by something the reverse of satyagraha; and then, too, they would not have converted the orthodox to their view, but would have imposed it on them by force.
('28', 170, 5, 22, 391305) A friend who has sent me the press cutting recording the interview suggests that, by reason of the violent advice of the guru, I should ask the local Congress committee to call off satyagraha.
('28', 170, 5, 23, 391498) I feel that would mean want of faith
('28', 170, 6, 24, 391535) 1 Community in Kerala
('28', 171, 0, 1, 391557) 172 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 171, 1, 2, 391599) in ones means and surrender to violence.
('28', 171, 1, 3, 391640) So long as the organizers strictly keep within the limits which they have prescribed for themselves, there is no cause for calling off satyagraha.
('28', 171, 1, 4, 391787) The friend cites Chauri Chaura as an illustration.
('28', 171, 1, 5, 391838) In doing so, he has betrayed confusion of thought or ignorance of facts.
('28', 171, 1, 6, 391911) The Bardoli satyagraha was suspended because Congress and Khilafat men were implicated in the Chauri Chaura outrage.
('28', 171, 1, 7, 392028) If Congressmen connected with the Vaikom movement entertain the suggestions said to be favoured by the Tiya spiritual leader, there would be a case for penance and, therefore, suspension, but not otherwise.
('28', 171, 1, 8, 392235) I would, therefore, urge the organizers at Vaikom to make redoubled efforts and, at the same time, keep stricter watch on the conduct of those who take part in the movement.
('28', 171, 1, 9, 392409) Whether it takes long or short to reach the goal, the way is the way of peaceful conversion of the orthodox by self suffering and self purification and no other.
