('28', 174, 1, 2, 398688) VALUE OF SILENT WORK
('28', 174, 2, 3, 398709) Borodada (Dwijendranath Tagore) sends the following hopeful note:
('28', 174, 3, 4, 398775) The following has come to my mind like a flash of lightning.
('28', 174, 3, 5, 398836) How great a value a simple good work has when done silently before the all seeing eye of God seems to me to be unknown to the generality of men of our present generation.
('28', 174, 3, 6, 399007) Most people, who are worthy in other respects, place an undue value on the high sounding names of things and persons, disregarding altogether their real import.
('28', 174, 3, 7, 399168) Are the rishis of ancient India less of rishis because their names are unknown to the superficial histories of modern times?
('28', 174, 3, 8, 399293) When will the eyes of our understanding be opened to this simple and soul satisfying truth that mere names are words echoed from mouth to mouth signifying nothing?
('28', 174, 3, 9, 399457) How many people pay homage to the name of Shakespeare without ever having opened a single book of Shakespeare?
('28', 174, 3, 10, 399568) How many people bow to the name of Christ with the appearance of sincere reverence, whose daily life throws to the dogs every word of Christ spoken in love to all humanity irrespective of caste and creed?
('28', 174, 3, 11, 399773) I am perfectly sure that each good work, however insignificant in appearance, will bear tenfold fruit in comparison to the grandiloquent and pompous works performed mostly with a view to acquire names in history.
('28', 174, 3, 12, 399986) It is obvious that if we want to gain success in this great movement which Providence has placed in our hands without our asking, we must concentrate all our efforts on the real work we have to do, and totally cut off all connection with those names of things and persons which exert undue influence over our untutored minds and which hover through the midnight air of our ignorance (of avidya) like the witches of Macbeth.
('28', 174, 3, 13, 400410) The name of non co operation may shock the prejudiced ear of a student of the abstract ethics of the schools, while the thug non co operation is the best medicine for the cure of our mad endeavour after the attainment of all the nourishment that bread can give from the stones thrown at us in mockery by the well fed and well clothed house holder at whose door we stand begging, in out present half starved and ragged condition, to be allowed the privilege of co operating with him, on equal teams, with regard to the right distribution of food and clothing amongst us for our mutual benefit.
('28', 174, 3, 14, 401003) I wish every worker will treasure the beautiful thought contained in Borodadas note and believe with him that all true work will abide when names will have been forgotten.

('28', 180, 2, 22, 415921) How would it do if, in answer to an advertisement for a red haired young man of thirty five measuring six feet six inches, a grey haired, old, toothless man of fifty five, broken down in health, offered his services?
('28', 180, 2, 23, 416138) All the four resolutions then constitute my application for emp loyment as general and lay down my qualifications and limitations.
('28', 180, 2, 24, 416269) Here there is no imposition of autocracy, no impossible demand.
('28', 180, 2, 25, 416333) The members, if they are true to the country and themselves, will not spare me if they find me to be in the wrong.
('28', 180, 2, 26, 416448) I hold no man to be indis pensable for the welfare of the country.
('28', 180, 2, 27, 416515) Every one of us is debtor to the land of our birth and there through to humanity.
('28', 180, 2, 28, 416597) Every debtor must be dismissed the moment he has ceased to pay.

('28', 181, 2, 25, 418814) Young India, 19 6 1924
('28', 181, 3, 26, 418837) 99. WHAT MAY HINDUS DO?
('28', 181, 4, 27, 418861) I have received many communications on the Hindu Muslim statement, but there being nothing new or striking in them, I have not
('28', 182, 0, 1, 418988) VOL.28 : 22 MAY 1924 15 AUGUST, 1924 183
('28', 182, 1, 2, 419029) published them.
('28', 182, 1, 3, 419045) But I gladly print Babu Bhagwandass letter 1 and answer his questions.
('28', 182, 1, 4, 419116) Regarding the first two questions, the writer has answered them himself.
('28', 182, 1, 5, 419189) In my opinion, they are only partly true.
('28', 182, 1, 6, 419231) Though the majority of the Mussalmans of India and the Hindus belong to the same stock, the religious environment has made them different.
('28', 182, 1, 7, 419370) I believe and I have noticed too that thought transforms mans features as well as character.
('28', 182, 1, 8, 419463) The Sikhs are the most recent illustration of the fact.
('28', 182, 1, 9, 419519) The Mussalman, being generally in a minority, has as a class developed into a bully.
('28', 182, 1, 10, 419604) Moreover, being heir to fresh traditions, he exhibits the virility of a comparatively new system of life.
('28', 182, 1, 11, 419710) Though, in my opinion, non violence has a predominant place in the Koran, the thirteen hundred years of imperialistic expansion has made the Mussalmans fighters as a body.
('28', 182, 1, 12, 419882) They are therefore aggressive.
('28', 182, 1, 13, 419913) Bully ing is the natural excrescence of an aggressive spirit.
('28', 182, 1, 14, 419975) The Hindu has an ages old civilization.
('28', 182, 1, 15, 420015) He is essentially non violent.
('28', 182, 1, 16, 420046) His civili zation has passed through the experiences that the two recent ones are still passing through.
('28', 182, 1, 17, 420151) If Hinduism was ever imperialistic in the modern sense of the term, it has outlived its imperialism and has, either deliberately or as a matter of course, given it up.
('28', 182, 1, 18, 420319) Predominance of the non violent spirit has restricted the use of arms to a small minority which must always be subordinate to a civil power highly spiritual, learned and selfless.
('28', 182, 1, 19, 420499) The Hindus as a body are, therefore, not equip ped for fighting.
('28', 182, 1, 20, 420564) But not having retained their spiritual training, they have forgotten the use of an effective substitute for arms and, not knowing their use nor having an aptitude for them, they have become docile to the point of timidity or cowardice.
('28', 182, 1, 21, 420801) This vice is, therefore, a natural excrescence of gentleness.
('28', 182, 1, 22, 420863) Holding this view, I do not think that the Hindu exclusiveness, bad as it undoubtedly is, has much to do with the Hindu timidity.
('28', 182, 1, 23, 420993) Hence, also, my disbelief in akhadas as a means of self defence.
('28', 182, 1, 24, 421058) I prize them for physical culture but, for self defence, I would restore the spiritual culture.
('28', 182, 1, 25, 421154) The best and most lasting self defence is self purification.
('28', 182, 1, 26, 421215) I refuse to be lifted off my feet because of the scares that haunt us today.
('28', 182, 1, 27, 421292) If Hindus would but believe in themselves and work in accordance with their traditions, they will have no reason to fear bullying.
('28', 182, 1, 28, 421423) The moment they recom mence the real spiritual training the Mussalman will respond.
('28', 182, 1, 29, 421507) He cannot help it.
('28', 182, 1, 30, 421526) If I can get together a band of young Hindus with faith
('28', 182, 2, 31, 421582) 1 Vide Appendix Letter from Bhagwan Das, 5 6 1924.
('28', 183, 0, 1, 421633) 184 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 183, 1, 2, 421675) in themselves and, therefore, faith in the Mussalmans, the band will become a shield for the weaker ones.
('28', 183, 1, 3, 421781) They (the young Hindus) will teach how to die without killing.
('28', 183, 1, 4, 421844) I know no other way.
('28', 183, 1, 5, 421865) When our ancestors saw affliction surrounding them, they went in for tapasya purification.
('28', 183, 1, 6, 421956) They realized the helplessness of the flesh and in their helplessness they prayed till they compelled the Maker to obey their call.
('28', 183, 1, 7, 422088) Oh yes, says my Hindu friend, but then God sent someone to wield arms. I am not concerned with denying the truth of the retort.
('28', 183, 1, 8, 422216) All I say to the friend is that as a Hindu he may not ignore the cause and secure the result.
('28', 183, 1, 9, 422310) It will be time to fight when we have done enough tapasya.
('28', 183, 1, 10, 422369) Are we purified enough, I ask?
('28', 183, 1, 11, 422400) Have we even done willing penance for the sin of untouchability, let alone the personal purity of individuals?
('28', 183, 1, 12, 422511) Are our religious preceptors all that they should be?
('28', 183, 1, 13, 422565) We are beating the air whilst we simply concentrate our attention upon picking holes in the Mussalman conduct.
('28', 183, 1, 14, 422676) As with the English men, so with the Mussalman.
('28', 183, 1, 15, 422724) If our professions are true, we should find it infinitely less difficult to conquer the Mussalman than the English.
('28', 183, 1, 16, 422840) But Hindus whisper to me that they have hope of the Englishman but none of the Mussalman.
('28', 183, 1, 17, 422930) I say to them, If you have no hope of the Mussalman, your hope of the Englishman is fored oomed to failure. The other questions can be briefly answered.
('28', 183, 1, 18, 423083) The goondas came on the scene because the leaders wanted them.
('28', 183, 1, 19, 423146) The leaders distrusted one another.
('28', 183, 1, 20, 423182) Distrust never comes from well defined causes.
('28', 183, 1, 21, 423229) A variety of causes, more felt than realized, breeds distrust.
('28', 183, 1, 22, 423292) We have not yet visualized the fact that our interests are identical Each party seems vaguely to believe that it can displace the other by some kind of manoeuvring.
('28', 183, 1, 23, 423457) But I freely confess, as suggested by Babu Bhagwandas, that our not knowing the kind of swaraj we want has also a great deal to do with the distrust.
('28', 183, 1, 24, 423607) I used not to think so, but he had almost converted me before I became Sir George Lloyds guest at the Yera vda Central Prison.
('28', 183, 1, 25, 423734) I am now a confirmed convert.
('28', 183, 1, 26, 423764) The points of contact referred to by me is a phrase intended to cover all social, religious and political relations alike as between individuals and masses.
('28', 183, 1, 27, 423921) Thus, for instance, instead of accentuating the differences in religion, I should set about discovering the good points common to both.
('28', 183, 1, 28, 424057) I would bridge the social distance wherever I can do so consistently with my religious belief.
('28', 183, 1, 29, 424152) I would go out of my way to seek common ground on the political field.
('28', 184, 0, 1, 424223) VOL.28 : 22 MAY 1924 15 AUGUST, 1924 185
('28', 184, 1, 2, 424264) As for the referee, I have named Hakim Sahebs name undoubtedly for the universal respect that it carried with it.
('28', 184, 1, 3, 424378) But I would not hesitate to put the pen even in the hands of a Mussalman who may be known for his prejudices and fanaticism.
('28', 184, 1, 4, 424503) For, as a Hindu, I should know that I have nothing to lose even if the referee gave the Mussalmans a majority of seats in every province.
('28', 184, 1, 5, 424641) There is no principle at stake in giving or having seats in elective bodies.
('28', 184, 1, 6, 424718) More over, experience has taught me to know that undivided responsibility immediately puts a man on his mettle and his pride or godfearingness sobers him.
('28', 184, 1, 7, 424873) Lastly, no proclamation or any such thing will avail unless some of us begin to act up to the proclamation even though we may be the fewest possible.

('28', 187, 6, 9, 429233) SPINNING WHEEL MADNESS
('28', 187, 7, 10, 429256) An old man, who is a friend, noting the mistakes of young people, fell to examining himself.
('28', 187, 7, 11, 429349) He writes: 2
('28', 187, 8, 12, 429362) This friend has started spinning only recently.
('28', 187, 8, 13, 429410) It is, therefore, not a small thing that he forgets the world while spinning.
('28', 187, 8, 14, 429488) I am sure that when the yarn comes out uniformly, he will catch a glimpse of God in his heart and he will even see God dancing on the thread.
('28', 187, 8, 15, 429630) Is there a single thing or place without Him?
('28', 187, 8, 16, 429676) Though we can see, we are in fact blind and, therefore, do not see Him.
('28', 187, 8, 17, 429748) When we come to associate with the spinning wheel the sacred idea that it will end the sufferings of the country, will feed the hungry, will protect the honour of women, will end the indolence of the idle, will win swaraj for the Swarajist and help a person in his effort for self control, then surely God will dance on the yarn and the writer of this letter will see Him as he plies the spinning wheel.

('28', 188, 2, 12, 431510) KHADI WEAR FOR WEDDINGS

('28', 188, 3, 20, 432565) How is it that the twenty six lakhs of people of Kathiawar do not purchase annually even ten lakhs worth of khadi?

('28', 189, 4, 6, 433305) 106 THE PURDAH AND THE PLEDGE
('28', 189, 5, 7, 433335) I have not given this caption because these two words have anything in common.
('28', 189, 5, 8, 433414) Writing about the Rajput Conference 1, I wish to write separately on these two topics only and have, therefore, put the words together here.
('28', 189, 5, 9, 433555) A visitor at the Conference informs me that there was unbounded enthusiasm there.
('28', 189, 5, 10, 433637) About fifteen thousand Rajputs must have gathered on the occasion.
('28', 189, 5, 11, 433704) Even the number of women present exceeded anyones expectations.
('28', 189, 5, 12, 433768) There must have been a thousand of them.
('28', 189, 5, 13, 433809) The number was indeed very large.
('28', 189, 5, 14, 433843) But the curtains were so effectively disposed that a stranger could not know that somewhere in the Conference pandal there were women too present.
('28', 189, 5, 15, 433990) Even the arrangements for carrying them from where they were lodged to the Conference site were so skilful that no one could judge that women were passing along.
('28', 189, 6, 16, 434152) The organizers of the Conference certainly deserve congratu lations on making such perfect arrangements.
('28', 189, 6, 17, 434257) But one can only express sorrow for the fact of curtains having been put up.
('28', 189, 6, 18, 434334) The time, one may say, when curtains were necessary is past.
('28', 189, 6, 19, 434395) There seem to have been no curtains during Ramas rule.
('28', 189, 6, 20, 434450) It is of course true that we still do not have Ramarajya 2, but, if we so desire, we may act right from now as if we had it.
('28', 189, 6, 21, 434575) We have yet to show that, even in the absence of curtains, we can conduct ourselves with decorum.
('28', 189, 6, 22, 434673) None can say that the communities which do not observe purdah show any the less decorum.
('28', 189, 6, 23, 434762) When women were regarded as chattels and were often kidnapped, the purdah might well have been necessary.
('28', 189, 6, 24, 434868) If men were kidnapped, they too might have to remain under purdah.
('28', 189, 6, 25, 434935) In places
('28', 189, 7, 26, 434945) 1 The Kathiawar Rajput Conference 2 Rule of Rama, traditionally regarded as the ideal social and political order
('28', 190, 0, 1, 435058) VOL.28 : 22 MAY 1924 15 AUGUST, 1924 191
('28', 190, 1, 2, 435099) where a man, when seen, is made to do forced labour, the men observe purdah even today, that is, they hide themselves.
('28', 190, 1, 3, 435218) The purdah, however, is not the means of saving women from mens evil eye; the only means is mens own purity of character.
('28', 190, 2, 4, 435340) A woman can take a big hand in teaching men such purity.
('28', 190, 2, 5, 435397) But how can a woman who remains in purdah, suppressed, teach a man purity?
('28', 190, 2, 6, 435472) If she is taught to live in fear of men right from the beginning, how can she reform them?
('28', 190, 2, 7, 435563) Moreover, the very fact of keeping a woman behind purdah has the effect of creating moral weakness in her.
('28', 190, 2, 8, 435670) I believe that purdah helps not the maintenance but the destruc tion of morality.
('28', 190, 2, 9, 435752) What is necessary for promoting it is education in morality, a moral environment and moral conduct among the elders.
('28', 190, 2, 10, 435869) I do not write at this length about purdah with a view to finding fault with the Conference.
('28', 190, 2, 11, 435962) It would have been difficult to abolish purdah right at the start.
('28', 190, 2, 12, 436029) But a few Rajputs must start working for the future.
('28', 190, 3, 13, 436082) Now about the pledge.
('28', 190, 3, 14, 436104) I hear that a good many people took it.
('28', 190, 3, 15, 436144) I also hear that it was taken with deliberation.
('28', 190, 3, 16, 436193) The procedure adopted for the taking of the pledge was also good.
('28', 190, 3, 17, 436259) Let us hope, therefore, that the pledge will be kept scrupulously.
('28', 190, 3, 18, 436326) It has been my experience, however, that a good many pledges taken in big gatherings are not acted upon.
('28', 190, 3, 19, 436431) This, of course, does not mean that we should not take pledges.
('28', 190, 3, 20, 436495) It is, certainly my opinion, confirmed by experience, that one never progresses without taking pledges.
('28', 190, 3, 21, 436599) A pledge means a resolution to be kept up unto death.
('28', 190, 3, 22, 436653) No task can ever be accomplished without such resolutions.
('28', 190, 3, 23, 436712) According to my capacity is of no help at all.
('28', 190, 3, 24, 436759) A pledge confers on man inexhaustible strength.
('28', 190, 3, 25, 436807) A person who would do a thing only to the best of his capacity is sure to weaken some time of other.
('28', 190, 3, 26, 436908) He will have, then, no support.
('28', 190, 3, 27, 436940) A pledge, however, will save him in such a contingency.
('28', 190, 3, 28, 436996) He had taken the pledge with God as witness.
('28', 190, 3, 29, 437041) When he loses his own strength, the Helper of the helpless will be there by his side.
('28', 190, 4, 30, 437127) Unfortunately, we put little value on pledges.
('28', 190, 4, 31, 437174) As people do not think much before taking one, they are unable to keep it.
('28', 190, 4, 32, 437249) Having got into the habit of not keeping pledges, they have almost come to believe that it is not necessary to keep them.
('28', 190, 4, 33, 437371) We should all wish that the Rajput brothers and sisters who have taken the pledge will keep it.

('28', 194, 1, 2, 443982) 109. THREE QUESTIONS
('28', 194, 2, 3, 444003) (1) Does not spinning and weaving make a man a Sudra?
('28', 194, 2, 4, 444057) (2) Is it not contrary to principles of economics that even one who can earn much more through his brains should make a living by spinning and weaving?
('28', 194, 2, 5, 444209) (3) Does not spinning and weaving by all destroy the principle of division of labour?
('28', 194, 2, 6, 444295) In my view a Sudra is one who earns his living by doing service or wage labour for others.
('28', 194, 2, 7, 444386) Thus considered all who do service are Sudras.
('28', 194, 2, 8, 444433) How can one who pursues an independent occupation be treated as a Sudra?
('28', 194, 2, 9, 444506) I do not see this does any harm to varnashrama.
('28', 194, 2, 10, 444554) Now the second question.
('28', 194, 2, 11, 444579) My conviction tells me that God gave us the intellect for knowing ourselves.
('28', 194, 2, 12, 444656) A living should be got out of agriculture, etc.
('28', 194, 2, 13, 444704) The chief cause of all the wickedness that there is in the world is the misuse of the intellect.
('28', 194, 2, 14, 444801) It is through the.
('28', 194, 2, 15, 444820) misuse of the intellect that there is so much inequality in the world.
('28', 194, 2, 16, 444891) Tens of millions go about begging while a hundred or two become millionaires.
('28', 194, 2, 17, 444969) The true economics is that by which every man and woman gets a living by physical labour.
('28', 194, 2, 18, 445059) Now as to the third question.
('28', 194, 2, 19, 445089) There is no harm done to the principle of division of labour.
('28', 194, 2, 20, 445151) For the masons, the goldsmiths, etc., are not being asked to take to spinning.
('28', 194, 2, 21, 445230) Yes, those who do service, or practise law, or have no occupation at all are advised to earn their livelihood by spinning and weaving.
('28', 194, 2, 22, 445365) Spinning, at the present time and in this field, I consider a yajna.
('28', 194, 2, 23, 445434) Spinning is a necessary yajna for all young and old, men and women, rich and poor.
('28', 194, 2, 24, 445517) Honest men have to go hungry.
('28', 194, 2, 25, 445547) They should feed themselves through spinning.
('28', 194, 2, 26, 445593) But the others should, for their sake, pray to God and spin.

('28', 196, 4, 20, 448422) 112. INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS OF INDIA 1
('28', 196, 5, 21, 448468) [AHMEDABAD, June 24, 1924]
('28', 196, 6, 22, 448495) Asked whether from all he had seen he was still certain that he would be able to avoid a fratricidal war, Mr. Gandhi replied: Certainly.
('28', 196, 6, 23, 448632) There seems nothing to make me despair of being able to avoid internal dissensions.
('28', 196, 6, 24, 448716) Opinions may differ as to the interpretation of the phrase, but I have very little doubt that there would be no unseemly dissensions.
('28', 196, 6, 25, 448850) I regard members of the All India Congress Committee, whether Swarajists or No changers, to be patri otic enough to consider the welfare of the country in preference to every other question.
('28', 196, 6, 26, 449041) It is perfectly true that the Swarajists feel keenly about their own position as I do about mine.
('28', 196, 6, 27, 449139) But I give them the same credit for love of country as I claim for myself.
('28', 196, 6, 28, 449214) That being so, there is not the slightest reason why it should be impossible to come to an understanding whereby both can work along their own lines.
('28', 196, 7, 29, 449364) 1 Gandhiji was interviewed in the afternoon at the Sabarmati Ashram by a special representative of the Associated Press of India.
('28', 197, 0, 1, 449494) 198 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 197, 1, 2, 449536) To the next question, if he did not think that the spinning wheel was too tame for young workers, Mr. Gandhi said: It appears to be too tame only to those who have not worked at it and who have been too lazy to think out its economy and unifying value.
('28', 197, 1, 3, 449789) Those who are nurtured on theories of political economy deduced by Western writers from Western conditions have taken no note of the special conditions of India.
('28', 197, 1, 4, 449951) It presents a problem all its own, as I have repeatedly said.
('28', 197, 1, 5, 450013) Whatever judgment may be pronoun ced upon many things I have advocated, history will pronounce only one judgment on the spinning wheel, namely, that it was the only thing that could put India on her feet.
('28', 197, 1, 6, 450218) I know that the difficulties are enormous, but they are not insurmountable and certainly not nearly as great as the difficulty of reaching the top of Mount Everest; and when a few brave Englishmen have succeeded in the enterprise, I must leave to the experts to say what the gain will be to the world.
('28', 197, 1, 7, 450520) But it requires no expert to say what the.
('28', 197, 1, 8, 450563) success of the spinning wheel must mean.
('28', 197, 1, 9, 450604) I am convinced that, as soon as the Congress workers realize for themselves the possibilities of this simple invention, in an incredibly short space of time the charkha will occupy a place in the Indian home next only to the simple village stove.

('28', 197, 2, 11, 450872) 113. OPEN LETTER TO A.I.C.C. MEMBERS [Before June 26, 1924]
('28', 197, 3, 12, 450932) DEA R FRI ENDS, We rightly regard the Congress to be the most representative of the nation whether for better or for worse.
('28', 197, 3, 13, 451056) In my opinion, the Congress has an almost perfect constitution designed to represent the nation to the fullest possible extent.
('28', 197, 3, 14, 451184) But being ourselves imperfect, we have worked it very indifferently.
('28', 197, 3, 15, 451253) Our voters roll has been reduced practically to nil in many parts of India.
('28', 197, 3, 16, 451329) But, in spite of it all, an organization that has persisted for forty years and weathered many a storm must remain the most powerful in the land.
('28', 197, 3, 17, 451475) We regard ourselves as its chosen representatives.
('28', 197, 3, 18, 451526) The Congress took a resolution in 1920 that was designed to attain swaraj in one year.
('28', 197, 3, 19, 451613) 1 At the end of that year we were within an ace of getting it.
('28', 197, 3, 20, 451676) But because we failed to get it then, we may not now regard

('28', 198, 1, 2, 451836) it as indefinitely postponed.
('28', 198, 1, 3, 451866) On the contrary, we must retain the same attitude of hopefulness as before.
('28', 198, 1, 4, 451942) Above all, we must be determined to get swaraj soon, sooner than the chilly atmosphere around us will warrant.
('28', 198, 1, 5, 452053) It is in that spirit that I have framed the resolutions for sub mission to you.
('28', 198, 1, 6, 452133) They have been before the country now for a week.
('28', 198, 1, 7, 452183) I have read some of the criticism directed against them.
('28', 198, 1, 8, 452240) I believe I am open to conviction.
('28', 198, 1, 9, 452275) But the criticism has not altered it.
('28', 198, 1, 10, 452313) I have no axes to grind, or the only axe I have to grind is that which will enable us to strike at the root of every impediment in our way.
('28', 198, 1, 11, 452453) I believe in khaddar, I believe in the spinning wheel.
('28', 198, 1, 12, 452508) It has two aspectsterrible and benign.
('28', 198, 1, 13, 452547) In its terrible aspect it is calculated to bring about the only boy cott we need for independent national existence, viz., that of foreign cloth.
('28', 198, 1, 14, 452693) It alone can kill the demoralizing British self interest.
('28', 198, 1, 15, 452751) Then and then only, when that interest is killed, shall we be in a position to talk to British statesmen on equal terms.

('28', 198, 1, 19, 453052) It alone can bring us in touch and in tune with the villagers.
('28', 198, 1, 20, 453115) It is the very best popular education that is needed for the millions.
('28', 198, 1, 21, 453186) It is life giving.
('28', 198, 1, 22, 453205) I would not, therefore, hesitate to turn the Congress into an exclusively khaddar producing and khaddar propaganda organization till the attainment of swaraj, just as I would not hesitate, if I believed in the use of arms and giving violent battle to England, to make the Congress an organization exclusively devoted to training the nation in the use of arms.
('28', 198, 1, 23, 453565) To be truly national the Congress must devote itself exclusively to that which will bring the nation most quickly within reach of swaraj.
('28', 198, 1, 24, 453703) Because I believe in the potency of khaddar to give swaraj, I have given it the foremost place in our programme.
('28', 198, 1, 25, 453816) You will not hesi tate summarily to reject it, if you do not share my belief.
('28', 198, 1, 26, 453894) But if you believe in khaddar you will regard the requirements I have sub mitted as a mild minimum.
('28', 198, 1, 27, 453994) I assure you, if I was not afraid of putting an undue strain on you, I would not have hesitated to implore you to give four hours per day to spinning instead of a paltry half hour.
('28', 198, 1, 28, 454175) In this connection, let me confess my distrust of Swarajists.

('28', 199, 1, 2, 454416) said final good bye to khaddar and that the material of which their dress was made was foreign.

('28', 201, 2, 3, 459158) SOME CONVICT WARDERS
('28', 201, 3, 4, 459179) I have already dealt with the system of appointing convicts as officers or warders.
('28', 201, 3, 5, 459263) I hold the system to be thoroughly bad and dem oralizing.
('28', 201, 3, 6, 459321) The prison officials know it.
('28', 201, 3, 7, 459351) They say it is due to economy.
('28', 201, 3, 8, 459382) They think that the jails cannot be efficiently administered with the present paid staff without supplementing it with convict officers.
('28', 201, 3, 9, 459519) There is no doubt that, unless the reform suggested by me in the last chapter is inaugurated, it is not possible to do away with the system of entrusting convicts with responsible duties without a very large increase in the prison expenditure.
('28', 201, 3, 10, 459763) However, it is not my purpose in this chapter to deal any further with prison reform.
('28', 201, 3, 11, 459849) I simply wish to relate my happy experiences of the convict officers who were appointed to watch over and look after us.
('28', 201, 3, 12, 459970) When Mr. Banker and I were transferred to the Yeravda Central Prison, there was one warder and one bardasi.
('28', 201, 3, 13, 460078) The latter is what the name implies, a mere servant.
('28', 201, 3, 14, 460131) The convict warder whose acquaintance we first made was a Hindu from the Punjab side.
('28', 201, 3, 15, 460217) His name was Harkaran.
('28', 201, 3, 16, 460240) He was convicted of murder.
('28', 201, 3, 17, 460268) The murder according to him was not premeditated but due to a fit of anger.
('28', 201, 3, 18, 460344) By occupation he was a petty merchant.
('28', 201, 3, 19, 460383) His sentence was fourteen years, of which he had almost served nine years.
('28', 201, 3, 20, 460458) He was fairly old.
('28', 201, 3, 21, 460477) The prison life had told on him.
('28', 201, 3, 22, 460510) He was always brooding and most anxious to be discharged.
('28', 201, 3, 23, 460568) He was therefore morose and peevish.
('28', 201, 3, 24, 460605) He was conscious of his high dignity.
('28', 201, 3, 25, 460643) He was patronizing to those who obeyed and served him.
('28', 201, 3, 26, 460698) He bullied those who crossed his path.
('28', 201, 3, 27, 460737) To look at him, no one would think he could be guilty of murder.
('28', 201, 3, 28, 460802) He could read Urdu fluently.
('28', 201, 3, 29, 460831) He was religiously minded and was fond of reading bhajans in Urdu.
('28', 201, 3, 30, 460898) The Yeravda library has a few books for prisoners in several Indian languages, e.g., Hindi, Urdu, Marathi, Gujarati, Sindhi, Canarese, Tamil.
('28', 201, 3, 31, 461040) Harkaran was not above keeping and hiding trifles in defiance of jail regulations.
('28', 201, 3, 32, 461123) He was in the majority.
('28', 201, 3, 33, 461147) It would be regarded snobbish and foolish not to steal trifles.
('28', 201, 3, 34, 461211) A prisoner who did not follow this unwritten law would have a bad time of it from his fellows.

('28', 202, 1, 10, 462306) He was horrified to discover that I was neither interested in the exploits nor was I minded to join the trade.

('28', 207, 1, 13, 475026) As a matter of fact, no disclaimer is necessary, and none can prevent such an attempt being made in the future.
('28', 207, 1, 14, 475138) A solemn declaration made by all the Sikhs can easily be thrown on the scrap heap if ever their successors entertain any such unworthy ambition.
('28', 207, 1, 15, 475283) The safety lies only in the determination of us all to work for the freedom of all.
('28', 207, 1, 16, 475367) From a practical standpoint too, moral support of the reform movement, it is clear, reduces the chances of unworthy ambition being harboured in the Sikh breast.
('28', 207, 1, 17, 475528) As a matter of fact, any such mutual suspicion necessarily hinders the swaraj move ment for it prevents hearty co operation between the communities and thus consolidates the forces of exploitation of this fair land and perhaps even makes possible an ambition which is at present clearly impossible.
('28', 207, 1, 18, 475827) We must therefore judge each communal movement on its merits and give it ungrudging support, when it is in itself sound, and the means employed for its conduct are honourable, open and peace ful.

('28', 208, 2, 13, 477092) MAHMUD AND FORCIBLE CONVERSIONS
('28', 208, 3, 14, 477124) Numerous letters, some angry and some even abusive, have been received by me regarding my reference to forcible conversions in the statement on Hindu Muslim tension.
('28', 208, 3, 15, 477290) One of them was a dispassionate and reasoned letter from Mr. Madhavan Nair protesting against the statement attributed by me to Dr. Mahmud.
('28', 208, 3, 16, 477430) I forwarded the letter to Dr. Mahmud for reply so that I could give the reader his version.
('28', 208, 3, 17, 477522) But before my letter could reach Dr. Mahmud, he had already posted one to me on the very thing, he having received many protests himself.
('28', 208, 3, 18, 477660) I now give from Dr. Mahmuds letter, which is in Urdu, a translation of the relevant part as follows: Quite a number of Hindu friends have written to me letters accusing me of having given you inaccurate information with regard to the affairs in Malabar.
('28', 208, 3, 19, 477914) Some of them have even treated me with round, mouth filling abuse.
('28', 208, 3, 20, 477981) I feel that their resentment is just.
('28', 208, 3, 21, 478019) There seems to have been some misunderstanding.
('28', 208, 3, 22, 478067) What I said was that no instances of conversion by circumcision could be found.
('28', 208, 3, 23, 478147) Only one such case had been reported, the one which Mr. Andrews had witnessed, and even that could not be properly investigated into.
('28', 208, 3, 24, 478281) As for instances of conversion by being made to wear fez cap, or shirt in case of women, or by clipping off the choti, they could be cited in any number.
('28', 208, 3, 25, 478435) l had mentioned this point in my statement to Shwaib also.
('28', 208, 3, 26, 478494) Please do publish the necessary correction in Young India or it might give rise to a fresh controversy in the Press.
('28', 208, 3, 27, 478611) I see that I have done an injustice to Dr. Mahmud.
('28', 208, 3, 28, 478662) I was thinking of forcible conversions only by circumcision.
('28', 208, 3, 29, 478723) It was that which had most shocked the Hindu sentiment.
('28', 208, 3, 30, 478779) Anyway, it was that which had affected me more than anything else.

('28', 211, 1, 2, 483858) NEWS TO ME
('28', 211, 2, 3, 483869) A correspondent says that I am reported to have said that: It is better that one cow be sacrificed rather than seven goats. He then asks me to disown or endorse the statement and, in the latter case, to justify it.
('28', 211, 2, 4, 484084) I do not recollect having made any such statement as the correspondent refers to.
('28', 211, 2, 5, 484166) And whoever has heard me make such a statement will oblige me by reminding me of the occasion.
('28', 211, 2, 6, 484261) According to my correspondent I am supposed to have made the statement as editor of Young India.
('28', 211, 2, 7, 484358) If so, there should be no difficulty about confronting me with it.
('28', 211, 2, 8, 484425) But what I am likely to have said or written is that, if I could non violently persuade people, I would have them to save the goat just as well as I would have people to save the cow.
('28', 211, 2, 9, 484609) As I have said before in these pages, for me the cow is the purest type of sub human life.
('28', 211, 2, 10, 484700) She pleads before us on behalf of the whole of the sub human species for justice to it at the hands of man, the first among all that lives.
('28', 211, 2, 11, 484840) She seems to speak to us through her eyes (let the reader look at them with my faith), You are not appointed over us to kill us and eat our flesh or otherwise ill treat us, but to be our friend and guardian.

('28', 217, 1, 2, 498185) 119. SPEECH AT A.I.C.C. MEETING 1
('28', 217, 2, 3, 498219) AHMEDABAD, June 27, 1924
('28', 217, 3, 4, 498244) Mr. Gandhi, who was called upon by the President to explain his position on the point of order raised by Pandit Motilal Nehru, spoke in Hindi.
('28', 217, 3, 5, 498387) Mr. Gandhi said that he was not going beyond the Congress constitution in bringing forward his resolution.
('28', 217, 3, 6, 498494) Articles 21 and 31 relied on by Mr. Das and Pandit Motilal Nehru laid down certain conditions and those conditions, in his opinion, were not transgressed.
('28', 217, 3, 7, 498649) His view was that the A.I.C.C. had full powers of the Congress, when the latter body was not in session.
('28', 217, 3, 8, 498754) His resolutions did not restrict the right of the electors, but only advised the electors to do the needful.
('28', 217, 4, 9, 498863) He said that only the All India Committee had full powers to make rules to see if members were efficiently carrying out the programme of the Congress or not.
('28', 217, 4, 10, 499021) The electors had certainly the right of free and unfettered choice, but once the elections were over they could exercise no sort of control over the conduct of their represen tatives.
('28', 217, 4, 11, 499205) Only the All India Committee could do that.
('28', 217, 4, 12, 499249) Surely it is the duty of the committee to remove every obstacle to progress in the direction of carrying out the resolutions of the Congress passed at Cocanada, which fully endorsed the Non co operation programme and ensure efficiency in the manner of work.
('28', 217, 4, 13, 499507) If it was argued that the provincial committees had theright to frame its own rules, imposing condi tions of membership, ipso facto it follows the All India Committee, which is the fountain head of all authority, has the like powers to condition its own membership.

('28', 217, 4, 15, 499835) The Congress passed certain resolutions and the All India Congress Committee had to see that they were carried out.

('28', 224, 3, 12, 516866) 122. SPEECH AND RESOLUTION ON PENAL CLAUSE1
('28', 224, 4, 13, 516910) AHMEDABAD, June 28, 1924
('28', 224, 5, 14, 516935) The President said that the motion proposed by him was carried only by 67 against 37. The Swarajists who left the meeting had not voted.
('28', 224, 5, 15, 517072) If their votes were also added, at the most it gave him only a narrow majority.
('28', 224, 5, 16, 517152) He therefore advised the meeting to rescind the penal clause.
('28', 224, 5, 17, 517214) It was suggested by one of those present that it would not be in the spirit of the constitution.
('28', 224, 6, 18, 517311) Mr. Gandhi, replying, reminded the House of a precedent at the Amritsar Congress whose Subjects Committee had passed a motion on the subject of disorders by the Punjab mob during the Rowlatt Act agitation days, but later on, on his plea, rescinded the original motion almost immediately.

('28', 232, 1, 2, 535638) 125. I ACCEPT DEFEAT
('28', 232, 2, 3, 535659) Sometimes people want to meet me and discuss the Shastras with me.

('28', 245, 1, 2, 565693) 132. INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS OF INDIA 1
('28', 245, 2, 3, 565739) AHMEDABAD, July 1, 1924 It is most difficult to give my impressions now, not because there is none to give, but because there are too many.
('28', 245, 2, 4, 565879) Just as a man who eats too much does no good to himself except to impair his digestion, so these impressions, not being digested and, therefore, not arranged in the brain, do not lend themselves to a readable descrip tion.
('28', 245, 2, 5, 566102) For the time being, therefore, I must invite the curious to be satis fied with the honest impressions of spectators or with the imaginary pictures of reporters.
('28', 245, 2, 6, 566263) It is highly probable that, on the principle that spectators see more of the play than the actors, the honest impressions of the former, supplemented by the enterprising imagination of reporters will give the public an idea of the very important proce edings of the Committee.
('28', 245, 2, 7, 566540) One definite impression, however, I can give.
('28', 245, 2, 8, 566586) Though on all of the four resolutions that I had the honour of moving I had a majority in their favour, I must own that, according to my conception, I was defeated.
('28', 245, 2, 9, 566751) The proceedings have been an eye opener to me and I am now occupied in a diligent search from within.
('28', 245, 2, 10, 566853) As yet, I am with out an answer.
('28', 245, 2, 11, 566886) After having seen the newspaper reports yesterday and a private telegram describing them, I am not sure that I was wise in discoura ging the Kerala members from pressing for a resolution of the All India Congress Committee on the Vykom Satyagraha.
('28', 245, 2, 12, 567134) My general opinion is that all such local struggles should depend for success on their own inherent strength and not upon support borrowed from the central body.
('28', 245, 2, 13, 567296) But the new development probably justifies an emphatic declaration by the A.I.C.C. I shall certainly recommend some resolution for the Working Committee for adoption.
('28', 245, 2, 14, 567463) If the reports are to be relied upon, the Travancore State authorities have abandoned the innocent satyagrahis to the goondas said to have been employed by the orthodox opponents reform for which the satyagrahis have been fighting.
('28', 245, 2, 15, 567695) Travancore is said to be one of the most enlightened States of India and I hope that, for its very fame, if not for the sake of
('28', 245, 3, 16, 567823) 1 Gandhiji was asked to give his impressions of the A.I.C.C. session which had just concluded.

('28', 246, 1, 2, 567960) humanity, the reports are without foundation.
('28', 246, 1, 3, 568006) It is a serious thing if satyagrahis are cruelly beaten by the goondas.
('28', 246, 1, 4, 568078) Limes are thrown into their eyes and their khaddar shirts torn from them and burnt.

('28', 259, 2, 21, 601044) I told them that the Congress had already taken up the Sikh cause and that, therefore, it could not very well now refrain without giving rise to the suspicion it had given up the Sikh cause.
('28', 259, 2, 22, 601235) The members did not perhaps appreciate my reasoning.
('28', 259, 2, 23, 601288) But they cheerfully submitted to it.
('28', 259, 2, 24, 601325) The Travancore authorities may, however, be respectfully told that the Congress cannot watch barbarity with philosophic indifference.
('28', 259, 2, 25, 601459) So long as satyagraha is met by ordinary State processes, the movement must remain local.
('28', 259, 2, 26, 601549) But the letting loose of the goondas on the devoted heads of the satyagrahis is bound to gather round the satyagrahis the full weight of all India public opinion.
('28', 259, 2, 27, 601712) A word now to the organizers of Vaikom Satyagraha.
('28', 259, 3, 28, 601763) 1 Vide, Interview to Associated Press of India, 1 7 1924.
('28', 260, 0, 1, 601821) VOL.28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15 AUGUST, 1924 261
('28', 260, 1, 2, 601863) challenge of the goondas must be taken up.
('28', 260, 1, 3, 601906) But the satyagrahis must not lose their heads.
('28', 260, 1, 4, 601953) The khaddar dress of the volunteers is said to have been torn from them and burnt.
('28', 260, 1, 5, 602036) This is all most provoking.
('28', 260, 1, 6, 602064) They must remain cool under every provocation and courageous under the hottest fire.
('28', 260, 1, 7, 602149) Loss even of a few hundred lives will not be too great a price to pay for the freedom of the unapproachables.
('28', 260, 1, 8, 602259) Only the martyrs must die clean.

('28', 260, 2, 10, 602349) AN APOLOGY
('28', 260, 3, 11, 602360) I have much pleasure in printing the following letter.
('28', 260, 3, 12, 602415) In my note on Barabanki, I did not give the name of my informant.
('28', 260, 3, 13, 602481) But I cannot withhold the name any longer.
('28', 260, 3, 14, 602524) I wish all will be as ready as Mr. Shuaib to admit mistakes and slow to believe stories about Hindu and Mussalman misdeeds.
('28', 260, 3, 15, 602648) The reader will share my gladness that the charge against the Hindu Municipal Commissioners of Barabanki was baseless.
('28', 260, 3, 16, 602767) I apologize to them for having been the unconscious instru ment of doing an injustice to them.
('28', 260, 4, 17, 602862) To the Editor, Young India
('28', 260, 6, 18, 602889) Since I wrote to you about conditions at Barabanki, I am informed by a Mussalman member of the District Congress Committee, Barabanki, who is also a member of the Provincial Congress Committee, U.P., that the facts are not as they were reported to me.
('28', 260, 6, 19, 603141) All that took place was that, in place of the old rule of Barabanki Municipal Board, by virtue of which applications to the Board could only be given in Urdu script, the Board passed a law that they could be given either in Devanagri or Urdu charactersa law which I personally consider to be just and fair.
('28', 260, 6, 20, 603448) I am very sorry that I supplied you with facts which have turned out to be are incorrect.
('28', 260, 6, 21, 603538) My only excuse is that my informants were very reliable persons.
('28', 260, 6, 22, 603603) I do not intend to name them, but should like to say that they are both of them office bearers of the Congress and recognized by all to be absolutely free from communal prejudices.
('28', 260, 6, 23, 603784) It was because of this that I readily believed what they said.
('28', 260, 6, 24, 603847) I, however, do not wish to blame these gentlemen who, I may in passing say, fully believed those facts themselves.
('28', 260, 6, 25, 603962) The mistake is all mine.
('28', 260, 6, 26, 603987) I should have thoroughly ascertained the facts before writing about them to you even though they were reported to me by persons whom I considered perfectly reliable.
('28', 260, 6, 27, 604153) I shall know how to act in future.
('28', 260, 6, 28, 604188) But for the present I can only express my sincere and profound regrets for having been an unconscious instrument in giving
('28', 261, 0, 1, 604311) 262 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 261, 1, 2, 604353) publicity to facts likely to affect adversely Hindu Muslim relations which are strained enough already.
('28', 261, 1, 3, 604457) Yours, etc.,
('28', 261, 2, 4, 604470) SHUAIB QURESHI
('28', 261, 3, 5, 604485) CORDIAL RELATIONS
('28', 261, 4, 6, 604503) Mr. K. Rajagopalachari of Tirupati sends the following by way of a variety in the unbroken series of unpleasantnesses between Hindus and Mussalmans:
('28', 261, 5, 7, 604652) As you seem to have been presented with the dark side only of Hindu Muslim tension, I wish to present you with the bright site of it also.
('28', 261, 6, 8, 604791) Tirupati is a small place with a population of 18,000 people of whom about 500 are Mussalmans, the rest being Hindus.
('28', 261, 6, 9, 604909) You know it is one of the sacred places of Hindus and men from all parts of India visit this place in thousands daily.
('28', 261, 6, 10, 605028) Naturally the Hindus are very influential, the head of the temple being a northern Indian Bairagi and extremely influential with Government.
('28', 261, 6, 11, 605169) The Mussalmans are all traders and some of them are leading merchants in the place.
('28', 261, 6, 12, 605253) The Mussalmans are new comers, but the relationship between them and the Hindus is as cordial as possible.
('28', 261, 6, 13, 605360) In September last, one of the leading Mussalmans of the place, in celebrating the birth month of the Prophet, had put paper festoons right across the street (the only main street in the town) and a red cloth in which was written Mahomeds birth month celebration on one side and Prophet of all prophets on the other side.
('28', 261, 6, 14, 605681) Hindus were silently murmuring protests against the latter writing on the cloth.
('28', 261, 6, 15, 605762) But no trouble arose in any of the previous years.
('28', 261, 6, 16, 605813) However, the temple authorities stopped a number of processions of the Hindu Deity through that street lest they should create some trouble between Hindus and Mussalmans; more with a view it appears to respect the sentiments of Muslims.
('28', 261, 6, 17, 606050) One day, however, the procession of the Deity through the street could not be prevented.
('28', 261, 6, 18, 606139) The temple authorities took the precaution of speaking to the Muslim friends beforehand and had arranged to get the cloth alone removed when the Deity had to pass that street.
('28', 261, 6, 19, 606315) The Muslim friend seems to have consented, but, when the Deity actually came near his shop, the Hindus wanted even the paper festoons to be removed, while the Muslim friend refused to remove even the cloth.
('28', 261, 6, 20, 606522) I happened to pass that way then and found a large number of Hindus assembled in front of the shop and about a hundred Muslims had also gathered to have a fight if necessary.
('28', 261, 6, 21, 606697) I could not convince the Hindus that there was nothing wrong in the Deity passing through the festoons nor the Mussalmans that they would not lose their prestige by removing them at
('28', 262, 0, 1, 606879) VOL.28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15 AUGUST, 1924 263
('28', 262, 1, 2, 606921) The Hindus were in no mood to listen to me, for a large number of them were drunk and no respectable Hindu was present there.
('28', 262, 1, 3, 607047) When I argued with such of the Hindus as were sober that it was not derogatory to Hinduism to take our Deity underneath the festoons, they said I was pro Muslim and even conspired to beat me.
('28', 262, 1, 4, 607239) Meanwhile, two or three responsible temple officials appeared on the scene and dramatically announced that the Deity should be taken underneath the festoons and no police help was needed so far as they were concerned.
('28', 262, 1, 5, 607457) The attitude of Muslims at once changed.
('28', 262, 1, 6, 607498) They suggested that their own men should go up and raise the paper festoons so that they might not touch any portion of the sacred Deity and its ornamentations and that the cloth should be removed at once.
('28', 262, 1, 7, 607704) The matter ended smoothly that night.
('28', 262, 1, 8, 607742) The next morning, a hakim friend, a good Mussalman, as soon as he came to know of the trouble the previous evening, ordered the festoons all to be removed or he would come and remove them himself.
('28', 262, 1, 9, 607939) The festoons were at once removed.
('28', 262, 1, 10, 607974) The temple authorities, even a few days after, declined to take the Deity through the street, because, one of them told me subsequently, they did not want to create the impression in the minds of the Muslims that the Hindus, being larger in number and more powerful, were coercing them into doing things which otherwise they would not do.
('28', 262, 1, 11, 608313) Many of the prominent Hindus agreed with us that what we did was commendable and we had their sympathies.
('28', 262, 2, 12, 608419) The Hakim Sahib, two or three days later, sent for me and told me that he was ashamed to look up in the face of any Hindu of their magnanimity, in the face of comparative unreasonableness on the part of Muslims.
('28', 262, 2, 13, 608631) A few days after that, both Hindus and Muslims closed their shops, the Hindus showing their sympathy towards Mussalmans during Ramzan.
('28', 262, 2, 14, 608766) Next time, the Muslims closed their shops along with the Hindus on the new moon day to please the Hindus and the mutual friendly relationship still continues and I am sure will continue for ever.
('28', 262, 2, 15, 608962) For a long time, there was only one mosque in this town and recently another mosque has been erected.
('28', 262, 2, 16, 609064) The Hindus refrain from music even in front of the new mosque today.
('28', 262, 2, 17, 609133) The Hindus are so powerful that, if they only care, they can ignore the Mussalmans and have their own way, but they are conducting themselves very considerately towards the Mussalmans and even yield when necessary.
('28', 262, 2, 18, 609348) By such behaviour, we have created in the minds of Mussalmans a certain amount of confidence in us, and many sensitive Mussalmans are ashamed even to talk of the incident of September last.
('28', 262, 2, 19, 609538) By our yielding to their demands, even though unreasonable, we disarm them of all opposition.
('28', 262, 2, 20, 609632) Our educated people can do and undo things.
('28', 262, 2, 21, 609676) The masses follow us, and if we lead them aright, there will be no Hindu Muslim trouble and we could reach our goal quickly.
('28', 263, 0, 1, 609801) 264 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 263, 1, 2, 609843) Let us hope that the cordial relations between the two sections will continue for ever.

('28', 263, 5, 10, 610416) 3 I had not read it before.

('28', 263, 5, 12, 610534) But wine is made after being thrice distilled.
('28', 263, 5, 13, 610581) It is, therefore, purer than water. 4 You will not misunderstand me.

('28', 268, 9, 9, 618062) COUNCIL ENTRY
('28', 268, 10, 10, 618076) After the closing of the session of the A.I.C.C., Pandit Motilalji went to Rajkot for a domestic visit and halted at Ahmedabad on his way to Bombay.
('28', 268, 10, 11, 618225) We met during the halt.
('28', 268, 10, 12, 618249) In the course of our discussion, I happened to say that it would be disastrous if the Swarajists retired from the Councils at this stage.
('28', 268, 10, 13, 618387) He immediately reminded me of my previous writing 3 that, if I could convince the Swarajists, I would ask them to withdraw.
('28', 268, 10, 14, 618511) I said I saw no contradiction between the two.
('28', 268, 10, 15, 618558) The one statement is permanent and based upon principle, the other is applicable to the immediate present only and is based on expedience.
('28', 268, 10, 16, 618697) There is no doubt that the Swarajists have created a stir in the Government circles.
('28', 268, 10, 17, 618782) There is no doubt, too, that any withdrawal at the present moment will be misunderstood as a rout
('28', 268, 11, 18, 618880) 1 This was in reply to Mathuradass telegram to Krishnadas, inquiring about Gandhijis health, which was received on July 7, 1924. 2 This was in reply to a telegram from the students of National College, Dacca, dated July 9, 1924, which read: Telegram suppressed by college authority.
('28', 268, 11, 19, 619163) Principal and professors faithless in school boycott.
('28', 268, 11, 20, 619217) How to read under them.
('28', 268, 11, 21, 619241) Wire clearly to Jilani thirty Jindabahar Dacca. Vide Telegram to G. Nalgola, on or after 5 7 1924.
('28', 268, 12, 22, 619340) 3 Vide Statement to Associated Press of India, 22 5 1924.
('28', 269, 0, 1, 619398) 270 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 269, 1, 2, 619440) and weakness.
('28', 269, 1, 3, 619454) As a matter of fact, so far as the A.I.C.C. is concerned, the Swarajist position has been never so strong as it is now.
('28', 269, 1, 4, 619574) They are entitled to claim a moral victory.
('28', 269, 1, 5, 619618) Believing as they do in giving battle to the Government in the Assembly and the Councils, they have no reason whatsoever for withdrawing from the Legislative bodies at the present moment.
('28', 269, 1, 6, 619806) Their withdrawal at this juncture can only add to the present depression in the country and strengthen the hands of a Government which wants to give nothing to justice and which yields gracelessly and reluctantly to pressure.
('28', 269, 1, 7, 620032) The only opportune time for the Swarajists to come out will be when we the whole hoggers have become active workers of our own programme, which we consider to be the only one that can bring us swaraj, and shown progressive success, or when the Swarajists are by bitter experience convinced that the Councils can only give condi ments but no bread, and that, therefore, they should give their whole time and attention to the constructive programme.
('28', 269, 1, 8, 620480) The key to the situation lies in the hands of us whole hoggers, We claim that the masses are behind us.
('28', 269, 1, 9, 620584) I at least feel so.
('28', 269, 1, 10, 620604) If they are, we must show it by resultsnot by merely securing a majority at the Congress, but by showing substantial work.
('28', 269, 1, 11, 620727) All the No changers in all the provinces cannot show adequate results.
('28', 269, 1, 12, 620798) The fault is probably not theirs.

('28', 278, 1, 14, 642641) But the insinuation does not prevent me from re acknowledging the pioneer work done by him in Gurukul.
('28', 278, 1, 15, 642744) Whilst, therefore, I am unable to withdraw a single word of my criticism of the Samaj, the Satyarth Prakash, Rishi Dayanand and Swami Shraddhanandji, I repeat that my criticism was that of a friend with the desire that the Samaj may render greater service by ridding itself of the shortcomings to which I drew attention.
('28', 278, 1, 16, 643065) I want it to march with the times, give up the polemical spirit and, whilst adhering to its own opinions, extend that toleration to other faiths which it claims for itself.
('28', 278, 1, 17, 643238) I want it to keep a watch on its workers and stop all discreditable writings.
('28', 278, 1, 18, 643316) It is no answer in justification that Mussalmans commenced the campaign of calumny.
('28', 278, 1, 19, 643400) I do not know whether they did or not.
('28', 278, 1, 20, 643439) But I do know that they would have been tired.
('28', 278, 1, 21, 643486) of repetition if there had been no retaliation.
('28', 278, 1, 22, 643534) I have not even urged the Samajsits to give up their shuddhi.
('28', 278, 1, 23, 643596) But I do urge them, as I would urge Mussalm ans, to revise the present idea of shuddhi.
('28', 278, 1, 24, 643684) To the Mussalman writers and speakers, of whose conduct I have received the letters referred, I venture to point out that they neither enhance their own reputation nor that of the religion they profess by unrestrained abuse of the opponent.
('28', 278, 1, 25, 643925) They can gain nothing, they can not serve Islam, by swearing at the Samaj and the Samajists.

('28', 279, 4, 4, 644131) Adan was a young Somali soldier who was sentenced to ten years hard labour for desertion from the British Army, which he had joined during the War.
('28', 279, 4, 5, 644279) He was transferred by the Aden Jail authorities.

('28', 279, 4, 7, 644378) He was prac tically illiterate.

('28', 279, 4, 16, 645048) He would often engage me in a discussion on complete fasts according to the Hindu custom as also on ahimsa.
('28', 279, 4, 17, 645156) He was a brave man.
('28', 279, 4, 18, 645176) He was very courteous, but never cringing.

('28', 279, 4, 20, 645321) We had, therefore.
('28', 279, 4, 21, 645340) sometimes to arbitrate between them.

('28', 286, 2, 9, 661583) 151. ONE PROGRAMME
('28', 286, 3, 10, 661602) Friends have asked me to suggest one universal programme in which rajas, maharajas, No changers, Pro changers, Liberals, Indepen dents, practising lawyers, Anglo Indians and all others could join without reserve.
('28', 286, 3, 11, 661815) I am asked to suggest such a programme with the condition that it must be effective and swift enough for the attainment of swaraj.
('28', 286, 3, 12, 661946) The most effective and the swiftest programme I can suggest is the adoption and organization of khaddar, promotion of Hindu Muslim unity, and removal by the Hindus of untouchability.
('28', 286, 3, 13, 662129) It is my unalterable belief that, if these three things are achieved, we can establish swaraj without the slightest difficulty.
('28', 286, 3, 14, 662257) I further believe that, if all the parties whole heartedly work the programme, it can succeed within one year.
('28', 286, 3, 15, 662368) Success of khaddar will mean boycott of foreign cloth.
('28', 286, 3, 16, 662423) It is Indias right and duty to manufacture all the cloth she needs.
('28', 286, 3, 17, 662491) She has the means of doing it.
('28', 286, 3, 18, 662522) And boycott of foreign cloth will automatically purify the English mind and remove the one insuperable obstacle in the way of Englishmen looking at things Indian from the Indian stand point.
('28', 286, 3, 19, 662713) If, therefore, the country as a whole adopts this threefold pro gramme, I would be prepared to advise suspension of the non co ope ration programme and civil disobedience for a period of one year.
('28', 286, 3, 20, 662910) I say one year, because an honest working of the programme must bring about a virtual boycott of foreign cloth within that period.
('28', 286, 3, 21, 663041) I need hardly say that the co operation of Swarajists alone in the above programme is not enough to suspend Non co operation or preparations for civil disobedience.
('28', 286, 3, 22, 663206) Their assent is already there.
('28', 286, 3, 23, 663237) They are pledged like all other Congressmen to the full constructive pro gramme.
('28', 286, 3, 24, 663318) Non co operation is necessary so long as there is no change
('28', 287, 0, 1, 663378) 288 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 287, 1, 2, 663420) of heart in the Government.
('28', 287, 1, 3, 663448) And without that change those who keep themselves outside the Congress pale will not actively and openly participate in the programme.
('28', 287, 1, 4, 663583) I fear that the time has not yet arrived for such sincere co ope ration with the people on the part of the Government or those whose position and prestige depend upon its patronage.
('28', 287, 1, 5, 663765) I know too that a very large number of people are not yet con verted to the programme of unadulterated khaddar.
('28', 287, 1, 6, 663877) They disbelieve in the mighty potency of the charkha.
('28', 287, 1, 7, 663931) They even suspect me of evil designs upon the Indian mills.
('28', 287, 1, 8, 663991) Few take the trouble of drawing a mental picture of the meaning of the message of the charkha.
('28', 287, 1, 9, 664086) I have no doubt that the country will soon come round to the charkha if its votaries are true to their faith.
('28', 287, 1, 10, 664196) But some of my friends tell me that I am wrong in my diagnosis.
('28', 287, 1, 11, 664260) They tell me that, if I would but drop non co operation and civil disobedience, everyone will gather round the charkha and that it is preposterous for me to suspect the Government of a desire to divide Hindus and Mussalmans.
('28', 287, 1, 12, 664485) I hope I am wrong.
('28', 287, 1, 13, 664504) Let me make the position clear regarding our mills.
('28', 287, 1, 14, 664556) I am not their enemy.
('28', 287, 1, 15, 664578) I believe they have a place in our economy for some time to come.
('28', 287, 1, 16, 664644) Boycott of foreign cloth cannot perhaps be brought about speedily without the assistance of mills.
('28', 287, 1, 17, 664743) But if they are to help, they must become national in spirit.
('28', 287, 1, 18, 664805) They must not be worked merely for the agents and shareholders but for the nation at large.
('28', 287, 1, 19, 664897) In our programme, however, we must erase the mills, for khaddar has to carve out a position for itself.
('28', 287, 1, 20, 665001) The message of khaddar has not even been delivered to one out of seven lakhs of villages.
('28', 287, 1, 21, 665091) The mills have, therefore, more than six sevenths of India yet at their disposal.
('28', 287, 1, 22, 665173) If khaddar is to establish a permanent footing, Congressmen can only use and popularize it to the exclusion of mill cloth.
('28', 287, 1, 23, 665296) Patriotic mill owners must see at a glance the utility, the necessity and the reasona bleness of my proposition.
('28', 287, 1, 24, 665409) Indeed, they can help khaddar without hurting themselves.
('28', 287, 1, 25, 665467) If the time comes when the whole of India adopts khaddar, they must rejoice with the nation and they will, even as the Lancashire mill owners will and must some day, find other uses for their capital and machinery.
('28', 287, 1, 26, 665682) I have sketched the universal programme for the satisfaction of insistent friends.
('28', 287, 1, 27, 665765) But I would warn the workers against turning their attention away from the immediate task before them which is to attend to their own and their neighbours spinning.
('28', 288, 0, 1, 665930) VOL.28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15 AUGUST, 1924 289
('28', 288, 1, 2, 665972) If universal acceptance does not come now, their spinning and theirfaith will precipitate it.
('28', 288, 1, 3, 666066) That it must come some day is a certainty.
('28', 288, 1, 4, 666109) The precise date can be determined only by those who have already a living faith in it and who have proved it by acting up to it in the face of heaviest odds.

('28', 289, 2, 9, 667912) Meanwhile do the following: reduce pulses; leave off chutney; eat boiled vegetables; take as much as you can of oranges or fresh grapes; and drink one or two bottles of Apollinarisa kind of [mineral] water.

('28', 289, 2, 12, 668281) The water should be slightly warm and half a spoon of boric acid should be added to it.
('28', 289, 2, 13, 668369) If this does not give relief, one spoon of castor oil and ten drops of turpentine should be added.
('28', 289, 2, 14, 668468) A little pure soap also should be dissolved in the water.
('28', 289, 2, 15, 668526) I do see that your health is deteriorating with medicines.
('28', 289, 2, 16, 668585) Change of climate and enemawith these two things, however, everything will be all right.

('28', 290, 1, 2, 669106) 155. SPEECH AT GUJARAT CONGRESS COMMITTEE MEETING 1
('28', 290, 2, 3, 669158) AHMEDABAD, July 11, 1924
('28', 290, 3, 4, 669183) Mahatmaji, with his loin cloth and characteristic smile on his lips, arrived at 3.15. All stood up.
('28', 290, 3, 5, 669283) In addressing the meeting, Mahatmaji reminded the audience of the Fourth Gujarat Political Conference held at Ahmedabad in 1920, 2 when Non co operation was first proclaimed by Gujarat, before the special session of the Calcutta Congress.
('28', 290, 3, 6, 669522) Mahatmaji emphasized that he was still conscious and retained the old, optimistic faith of those days, despite signs.
('28', 290, 3, 7, 669640) Of depression, which was evinced in the country.
('28', 290, 3, 8, 669689) Gujarat should always be ahead of the Congress.
('28', 290, 3, 9, 669737) Mahatmaji continued: Our representatives should undertake to spin not only half an hour as ordered by the A.I.C.C. and produce 2,000 yards, but they must spin for one hour and produce 5,000 yards instead, in order to encourage other provinces and also to set a precedent for other provinces.
('28', 290, 3, 10, 670029) Let there be no harangue now, but let your spinning transmit its message of the charkha to those who are our neighbours and friends.
('28', 290, 3, 11, 670162) I know there are friends who are pessimistic about the capacity of Gujarat to fulfil this programme.
('28', 290, 3, 12, 670263) But let Gujarat, in whom lies my only hopeexcept, of course, my hope in the Almighty, which never leaves merise to the occasion and give the lie direct to the pessimism and distrust of these friends.
('28', 290, 3, 13, 670463) If we are not concentrating on spinning even for half an hour every day, I have not the shadow of a doubt that we will not be able to attain swaraj by non violent means.
('28', 290, 3, 14, 670633) Rest assured that Councils shall not bring us swaraj.
('28', 290, 3, 15, 670687) Without constructive work outside, Councils can achieve nothing.
('28', 290, 3, 16, 670752) The death of constructive work would be the death knell of swaraj.
('28', 290, 4, 17, 670819) Coming to the presidentship of the ensuing Belgaum Congress, Mahatmaji said that, fortunately or unfortunately, there had been a split in the Congress camp and people rather superstitiously believed that he was the man who would remove the split.
('28', 290, 4, 18, 671066) He informed members that Mrs. Sarojini Naidu would be landing in Bombay within a day or two and he concurred with The Bombay Chronicle, which had proposed Srimati Naidus name as the President of this years Congress.
('28', 290, 5, 19, 671282) 1 A meeting of the Gujarat Congress Committee was held on July 11 at 3 p.m.
('28', 290, 5, 20, 671358) The agenda included, among other things, the future programme of Gujarat, action to be taken on the A.I.C.C. resolutions and the appointment of the President of the forthcoming Congress.

('28', 292, 6, 8, 673990) 157. FORCE OR RESTRAINT?
('28', 292, 7, 9, 674015) A friend has raised a very difficult question.
('28', 292, 7, 10, 674062) He says:
('28', 292, 8, 11, 674071) If it is against the principle of non violence to bring about any reforms by force, it is violence to compel anyone to give up drink by legislation.
('28', 292, 8, 12, 674220) Here is some confusion of thought.
('28', 292, 8, 13, 674255) The friend seems to believe that law always connotes coercion.
('28', 292, 8, 14, 674318) But this is not so.
('28', 292, 8, 15, 674338) It is violence to cause suffering to others out of our selfishness or just for the sake of doing so.
('28', 292, 8, 16, 674439) If, however, it becomes necessary to cause suffering to anyone in order to make someone else happy, to do so dispassionately and unselfishly can be non violence.
('28', 292, 8, 17, 674601) When I injure a thief to save myself from him (that is, for my benefit), that is violence.
('28', 292, 8, 18, 674692) When a surgeon uses a knife on a patient and makes him suffer in order to bring him reliefs that is non violence.
('28', 292, 8, 19, 674806) From this point of view, if a thief is arrested and put into a reformatory, not in order to harass him but to reform him, if kindness is shown to him and he is placed in a good environment so that he may become a good manin this there is neither force nor violence but restraint exercised by society or the ruler.
('28', 292, 8, 20, 675120) The ruler who does this saves the thief from the risk of a prosecution, which is a further kindness done to him.
('28', 292, 8, 21, 675233) Similarly, there is mere violence in a law that provides for the whipping of drunkards, but to close down every liquorbooth by law and thereby to remove the temptation from the drunkard is a form of restraint and is non violence.
('28', 292, 8, 22, 675463) There is in this nothing but pure love.
('28', 292, 8, 23, 675503) Likewise, if I intimi date someone to give up foreign cloth, that is force.
('28', 292, 8, 24, 675579) But passing a law to stop the import of foreign cloth is restraint.
('28', 292, 8, 25, 675647) There is nothing but pure love in this.
('28', 292, 8, 26, 675687) However, a law to punish anyone for wearing foreign cloth would be coercion.
('28', 292, 8, 27, 675764) It signifies anger on the part of society.
('28', 292, 8, 28, 675807) We thus see that all laws do not connote force.
('28', 292, 8, 29, 675855) Modern laws do have an element of force in them because their makert object is to produce fear in order to protect society from criminals, it is not to
('28', 293, 0, 1, 676007) 294 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 293, 1, 2, 676049) reform the criminals.
('28', 293, 1, 3, 676071) The only question which remains is this.
('28', 293, 1, 4, 676112) We see reforms effected even through force.
('28', 293, 1, 5, 676156) A person can be made to give up stealing by beating him.
('28', 293, 1, 6, 676213) Quite a few people say and believe that many children have been reformed through beating.
('28', 293, 1, 7, 676303) It is this belief which is respon sible for the increasing burden of sin in the world at present.
('28', 293, 1, 8, 676401) The use of force is soul destroying and it affects not only the person who uses it but also his descendants and the environment as a whole.
('28', 293, 1, 9, 676541) We should examine the total effect of the use of force, and that over a long period of time.
('28', 293, 1, 10, 676634) The use of force has continued over a long period of time, but we do not find that those things against which force has been employed have been destroyed.
('28', 293, 1, 11, 676789) Formerly there used to be heavy punishments for theft.
('28', 293, 1, 12, 676844) It is the opinion of all expert obser vers that heavy punishments have not stopped thefts.
('28', 293, 1, 13, 676935) As the punish ments began to be tempered with mercy, the number of thefts decli ned.
('28', 293, 1, 14, 677020) But the strongest proof of the damage that is being done by the use of force is to be found in the fact that once the custom of effecting reforms by force gets established, the people tend to become dull and lifeless and, as the indolent and savage remedy of using force is resorted to in respect of every matter, the people lose two of their precious qualities: patience and perseverance.
('28', 293, 1, 15, 677410) We may perhaps be deluded into believing that we can secure peace through the use of force, but there are innumerable instances to prove that, on the whole, only evil consequences flow from the use of force.
('28', 293, 2, 16, 677618) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 13 7 1924
('28', 293, 3, 17, 677655) 158. INFANTICIDE OF GIRLS
('28', 293, 4, 18, 677681) I have kept the following letter 1 with me for a number of days.
('28', 293, 4, 19, 677746) I have not reproduced some part of the letter which contains details.
('28', 293, 4, 20, 677816) How far the evils mentioned in the letter are realPatidars alone know.
('28', 293, 4, 21, 677887) I am supposed to have stayed among them for a time and yet, my task being to know the good qualities, made no attempt to acquaint myself with their defects, nor did anyone draw my attention to them.
('28', 293, 5, 22, 678086) 1 Not translated here
('28', 294, 0, 1, 678108) VOL.28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15 AUGUST, 1924 295
('28', 294, 1, 2, 678150) But if the account given in the letter is true, that should put us to shame.
('28', 294, 1, 3, 678227) The sinful superstition that the birth of a baby girl is in auspicious is common among us.
('28', 294, 1, 4, 678318) This superstition has as its basis mere selfishness.
('28', 294, 1, 5, 678371) It might well have originated in the dark ages.
('28', 294, 1, 6, 678419) That people should have detested the birth of a female child in the age when virgins were being kidnapped is in some measure understan dable.
('28', 294, 1, 7, 678561) Today that fear is practically non existent.
('28', 294, 1, 8, 678606) Even if it were there, we are in a position to take remedial measures.
('28', 294, 1, 9, 678677) If there is any reason to rejoice at a birth, we should rejoice whether it is the birth of a boy or a girl; both should be equally dear to us.
('28', 294, 1, 10, 678820) The world certainly needs both.
('28', 294, 1, 11, 678852) One is a complement to the other.
('28', 294, 1, 12, 678886) That being so, to rejoice at the birth of one and to feel depressed at the birth of the other benefits neither.
('28', 294, 1, 13, 678998) In a well balanced society, the proportion of men and women ought to be equal.
('28', 294, 1, 14, 679077) It is common in Hindu society that the father of a girl has to bear heavy expenses on the occasion of her wedding.
('28', 294, 1, 15, 679192) Perhaps this custom assumed grave proportions among the Patidars.
('28', 294, 1, 16, 679258) There cannot be two opinions on the absolute need to do away with this expendi ture.
('28', 294, 1, 17, 679343) A very expensive custom only ruins poor parents and it becomes almost impossible for them to get their daughters married and con sequently there arises the practice of administering poison to girls.
('28', 294, 1, 18, 679542) The example 1 the teacher of Sunav has set is worth following.
('28', 294, 1, 19, 679605) In this age of khadi, weddings can certainly be celebrated with only khadi garlands.
('28', 294, 1, 20, 679690) The writer has thrown the entire blame on the old folk.
('28', 294, 1, 21, 679746) There must be some exaggeration in this.
('28', 294, 1, 22, 679787) But if the old should remain still obstinate owing to their proud temper, youth organizations should take control.
('28', 294, 1, 23, 679902) If the young would firmly decline to participate in expensive weddings, the extravagance would at once stop.
('28', 294, 1, 24, 680011) For this neither discourtesy nor great effort is called for.
('28', 294, 1, 25, 680072) The deplorable thing is that till today the youths have regarded such matters as outside their sphere of activity.
('28', 294, 1, 26, 680187) They have never used their educational attainments for securing social reform.
('28', 294, 1, 27, 680266) But the order of things has changed now.
('28', 294, 1, 28, 680307) The young have begun to think for themselves.
('28', 294, 1, 29, 680353) Hence this reform can be effected
('28', 294, 2, 30, 680387) 1 In the marriage ceremony of a teacher of the national school at Sunav, there were only ten persons in the bridegrooms party, both the bride and the bridegroom put on khaddar garments made from yarns spun by themselves, and the wedding expenditure amounted to a hundred rupees only.
('28', 295, 0, 1, 680671) 296 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 295, 1, 2, 680713) without great effort.
('28', 295, 1, 3, 680735) Only unshakable determination is called for.
('28', 295, 1, 4, 680780) I for one do not like even the association of twelve villages.
('28', 295, 1, 5, 680843) 1 I believe in the four castes only.
('28', 295, 1, 6, 680880) It is necessary to merge the sub castes.
('28', 295, 1, 7, 680921) But that will take time.
('28', 295, 1, 8, 680946) Yet, to divide Patidars into groups of villages is the climax of caste division.
('28', 295, 1, 9, 681027) Why should those who can interdine with the Patidars of the whole of Gujarat not intermarry with them?

('28', 297, 4, 8, 683376) 163. LETTER TO GANGABEHN VAIDYA Ashadh Sud 15 [July 16, 1924] 4
('28', 297, 5, 9, 683440) GANGABEHN, I have your letter.
('28', 297, 5, 10, 683471) Whenever you get angry, you should ask yourself, Against whom do I have all this [wrath]?
('28', 297, 5, 11, 683561) The atman is free from passion; with whom can it be angry? The external remedy to control anger is to keep silent.
('28', 297, 5, 12, 683676) One should speak only after one is calm again.
('28', 297, 5, 13, 683723) You should forget past things.
('28', 297, 5, 14, 683754) Just as we do not eat food left by others after a meal, so also we should not remember past happenings and derive pleasure or pain from them.
('28', 297, 5, 15, 683896) We are entitled to take care of the present only; we should not think about the future either.
('28', 297, 5, 16, 683991) Since you are not going to leave Borivli out of anger or malice, you may pay a visit to them if your son is very importunate.
('28', 297, 5, 17, 684117) After all, you are not going to forsake either your son or daughter in law.
('28', 297, 5, 18, 684193) You are going to make room for her, so that she may not be embarrassed and you despondent.
('28', 297, 5, 19, 684284) I shall be here till, at any rate, the end of this month.
('28', 297, 5, 20, 684342) Even during the first week of August, I shall be here.
('28', 297, 5, 21, 684397) Vandemataram from MOHANDAS
