('28', 298, 10, 18, 685594) 166. NOTES
('28', 298, 11, 19, 685605) SAROJINI THE SINGER
('28', 298, 12, 20, 685625) The readers of Young India have shared with me several letters received by me 4 from South Africa regarding the wonderful work of Indias gifted daughter.
('28', 298, 12, 21, 685779) Here is one sentence for them to share from a letter from Mr. P. K. Naidu:
('28', 298, 13, 22, 685854) Her work here was wonderful.
('28', 298, 13, 23, 685883) Her charming personality and winsome elo quence won us not hundreds but thousands of European friends and also shook up the Smuts Government.
('28', 298, 14, 24, 686025) 1 The postmark is dated, Sabarmati, July 17, 1924. 2 This was written on a silence day in reply to Mathuradass letter, in which he had appealed to Gandhiji to leave the Congress because there were internal squabbles in it.
('28', 298, 14, 25, 686248) 3 As in the source 4 Vide Sarojinis Magnetism, 10 4 1924.
('28', 299, 0, 1, 686306) 300 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 299, 1, 2, 686348) India is therefore honouring herself by honouring her.
('28', 299, 1, 3, 686403) For myself I must confess that her presence is a great relief to me.
('28', 299, 1, 4, 686472) For, though I believe that I can contribute my humble share in the promotion of Hindu Muslim unity, in many respects she can do much better.
('28', 299, 1, 5, 686613) She intimately knows more Mussalmans than I do.
('28', 299, 1, 6, 686661) She has access to their hearts, which I cannot pretend to.
('28', 299, 1, 7, 686720) Add to these qualifications her sex, which is her strongest qualification in which no man can approach her.
('28', 299, 1, 8, 686828) For peace making is womans special prero gative.
('28', 299, 1, 9, 686877) Sarojini Devi has deliberately cultivated that special quality of her sex.
('28', 299, 1, 10, 686952) She showed it to perfection at the time of the disgraceful rioting in Bombay in 1921. Her personal bravery and her tireless energy had become infectious.
('28', 299, 1, 11, 687106) Wherever she went, the rioters laid down their arms.
('28', 299, 1, 12, 687159) She has been a veritable angel of peace in East Africa and South Africa.
('28', 299, 1, 13, 687232) The best welcome India can extend to her is to pray that God may give her the strength to continue her mission of peace and that she may become an indissoluble cement between the two communities.
('28', 299, 1, 14, 687428) May the so called weaker sex succeed where we, the so called stronger sex, have failed.
('28', 299, 1, 15, 687516) God presses not pride but humility in His service.
('28', 299, 1, 16, 687567) Man knows how to destroy, it is womans prerogative to construct.
('28', 299, 1, 17, 687632) May Sarojini be the instrument in Gods hands for constructing real unity between Hindus and Mussalmans.
('28', 299, 2, 18, 687736) DELHI AND NAGPUR
('28', 299, 3, 19, 687753) Delhi has disgraced itself.
('28', 299, 3, 20, 687781) The riots in Delhi would show that there is no non co operation left there, for non co operation with the Government means co operation among the people.
('28', 299, 3, 21, 687935) But in Delhi last week there was more non co operation with one another than with the Government.
('28', 299, 3, 22, 688033) The Congress and the Khilafat men could not produce peace among the people.
('28', 299, 3, 23, 688109) It was reserved for the police and the military to do so.
('28', 299, 3, 24, 688167) Theirs is the glory and ours the disgrace.
('28', 299, 3, 25, 688210) The letters before me tell me that our volunteers, being baffled in their attempt to bring about peace, chose the next best thing, viz., that of nursing those who were hurt, not by the police, but in an affray among themselves.
('28', 299, 3, 26, 688438) The whole affair is said to have been due to an assault alleged to have been committed by some Hindus on a Mussalman youth.
('28', 299, 3, 27, 688562) What though the youth had died?
('28', 299, 3, 28, 688594) The aggrieved Mussalmans could have had their remedy either through the recently appointed arbitration board or through the Government courts.
('28', 299, 3, 29, 688737) Granted that some Hindus assaulted a Muslim boy, that
('28', 300, 0, 1, 688791) VOL.28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15 AUGUST, 1924 301
('28', 300, 1, 2, 688833) thereupon some Mussalmans assaulted the Hindus, why did the other Hindus, whoever they might be, retaliate?
('28', 300, 1, 3, 688941) For according to the letters received by me, the fighting had spread to the whole of the Indian area.
('28', 300, 1, 4, 689043) The same letters tell me that, though it had so spread, the main population was unaffected by the disturbance and that there were instances of Hindus having sheltered Mussalmans and the latter having done likewise to Hindus.
('28', 300, 1, 5, 689268) All this is no doubt creditable.
('28', 300, 1, 6, 689301) But the fact remains that the main population was powerless to restrain the mob.
('28', 300, 1, 7, 689382) We have not yet gained control over the turbulent element.
('28', 300, 1, 8, 689441) Nagpur has fared no better.
('28', 300, 1, 9, 689469) As yet only meagre details have come to hand.
('28', 300, 1, 10, 689515) It is evident that the Hindus and the Mussalmans of Nagpur consider a free fight among themselves to be more profitable than a joint fight (non violent though it must be) against the Government.
('28', 300, 1, 11, 689710) Thus, if Delhi and Nagpur are any indication of the temper of the people at large, we must say good bye to Hindu Muslim unity for a long while and must, therefore, be content to live as slaves rather than strive to be free.
('28', 300, 1, 12, 689934) But I do not despair.
('28', 300, 1, 13, 689956) I believe with Maulana Shaukat Ali that these quarrels are a short lived distemper and that both the commu nities are bound, in the near future, to settle down to a peaceful programme.
('28', 300, 1, 14, 690141) And if we are to settle down to such a programme, I would like to suggest both to the Delhi and the Nagpur Congressmen and Khila fatists that neither party goes to court on any account whatsoever, but that the disputes be settled by arbitration.
('28', 300, 1, 15, 690387) The lawyers, whether practising or otherwise, can help a great deal in this direction.
('28', 300, 1, 16, 690474) They can simply refuse to take cases to court, but point out to the parties that they have nothing to gain thereby and probably much to lose.
('28', 300, 1, 17, 690616) They can assure them, too, that if it is real peace they want they will not get it through courts.
('28', 300, 2, 18, 690715) BARA BAZAAR CONGRESSMEN
('28', 300, 3, 19, 690739) When I read the account of disturbances ending in assault between Congressmen in Bara Bazaar, Calcutta, I was disinclined to believe it.
('28', 300, 3, 20, 690876) But three letters received by me from Congressmen who were most of them eye witnesses show that there was a free fight at the meeting and all this for the sake, not of attaining the object of the Congress, but for the sake of capturing the committee.
('28', 300, 3, 21, 691127) All the three
('28', 301, 0, 1, 691141) 302 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 301, 1, 2, 691183) letters are from professed No changers.
('28', 301, 1, 3, 691223) The letters do not enable one to fix the guilt on any one party.
('28', 301, 1, 4, 691288) I have no doubt that a Swarajist account would entirely blame the No changers.
('28', 301, 1, 5, 691367) What puzzles me is that any party should resort to violence for the sake of capturing an organization which is claimed to be non violent.
('28', 301, 1, 6, 691505) The writers of the letters say that they are my followers.
('28', 301, 1, 7, 691564) If, by calling themselves my followers, they claim to be votaries of non violence, they must avoid every occasion for conflict.
('28', 301, 1, 8, 691692) They must, therefore, cease to take part in an armed fight for capturing the Congress or any of its committees.
('28', 301, 1, 9, 691804) My correspondents tell me that, although No changers are in a decided majority in Bara Bazaar, the Swarajists are likely to pack their meetings or break up No changers meetings and thus control the Congress organization.
('28', 301, 1, 10, 692025) Supposing that all these charges are true, surely the No changers have a non violent remedy open to them.
('28', 301, 1, 11, 692131) They must simply cease to attend Swarajist meetings and form their own organization for working their programme, if it is the programme they want to work and not the Congress they want to capture.
('28', 301, 1, 12, 692328) I promise that the No changers will, if they work, make themselves indispensable to the Swarajists.
('28', 301, 1, 13, 692428) There is but one God, one goal, one means.
('28', 301, 1, 14, 692471) There is unity in disease, therefore, there is unity in remedy.
('28', 301, 1, 15, 692535) Whether it is the Government or the Swarajists, there is only one sovereign remedy, namely, non violent non co operation.
('28', 301, 1, 16, 692657) My follo wers will, therefore, do well to set up their own organization of work and no talk.
('28', 301, 1, 17, 692750) They must cut their way to the nations heart through service.
('28', 301, 1, 18, 692812) I have addressed my argument to the No changers because they are the protesting party and they write as my followers.
('28', 301, 1, 19, 692930) I neither believe nor disbelieve their charges against Swarajists.
('28', 301, 1, 20, 692997) I claim the latter too to be my followers since they claim equally with the No changers to be the votaries of the Congress creed.
('28', 301, 1, 21, 693127) If they assert, as I have no doubt they will assert, that they were not in the wrong, I would suggest to them the same remedy as I have to the No change followers of mine.
('28', 301, 1, 22, 693299) My followers wait for no response from the opposite party, for they do not retaliate.
('28', 301, 1, 23, 693385) Those that do not, expect no return.
('28', 301, 1, 24, 693422) They are, therefore, never hurt.
('28', 301, 1, 25, 693455) To put it in the most concrete manner possible, no one who wants to spin, or do what lies in him to promote Hindu Muslim unity, or, if a Hindu, to remove untouchability, requires any organization.
('28', 301, 1, 26, 693652) Organizations may want him and he will gladly give his service wherever he is wanted.
('28', 301, 1, 27, 693738) A Swarajist friend tells me that in Maharashtra No changers have and retain their majority purely through brute force and that in Berar it
('28', 302, 0, 1, 693877) VOL.28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15 AUGUST, 1924 303
('28', 302, 1, 2, 693919) was they who resorted to blows.
('28', 302, 1, 3, 693951) If that be so, I would ask the No changers to apologize and, wherever they are holding office through brute force or unclean methods, to vacate office and yet do their task.
('28', 302, 1, 4, 694125) It is a gross superstition to believe that one cannot serve effectively without the Congress prestige at ones back.
('28', 302, 2, 5, 694241) A STEP IN ADVANCE
('28', 302, 3, 6, 694259) The Gujarat P.C.C., while endorsing the A.I.C.C. resolution on spinning, has advanced upon the original and has made 3,000 yards of yarn obligatory for the first month and contemplates making 5,000 yards obligatory in the near future.
('28', 302, 3, 7, 694494) It has also prescribed the penalty clause that was dropped by the A.I.C.C. I have always held that it is open to every provincial committee to advance upon the A.I.C.C. requirements.
('28', 302, 3, 8, 694677) Every province having the capacity should regard it as its duty to do so.
('28', 302, 3, 9, 694751) 2,000 yards is in the nature of subscription payable by every representative.
('28', 302, 3, 10, 694829) It is meritorious to give more.
('28', 302, 3, 11, 694861) And there is nothing wrong in disqualifying a member who does not pay his subscription.
('28', 302, 3, 12, 694949) I hope, therefore, that the other provinces which can will follow the example of Gujarat.
('28', 302, 3, 13, 695039) The 15th of August will give the country a clear indication of where Congress representatives stand regarding their faith in spinning.
('28', 302, 3, 14, 695174) Let them remember that faith without works is like a body without soula corpse fit only to be burnt or buried.
('28', 302, 3, 15, 695285) The burden of organizing spinning in every province rests with the provincial committees.
('28', 302, 3, 16, 695375) They should lose no time in ascertaining the names of representatives and seeing that they do not neglect their duty for want of material or knowledge.
('28', 302, 3, 17, 695527) Our helplessness is pitiable; we can be saved from impending ruin only if we become what we were, a nation of spinners and weavers.
('28', 302, 3, 18, 695659) The Congress has, on paper at least, accepted the truth of the proposition.
('28', 302, 3, 19, 695735) Its representatives through out the country are now expected to become skilled carders and spin ners, learn all about the science of spinning and organize their respec tive districts.
('28', 302, 3, 20, 695919) Half hours labour is the preliminary.
('28', 302, 3, 21, 695957) But the preliminary pro cess requires attention to details, stocking and supplying cotton, card ing and turning it into slivers and spinning it.
('28', 302, 3, 22, 696102) The yarn collected would have to be examined at the provincial centre.
('28', 302, 3, 23, 696173) The wheels would need attention.
('28', 302, 3, 24, 696206) A proper wheel with a proper spindle will naturally cause a great saving of time and would give pleasure to the spinner.
('28', 302, 3, 25, 696327) The duty of spinning by a Congress representative arises from
('28', 303, 0, 1, 696389) 304 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 303, 1, 2, 696431) the A.I.C.C. resolution.
('28', 303, 1, 3, 696456) But as a matter of fact, it is a duty incumbent upon everyone, whether Congressman or other.
('28', 303, 1, 4, 696549) Every enthusiastic worker may form a spinning club whose business will be to get as much yarn as possible spun by every one of its members for presentation to the Secretary, Khadi Board.
('28', 303, 1, 5, 696736) The reader will be glad to know that the Registrar of the Gujarat Vidyapith has already set the ball rolling by getting the staff of office to promise to spin five thousand yards per month, of which two thousand yards are to be presented to the Vidyapith and the rest to be preserved.
('28', 303, 2, 6, 697021) A DANGER
('28', 303, 3, 7, 697030) Gujarat has been in the habit of absorbing khadi to a very large extent from Andhra, Punjab and Bihar.
('28', 303, 3, 8, 697133) Whilst it was perhaps nece ssary to do so in the initial stages when Gujarat could produce practi cally no khadi for her requirements and the provinces named needed encouragement, as a system it is vicious.
('28', 303, 3, 9, 697340) The central fact of khaddar is to make every village self supporting for its food and clothing.
('28', 303, 3, 10, 697436) Therefore, every province must become self supporting.
('28', 303, 3, 11, 697491) It cannot become so if it has to import khadi from another.
('28', 303, 3, 12, 697551) For one thing such a province has no staying power against famine.
('28', 303, 3, 13, 697618) The exporting province must suffer too.
('28', 303, 3, 14, 697658) Abuse must creep in both production and sale and there will be the greatest temptation to use mill spun instead of hand spun yarn.
('28', 303, 3, 15, 697789) I have a letter before me from Masulipatam in which the writer says that habit is growing up among dealers of stock ing hand spun yarn and getting it woven for export.
('28', 303, 3, 16, 697957) The writer further adds that the spinners, instead of themselves wearing hand spun, almost invariably wear mill spun.
('28', 303, 3, 17, 698075) It is, therefore, highly necessary for workers to guard against such trafficking in khaddar.
('28', 303, 3, 18, 698168) The way to induce those spinners to wear homespun is to weave for them free of charge.
('28', 303, 3, 19, 698255) Yard for yard mill spun is likely, for some time, to sell cheaper than handspun.
('28', 303, 3, 20, 698336) The poor spinners who spin merely for their living will not listen to patriotic argument or that of national economy.
('28', 303, 3, 21, 698454) The only argument they will listen to would be that of their pockets.
('28', 303, 3, 22, 698524) And if they can have their own yarn woven for them free of charge, they will gladly wear khaddar.
('28', 303, 3, 23, 698622) For such work to be done thoroughly and cheaply, it is necessary for many young men not merely to learn spinning but also weaving so that they may weave for the sake of their poor sisters.
('28', 303, 3, 24, 698811) All these things cannot happen unless the Congress becomes chiefly a khaddar propaganda organization.
('28', 303, 3, 25, 698913) But the foregoing argument does not mean that there will be no
('28', 304, 0, 1, 698976) VOL.28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15 AUGUST, 1924 305
('28', 304, 1, 2, 699018) export of khadi.
('28', 304, 1, 3, 699035) The special talent of Andhra will always be in demand.
('28', 304, 1, 4, 699090) But this interchange must be left to private enterprise.
('28', 304, 1, 5, 699147) The Congress can concern itself only with the things that need tender nursing.
('28', 304, 2, 6, 699226) ADD THE GAG
('28', 304, 3, 7, 699238) An English friend writes:
('28', 304, 4, 8, 699264) Only a week ago I wrote to a friend and said Gandhi forgot when he recommended rentia to add bookani or gag. You may remember my lecture when I said the abuse of leisure or spare time was the curse of India and recommended hobbies, i.e.
('28', 304, 4, 9, 699501) gardening, carpentry, photography, reading history, philosophy, etc.
('28', 304, 4, 10, 699570) It is foolish, vapid talk which engrosses all the spare time of the people of this country.
('28', 304, 4, 11, 699662) They have not learnt to read, mark, learn and inwardly digest.
('28', 304, 4, 12, 699725) The remedy is continual essay writing in schools and colleges on every kind of subject which will necessitate the study of books and the mastery of their contents, the formulation of ideas and their logical arrangement.
('28', 304, 4, 13, 699945) I have no hesitation in endorsing the friends suggestion as to gagging.
('28', 304, 4, 14, 700017) There is no doubt that we are suffering from a surfeit of talking and writing.
('28', 304, 4, 15, 700096) Much of both is inane when it does not contain abuse or the Government or ones opponent.
('28', 304, 4, 16, 700185) I have suggested that talking may well be left to Maulana Shaukat Ali and me.
('28', 304, 4, 17, 700263) As for writing, I am doing it already.
('28', 304, 4, 18, 700302) We need not discount the friends criticism because he is an Englishman.
('28', 304, 4, 19, 700374) He also happens to be a criminal.
('28', 304, 4, 20, 700408) He takes part in running the machinery which we are seeking to destroy.
('28', 304, 4, 21, 700480) But as I have no ill will against these English criminals who find themselves running the machinery, some of them retain their friendship with me in spite of my opposition (mad as it appears to some of them to be) to the system they are administering.
('28', 304, 4, 22, 700732) I would, therefore, ask the reader to give due weight to the friends criticism.
('28', 304, 4, 23, 700812) Essay writing is good only to a certain extent.
('28', 304, 4, 24, 700860) It does not make a writer necessarily brief unless he practises the art of conden sation.
('28', 304, 4, 25, 700950) Everyone who wishes may try to boil down all his thoughts and compress them so as to take up no more than one side of half a sheet of note paper.
('28', 304, 4, 26, 701096) Gokhale was once asked by Morley to perform a similar feat.
('28', 304, 4, 27, 701156) He did it.
('28', 304, 4, 28, 701167) It took him more time than if he had to write 50 sheets which nobody would read.
('28', 304, 4, 29, 701248) Shankara delivered the whole of his cele brated message in half a verse: God alone is; all else is not. The real discipline, however, lies in curbing the desire to speak or write.
('28', 305, 0, 1, 701428) 306 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 305, 1, 2, 701470) would then speak or write only when one must.
('28', 305, 1, 3, 701516) But, as a matter of fact, spinning carries its own gag.
('28', 305, 1, 4, 701572) When spinning grows on a man or woman he or she has little leisure for anything else.
('28', 305, 1, 5, 701658) And whilst the English friend, not feeling as we do, not knowing the condition of the masses as we do, can only speak of spinning as one of the many hobbies for occupying idle hours, we think of spinning as a sacred duty for the age and the country we are living in.
('28', 305, 1, 6, 701925) It, therefore, derives from that fact a value all its own and cannot be spoken of in the same breath as the other occupations.
('28', 305, 1, 7, 702052) When Englishmen have realized this fact, they will no longer be strangers in a strange land for its exploitation.
('28', 305, 1, 8, 702166) They, too, will then spin not for amusement or curiosity, but as a duty they owe to the country whose salt they eat.
('28', 305, 1, 9, 702283) But before we can expect them to do so, we must prove our faith by our work.

('28', 306, 4, 23, 705479) 167. AN APPEAL TO THE NATION
('28', 306, 5, 24, 705508) Under the above heading Mr. Srish Chandra Chatterji and eigh teen other signatories have issued a document which I copy below:
('28', 306, 6, 25, 705635) We are passing through a series of national crises the gravity of which can hardly be exaggerated.

('28', 306, 7, 27, 705935) 1 Prafulla Chandra Ray (1861 1944); professor of chemistry at Presidency College, Calcutta; author of History of Hindu Chemistry; educationist and patriot
('28', 307, 0, 1, 706090) 308 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 307, 1, 2, 706132) indecisive steps, it takes long centuries to retrieve the loss.
('28', 307, 1, 3, 706196) India is passing through some such crisis and we are extremely fortunate that the crisis is not yet over.
('28', 307, 1, 4, 706302) The whole world is shivering from the pains of labour, the indications of a new life are manifest everywhere, and a regenerated India must find a place among the new born nations of the world.
('28', 307, 1, 5, 706495) This rejuvenated India cannot accept any overlord, she must be a free and independent nation.
('28', 307, 2, 6, 706589) At a time when all the nations of the world are fighting for independence and liberty, at a time when our Indian heroes are championing the cause of Indias independence abroad, it is simply ridiculous and shameful that we Indians should hesitate to accept independence as our only legitimate and logical goal; we therefore appeal to our nation to declare in the open Congress in unmistakable terms that independence and complete independence is our destined goal; let there be no ambiguous phrases to qualify it, let it be preached in all its nakedness.
('28', 307, 2, 7, 707143) It is the moral force of this ideal that creates nations.
('28', 307, 3, 8, 707201) We must educate the country from this very moment in a way so that the people may realize the significance of a republic and a federation.
('28', 307, 3, 9, 707340) We may postpone it for the future only at the risk of a great national calamity.
('28', 307, 3, 10, 707421) We therefore appeal to the Congress delegates to define swaraj as a Federated Republic of the United States of India.
('28', 307, 4, 11, 707539) We also appeal to the delegates of this Congress to delete the words by peaceful and legitimate means from the Congress creed, so that men holding every shade of opinion may have no difficulty in joining the only national organization in the country, though for the present it may be retained as a part of the actual programme of Congress work.
('28', 307, 4, 12, 707884) Our time is short and we cannot dilate upon this point at any length, but we only say that means are after all means and our object and means should not be confounded with each other.
('28', 307, 5, 13, 708068) We are further of opinion that mere changing of the creed and passing of resolutions would not bring us independence.
('28', 307, 5, 14, 708186) We thereforerequest the representative of our nation to engage the whole strength and the whole resources of the Congress in organizing a band of national workers who will devote all their time and all their energy in the service of their motherland and who must be ready to suffer and even be ready to sacrifice their lives for the national cause.

('28', 314, 1, 2, 724068) argument.
('28', 314, 1, 3, 724078) I have noted in the course of my journalistic experience dating from 1904 that most of the criticism received by editors is based upon an imperfect under standing of an opponents statement.
('28', 314, 1, 4, 724268) In the case in point, if only the friend had borne in mind that I had presented the message of the wheel, not to the Hindus alone, but to all Indians without exception, to men and women, to Mussalmans, Parsis, Christians, Jews, Sikhs and all others who claimed to be Indians, she would have written differently.
('28', 314, 1, 5, 724580) She would then have inferred that I had placed before the people of India something which not only did not come in conflict with the several religions but which, in so far as it was taken up, added lustre to ones own religion and, in Hinduism, to ones own varna or caste.
('28', 314, 1, 6, 724852) Mine, therefore, I claim to be a method not of confusion but cleansing.
('28', 314, 1, 7, 724924) I ask no one to forsake his own hereditary dharma or occupation, but I ask everyone to add spinning to his natural occupation.
('28', 314, 1, 8, 725051) The Rajputs of Kathiawar knew this.
('28', 314, 1, 9, 725087) They asked me whether I wanted them to give up their swords.
('28', 314, 1, 10, 725148) I told them I wanted them to do no such thing.
('28', 314, 1, 11, 725195) On the contrary, I added, I wanted each one of them to possess a trusty sword so long as they believed in it.
('28', 314, 1, 12, 725305) But I certainly told them that my ideal Rajput was he who defended without the sword and who died at his post without killing.
('28', 314, 1, 13, 725432) A sword may be snatchedfrom one, not so the bravery to die without striking.
('28', 314, 1, 14, 725509) But this is by the way.
('28', 314, 1, 15, 725533) For my purpose, it is enough to show that the Rajputs were not to give up their calling of protecting the weak.
('28', 314, 1, 16, 725645) Nor do I want the Brahmins to give up their vocation as teachers.
('28', 314, 1, 17, 725711) I have suggested to them that they become better teachers for sacrificial spinning.
('28', 314, 1, 18, 725795) Vinoba and Balkoba are better Brahmins for having become spinners and wea vers and scavengers.
('28', 314, 1, 19, 725890) Their knowledge is more digested.
('28', 314, 1, 20, 725924) A Brahmin is one who knows God.
('28', 314, 1, 21, 725956) Both these fellow workers are nearer God today by reason of their having felt for and identified themselves through spinning with the starving millions of India.
('28', 314, 1, 22, 726118) Divine knowledge is not borrowed from books.
('28', 314, 1, 23, 726163) It has to be realized in oneself.
('28', 314, 1, 24, 726197) Books are at best an aid, often even a hindrance.
('28', 314, 1, 25, 726247) A learned Brahmin had to learn divine wisdom from a godfearing butcher.
('28', 314, 2, 26, 726319) What is this varanashrama?
('28', 314, 2, 27, 726346) It is not a system of water tight compartments.
('28', 314, 2, 28, 726394) It is a recognition to me of a scientific fact whether we know it or not.
('28', 314, 2, 29, 726468) A Brahmin is not only a teacher.
('28', 314, 2, 30, 726501) He is only predo 
('28', 315, 0, 1, 726519) 316 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 315, 1, 2, 726561) minantly that.
('28', 315, 1, 3, 726576) But a Brahmin who refuses to labour will be voted down as an idiot.
('28', 315, 1, 4, 726644) The rishis of old who lived in the forests cut and fetched wood, tended cattle and even fought.
('28', 315, 1, 5, 726740) But their pursuit in life was pre eminently search after Truth.
('28', 315, 1, 6, 726804) Similarly, a Rajput without learning was good for nothing, no matter how well he wielded the sword.
('28', 315, 1, 7, 726904) And a Vaisya without divine knowledge suffi cient for his own growth will be a veritable monster eating into the vitals of society, as many modern Vaisyas, whether of the East or the West, have become.
('28', 315, 1, 8, 727106) They are, according to the Gita incarnations of sin who live only for themselves.
('28', 315, 1, 9, 727188) The spinning wheel is designed to wake up everyone to a sense of his duty.
('28', 315, 1, 10, 727263) It enables every one better to fulfil his dharma or duty.
('28', 315, 1, 11, 727321) When a vessel is running on smooth waters, work on board is exquisitely divided.
('28', 315, 1, 12, 727402) But when it is caught in the grip of a violent storm and is about to sink, everyone has to give a helping hand to the necessary work of life saving.
('28', 315, 1, 13, 727551) Let us also bear in mind that, with the rest of the world, India finds herself in the deadly coil of the mercantile cobra.
('28', 315, 1, 14, 727674) It is a nation of shop keeping soldiers that claims to rule her.
('28', 315, 1, 15, 727739) It will tax all the resources of all her best Brahmins to unwind India from that coil.
('28', 315, 1, 16, 727826) Her learned men and her soldiers will, therefore, have to bring their learning and their prowess to bear upon the mercantile require ments of India.
('28', 315, 1, 17, 727975) They must, therefore, in order to be able faithfully to carry out their dharma, learn and practise spinning.
('28', 315, 1, 18, 728084) Nor have I the least hesitation in recommending hand wea ving as a bread winning occupation to all who are in need of an honest occupation.
('28', 315, 1, 19, 728224) To the Brahmins, the Kshatriyas and others, who are at the present moment not following their hereditary occu pation, but are engaged in the mad rush for riches, I present the honest and (for them) selfless toil of the weaver and invite them, with a view to return ing to their respective dharmas, to be satisfied with what little the handloom yields to them.
('28', 315, 1, 20, 728584) Just as eating, drink ing, sleeping, etc., are common to all castes and all religions, so must spinning be common to all without exception whilst the confusion, selfish greed and resul ting pauperism persist.
('28', 315, 1, 21, 728793) Mine, therefore, is a method not of making varnasankaraconfusion worse confoundedbut it is one of making varnashramacleansing more secure.

('28', 316, 0, 1, 728955) VOL.28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15 AUGUST, 1924 317
('28', 316, 1, 2, 728997) 170. WHAT KHADDAR CAN DO
('28', 316, 2, 3, 729022) A correspondent from the Andhra district writes:
('28', 316, 3, 4, 729071) When I discontinued my studies from the Presidency College, Madras, in January 1921, I did so because I could not resist the appeal made by you.
('28', 316, 3, 5, 729216) Then I knew nothing about the greatness of khaddar.
('28', 316, 3, 6, 729268) After I had come from Madras to my village, I had to work hard for four months to get me two khaddar dhotis and khaddar cloth enough for three shirts.
('28', 316, 3, 7, 729419) Such was the situation then, and having left the College, I did not know what to do.
('28', 316, 3, 8, 729504) Fortunately, in May 1921, my uncle gave me wood for twenty charkhas, some cotton and twenty rupees to do khaddar business.
('28', 316, 3, 9, 729627) With the help of a carpenter, I made charkhas out of the wood and distributed about four of them to the Panchamas.
('28', 316, 3, 10, 729742) With these five
('28', 316, 4, 11, 729758) charkhas I began the work, and now the spinning wheels working under my supervision are about four hundred.
('28', 316, 4, 12, 729866) Till two months ago, the process of my khaddar business was buying cotton, getting it done into slivers by pinjarees,
('28', 316, 5, 13, 729984) distributing the slivers to spinners and, after they spin the yarn, getting the yarn done into cloth by weavers.
('28', 316, 5, 14, 730097) To the spinners and the weavers I was giving wages for their work.
('28', 316, 5, 15, 730164) I had to do thus all these days and whenever I did not or could not get cotton, the spinners and weavers had to suffer and so they had always to depend upon me or someone like me.
('28', 316, 5, 16, 730344) After struggling these three years in khaddar business, I along with Mr. Ponniah, who is doing the same business at Nagalapuram in Kurnool District, had to think out some other scheme of doing khaddar business by which the spinners and weavers would not suffer for want of helpers (khaddar workers) like us.
('28', 316, 5, 17, 730652) We, after three years experience, found from the village people how thirty or forty years ago the spinners used to preserve their own cotton, make it into yarn, sell yarn made into warps of 15 cubits and 5 panjams (each punjam consists of sixty threads)
('28', 316, 6, 18, 730906) at the rate of eight warps per rupee, and how the weavers used to buy yarn from them, make it into cloth and sell the cloth to buyers.
('28', 316, 6, 19, 731041) This done, the spinners do not suffer for want of mediators like us and, if there could be people to buy all the cloth that the weavers make, there would be no difficulty at all.
('28', 316, 6, 20, 731220) For two months Mr. Ponniah at Nagalapuram and myself here are trying to bring this process into working order and to the great relief of us and the people, we have almost succeeded.
('28', 316, 6, 21, 731402) The writer gives further details of his interesting work into which I need not go.
('28', 316, 6, 22, 731485) There is sufficient in the foregoing to show what a silent revolution khaddar is working in the economic life of the nation.
('28', 317, 0, 1, 731610) 318 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 317, 1, 2, 731652) Here are a few extracts from a report from the Bijapur district.
('28', 317, 2, 3, 731717) From Bilgi we went to Badgi.
('28', 317, 2, 4, 731746) We had come to this village in Febru ary 1923. Then there were only 10 or 15 charkhas working and no looms.
('28', 317, 2, 5, 731854) The villagers have been quick in seeing the benefits of khadi.
('28', 317, 2, 6, 731917) Now there are nearly 90 charkhas working.
('28', 317, 2, 7, 731959) Being tired of the inconveniences of getting khadi woven by outside weavers, they have got a weaver from Nagral.
('28', 317, 2, 8, 732072) He has started 2 looms at Badgi and will start 2 more within the next fortnight.
('28', 317, 2, 9, 732153) One or two of the villagers are learning weaving at the Nagral weavers.
('28', 317, 2, 10, 732225) The villagers are not in a mood to sell their yarn.
('28', 317, 2, 11, 732277) They have determined to get it woven for their own use and will sell only the surplus.
('28', 317, 2, 12, 732364) We arranged a spinning competition among
('28', 317, 3, 13, 732405) the village spinners.
('28', 317, 3, 14, 732427) Twenty charkhas were merrily running for more than an hour.
('28', 317, 3, 15, 732487) The yarn spun was uniform and ranged from 15 to 20 counts.
('28', 317, 3, 16, 732546) We gave prizes to some 10 ladies as a token of our happiness.
('28', 317, 3, 17, 732608) So long there were no spinners among the Mahars there.
('28', 317, 3, 18, 732663) At our exhortation a Mahar woman showed
('28', 317, 4, 19, 732703) her readiness to spin.
('28', 317, 4, 20, 732726) She brought her broken wheel to the Congress Committee which will forthwith repair the charkha and supply slivers and a spindle to the enthusiastic spinner.
('28', 317, 4, 21, 732883) I hope Badgi will be a model village in respect of khadi.
('28', 317, 4, 22, 732941) Much depends on the local workers.
('28', 317, 5, 23, 732976) From Gani I proceeded to Bidri.
('28', 317, 5, 24, 733008) This village has been foremost in spinning work ever since the beginning.
('28', 317, 5, 25, 733082) The yarn is fine and also spun in great quantities.
('28', 317, 5, 26, 733134) I visited nearly 50 houses and every house had got 2 to 4 charkhas, i.e., as many as there are adult ladies in the house.
('28', 317, 5, 27, 733256) One old woman said that she had been maintaining herself on spinning for the last two years.
('28', 317, 5, 28, 733349) There are nearly 250 charkhas working.
('28', 317, 5, 29, 733388) They store their own cotton and sell
('28', 317, 6, 30, 733425) the yarn.
('28', 317, 6, 31, 733435) Khadi producers from Bijapur, Jamakhandi, etc., purchase the yarn from this place.
('28', 317, 6, 32, 733518) The local khadi worker supported by the Congress committee has been asked to prepare dhotis for the Congress Committee.
('28', 317, 6, 33, 733638) There is great promise of work in the village and also in three or four villages round this place.
('28', 317, 7, 34, 733737) From Bidri I went to Devargannur on the 19th.
('28', 317, 7, 35, 733783) We had visited this place in February 1923. There were only 10 charkhas working then.
('28', 317, 7, 36, 733869) Now at least 100 charkhas are working and the families are getting their yarn woven into cloth for themselves.
('28', 317, 7, 37, 733980) The surplus yarn, if any, will be sold to the local Congress khadi workers.
('28', 317, 7, 38, 734056) We arranged a spinning competition here.
('28', 317, 7, 39, 734097) It was a happy sight to see 25 village ladies, young and old, rich and poor, spinning their hardest for one whole hour.
('28', 317, 7, 40, 734217) We gave prizes to the ladies.
('28', 317, 7, 41, 734247) A khadi worker disheartened by the lull in the cities should go to such villages to see such competitions to get hope and strength for his work.
('28', 317, 7, 42, 734392) These are examples of paid labour.
('28', 317, 7, 43, 734427) When, in terms of the
('28', 318, 0, 1, 734449) VOL.28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15 AUGUST, 1924 319
('28', 318, 1, 2, 734491) A.I.C.C. resolution, the chosen representatives of the Congress and others begin to spin as part of national duty, there will be no lull in the cities either.
('28', 318, 1, 3, 734650) The latter will be, as they ought to be, an extension of the village life, and not as they now arealmost foreign growths blighting and sapping the healthy life of the villagers.

('28', 318, 2, 5, 734851) 171. A PLEA FOR MILLS
('28', 318, 3, 6, 734873) A correspondent writes:
('28', 318, 4, 7, 734897) According to you charkha and spinning wheel are the best means of winning swaraj.
('28', 318, 4, 8, 734979) It is impossible to dispute your noble intentions or self sacri fice, but it is not understood why you fail to realize that, by insisting on the wholesale adoption of khaddar, you will be putting a large number of mill owners and a considerably larger number of shareholders to terrible loss and distress, for, whereas the former have expended huge sums of money on mills, the latterof whom there are very many of even below passable competencehave sunk their all in mill shares in the earnest hope of eking out a comfortable living with the decent dividends would realize, having been emboldened by the prosperity of the mills.
('28', 318, 4, 9, 735608) Thus, while you hope to bring prosperity to a very large number of lower orders who know no respectability and can in any way make both ends meet, you will doubtless be bringing ruin to an equally large or at least a very considerable number of high and middle class men.
('28', 318, 4, 10, 735880) 2. As a great mahatma imbued with the most disinterested and sympa thetic feelings towards mankind at large, it behoves you to hold the scales even and to exercise your best intellect in striking a middle course so as, on the one hand, to encourage charkha and spinning wheel to a reasonable extent and, on the other, to help the mill owners and the huge body of shareholders.
('28', 318, 4, 11, 736257) 3. By all means boycott foreign cloth, but allow the optional use of mill cloth and khaddar.
('28', 318, 4, 12, 736350) You will thereby be helping many a high and middle class man.
('28', 318, 4, 13, 736412) This is a pathetic letter.
('28', 318, 4, 14, 736439) I wish the correspondents fears were realized.
('28', 318, 4, 15, 736486) Then he will discover that the impending ruin of mills and shareholders of mills would be the time of their own and Indias salvation.
('28', 318, 4, 16, 736620) He will discover then that India will be pulsating with a new life and the middle class will be drawing their sustenancenot as now from a starving peasantry, but from prosperous farmers who would gladly exchange their produce for things they need but cannot themselves manufacture.
('28', 318, 4, 17, 736902) A little reflection will enable the corres 
('28', 319, 0, 1, 736946) 320 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 319, 1, 2, 736988) pondent to realize that he and the rest of the shareholders as well as directors of mills will have to co operate with the people before the spinning wheel is so well established as to oust the mills.
('28', 319, 1, 3, 737189) Let the correspondent derive consolation from the fact that the spinn ing wheel has to displace nearly sixty crores worth of foreign cloth before it can touch the Indian mill cloth.
('28', 319, 1, 4, 737371) But for reasons I have stated in these pages, every one of us must simply think of khaddar to the exclusion of even Indian mill cloth.
('28', 319, 1, 5, 737506) Our mills need no patronage from anyone else.
('28', 319, 1, 6, 737552) They have their own agencies and peculiar methods of advertising their wares.
('28', 319, 1, 7, 737630) For those who are within the Congress beat to have the option of using mill spun is to kill the khaddar industry.
('28', 319, 1, 8, 737744) Khaddar needs all the protection that can be given to it before it can produce an impression upon the market.
('28', 319, 1, 9, 737854) So much for the consolation of the correspondent or those who think like him.
('28', 319, 1, 10, 737932) May I, however, remind him that, if the letter were not written in ignorant fear of consequences to the mills and the middle class, it would be considered a heartless performance?
('28', 319, 1, 11, 738112) What does the correspondent mean when he refers to lower orders who know no respectability and can in any way make both ends meet? Is he sure that lower orders know no respectability? Have they no feelings, are they not injured by an angry word?
('28', 319, 1, 12, 738358) In what sense are they lower except in their poverty, for which we, the middle class, are respon sible?
('28', 319, 1, 13, 738462) And may I inform the correspondent that the lower orders not only do not make the two ends meet, but the majority of them are living in a state of semistar vation?
('28', 319, 1, 14, 738626) If the middle class people voluntarily suffer losses for the sake of the lower classes, it would be but tardy reparation for their participation in their exploitation.
('28', 319, 1, 15, 738794) It is this arrogation of superiority and consequent callousness to the sufferings of the so called lower classes that keeps us from swaraj and that retards the progress of the life giving charkha.
('28', 319, 1, 16, 738991) I invite the corres pondent to think in terms of the masses and, by taking to the charkha, identify himself with his less fortunate countrymen.
('28', 319, 1, 17, 739135) Lastly, let the correspondent remember that, if I may be advised on the ground of my broad humanity to be tender to our mills at the expense of the lower classes, I must also be urged, as I have been by other friends to be tender to foreign mills for the same reasons.
('28', 319, 1, 18, 739404) But if it is true, as it is true, that foreign mills have destroyed the prosperity of the masses, the consideration of humanity demands that the masses should be taught to revert to the charkha even though
('28', 320, 0, 1, 739610) VOL.28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15 AUGUST, 1924 321
('28', 320, 1, 2, 739652) foreign mill owners may suffer.
('28', 320, 1, 3, 739684) Even so must indigenous mills suffer, if need be, for the sake of those on whose poverty their fortunes are built.
('28', 320, 1, 4, 739799) If an enterprising baker puts up cheap bakeries in our villages so as to replace household kitchens, the whole nation, I hope, will rise against such an enterprise.
('28', 320, 1, 5, 739964) The reason for the opposition would be the same as the reason for my opposition to the mills when they come in conflict with the interest of the masses.

('28', 320, 2, 7, 740140) 172. DEPRIVED OF HIS RIGHT
('28', 320, 3, 8, 740167) Mr. Jamaluddin Mukhmoor writes:
('28', 320, 4, 9, 740199) At the last municipal election held in the month of November 1923, the Extra Assistant Commissioner, Merwara, who acted as the Polling Officer, most autocratically rejected my name from the Beawar municipal electoral roll on the ground of my conviction under section 108 Criminal Procedure Code for the period of 6 months.
('28', 320, 4, 10, 740522) He passed the order in the month of October 1923 and, since it was appealable, I appealed to the Commissioner on the 10th October.
('28', 320, 4, 11, 740653) For one month complete silence was assumed.
('28', 320, 4, 12, 740697) In the meantime, 26th of November was fixed for recording the votes.
('28', 320, 4, 13, 740766) Consequently, on the 20th November, I sent a reminder to the Commissioner and a registered notice to the Extra Assistant Commis sioner, Merwara, to stop the further proceedings till the final decision of my appeal.
('28', 320, 4, 14, 740981) No heed was paid and the election carried on the same day.
('28', 320, 4, 15, 741040) Since then I had been waiting for the reply from the Commissioners office and only today, 10th July, the following communique
('28', 320, 5, 16, 741166) has been received by me:
('28', 320, 6, 17, 741191) With reference to his letter No.
('28', 320, 6, 18, 741224) 117/J dated the 22nd June 1924, Mr. Jamaluddin is informed that the order by which his name was omitted from the Beawar municipal electoral roll was revised by the Commis sioner, who directed that his name might be entered, but as this order was only passed on the 26th November 1923, it could not be communicated in time to enable the applicant to exercise the privilege of voting.
('28', 320, 6, 19, 741607) This is like sending a reprieve after hanging.
('28', 320, 6, 20, 741654) The right of voting at the present moment may not be of much consequence.
('28', 320, 6, 21, 741728) But when people become alive to their rights, one vote is enough to turn the scales on momentous occasions.
('28', 320, 6, 22, 741836) Mr. Jamaluddin is entitled to an explanation of the extraordinary delay in a matter that required no prolonged investigation and when the Commissioner must have known that the elections were pending.
('28', 320, 6, 23, 742036) For me the incident furnishes
('28', 321, 0, 1, 742066) 322 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 321, 1, 2, 742108) an additional cause for non co operation.
('28', 321, 1, 3, 742150) I look upon all such official acts with considerable suspicion.
('28', 321, 1, 4, 742214) They betray contempt of popular opinion and rights.
('28', 321, 1, 5, 742266) That people may not have an immediate remedy against the abuse is to me no reason for associating directly or indirectly with the authorities in conducting Indian administration in utter defiance of public opinion.

('28', 324, 1, 2, 748423) 175. QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
('28', 324, 2, 3, 748450) A friend who is a student of non co operation has asked me some questions which I reproduce here as they are of interest to many:
('28', 324, 3, 4, 748580) Q. Our opposition is directed not against individuals but against a system.
('28', 324, 3, 5, 748656) Then what does system meanmobilization, tradition or culture?
('28', 324, 4, 6, 748718) A. Certainly, it is not mobilization.
('28', 324, 4, 7, 748756) Tradition, yes; also culture to the extent that it is responsible for tradition.
('28', 324, 5, 8, 748837) Q. In the article entitled Rabbi May in Young India, 1 you write that,
('28', 324, 6, 9, 748908) through the injustice meted out to Sir Sankaran Nair, the wickedness of this regime has been further exposed.
('28', 324, 6, 10, 749018) You write to the members of the Indian national Congress: If the Government courts and schools attract us and yet we oppose them, then our opposition is not against a system but against individuals .
('28', 324, 6, 11, 749218) My swaraj consists in maintaining intact the spirit of our culture .
('28', 324, 7, 12, 749287) Considering these two extracts, we find it suggested in the first that the government is under the control of the whites, while the second one contains a dig at our culture.
('28', 324, 8, 13, 749461) A. That is not so at all.
('28', 324, 8, 14, 749487) Even if there had been an Indian judge in the Sankaran Nair case, he would have dealt him similar injustice.
('28', 324, 8, 15, 749596) Since the judge was a supporter of the present policy of the British Government, he could give no other judgment.
('28', 324, 8, 16, 749710) We in India know from experience that, at critical junctures, we cannot expect justice from Indian judges working under the current administration.
('28', 324, 8, 17, 749858) The fault is not theirs but that of the system.
('28', 324, 8, 18, 749906) An ordinary man cannot transcend his environment.
('28', 324, 8, 19, 749956) He who can transcend it will not work a moment under such an unacceptable system.
('28', 324, 8, 20, 750038) Non co operation teaches us this very principle.
('28', 324, 8, 21, 750087) I have often said that, if the adminis tration is to continue according to the current system, it would be unacceptable to me even if every official is an Indian.
('28', 324, 9, 22, 750250) Q. It is my impression that the scheme of non co operation was devised not to protect our cultureprotection of culture may well be its indirect though, in a sense, very important resultbut to maintain our self respect.
('28', 324, 10, 23, 750469) A. Since the attack on our self respect was obvious, it was more effective to give prominence to it.
('28', 324, 10, 24, 750570) But our self respect was the basis of our culture.
('28', 324, 10, 25, 750621) Now, when we see the danger of fascination exercised by
('28', 324, 11, 26, 750677) 1 Vide Notes, 12 6 1924.
('28', 325, 0, 1, 750702) 326 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 325, 1, 2, 750744) courts, schools, etc., despite the fact that the respect due to us has not been restored as yet, we expose the veiled attack on our culture.
('28', 325, 1, 3, 750885) Such successive arguments, of course, are not deliberately advanced.
('28', 325, 1, 4, 750954) Circumstances give rise to them.
('28', 325, 1, 5, 750987) If we go deep into the subject, we are able to see that words like honour, culture, system, etc., have a close relationship to one another and that all of them have a common origin.
('28', 325, 2, 6, 751169) Q. I am not sure whether there is anything really harmful in Government courts
('28', 325, 3, 7, 751248) and yet I would not lodge there a complaint against my neighbour because they are the
('28', 325, 4, 8, 751334) courts of an alien Government which oppresses us.
('28', 325, 4, 9, 751384) Likewise, he who does not see any
('28', 325, 5, 10, 751418) defect in the present educational system should also boycott it.
('28', 325, 5, 11, 751483) Even if the medicines to be
('28', 325, 6, 12, 751511) had at a Government hospital are very good or even if the police arrangements are
('28', 325, 7, 13, 751593) praiseworthy, the non co operator should not take the benefit of these.
('28', 325, 8, 14, 751665) A. Those who see nothing wrong in the courts and schools except that they are run by an alien Government find it difficult to non co operate.
('28', 325, 8, 15, 751807) What is wrong in these institutions is not their being run by an alien Government, but their being a part of a faulty system.
('28', 325, 8, 16, 751933) But here a definition of system is called for because the questioner has used the word educational system.
('28', 325, 8, 17, 752040) I see defects even in the educa tional system of the Government.
('28', 325, 8, 18, 752105) But that is not the reason for my opposition.
('28', 325, 8, 19, 752151) My opposition is to the system of Government adminis tration.
('28', 325, 8, 20, 752213) It is the system in which the financial interest of the rulers is dominant and in which religion or morality, call it what you will, has a minor place.
('28', 325, 8, 21, 752365) It is the system in which the rulers do not hesitate to employ Dyerism in order to protect their economic interests and are not afraid of committing any sin.
('28', 325, 8, 22, 752523) If the system were not so selfish, there would have been no reason to call the British Government alien.
('28', 325, 8, 23, 752628) The truth of this argument may be tested thus: Suppose this Govern ment feels sorry for the Punjab massacre, stops the import of foreign cloth, encourages khadi, forgoes the income from opium and liquor, reduces its military expenditure by 75 per cent, regards the promotion of Hindu Muslim unity as its duty and respects public opinion in other ways; then who will oppose it?
('28', 325, 8, 24, 753005) And if anyone does so, who will listen to him?
('28', 325, 8, 25, 753052) Even if they are defective in other respects, we shall not boycott the existing courts and schools.
('28', 325, 8, 26, 753152) This kind of selfishness in Government administration or system is at the very basis of modern or Western culture.
('28', 325, 8, 27, 753267) But the Governments Dyerism, etc., which are the manifest results of that culture, are sufficient to rouse opposition even in those who do not wish to think thus deeply over the matter.
('28', 326, 0, 1, 753453) VOL.28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15 AUGUST, 1924 327
('28', 326, 1, 2, 753495) Q. You write: The aim of the Governments policy is to Anglicize us.
('28', 326, 1, 3, 753563) The moment we get Anglicized, our English rulers will hand over the reins of Government to us and accept us as their agents. Have the Englishmen been here with such an unselfish motive?
('28', 326, 1, 4, 753749) They loudly proclaim as a virtue what you regard as a fault in them.
('28', 326, 1, 5, 753818) Will the Englishmen quit if we adopt the European system?
('28', 326, 1, 6, 753876) Even then, how can we become their voluntary agents?
('28', 326, 1, 7, 753929) Do not conflicts arise between England and Germany even though they have a common culture?
('28', 326, 1, 8, 754020) I should say that conflicts arise precisely because their culture is common.
('28', 326, 2, 9, 754097) A. Many issues are involved in this question.
('28', 326, 2, 10, 754143) If we become Anglicized we shall certainly cease to be wearers of khadi.
('28', 326, 2, 11, 754216) Modern culture is, in effect, materialistic and opposed to the claims of atman.
('28', 326, 2, 12, 754296) By becoming Anglicized, we shall be adopting a system of exploiting all others in the world.
('28', 326, 2, 13, 754389) Then we shall be indifferent to the condition of farmers and make brute force the basis of our existence.
('28', 326, 2, 14, 754495) In that case, military expenditure, etc., will remain unchanged.
('28', 326, 2, 15, 754560) If that happens, they will have nothing to say against us.
('28', 326, 2, 16, 754619) When our wants considerably multiply, we shall be Englands biggest customers and, consequently, its willing retailers, that is, agents.
('28', 326, 2, 17, 754755) That England and Germany fought with each other is also a result of that same culture brought about in a different way.
('28', 326, 2, 18, 754875) Both wanted to exploit weak nations and both wanted the largest share; hence the conflict.
('28', 326, 2, 19, 754966) But there is a big difference between that fight and our fight.
('28', 326, 2, 20, 755030) Theirs was a confrontation of equals, so there was no ques tion of self respect.
('28', 326, 2, 21, 755111) We, of course, are conscious of our self res pect every moment.
('28', 326, 2, 22, 755175) Once we adopt the culture of Europe, there will be no possibility of a conflict between Englishmen and us as long as we remain the customers of England.
('28', 326, 2, 23, 755328) Englishmen repeatedly tell us that we are not yet fit to manage our own affairs; this is far from being absolute hypocrisy.
('28', 326, 2, 24, 755452) Many believe and say that as long as our culture remains distinct, we shall not be qualified to carry on Government in accordance with the European system.
('28', 326, 2, 25, 755608) How is it that South Africa, etc., have complete autonomy?
('28', 326, 2, 26, 755667) Observers may see for themselves that since the whites there swear by the same culture, they have become Englands agents.
('28', 326, 2, 27, 755789) England sells its goods through those whites, hence it has no need to post its own men there.
('28', 326, 2, 28, 755883) No one should believe that the same blood flows in their veins.
('28', 326, 2, 29, 755947) If the whites of South Africa would now turn selfless and give first priority to the interests of the Negroes, England would feel embarrassed and worried despite the fact that the former are whites.
('28', 326, 2, 30, 756146) Our experience tells us that, when some

('28', 327, 1, 2, 756228) Englishmen adopt such a selfless attitude, English society boycotts them.

('28', 327, 3, 5, 756353) SHRI INDULALS LETTER
('28', 327, 4, 6, 756374) I believe everyone has read Shri Indulal Yagniks open letter to me.
('28', 327, 4, 7, 756442) One sees clearly the spirit of patriotism in every line of this letter.
('28', 327, 4, 8, 756514) Nowhere can one notice even a shadow of discourtesy.
('28', 327, 4, 9, 756567) One does not like to point out blemishes, if at all there are any, in an article written with such a good intention.
('28', 327, 4, 10, 756684) A feeling persists in my heart that it would be a sin to offer any reply to this letter.
('28', 327, 4, 11, 756773) Is not refraining from reply the perfect answer to it?
('28', 327, 4, 12, 756828) Shri Indulals curiosity is endless.
('28', 327, 4, 13, 756864) He wishes to find out the logical conclusion of every question.
('28', 327, 4, 14, 756928) He is a born soldier and hence out for adventure.
('28', 327, 4, 15, 756978) Just as he wishes to know every thing, he wishes to do everything.
('28', 327, 4, 16, 757045) Because of his excessive attachment to a cause, he does not feel even for a moment that there are things beyond his capacity.
('28', 327, 4, 17, 757171) Can attachment recognize any limit?
('28', 327, 4, 18, 757207) What can attachment not do?
('28', 327, 4, 19, 757235) Hence, instead of setting a limit himself, he has left it to God to do it.
('28', 327, 4, 20, 757310) This is as much a virtue as a weakness.
('28', 327, 4, 21, 757350) In this letter I find him under the influence of both.
('28', 327, 4, 22, 757405) I for one welcome from him such a letter written out of love.
('28', 327, 4, 23, 757467) I take this and similar articles as warnings to me.
('28', 327, 4, 24, 757519) I learn patience from them and I come to understand my limitations.
('28', 327, 4, 25, 757587) It is not that I have given no thought to any of the draw backs or arguments that Shri Indulal has brought to my notice.
('28', 327, 4, 26, 757708) I have politely placed before the people the decision I have reached after full deliberation.
('28', 327, 4, 27, 757802) In this weekly I have already cleared most of the doubts arising therefrom and shall give further clarification as occa sion demands.
('28', 327, 4, 28, 757936) Nevertheless, in regard to what I cannot explain, I shall merely say: please find the rest of my explanation in my conduct. HUMOUR A correspondent writes: 1

('28', 329, 5, 27, 763146) EXAGGERATION
('28', 329, 6, 28, 763159) A correspondent writes: 2
('28', 329, 7, 29, 763185) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('28', 329, 7, 30, 763222) 2 The letter is not translated here.
('28', 329, 7, 31, 763259) The correspondent had stated that Gandhiji wished that all should cook and spin for themselves, but had wanted to know whether Gandhiji wanted everyone to be self dependent in respect of all work.
('28', 330, 0, 1, 763456) VOL.28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15 AUGUST, 1924 331
('28', 330, 1, 2, 763498) This is a very illusive argument and hence deserves to be rejected.
('28', 330, 1, 3, 763566) A man is born dependent.
('28', 330, 1, 4, 763591) If he were not born that way, his pride would have no limit.
('28', 330, 1, 5, 763652) Leading an ascetics life is the highest state of dependence, because an ascetic has to live on what others give him.
('28', 330, 1, 6, 763769) This state enables him to secure the freedom of the atman and to realize its identity with the Supreme.
('28', 330, 1, 7, 763873) We may do everything ourselves to avoid giving trouble to others, we may do without a thing which we cannot make, but a man who attempts to do all his work himself merely to prove his claim of self dependence finally ends up as a self willed individual.
('28', 330, 1, 8, 764127) We wish to see the whole of society self suffi cient in the matter of food and clothing.
('28', 330, 1, 9, 764216) People have become dependent on others in regard to cloth and hence they doubt whether they can again become self dependent in that respect.
('28', 330, 1, 10, 764357) So I advise every man and woman to become self dependent in respect of cloth.
('28', 330, 1, 11, 764435) It is likely that society can become self sufficient only after indivi duals become self dependent.
('28', 330, 1, 12, 764535) The attempt to become self dependent in matters other than this will halt the great, universal and essential endeavour in respect of cloth.
('28', 330, 1, 13, 764675) Suppose that we can make for ourselves our own soap, pencils, pens, inkstand, etc., in addition to making cloth, we shall find that only one or two of us can do so; but that will not remove Indias poverty.
('28', 330, 1, 14, 764881) To eradicate Indias poverty, just the opposite course must be adopted.
('28', 330, 1, 15, 764952) That is to say, people must give up all other unnecessary activities and try to make India self sufficient in regard to cloth by spinning with their own hands.
('28', 330, 1, 16, 765112) We have for years been doing wrong in our activities.
('28', 330, 1, 17, 765166) Some say they will deliver India from bondage by starting soap mills, others say they will do so by starting lock factories, or leather works or bamboo mat factories.
('28', 330, 1, 18, 765333) This indicates the mis directed activities of society.
('28', 330, 1, 19, 765388) It is only when we concentrate our minds firmly on one objective and become engrossed in the task of imple menting it that we can achieve swaraj.
('28', 330, 1, 20, 765534) I have found that such an objective is only the spinning wheel activity, and hence I keep on harping on the theme.
('28', 330, 1, 21, 765649) Hitherto no one has been able to point out to me any other activity comparable to it.

('28', 331, 5, 9, 766244) 178. NEW TYPE OF SPINNING WHEEL
('28', 331, 6, 10, 766276) We find a note on a new type of spinning wheel in the news papers of Bombay.
('28', 331, 6, 11, 766353) The Khadi Board has been asked to examine this wheel.
('28', 331, 6, 12, 766407) So far no one has to our knowledge been able to make a spinning wheel capable of turning out yarn with greater ease or of better quality.
('28', 331, 6, 13, 766545) We see several types of spinning wheels with negligible points of difference, but one need not give them any importance.
('28', 331, 6, 14, 766666) I urge every lover of khadi not to buy any new type of spinning wheel which has not been approved by the Khadi Board.
('28', 331, 6, 15, 766784) Many spinning wheels of a new type have proved utterly useless and belied the claims advanced in their behalf.
('28', 331, 6, 16, 766895) As things stand now, we are in a position to say that no one can supersede the old spinning wheel once a few changes are introduced in it.
('28', 331, 6, 17, 767034) It would be, therefore, good if no one goes in for any new type of spinning wheel.
('28', 331, 6, 18, 767117) If someone comes across a miraculous spinning wheel, he should send it to the Khadi Board for inspection.
('28', 331, 6, 19, 767223) He may propagate it or buy it only if the Board has approved of it.

('28', 334, 5, 7, 770850) 183. THE PLIGHT OF TEACHERS
('28', 334, 6, 8, 770878) After describing the declining condition of national schools in a district, where out of fourteen seven have died out and the rest are sinking, and where attendance is reduced from 2,000 to 500, the headmaster of one of them writes:
('28', 334, 7, 9, 771111) To be frank, the hearts of many of us, teachers of the national schools, sink when they think of their half starved families and their crushing debts, and misgivings arise as to whether it is wise or foolish for a man embarrassed with debts to undergo so much suffering and whether it is advisable or not to serve the country in other ways than as starving schoolmasters, I should mention here that some of these teachers gave up at the call of their country much more lucrative situation.
('28', 334, 7, 10, 771601) This tale of woe need not frighten us.
('28', 334, 7, 11, 771640) Nations are made after much travail.
('28', 334, 7, 12, 771677) Either we must die like flies in an armed rebellion, then submit to military autocracy and, in the distant and dim future, hope to have democratic rule; or by patient, natural, unperceived suffering evolve as a self ruling, self respecting nation.
('28', 334, 7, 13, 771925) It is by sufferings such as the correspondent describes that we shall find a remedy for the difficulties that face us.
('28', 334, 7, 14, 772044) These constitute the real training in swaraj.
('28', 334, 7, 15, 772090) The fault is not wholly the parents.
('28', 334, 7, 16, 772127) It is in our surroundings.
('28', 334, 7, 17, 772154) We have not yet learnt the virtue of sustained work in defiance of all odds.
('28', 334, 7, 18, 772231) Teachers are the centre round whom the whole of the national edu cation system must revolve.
('28', 334, 7, 19, 772324) If they lose their balance, the system must topple.
('28', 334, 7, 20, 772376) But the teachers have been inexperienced.
('28', 334, 7, 21, 772418) They have not all had the unquenchable fire for keeping alive the taste for national education.
('28', 334, 7, 22, 772514) They have not the organizing ability, nor the power of concentration and consecration.
('28', 334, 7, 23, 772601) Everywhere the workers, instead of specializing in one branch of service, have dabbled in everything with
('28', 334, 8, 24, 772707) 1 Vide Religion on Trial, 27 7 1924.
('28', 335, 0, 1, 772744) 336 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 335, 1, 2, 772786) the result that they have been able to do nothing thoroughly.
('28', 335, 1, 3, 772848) But this was inevitable.
('28', 335, 1, 4, 772873) We are new to the game.
('28', 335, 1, 5, 772897) Our rulers have trained us as clerks and put us to work requiring little thinking and less initiative.
('28', 335, 1, 6, 773000) But the old order is changing.
('28', 335, 1, 7, 773031) In the first flush of enthusiasm we seemed to be doing well, if not very well.
('28', 335, 1, 8, 773110) No v that the enthusiasm has died out and the moisture of public support has dried up, only the hardiest plants will survive.
('28', 335, 1, 9, 773236) Let me hope the schools and the schoolmasters that still remain are of the right stuff.
('28', 335, 1, 10, 773324) They must beg from door to door for maintenance and not feel ashamed if they are honest workers.
('28', 335, 1, 11, 773421) The headmaster has asked also specific questions, which being of general utility, I copy and answer below.
('28', 335, 2, 12, 773528) Q. How long can the poor teachers, embarrassed with increasing debts, continue to have connection with these schools working on starvation allowance?
('28', 335, 3, 13, 773678) A. Till death, even as a soldier fights till he is Victorious or, which is the same thing, drops down dead.
('28', 335, 4, 14, 773786) Q. How long will the authorities continue these schools at a great at loss of money, if even I per cent of the people do not want them?
('28', 335, 5, 15, 773922) A. No school has a right to exist if the people do not want it.
('28', 335, 5, 16, 773986) But I would blame the authorities if the people who brought a school into being afterwards do not want it.
('28', 335, 6, 17, 774093) Q. Education can be suspended and workers can suffer for one year or two years or three years, but what will be the case if the fight for swaraj continues for an indefinite period?
('28', 335, 7, 18, 774274) A. Those who can suffer for one to three years will find themselves inured to suffering for thirty years.
('28', 335, 8, 19, 774380) Q. How can the few boys that really want national education read where no national school exists?
('28', 335, 9, 20, 774478) A. If the parents or the boys or girls, for that matter, are resourceful, they will find out a way.
('28', 335, 9, 21, 774578) It is a superstition to think that education can only be had at schools or only through English or in a particular, orthodox style.
('28', 335, 9, 22, 774710) To learn spinning and weaving is an edu cation of first class importance at the present moment.
('28', 335, 9, 23, 774806) Let us also remember that the majority of Indian villages have no schools at all.
('28', 335, 10, 24, 774888) Q. How long should our countrymen be allowed to vote for a resolution which they will never carry out in practice?
('28', 335, 10, 25, 775003) All will vote for boycott of Government schools but very few of these voters will send their boys to national schools.
('28', 335, 11, 26, 775122) A. Not one minute longer than I can help.
('28', 335, 11, 27, 775164) All my fight in the A.I.C.C. was directed towards our being true to our resolutions.
('28', 336, 0, 1, 775249) VOL.28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15 AUGUST, 1924 337
('28', 336, 1, 2, 775291) I know that the replies I have given will be considered unsatisfactory by many.
('28', 336, 1, 3, 775371) But I dare say that they are the only correct and practical answers.
('28', 336, 1, 4, 775440) We must do away with camouflage.
('28', 336, 1, 5, 775473) If the nation as a whole does not want national schools in answer to the boycott of (not supplementary to) Government schools, it must be altered.
('28', 336, 1, 6, 775620) The minority that may still want the boycott must make good their desire by running their own national schools, but not under the Congress aegis.
('28', 336, 1, 7, 775766) These schools will be run only where they are wanted.
('28', 336, 1, 8, 775820) If there be only one such school, it will continue without being disheartened.
('28', 336, 1, 9, 775899) Faith knows no disappointment.

('28', 336, 6, 15, 776281) The Khadi Board continues to receive queries as to the use to be made of the yarn that is to be delivered to it by Congress represen tatives.
('28', 336, 6, 16, 776423) In accordance with the Congress resolution, every represen tative has to send at least 2,000 yards of well twisted, even yarn per month.
('28', 336, 6, 17, 776560) It is in the nature of a subscription.
('28', 336, 6, 18, 776599) But all kinds of questions are being raised.
('28', 336, 6, 19, 776644) Some members want to keep the yarn themselves and have it woven for personal wear.
('28', 336, 6, 20, 776727) It is an excellent idea but, at the present moment, I would suggest suppression of that desire.
('28', 336, 6, 21, 776823) The efficacy of any programme depends upon uniformity and punctuality and the magnitude of execution.
('28', 336, 6, 22, 776925) It is the volume that counts.
('28', 336, 6, 23, 776955) But the volume is impossible if each member wants to act according to his own wish.

('28', 338, 2, 6, 780274) 186. A GLOOMY PICTURE
('28', 338, 3, 7, 780296) A Mussalman correspondent writes thus feelingly from Amritsar:
('28', 338, 4, 8, 780359) The free fights between Hindus and Mussalmans in Upper India which have become almost a daily occurrence indicate the complete inability of the two slave nations to find a solution of their domestic problems, more so their inability to assume responsibility of governing a vast country composed of many heterogeneous elements.
('28', 338, 5, 9, 780686) Your efforts at bridging the gulf were no doubt successful, but the warring elements reappeared soon after your incarceration.
('28', 338, 5, 10, 780813) Where before your incarceration there existed fellow feeling and sympathy between the two for their having been long neighbours, today there is disunion and discord.
('28', 338, 5, 11, 780979) All the big towns of the Punjab are cockpits for both the nations and there appears to be no prospect of the old relations ever being restored.
('28', 338, 6, 12, 781123) Will you please think out a remedy before the disease becomes incurable?
('28', 338, 6, 13, 781196) Please do come to the Punjab and see things for yourself Your zest for khaddar is useless unless and until you have restored the old conditions.
('28', 338, 6, 14, 781341) Amritsar which saw the glorious days of 1919 is today a picture of gloom.
('28', 338, 6, 15, 781415) Out of nearly two hundred thousand people hardly 50 would be found wearing khadi, and even these do so because they must, holding as they do Congress offices.
('28', 338, 6, 16, 781574) All this is due to the Hindu Muslim tension.
('28', 338, 6, 17, 781619) Remove tile curse and everything will be all right.
('28', 338, 6, 18, 781671) Alas, the foundation of sangthan was laid at a
('28', 338, 7, 19, 781718) most inauspicious moment.
('28', 338, 7, 20, 781744) There is no doubt that the picture given by the correspondent is exaggerated.
('28', 338, 7, 21, 781822) If there are free fights between Hindus and Mussalmans daily in the Punjab, it must be a most difficult place to live in today.
('28', 338, 7, 22, 781950) But I have no doubt that at least outwardly the Punjab is as peaceful as any other province in India.
('28', 338, 7, 23, 782052) Nor is the correspondent correct when he lays everything at the door of the sangathan.
('28', 338, 7, 24, 782139) It has no doubt aggravated the disease which was already there.
('28', 338, 7, 25, 782203) Both the communities have lost their balance.
('28', 339, 0, 1, 782249) 340 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 339, 1, 2, 782291) If the Punjabis have given up khaddar because of the tension, their love of khaddar or of the country could only be skin deep.
('28', 339, 1, 3, 782418) But as I do not think that they have less love of the country than the others, the cause of the decline of khaddar must be sought elsewhere.
('28', 339, 1, 4, 782559) The obvious cause lies in the want of faith in the necessity of khaddar for swaraj and the desire for the soft life which the muslin and the calico denote.
('28', 339, 1, 5, 782715) Of all the provinces, the Punjab is today able to carry out the boycott of foreign cloth if it wishes.
('28', 339, 1, 6, 782818) But it does not.
('28', 339, 1, 7, 782835) I have heard it said that many Hindus decline to wear khaddar because it is woven by the Mussalman weavers and the Mussalmans refuse to wear it because they say they are not interested in swaraj; they want to drive away the English but they want to revive the old Mussalman rule.
('28', 339, 1, 8, 783115) And it is contended the old Mussalman rule cannot be revived if the charkha binds both Hindus and Mussalmans to a common ideal.
('28', 339, 1, 9, 783243) These I regard as vapourings of heated brains.
('28', 339, 1, 10, 783290) The poor Hindus and the poor Mussalmans have no time to think of the things mentioned above.
('28', 339, 1, 11, 783383) They will gladly add a few rupees to their annual income which spinning does.
('28', 339, 1, 12, 783461) Apart, however, from the decline of the khaddar and from the exaggerations of the correspondent, the seriousness of the tension cannot be denied, The break down at Delhi of the authority of the leaders is too glaring to be slurred over.
('28', 339, 1, 13, 783698) Fortunately, there are already indications of reviving sanity.
('28', 339, 1, 14, 783761) The Jats and the butchers are reported to have realized the folly of breaking one anothers heads and to have made peace.
('28', 339, 1, 15, 783882) But the most hopeful news comes from correspondents who tell me that, if there were frenzied men bent on slaughter, there were also sane men and women bent on saving.
('28', 339, 1, 16, 784049) These instances are not isolated but suffi ciently numerous to show that love of peace was at least as keen between the two communities as the love of war.
('28', 339, 1, 17, 784205) The latter is not natural.
('28', 339, 1, 18, 784232) It is like a carbuncle.
('28', 339, 1, 19, 784256) But peace persists.
('28', 339, 1, 20, 784276) The two sections have simply to make up their minds to respect each others religious customs and the rest will be easy.
('28', 339, 1, 21, 784396) So far as asking me to go to the Punjab is concerned, it is an open secret that I am pining to go there as well as the other places where tension exists.
('28', 339, 1, 22, 784550) The spirit is willing, the flesh alone is weak.
('28', 339, 1, 23, 784598) As soon as I can undertake travels with any degree of safety, I propose in the company of Maulana Shaukat Ali to visit Sand and the Punjab.

('28', 340, 1, 2, 784803) 187. AFFLICTED SOUTH
('28', 340, 2, 3, 784824) The monsoons are playing an exasperating trick.
('28', 340, 2, 4, 784872) The South is submerged and the North is pining for the rains.
('28', 340, 2, 5, 784934) There is a heart rending wire from South Canara which says: Devastating floods again.
('28', 340, 2, 6, 785020) Forty feet above normal.
('28', 340, 2, 7, 785045) River level only four feet below last years. Then follows a detailed account of families rendered home less; people fleeing terror struck in all directions.
('28', 340, 2, 8, 785202) The volunteers were hoping that the relief work done by them after last years floods would put the starving families on their feet again.
