('28', 340, 3, 16, 785774) 188. WAR AGAINST OPIUM
('28', 340, 4, 17, 785797) The White Cross is an international anti narcotic society whose headquarters are in Washington.
('28', 340, 4, 18, 785893) It appears to have branches all over the world.
('28', 340, 4, 19, 785941) Its letter head contains distinguished names as trustees or standing council.
('28', 340, 4, 20, 786019) Its executive secretary, Mr. McKibben, writes a long letter urging me to secure Indias co operation in the White Cross crusade against opium.
('28', 340, 4, 21, 786161) I cull the following passages from the letter:
('28', 340, 5, 22, 786208) The people of China resisted its invasion in two wars and in 1906 took the first opportunity in a century and a half to gain deliverance by pulling up or ploughing under the poppy on millions of acres.
('28', 340, 5, 23, 786410) So long and so binding had been their enslavement that it was predicted that at any attempt to take opium away the Chinese people would rise in insurrection.
('28', 340, 5, 24, 786568) Spence, an English writer, said in 1882 that revolution would result if the Chinese Government would undertake suppression of the growth of the poppy, the quiet seaports would be turned into hell, streets would run with blood. So far were these dire forecasts from coming true that no action of the Chinese Government was ever so popular as its determined and successful campaign for poppy destruction.

('28', 341, 1, 2, 787168) became a fervent, sweeping, religious movement.

('28', 347, 2, 3, 802385) Under the above heading, the indefatigable Mr. B. F. Bharucha has issued a report of his tour in Bengal.
('28', 347, 2, 4, 802490) It is a business like and instructive document.
('28', 347, 2, 5, 802538) I pass by the paragraph bemoaning the fact that, had the Ahmedabad mills not played false during the Partition days, Bengal would today be wholly swadeshi; also the fact that, at Serajganj Swadeshi Exhibition, the khadi was bastard khadi except at Dr. P. C. Rays stall.
('28', 347, 2, 6, 802808) I pass by Mr. Bharuchas appeal to Deshbandhu Das ask ing him to insist upon his Satyagrahis wearing khaddar and to set apart a number of workers for pure khaddar organization.
('28', 347, 2, 7, 802984) But I must let Mr. Bharucha speak in his own enthusiastic manner of the splendid work being done by Dr. Ray and his able lieutenant, Babu Satis Chandra Dasgupta:
('28', 347, 3, 8, 803146) Dr. P. C. Ray is the Apostle of charkha in Bengal.
('28', 347, 3, 9, 803197) Despite a weak frame and poor health, this old Professor of Chemistry is crossing fields and flooded areas to save the Bengal farmer from the ravages of famine and flood.
('28', 347, 3, 10, 803368) And his panacea today is rot any Western mechanism, nor Western preparation.
('28', 347, 3, 11, 803445) It is the ancient and universal cottage wheel, the charkha.
('28', 347, 3, 12, 803505) In the flooded areas of
('28', 347, 4, 13, 803529) Rajshahi, etc., Dr. Ray has saved the starving people by reviving the charkha, and by popularizing khaddar.
('28', 347, 4, 14, 803637) Besides that, he started the Khaddar Board, the Khadi Pratishthan and the Deshi Rang.
('28', 347, 4, 15, 803723) Fund to carry on the khaddar propaganda in Bengal.

('28', 347, 4, 17, 803854) He has been having a fairly large stock of khaddar, and unless this is sold off regularly, it will be very difficult for old Dr. Ray to keep all the charkhas going.
('28', 347, 4, 18, 804019) The revered Acharya went on his knees at the Serajganj Khaddar Exhibition, and begged of the audience to buy khadi.
('28', 347, 4, 19, 804135) Will not Bengalpatriotic, sensitive, swadeshi Bengalrespond to the clarion call of her devoted son: Buy khadi and keep the charkhas going? Dr. Ray has given away even his savings (Rs. 40,000/ ), for khadi work.
('28', 347, 4, 20, 804346) Verily he is the Apostle of khaddar in Bengal.
('28', 347, 5, 21, 804393) I shall now give some glimpses of the spinning and weaving centres visited by me.
('28', 347, 5, 22, 804475) They are Atrai, Raninagar, Talora and Sukhia (Chittagong).
('28', 347, 5, 23, 804534) At Atrai they (Dr. Ray and Satish Babu) run a school for ginning, carding, spinning, dyeing and weaving.
('28', 347, 5, 24, 804639) They also have a dispensary and a small hospital which is a real boon to villagers.
('28', 347, 5, 25, 804723) Atrai is the base where they stock kapas and
('28', 347, 6, 26, 804768) distribute it in surrounding villages for ginning, carding spinning and weaving.
('28', 347, 6, 27, 804849) Atrai had an old silk industry, which was practically killed by the East India Company.
('28', 347, 6, 28, 804937) Here we saw the charkhas plying again; and the yarn was good.

('28', 348, 0, 1, 805070) VOL.28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15 AUGUST, 1924 349
('28', 348, 1, 2, 805112) charkha very well.
('28', 348, 1, 3, 805131) At Raninagar we saw the handlooms working.
('28', 348, 1, 4, 805174) Whilst it was pleasant to see them running, it was painful to see the weavers clad in foreign cloth, and worse still, making their own clothes from mill or foreign yarn!
('28', 348, 1, 5, 805344) They promised to discontinue this.
('28', 348, 1, 6, 805379) At Talora, we saw the spinning and weaving centres.
('28', 348, 1, 7, 805431) At all these places, there was much enthusiasm for the charkha and the loom.
('28', 348, 1, 8, 805508) Even girls of seven and eight could spin so well.

('28', 348, 1, 13, 805925) He has standardized the gin, the carding bow, and the charkha.

('28', 348, 2, 29, 807009) Nay, they are welcomed even by the purdah women.
('28', 348, 2, 30, 807058) They give the cotton, take yarn, pay charges, and write up the spinners a/c card.
('28', 348, 2, 31, 807140) They repair the charkhas, give some help or instruction to that need it, and thus are means of supplementing the familys income.
('28', 348, 2, 32, 807269) The weavers usually call at the centre for yarn, deliver khadi, get the charges and take away further quantity of yarn.
('28', 348, 2, 33, 807389) They have their cards also, and these are regularly written up.
('28', 348, 2, 34, 807453) The workers return in the evening after their village rounds, and it is a sight to see them toiling in scorching sun or heavy rain, and yet all cheerful!
('28', 348, 2, 35, 807607) Satish Babu has not only put his heart and soul into the khadi work; he has even given away [rupees] three thousand at the start and rupees six thousand in June last for khadi work, and he is not a rich man.
('28', 348, 2, 36, 807815) Satish Babu has prepared slides for khadi propaganda.
('28', 348, 2, 37, 807869) He has written a book, with telling illustrations.
('28', 348, 2, 38, 807920) May God bless pioneers and workers like Dr. P. C. Ray and his able lieutenant, Babu Satish Chandra Dasgupta!
('28', 348, 2, 39, 808029) I join mine with Mr. Bharuchas Amen.
('28', 349, 0, 1, 808066) 350 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 349, 1, 2, 808108) Mr. Bharucha is equally enthusiastic about the ability of the charkha to bring the Hindus and the Muslims together.
('28', 349, 1, 3, 808224) Here is his paragraph:
('28', 349, 2, 4, 808247) In Bengal all the volunteers and the workers of the Bengal Relief Committee khadi work, of the Khadi Board, the Khadi Prathishthan, and Deshi Rang Fund are almost all Hindus.
('28', 349, 2, 5, 808422) And the largest numbers of those who take the benefit of these institutions are Muslims.
('28', 349, 2, 6, 808511) These Hindu workers walk miles from their centres, and carry kapas or cotton to Muslim hamlets.
('28', 349, 2, 7, 808607) They weigh
('28', 349, 3, 8, 808618) the spun yarn, and pay for it; they repair the charkhas, supply parts, prepare the spinners a/c, and give kapas or cotton as required.
('28', 349, 3, 9, 808753) They (the Hindus) thus
('28', 349, 4, 10, 808776) render such splendid brotherly service to their Muslim sisters.
('28', 349, 4, 11, 808840) There is such regard and respect between the Hindu workers and Muslim spinners, weavers, and their families, that none can ever perceive or feel that they are divided by their religions.
('28', 349, 4, 12, 809027) They talk and act as though they are of one raceBengali and of one brotherhoodof humanity.
('28', 349, 4, 13, 809118) Verily, if the charkha is pushed on in other parts of the country as assiduously and amiably as is done by Satish Babus boys, much of the present tension amongst Hindus and Muslims will diminish, and Heaven helping, will vanish.
('28', 349, 5, 14, 809347) OVER PRODUCTION?
('28', 349, 6, 15, 809364) The reader will have noticed in Mr. Bharuchas report Dr. Rays difficulty in finding purchasers for his khadi.
('28', 349, 6, 16, 809474) The same complaint is lodged by Dr. Hardikar from Karnatak.
('28', 349, 6, 17, 809534) I have already referred in an early issue to the stock lying idle in the Punjab.
('28', 349, 6, 18, 809615) As Gujarat must stop buying much from Andhra, even Andhra may complain of over production.
('28', 349, 6, 19, 809706) The same thing applies to almost every khadi producing province.
('28', 349, 6, 20, 809771) And yet the whole stock of khadi throughout India will not be more than twenty lakhs at the outside.
('28', 349, 6, 21, 809872) Compare this with crores of rupees worth of foreign stock.
('28', 349, 6, 22, 809931) Is it not a sad commentary on our work and the patriotism of monied men?
('28', 349, 6, 23, 810004) One millionaire can buy out the whole of the present stock of khadi and sell at cheap rates to the poor.
('28', 349, 6, 24, 810109) Yes, even a patriotic mill owner can do so without hurting himself.
('28', 349, 6, 25, 810177) Tens of thousands of men and women flock to our meetings.
('28', 349, 6, 26, 810235) They can buy up all the khadi in one single day without having to pauperize themselves.
('28', 349, 6, 27, 810323) Public institutions can make their cloth purchases in khadi without losing anything or much.
('28', 349, 6, 28, 810416) Bombay has always been to the fore in such matters.
('28', 349, 6, 29, 810468) If Bombay willed it, its immense population can buy out the present surplus without much hurt to her two million pockets.
('28', 349, 6, 30, 810590) But I do not wish to grumble.
('28', 349, 6, 31, 810620) The fault is not the peoples.
('28', 349, 6, 32, 810650) In any event, it is not yet proved.
('28', 349, 6, 33, 810686) It lies
('28', 350, 0, 1, 810694) VOL.28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15 AUGUST, 1924 351
('28', 350, 1, 2, 810736) at the workers doors.
('28', 350, 1, 3, 810758) We must organize sales as we organize production.
('28', 350, 1, 4, 810808) The formula being each province to sell what it produces.
('28', 350, 1, 5, 810866) At the same time each province must produce to its fullest capacity and send the surplus, if any, to the chief towns such as Bombay, Cal cutta, Madras, etc., which will not themselves be effective producing centres.
('28', 350, 1, 6, 811082) All this means organizing and thinking out.
('28', 350, 1, 7, 811126) Each province must fix its own minimum sales.
('28', 350, 1, 8, 811172) It would not do for spinners and workers of a province themselves to be clad in foreign or mill cloth and send their manufactures for sales.
('28', 350, 1, 9, 811313) The first step towards such organization is undoubtedly the full working of the spinning resolution of the A.I.C.C.
('28', 350, 2, 10, 811429) NON REPRESENTATIVES
('28', 350, 3, 11, 811449) It is, therefore, a matter of joy that the various provinces are endorsing the spinning resolution and organizing spinning in their own provinces.
('28', 350, 3, 12, 811596) Let me hope that no province will be found wanting.
('28', 350, 3, 13, 811648) But I hope no one thinks that, because the spinning reso lution does not apply to him or her, he or she need not spin or send yarn to the All India Khadi Board.
('28', 350, 3, 14, 811809) The resolution is mandatory and the A.I.C.C. cannot issue mandates to the whole nation.
('28', 350, 3, 15, 811897) But if it is obligatory on Congress representatives, it follows that all the other Congress members, i.e., the electors who have paid 4 as.
('28', 350, 3, 16, 812037) and even others should impose the obligation on themselves and make it a point of honour to send as much hand spun yarn as possible to the All India Khadi Board Secretary or to the provincial representative for despatch to the central organization.
('28', 350, 3, 17, 812286) If the whole nation, irrespective of parties, co operates, it will be found that we can banish foreign cloth and with it pauperism from our midst in an incredibly short space of time.
('28', 350, 3, 18, 812470) Nothing is so easy as the organization of this khadi work and if we cannot as a nation organize this simple thing, we shall organize nothing else that is constructive on any large national scale.
('28', 350, 4, 19, 812666) CLOTH OR STEEL
('28', 350, 5, 20, 812681) Acharya Ray has issued a pathetic appeal to the nation.
('28', 350, 5, 21, 812737) He says in effect that, if it is good to pay one crore and a half annually for protecting steel, surely it is infinitely better to protect khadi cloth by paying a much larger bounty.
('28', 350, 5, 22, 812920) Dr. Ray says:
('28', 350, 6, 23, 812934) But of the two industries, cloth and steel, which is of greater importance?
('28', 350, 6, 24, 813010) Our cloth industry died on account of unfair foreign competition.
('28', 350, 6, 25, 813076) If protection is
('28', 351, 0, 1, 813093) 352 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 351, 1, 2, 813135) to be given, which industry has the strongest claim for receiving State protection?
('28', 351, 1, 3, 813219) Our people are in dire want of the primary necessities of life, food and clothes.
('28', 351, 1, 4, 813301) Could not our hand spinning industry be protected by duties, from competition with imported cotton goods?
('28', 351, 1, 5, 813407) But the Government would not do it.
('28', 351, 1, 6, 813443) India cannot do it until she has swaraj.
('28', 351, 1, 7, 813484) What the Government would not do the popular will can accomplish.
('28', 351, 1, 8, 813550) It is for to say that we refuse to wear imported cotton goods.
('28', 351, 1, 9, 813613) It is for we to say that we shall use only hand spun and hand woven khadi and thereby stop a drain of sixty crores of rupees annually.
('28', 351, 1, 10, 813748) It is for us to protect our cloth industry against foreign competition.
('28', 351, 2, 11, 813820) From my experience I can say that hand spinning has come to stay if our countrymen will out of their patriotism bear with coarse product and costlier stuff for only a few years.
('28', 351, 2, 12, 813998) I would ask you who are unconsciously paying one and a half crores to Tata steel, to consciously pay something for revival of an industry in comparison with which even Tatas steel industry is a pigmy.
('28', 351, 2, 13, 814199) Our patriotism must carry us through to success during the earlier days of our struggletill only the infant industry is established on a sure footing.
('28', 351, 3, 14, 814350) OPIUM IN ASSAM
('28', 351, 4, 15, 814365) The opium inquiry committee appointed by the Assam P.C.C. has already commenced work and examined several witnesses at Sibsagar.
('28', 351, 4, 16, 814494) Many witnesses were leading men of the district and chosen from all parties.
('28', 351, 4, 17, 814571) They unanimously advocated total prohibition.
('28', 351, 4, 18, 814617) An experienced witness said that it was a preposterous suggestion that opium has any prophylactic action against kala azar or malaria.
('28', 351, 4, 19, 814752) The largest number of deaths, the witness added, were among opium eaters at Angera Khowa, a village in Sibsagar.
('28', 351, 4, 20, 814865) Some witnesses gave the interesting information that temperance workers were harassed and prosecuted for the offence of asking people not to smoke or eat opium.
('28', 351, 4, 21, 815026) I hope that the committee will not be satisfied with general statements, but will collect comparative statistics about opium culti vation, opium shops, opium dens.
('28', 351, 4, 22, 815190) There should also be medical evi dence as to the effect of opium on the population of Assam.
('28', 351, 4, 23, 815283) There should be evidence showing the effect likely to be produced by complete prohibition of opium.
('28', 351, 4, 24, 815383) The report to be of use must be a veritable mine of information.

('28', 358, 4, 7, 825497) 200. MY NOTES
('28', 358, 5, 8, 825511) ACHARYA RAY SPINS DAILY
('28', 358, 6, 9, 825535) Acharya Ray is now over sixty years old.
('28', 358, 6, 10, 825576) But he has started spinning.
('28', 358, 6, 11, 825605) He writes:
('28', 358, 7, 12, 825616) As a matter of fact, the music of the spinning wheel has proved a solace to my mind.
('28', 358, 7, 13, 825701) My faith in khadi grows day by day, and as my khadi work increases, the spinning wheel has come to be a perennial fountain sustaining my enthusiasm.
('28', 358, 7, 14, 825850) Thus if very busy veterans like Acharya Ray have begun to spin, why should not young men and women with lots of leisure do so too?
('28', 358, 7, 15, 825981) It is easy to understand the source of Acharya Rays enthusiasm.
('28', 358, 7, 16, 826045) For many years he has been at the job of bringing relief to famine stricken people of Bengal.
('28', 358, 7, 17, 826139) He has realized in the course of it that mere charity saps the character of the famine stricken and hence does more harm than good to them.
('28', 358, 7, 18, 826279) What sort of work can be given to thousands of men and Women to enable them to earn their livelihood?
('28', 358, 7, 19, 826381) What else but the spinning wheel can be so all embracing?
('28', 358, 7, 20, 826439) It was not difficult for his keen and well meaning intellect to discover this.
('28', 358, 8, 21, 826518) RESIGNATIONS
('28', 358, 9, 22, 826531) A number of office bearers of the Congress Committee at Hubli have tendered their resignations on account of the A.I.C.C. resolution.
('28', 358, 9, 23, 826665) This situation has frightened some of us, but I regard it as a good omen, because these resignations imply respect for A.I.C.C. resolu tions.
('28', 358, 9, 24, 826807) Those organizations which have no sanctions like the Govern ment depend for their functioning on the respect they command from their members.
('28', 358, 9, 25, 826949) I did know that there were many office bearers who did not believe in the fivefold boycott or who did not practise it.
('28', 358, 9, 26, 827068) Hence, I had suggested a resolution calling on them to quit office.
('28', 358, 9, 27, 827136) If those office bearers have thought it fit to quit and that, too, without any resentment, it will benefit them and the community.
('28', 358, 9, 28, 827267) By taking this
('28', 359, 0, 1, 827282) 360 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 359, 1, 2, 827324) needed step of handing in their resignations, they have proved their own worth and have purified the Committee.
('28', 359, 1, 3, 827436) And yet the public will not be deprived of their services.
('28', 359, 1, 4, 827495) If they have resigned out of anger, they stand to lose, because they are likely to forfeit the love of the people which they have earned.
('28', 359, 1, 5, 827633) But from what I hear, all of them have resigned with goodwill.
('28', 359, 1, 6, 827696) The public will continue to be served by them.
('28', 359, 1, 7, 827743) The good example that Shri Gangadharrao [Deshpande] has set not only to Karnatak but also to the whole of India makes us hope that it will be followed by all those who have resigned and yet continue to serve the public.
('28', 359, 1, 8, 827963) Gujarat, of course, has before it the example of Shri Kalidas Zaveri.
('28', 359, 1, 9, 828033) His resignation does not mean that he will cease to serve the public.
('28', 359, 1, 10, 828103) Those who continue as office bearers in the Congress even though they cannot comply with its resolutions deceive the public and themselves too.
('28', 359, 1, 11, 828247) No organization can ever be run that way.
('28', 359, 1, 12, 828289) How can they who themselves wear foreign cloth get others to boycott it?
('28', 359, 1, 13, 828362) How can those who continue their own legal practice make others give it up?
('28', 359, 1, 14, 828438) How can those who get their own children educated in Government schools conduct national schools?
('28', 359, 1, 15, 828536) If those who believe in the triple boycott and practise it have no capacity to run the Congress organization, of what use will swaraj be?
('28', 359, 1, 16, 828674) And if there is none who can practise the boycott, how can the programme of boycott be allowed to continue even as a sentiment?
('28', 359, 1, 17, 828802) A thing can continue to exist even as a sentiment only if it is practised by a few at any rate.
('28', 359, 1, 18, 828898) Something comes to be fixed as a symbol of sentiment in the hope that some day it will be a reality.
('28', 359, 1, 19, 828999) If no one translates it into action, it will be regarded not as a sentiment but as hypocrisy.
('28', 359, 1, 20, 829093) It is not a small thing that the clearing up that is being done at present rules out hypocrisy; hence, viewing the matter from whatever angle we like, we shall reach only one conclusionthat the A.I.C.C. resolution and the resultant resignations are both to be welcomed.
('28', 359, 2, 21, 829363) WHAT ABOUT TEACHERS?
('28', 359, 3, 22, 829384) But one headmaster of a primary school puts this question to me: What should teachers do when the people in a village do not care for a national school and teachers starve without pay? A very similar question was asked by a Bengali teacher and I have replied to it in Young India 1. Let us consider the question a little further here.
('28', 359, 3, 23, 829719) Abbas Saheb has asked me to consider the question in another way.
('28', 359, 4, 24, 829785) 1 Vide The Plight of Teachers, 24 7 l924.
('28', 360, 0, 1, 829827) VOL.28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15 AUGUST, 1924 361
('28', 360, 1, 2, 829869) He says: There are no schools at all in a number of villages; what should be done in their case?
('28', 360, 1, 3, 829966) The reply to the first difficulty is simple.
('28', 360, 1, 4, 830011) If there is dynamism in the teacher, he will somehow accomplish his work.
('28', 360, 1, 5, 830085) A teacher works like a magnet.
('28', 360, 1, 6, 830116) Children surround him and do not leave him alone even for a moment.
('28', 360, 1, 7, 830184) Separation from the teacher becomes unbearable to the pupils.
('28', 360, 1, 8, 830246) Parents would never forsake such a teacher.
('28', 360, 1, 9, 830290) If a teacher becomes rich, he is looked upon as a dishonest person, and if he starves, he is taken to be dull.
('28', 360, 1, 10, 830401) I advise the teacher correspondent to live by begging from door to door, but not to abandon his duty of teaching.
('28', 360, 1, 11, 830515) Kaka 1 has written somewhere that teaching should not be regarded as a profession.
('28', 360, 1, 12, 830598) That is certainly correct.
('28', 360, 1, 13, 830625) Moreover, education should cost less today.
('28', 360, 1, 14, 830669) Children may study and also earn for their education.
('28', 360, 1, 15, 830723) In olden times it used to be exactly so.
('28', 360, 1, 16, 830764) A pupil used to go to a teacher with sacrificial fuel in his hand.
('28', 360, 1, 17, 830831) This had two meanings.
('28', 360, 1, 18, 830854) One, that it amounted to taking a vow that he would not be a burden on his preceptor, but would work to maintain his guru and himself.
('28', 360, 1, 19, 830989) The second implication was that a pupil would ever be courteous.
('28', 360, 1, 20, 831054) There is need of both these things even today.
('28', 360, 1, 21, 831101) There are elements of both labour and courtesy in the spinning wheel activity.
('28', 360, 1, 22, 831180) The teacher concerned should teach his pupils all the pro cesses in respect of cotton and make them spin beautiful yarn.
('28', 360, 1, 23, 831301) While getting them to spin, he should sit in front of them and himself spin.
('28', 360, 1, 24, 831378) Alongside this he should make them learn multiplication tables, make them memorize Sanskrit declensions, explain the meaning of verses, and narrate good historical stories.
('28', 360, 1, 25, 831551) He should make the pupils spinning activity interesting and instructive.
('28', 360, 1, 26, 831624) When this is done, the children will not feel bored.
('28', 360, 1, 27, 831677) I have proposed the use of takli 2. Its use can ensure rapid performance.
('28', 360, 1, 28, 831751) Now let us consider Abbas Sahebs question.
('28', 360, 1, 29, 831794) The readers of Navajivan may hardly be aware of the fact that, although knowledge of English may have increased in India, knowledge of the three Rs has on the whole diminished.
('28', 360, 1, 30, 831971) The number of village schools in India has dwindled in the last fifty years.
('28', 360, 1, 31, 832048) That is to say, to the extent we middle class people believe ourselves to have advanced, the children living in villages have lagged behind.
('28', 360, 1, 32, 832189) As we in cities have prospered economically, the villages have suffered a decline.
('28', 360, 1, 33, 832272) Likewise, while we
('28', 360, 2, 34, 832291) 1 D. B. Kalelkar, popularly known as Kaka or Kaka Saheb 2 Spinning device
('28', 361, 0, 1, 832365) 362 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 361, 1, 2, 832407) have advanced educationally, the villages have had a set back.
('28', 361, 1, 3, 832470) Any statistician can prove that this is a true fact, terrible though it is.
('28', 361, 1, 4, 832546) It has been found that, in Burma, almost all the children were literate before the advent of British rule there, because there was not a single village then without a rural school.
('28', 361, 1, 5, 832727) Today the picture is being changed.
('28', 361, 1, 6, 832763) Rural schools are being destroyed and hence illiteracy has been growing.
('28', 361, 1, 7, 832836) Since our movement is chiefly concerned with the poor, to the extent that it spreads among them, their material condition and literacy will be promoted.
('28', 361, 1, 8, 832989) The remedy is to seek out the teacher in every village and get him to run a school.
('28', 361, 1, 9, 833073) He should teach, sitting under a tree.
('28', 361, 1, 10, 833112) Hindu children should study in the premises of a temple; Muslim children in, those of a mosque.
('28', 361, 1, 11, 833208) Once such a beginning is made, a full fledged school for both can be set up in course of time.

('28', 361, 1, 14, 833504) All these things are implicit in the spinning wheel movement.
('28', 361, 1, 15, 833566) The district and taluka committees have to become alert and undertake this task.

('28', 363, 4, 7, 837282) 201. RELIGION ON TRIAL
('28', 363, 5, 8, 837305) A cloud is hanging over the national school of Wadhwan.
('28', 363, 5, 9, 837361) Whether it disappears or grows in size and bursts over the school, this is a moment of trial for the latter.
('28', 363, 6, 10, 837470) I think the question of admitting Antyaja children to the school was raised even at the time of its establishment and that the Governing Board had then decided that they too could be admitted.
('28', 363, 6, 11, 837663) The money which was donated towards a building for that school was also given on the understanding that Antyajas would be admitted to it.
('28', 363, 6, 12, 837801) Now that the time has come for admitting Antyaja children to it, all sorts of difficulties seem to have arisen.
('28', 363, 6, 13, 837913) Even if, on Antyaja children being admitted to the school, some members of the Board leave it, parents withdraw their children from the school and some teachers resign, even if all this happens, the teacher and the parent to whom their religion is dear should not swerve an inch from the path of duty.
('28', 363, 6, 14, 838215) In my humble view, there can be no two opinions on what dharma requires in this situation.
('28', 363, 6, 15, 838306) It requires that the original pledge must be kept.
('28', 363, 6, 16, 838357) Not a single new factor has arisen which may put us in doubt as to what our dharma is on this occasion.
('28', 363, 6, 17, 838461) Antyajas have as much claim on the school as the others.
('28', 363, 6, 18, 838518) If we were among those who would appeal to a court, there is only one decision the latter could give, and it is that the teachers and the Governing Board were bound to admit Antyaja children to the school.
('28', 363, 6, 19, 838724) Members of the management or teachers who objected to this would be committing a breach of trust with the donors.

('28', 365, 3, 8, 841971) 202. NEED FOR CLOSED ATTENTION TO DETAIL
('28', 365, 4, 9, 842012) In order to observe the spinning vow thoroughly, it is necessary to pay attention to the smallest details.
('28', 365, 4, 10, 842119) There is a saying in English, Take care of the pence, and the pounds will take care of them selves. One who is not careful about a pie will never save a rupee.
('28', 365, 4, 11, 842279) This is true about all big undertakings.
('28', 365, 4, 12, 842320) If small details are neglected, big tasks suffer.
('28', 365, 4, 13, 842370) If, in a big machine, a small nail is not in its place or has become loose, or when a very small particle is sticking somewhere, it very often comes to a halt.
('28', 365, 4, 14, 842530) Our capacity to manage our affairs under swaraj will be mea sured by our ability to pay attention to details.
('28', 365, 4, 15, 842640) Our vow of spinning will give us that ability.
('28', 365, 4, 16, 842687) That spinning should be done regularly, the yarn produced should be collected and registered with the Provincial Congress Committee, that from there the record should go to the All India Congress Committee and the figure noted, that the yarn should be collected into a central pool and then woven into khadi and that, finally, the khadi should be soldthis is easily said, but to do it all we shall need many kinds of capacity and great many workers.
('28', 365, 4, 17, 843137) The village should manage its own work; the taluka should look after the villages, the district after the talukas and the province after the districts and above them all should be the Khadi Board.
('28', 365, 4, 18, 843334) Where everyone understands his duty and is competent enough in doing it, things will run smoothly.
('28', 365, 4, 19, 843433) But where people do not understand their responsibility, the Provincial Congress Committees will have to look after everything.
('28', 366, 0, 1, 843561) VOL.28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15 AUGUST, 1924 367
('28', 366, 1, 2, 843603) A good stock of spinning wheels should be maintained, they should be repaired and kept in working condition.
('28', 366, 1, 3, 843712) It should be seen that spindles are serviceable and straight.
('28', 366, 1, 4, 843774) The leather supporting the spindles should be maintained in such a condition that it easily fits in.
('28', 366, 1, 5, 843875) Mals 1 should be provided for.
('28', 366, 1, 6, 843906) Cotton should be stocked.
('28', 366, 1, 7, 843932) Cotton should be ginned, carded and turned into slivers and supplied where required, and, thereafter, the yarn produced should be collected.
('28', 366, 1, 8, 844073) One who takes interest in this work will have time neither for speeches nor for criticism, nor for ill will towards others.
('28', 366, 1, 9, 844197) Such a one will remain occupied in his own work.
('28', 366, 1, 10, 844246) The ideal is that everyone should provide himself with his own spinning wheel, procure the cotton he will require, card it, make slivers from it, blow water on the yarn spun, take it off, wind it properly and, together with his name and information about the count of the yarn, its weight and its length in yards neatly set down, have it packed and forwarded every month to the Provincial Congress Committee.
('28', 366, 1, 11, 844655) But till all spinners have become trained for this work, the Provincial Congress Committee will have to take the responsibility for most of it and for that purpose one or more spinning experts will also have to be engaged for some time.
('28', 366, 1, 12, 844892) If we get men and women spinners in large numbers, we do not have enough spinning wheels for them, and it will take some time to get them in sufficient number.

('28', 372, 5, 19, 859523) In my humble view, it is our duty to build up public opinion against such attacks; we should do this instead of denying that the incident occurred, for we know that similar incidents do occur and we should, therefore, believe that this one also is likely to have occurred.

('28', 381, 6, 8, 872195) The fair friend whose letter I reproduced in part in the issue of the 17th 2 with comments complains that I have not done justice to her by giving only part of her letter and omitting that which was incon venient for my argument and challenges me to reproduce the whole of the letter.
('28', 381, 6, 9, 872480) As I had no intention whatever of suppressing any part of her letter for the cause she mentions, I gladly place before the reader the whole of her letter and her comments on my remarks.
('28', 381, 6, 10, 872666) As I have no desire to enter into any further discussion on the matter I have told her that hers shall be the last say.

('28', 381, 7, 12, 872809) 221. THE LOKAMANYA ANNIVERSARY
('28', 381, 8, 13, 872840) This fourth anniversary of the withdrawal of the physical presence of the Lokamanya from our midst has a special significance for me and the movement I represent.
('28', 381, 8, 14, 873003) Both friends and critics inform me that a section of the Maharashtra Press is delivering a series of attacks on the movement and me which I should read and answer.
('28', 381, 9, 15, 873167) 1 This was in reply to a telegram from the Secretary, Trivandrum Congress Committee, received on July 30, 1924, which read: Tremendous floods in Kerala especially Travancore.
('28', 381, 9, 16, 873342) Terrible ruin famine.
('28', 381, 9, 17, 873364) Congress organizing relief work.
('28', 381, 9, 18, 873397) Subs tantial help needed.
('28', 381, 9, 19, 873423) Pray do needful.
('28', 381, 9, 20, 873440) Direct funds Changanacherry Parameshwaran Pillay, president Congress Relief Committee Trivandrum, 2 Vide Varnashrama or Varnasankara? 17 7 1924.
('28', 382, 0, 1, 873585) VOL.28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15 AUGUST, 1924 383
('28', 382, 1, 2, 873627) have resisted the temptation to do so.
('28', 382, 1, 3, 873666) But from what they write and the extracts they send, I know enough to understand their meaning.
('28', 382, 1, 4, 873762) I am anxious to pay my quota of tribute to the memory of the deceased on this occasion of the fourth anniversary.
('28', 382, 1, 5, 873876) But, in the midst of distrust of me by some of the best of the followers of the Lokamanya, how shall I pay my quota?
('28', 382, 1, 6, 873993) The task is difficult.
('28', 382, 1, 7, 874016) Just as, on that memorable night in 1920, I returned from Sardar Griha after having had a last look at the remains as they lay in the death chamber, I felt an oppressive loneliness.
('28', 382, 1, 8, 874198) I was secure in the Lokamanyas presence.
('28', 382, 1, 9, 874239) But by his departure I felt hopelessly insecure.
('28', 382, 1, 10, 874288) I could differ from him and express my difference in respectful terms, but we could never misunderstand each other.
('28', 382, 1, 11, 874404) I could not feel so with his followers, not because they would want to distrust me but because, being without a guide whose word was law to them, they would always feel insecure and hesitant about my views and not in perfect agreement among themselves.
('28', 382, 1, 12, 874657) Division in their ranks was the last thing in the world I desired.
('28', 382, 1, 13, 874724) I have more than once expressed my admiration for the Maharashtra party.
('28', 382, 1, 14, 874797) It has a determined policy.
('28', 382, 1, 15, 874825) It is well drilled.
('28', 382, 1, 16, 874845) It is able.
('28', 382, 1, 17, 874857) It has a record of great sacrifice behind it.
('28', 382, 1, 18, 874903) I wanted and want still to capture, not to divide the party.
('28', 382, 1, 19, 874964) I wanted and still want to convert it to my view of the means for the attainment of swaraj.
('28', 382, 1, 20, 875056) With Lokamanya alive, I had only him to convert or to be converted by him.
('28', 382, 1, 21, 875131) He had an instinctive perception of things and situations.
('28', 382, 1, 22, 875190) As he said to me, If the people follow your method, I am yours. But today there is a divided Maharashtra.
('28', 382, 1, 23, 875296) If, however, my faith in satyagraha is immutable, I must conquer Maharashtra as I hope to conquer Englishmen.
('28', 382, 1, 24, 875406) But I must have the help of Maharashtra No changers.
('28', 382, 1, 25, 875459) If they have understood the secret of non violence and truth, they must actively love the Pro changers even whilst they differ from them.
('28', 382, 1, 26, 875597) They must not criticize them.
('28', 382, 1, 27, 875627) Each party has enough work to do without flying at each others throats.
('28', 382, 1, 28, 875699) Two distinguished friends have appealed to me to bring the two parties together and lead them.
('28', 382, 1, 29, 875794) One of them, in the course of a long letter, says:
('28', 382, 2, 30, 875845) To my mind there is no more necessary or radical contradiction but only a difference between the Tilak policy and the Gandhi policy than between submarine blockade and aeroplane attack.
('28', 382, 2, 31, 876031) Indeed, the two can work together, (but along separate
('28', 383, 0, 1, 876086) 384 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 383, 1, 2, 876128) linesthe Tilak policy within the Councils, the Gandhi policy in the country outside, at large) in open, express and, therefore, rightous alliance against the common enemy for the common good.
('28', 383, 1, 3, 876320) These sentences put forth the position clearly up to a point.
('28', 383, 1, 4, 876382) I say up to a point because my conception of non co operation is exclusive of participation in the Councils.
('28', 383, 1, 5, 876491) That may be and is my limitation.
('28', 383, 1, 6, 876525) One man cannot control both the movementsthose of the submarine and the aeroplane; Nor can the two directors change places though both may have a common aim.
('28', 383, 1, 7, 876683) I can strengthen the work in the Councils only by working outside and even by decrying the Councils and thus turning the attention of the people away from them.
('28', 383, 1, 8, 876844) The better analogy for my purpose is that of anti septic and aseptic treatment.
('28', 383, 1, 9, 876924) The two cannot be applied at the same time and on the same patient.
('28', 383, 1, 10, 876992) But the surgeons belonging to the two schools may try their methods on different patients likely to submit to them and can do so without hampering each other.
('28', 383, 1, 11, 877151) The same friend says further:
('28', 383, 2, 12, 877181) While Tilakji and Gandhiji remain unreconciled, the heart of India will continue to be torn between the two and will not be able to settle down to steady work.
('28', 383, 2, 13, 877341) If such a catastrophe happens, if the country does not settle down, I would prove, indeed an unskilful surgeon and an indifferent representative of my own method.
('28', 383, 2, 14, 877504) I assure the friend and the reader that I am all attention.
('28', 383, 2, 15, 877564) It is a matter of no pleasure to me that the strain continues.
('28', 383, 2, 16, 877627) It will not, however, continue a day longer than is inevitable.
('28', 383, 2, 17, 877691) I invite assistance of the No changers in hastening the process of settling down.
('28', 383, 2, 18, 877773) The No changers faith consists in workings from with in and in that only.
('28', 383, 2, 19, 877847) They can, therefore, religiously gag them selves.
('28', 383, 2, 20, 877897) They will turn out better work.
('28', 383, 2, 21, 877929) They must not retaliate.
('28', 383, 2, 22, 877954) In every case where a fight in the shape of canvassing or wire pulling is required, they may relinquish the Congress control.
('28', 383, 2, 23, 878080) The Pro changers cannot afford to do without outside activity and agitation.
('28', 383, 2, 24, 878157) They may therefore control the Press and the Congress organization if they choose.
('28', 383, 2, 25, 878240) I would liken by their consent, to keep the Congress a mass organization which it can only be, if the workers concentrate their attention upon that: toe the exclusion of everything else.
('28', 383, 2, 26, 878427) But it cannot be so kept if there has to be a pitched and bitter fight between two parties.
('28', 383, 2, 27, 878519) In that case the No changers must, even if it is possible by manoeuvring to secure a majority, surrender control
('28', 384, 0, 1, 878632) VOL.28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15 AUGUST, 1924 385
('28', 384, 1, 2, 878674) with the greatest good grace to the Pro changers.
('28', 384, 1, 3, 878724) Let us recognize this one fact.
('28', 384, 1, 4, 878756) The masses do not yet actively participate in or understand our method of works.
('28', 384, 1, 5, 878837) Only workers in their midst can gain influence over them.
('28', 384, 1, 6, 878895) I could quote a dozen illustrations of silent workers who have more influence with the masses than any of our notable orators.
('28', 384, 1, 7, 879022) We must not, therefore, use the masses as pawns in the game.
('28', 384, 1, 8, 879083) Nor should control of the Congress be surrendered in a manner to embarrass the Pro changers.
('28', 384, 1, 9, 879176) The passage to their hands must be decorous and frank, without mental reservations.
('28', 384, 1, 10, 879260) Such delivery can only be made by those who have a living faith in the charkha and who will grudge to take away a single minute from it and its organization.
('28', 384, 1, 11, 879418) But whether the No changers appreciate and follow my advice or not, I hope, God willing, to prove my faith by completest surrender at a time and in a manner that cannot embarrass the Pro changers and cannot compromise the national cause.
('28', 384, 1, 12, 879656) When I have succeeded in so doing, not before, I shall have paid my humble tribute to the memory of the Lokamanya.
('28', 384, 1, 13, 879771) I can deserve the heritage left by him only by being true to myself.
('28', 384, 1, 14, 879840) Young India, 31 7 1924
('28', 384, 2, 15, 879863) 222. NOTES
('28', 384, 3, 16, 879874) UNHAPPY MALABAR
('28', 384, 4, 17, 879890) Last week I referred to the floods in South Kanara.
('28', 384, 4, 18, 879942) This week the public has the painful news that Malabar is practically under water.
('28', 384, 4, 19, 880025) I have also a wire from Mr. Nambudripad giving details of the havoc played by the floods and asking me for help.
('28', 384, 4, 20, 880138) The matter, however, seems to me to be beyond the capacity of private agency.
('28', 384, 4, 21, 880216) The Congress neither possesses funds nor influence nor an organization that can cope with a calamity of the magnitude such as Malabar has to face.
('28', 384, 4, 22, 880363) It is best in all humility to admit our limitations.
('28', 384, 4, 23, 880416) I would even not hesitate to help the distressed people, if necessary, through any committee that the authorities may appoint, provided, of course, that they would accept our help.
('28', 384, 4, 24, 880597) If we find that our service is unwelcome or the organization of official help is make believe, I should refrain from joining the committee and should render such personal and individual help as I may be capable of rendering.
('28', 384, 4, 25, 880822) God will not punish me for want of capacity.
('28', 384, 4, 26, 880867) But He will for want of will.
('28', 384, 4, 27, 880897) I would therefore, advise local workers to do whatever lies in their power and
('28', 385, 0, 1, 880976) 386 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 385, 1, 2, 881018) neglect no opportunity of alleviating distress.
('28', 385, 1, 3, 881066) After all, money plays the least part in such times.
('28', 385, 1, 4, 881119) It is the personal touch, the readiness to suffer for the sake of the sufferers, readiness to share the last morsel with the neighbour in distress that counts for much more than millions.
('28', 385, 1, 5, 881307) The sacrifice of the Brahmin who shared his scanty meal with the man in distress was infinitely more meritorious than the rich sacrifice of king Yudhishthira who showered gold mohurs as donations.
('28', 385, 2, 6, 881504) TO S. V. K.
('28', 385, 3, 7, 881516) I must apologize for having delayed my reply to your ques tions.
('28', 385, 3, 8, 881581) Here it is: (1) My fast in Ahmedabad in connection with the mill strike of 1917 1 was against loversthe mill hands, and not against the ownersthe tyrants.
('28', 385, 3, 9, 881736) I announced at the time that my fast was not flawless, because it was bound to influence the mill owners who were personal friends.
('28', 385, 3, 10, 881868) But it was not possible for me unconcerned to see the mill hands, my associates, committing a breach of a vow, solemnly repeated by them in my presence for twenty one days.
('28', 385, 3, 11, 882041) The effect of the fast was electrical.
('28', 385, 3, 12, 882080) The wavering labourers became at once strong in their determination.
('28', 385, 3, 13, 882149) (2) My philosophy does teach me to love alike friend and foe.
('28', 385, 3, 14, 882211) But that does not do away with the distinction till the foe has become friend.
('28', 385, 3, 15, 882290) The letter to Mr. Joseph was cryptic.

('28', 388, 5, 9, 889477) They are widely used in national schools.

('28', 388, 5, 13, 889906) The Government contend that the books are in breach of Section 124A of the Penal Code.
('28', 388, 5, 14, 889993) It was then open to them to prosecute the author and secure a conviction against him.

('28', 388, 5, 18, 890296) The least that the Government owed the public was to inform it of the objectionable matter in the several books so as to enable the public to judge for itself as to the propriety or otherwise of the Government order, assuming, of course, that it is proper to exercise arbitrary powers in cases such as this.
('28', 388, 5, 19, 890604) As it is, the conclusion is irresistible that the Government do not like the growing popularity of the readers and are seeking by questionable methods to favour its proteges whose readers may have suffered a check in competition with Professor Ramdas Gours.

('28', 393, 5, 29, 903376) But the manner of doing the hanks, etc. is naturally not as it should be.
('28', 393, 5, 30, 903450) Over an hour had to be given to examining and classifying the yarn.
('28', 393, 5, 31, 903518) As a result of the examination of this lot, the Secretary sends me the following specific instructions for the attention of spinners: (l) Each spinner should attach a label on each of his or her
('28', 394, 0, 1, 903713) VOL.28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15 AUGUST, 1924 395
('28', 394, 1, 2, 903755) hanks and it should contain: (a) The length and number of strands in it.
('28', 394, 1, 3, 903828) (b) The weight in tolas.
('28', 394, 1, 4, 903853) (c) The count which may result on calculation.
('28', 394, 1, 5, 903900) These labels are in addition to the main label referred to, containing name, etc., of the spinners.
('28', 394, 1, 6, 904000) (2) All hanks should be of uniform size and bulk.
('28', 394, 1, 7, 904050) (3) Every hank should contain two or more leases in it, which is done by passing a piece of strong string round each skein of 80 or 100 or more strands and crossing the string after each successive skein in the hank.
('28', 394, 1, 8, 904267) (4) It would be better to write down on the card attached to the bundle the kind of cotton used.
('28', 394, 1, 9, 904364) It will give an opportunity to the collector of the yarn of knowing the varieties used in the different provinces and of instructing as to the counts to be drawn from a given variety.
('28', 394, 1, 10, 904548) It has been customary in Bombay, and elsewhere, too, for that matter, to use mill slivers.
('28', 394, 1, 11, 904639) Yarn drawn from mill slivers is perfectly useless for the purpose intended.
('28', 394, 1, 12, 904715) The purpose is to popularize all the hand processes in connection with raw cotton.
('28', 394, 1, 13, 904798) Between mill slivers and mill cotton there is only a shade of difference.
('28', 394, 1, 14, 904872) If we may use mill slivers, we may as well use mill spun yarn.
('28', 394, 1, 15, 904935) The central idea behind hand spinning is to put money into the pockets of millions by finding them an easy uniform cottage industry.
('28', 394, 1, 16, 905068) Slivers must, therefore, be hand made.
('28', 394, 1, 17, 905107) The question of the circum ference of the reel should also be decided.
('28', 394, 1, 18, 905178) That the reels should be uniform goes without saying.
('28', 394, 1, 19, 905232) If they are not, it is tedious to find the count of a given quantity of yarn.
('28', 394, 1, 20, 905310) Experience has shown that the circumference of the reel should be four feet.
('28', 394, 1, 21, 905387) Then 375 lengths or strands would make a hank of 500 yards.
('28', 394, 1, 22, 905447) Four such hanks would make 2,000 yards.
('28', 394, 1, 23, 905487) It is incredibly simple to find the count of such hanks if we know the weight.
('28', 394, 1, 24, 905566) Convert the tolas weight into anies and divide the number of strands by the anies, the answer is the count.
('28', 394, 1, 25, 905674) Thus, if a hank of 375 strands weighs, say, 15 anies, the count is 375/15 = 25. Many suggestions have been made as to the size of the reel.
('28', 394, 1, 26, 905814) Experience seems to favour four feet circumference.
('28', 394, 1, 27, 905866) These reels are attached to the Ashram wheels.
('28', 394, 1, 28, 905913) It is a convenience no doubt to have them so.
('28', 394, 1, 29, 905959) But reels can be easily improvised with slit bamboo.
('28', 395, 0, 1, 906012) 396 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 395, 1, 2, 906054) Four to six pieces of slit bamboos of required length, pierced in the middle and supported on an upright [sic] whose ends pass through three bamboo pieces on either side and held in position by means of strings, make a serviceable reel.
('28', 395, 1, 3, 906291) The appliances accompanying the wheel are as simple as the wheel itself.
('28', 395, 1, 4, 906364) Lastly, it would be well to remember that the yarn should be sprayed and kept on the reel for an hour for saturation and drying.
('28', 395, 1, 5, 906493) The spraying settles the twist.

('28', 410, 2, 6, 942434) 228. NATIONAL EDUCATION CONFERENCE RESOLUTIONS 1
('28', 410, 3, 7, 942483) AHMEDABAD, August 1, 1924 Resolution No.
('28', 410, 3, 8, 942524) 1:This Conference is of opinion that, since the object of establishing national schools is that they may help in winning swaraj and promote the Non co operation movement, the principles of non co operation should not at all be compromised in conducting these schools.
('28', 410, 3, 9, 942792) Resolution No.
('28', 410, 3, 10, 942807) 2:This Conference is of opinion that in run ning these schools importance should be attached not to the number of pupils but to their quality.

('28', 420, 2, 3, 963181) SATYAGRAHA IN EAST AFRICA
('28', 420, 3, 4, 963207) A correspondent living in East Africa writes: 1
('28', 420, 4, 5, 963255) A similar picture has been painted by another person also.
('28', 420, 4, 6, 963314) There must be, therefore, some truth in what he says.
('28', 420, 4, 7, 963368) A struggle in which even a few went to jail with pure hearts cannot fail altogether.
('28', 420, 4, 8, 963453) But, to the people, it will seem to have.
('28', 420, 4, 9, 963495) failed as long as discriminatory laws remain unrepealed.
('28', 420, 4, 10, 963552) The correspondent has pointed out good reasons for the failure.
('28', 420, 4, 11, 963616) The community must remove them.
('28', 420, 4, 12, 963648) But those who believe that satyagraha is a means merely of harassing the Government commit a serious error.
('28', 420, 4, 13, 963756) The aim of satyagraha is self purification.
('28', 420, 4, 14, 963800) The harassment which naturally follows our doing our duty cannot be helped.
('28', 420, 4, 15, 963876) But our aim should not be harassment.
('28', 420, 4, 16, 963914) If drink addicts give up drinking, the owners of liquor booths will in deed suffer, but the aim of those who give up drinking is not to make them suffer.
('28', 420, 4, 17, 964068) Their aim can be to reform the owners as well.
('28', 420, 4, 18, 964115) But, undoubtedly, it is wrong to boycott those who do not join satyagraha.
('28', 420, 4, 19, 964190) That will harm the movement, not help it.
('28', 420, 4, 20, 964232) A satyagrahi should rely only on his own truth and on his capacity to bear suffering, that is, for tapascharya.
('28', 420, 4, 21, 964344) He need not be concerned if others do not follow him.
('28', 420, 4, 22, 964398) People do not join him for lack of faith or of strength.
('28', 420, 4, 23, 964455) Experience alone removes lack of faith.
('28', 420, 4, 24, 964495) Strength comes from example.
('28', 420, 4, 25, 964524) In neither case is coercion justified.

('28', 420, 6, 27, 964594) I have often admitted that it is the fault of the non co operators that they have not been able to win the love of the co operationists.
('28', 420, 6, 28, 964731) But that does not give either the right to harm the country.

('28', 420, 6, 31, 965000) The matter rested there.

('28', 428, 1, 2, 977930) of sedition and libel.
('28', 428, 1, 3, 977953) Everything the Government were able to do under the Press Law is now being done without it and without diffi culty.
('28', 428, 1, 4, 978069) The extraordinary judgment given against the Chronicle does but confirm this view.
('28', 428, 1, 5, 978152) It is difficult to believe that a public servant can possibly bring an action for damages for comment upon his acts as such made by a journalist in the discharge of his profession.
('28', 428, 1, 6, 978333) I understand that the case against the Chronicle is not the first of its kind.
('28', 428, 1, 7, 978412) The Bande Mataram and the Zamindar of Lahore had to pay damages under similar circumstances.
('28', 428, 1, 8, 978505) Which is worse?
('28', 428, 1, 9, 978521) Forfeiture under the defunct law or damages under a libel suit?
('28', 428, 1, 10, 978585) After the result of the Chronicle case, who can dare criticize frankly and freely the acts of Government servants?
('28', 428, 1, 11, 978700) The editor of a daily newspaper, when he begins writing his leading article, does not weigh his words in golden scales.
('28', 428, 1, 12, 978820) He may be betrayed into a hasty word.
('28', 428, 1, 13, 978858) Must he pay for it even though it did it obviously in good faith, without malice and in the public interest?
('28', 428, 1, 14, 978967) The writer in the Chronicle certainly did not know Mr. Painter and had no more interest in maligning him than the learned judge himself who has awarded what I venture to regard as vindictive damages.
('28', 428, 1, 15, 979167) The public will refuse to believe that Mr. Painter had suffered anything because of the Chronicle comments.
('28', 428, 1, 16, 979275) But I make bold to think that he has lost more in public estimation by his victory than by the Chronicle comment.
('28', 428, 1, 17, 979389) He has cleared nothing by getting a verdict against the Chronicle.
('28', 428, 1, 18, 979456) But he has shown that he is not capable, in a sportsman like manner, of standing strong public criticism.
('28', 428, 1, 19, 979562) I feel sorry for him.
('28', 428, 1, 20, 979584) What, however, I am concerned about is the position of journalists in view of this case.
('28', 428, 1, 21, 979673) One is not always able to prove ones convictions and, if one is to criticize public acts and their doers, it is necessary to set forth ones convictions without being called upon always to prove them.
('28', 428, 1, 22, 979873) For instance, I feel morally certain that the judgment of the judge in Sir Sankaran Nairs case was warped.
('28', 428, 1, 23, 979980) 1 I am morally certain that the judge was politically biased in favour of Sir Michael ODwyer.
('28', 428, 1, 24, 980074) And yet, if what I have said be regarded libellous and if the judge sent me notice of action, I should have to tender a humble, abject and unconditional apology for having expressed my candid opinion in the interest of public good.

('28', 429, 4, 19, 981947) The Gujarat Vidyapith has at the present moment nearly 30,000 children in its national schools who are being taught by over 800 teachers in nearly 140 institutions, of which two are colleges and one devoted to ancient research.
('28', 429, 4, 20, 982175) The figures include also 13 high schools, 15 middle schools, 15 special schools for untouchables teaching over 300 boys and girls.

('28', 430, 1, 2, 982810) likely to close in course of time.

('28', 430, 1, 6, 983164) Measured by the swaraj standard, the experiment may not be regarded as an achievement; but, judged by itself, the experiment is an amazing record of progress for its four years existence.

('28', 431, 1, 2, 985400) untouchable children in them.
('28', 431, 1, 3, 985430) The Mussalman attendance at the schools is poor.
('28', 431, 1, 4, 985479) I had, therefore, no hesitation in advising that now we were to strive nor after quantity but quality.

('28', 433, 10, 23, 992263) 4. If any election to these bodies is to take place, it can only be of those persons who will not be able to conform to the Ahmedabad recommendations in toto.

('28', 434, 2, 20, 995164) FOR FAMINE RELIEF

('28', 435, 1, 2, 995371) It may not perhaps be accurate to describe the Coimbatore District as poor.
('28', 435, 1, 3, 995447) But it is mostly a dry district and a failure of the monsoons, as happened last year, necessarily involves a famine.

('28', 435, 1, 5, 995618) Cattle were available gratis.

('28', 435, 3, 16, 996764) WHAT A BRAHMIN SAYS
('28', 435, 4, 17, 996784) A friend sends the following which will be read with interest:
('28', 435, 5, 18, 996847) I am a Brahmin born and bred in Konkan.
('28', 435, 5, 19, 996887) During the first thirteen years of my life, I may be said to have exclusively lived in villages and, for seven years after that, divided my time between villages and cities.
('28', 435, 5, 20, 997061) My great grandfather died an ascetic; my grandfather was so strict in his Brahmin observances that he bathed even on the day of his death.
('28', 435, 5, 21, 997200) My father used to recite two chapters of Gita every day besides the whole of Rudri, the lengthy scriptural prayer to God Shankara.
('28', 435, 5, 22, 997331) On Mondays and especially Sravana
('28', 435, 6, 23, 997365) Mondays, he would be reciting it for eight to ten hours in the presence of our village Shankara.
('28', 435, 6, 24, 997462) I did not know the scripture in the beginning when I was drenching the Linga with at least five hundred ghadas of water during those
('28', 435, 7, 25, 997595) I am narrating these facts only to prove that I was not born or bred in Anglicized or civilized atmosphere but in a dharmik one.
('28', 435, 8, 26, 997724) In that atmosphere I was taught that it brought spiritual welfare to be able to spin sufficient yarn for my sacred threads.
('28', 435, 8, 27, 997848) My grandfather, my father and my uncles all used to spin.
('28', 435, 8, 28, 997906) My spiritual preceptor used to spin all the while that he was teaching me sandhya or Rudri.
('28', 435, 8, 29, 997998) We had a cotton tree of our
('28', 435, 9, 30, 998026) We made slivers in the crudest fashion.
('28', 435, 9, 31, 998066) I had a great hankering for spinning.
('28', 435, 9, 32, 998104) The spindle was a most inefficient variety.
('28', 435, 9, 33, 998148) A thin sticklet passed
('28', 436, 0, 1, 998171) VOL.28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15 AUGUST, 1924 437
('28', 436, 1, 2, 998213) through a hole bored in the centre of a pice that had got too smooth to be current was my spindle.
('28', 436, 1, 3, 998312) We called it chatee.
('28', 436, 2, 4, 998333) I nave to say much the same thing of our women.
('28', 436, 2, 5, 998381) Women, and
('28', 436, 3, 6, 998392) especially widows, who in those days had no aim except to get spiritual benefit, went to listen to kathas and Puranas.
('28', 436, 3, 7, 998511) While they listened, they spun
('28', 436, 4, 8, 998542) yarn with their fingers alone which they collected round the neck of a small earthen pot.
('28', 436, 4, 9, 998632) That yarn was then twisted into wicks which were soaked in ghee and burnt as an oblation to earn merit (punya) in the eyes of God.
('28', 436, 5, 10, 998763) spinning not only did not lower those women, but gave those ladies a higher Brahminic and religious position.

('28', 436, 6, 12, 998988) I am a Chitpavan Brahmin belonging to the Ratnagiri District.

('28', 437, 2, 22, 1002562) A HOMILY

('28', 452, 2, 6, 1033594) 255. FLOODS IN MALABAR
('28', 452, 3, 7, 1033617) I have been receiving telegrams asking for help in connection with the floods in Malabar.
('28', 452, 3, 8, 1033707) Who can help where thousands of houses have been destroyed, crops washed away and fertile soil turned into sandy waste!
('28', 452, 3, 9, 1033827) At this juncture, one way out is to rest content with what ever help the Government extends.
('28', 452, 3, 10, 1033920) Such aid as it wishes us to provide, we should offer, if we can.
('28', 452, 3, 11, 1033985) Even when all this is done, there is certainly room for private donations and voluntary service.
('28', 452, 3, 12, 1034082) Relief measures in respect of this calamity cannot be completed in a day or even in a month.
('28', 452, 3, 13, 1034175) They will go on for a year or more.
('28', 452, 3, 14, 1034211) The relief work in connection with the floods in South Kanara last year has continued till today.
('28', 452, 3, 15, 1034309) Meanwhile, there have been floods there once again, so they have now to start relief work afresh.
('28', 452, 3, 16, 1034407) But when relief measures taken for one whole year could not cope with the damage caused by a minor flood, how much more time is likely to be taken when a whole province is as good as submerged in water?
('28', 452, 3, 17, 1034610) Hence I certainly wish to rouse the generosity of the people of Gujarat.
('28', 452, 3, 18, 1034683) The Gujaratis had very liberally helped famine stricken Orissa.
('28', 452, 4, 19, 1034747) They have contributed to many other funds.
('28', 452, 4, 20, 1034790) Appeal for help can be made only to those who have been accustomed to give help.
('28', 452, 4, 21, 1034871) There fore, I appeal to every reader of Navajivan on behalf of the helpless people of Malabar.
('28', 452, 4, 22, 1034966) One may send whatever one likes and however much one likes.
('28', 452, 4, 23, 1035026) We can get some help through children even by teaching them the geography of Malabar, by telling them of the cala mity and thereby rousing their sentiment of love.

('28', 455, 3, 11, 1040613) 257. MY NOTES
('28', 455, 4, 12, 1040627) GREATNESS OF THE HIMALAYAS
('28', 455, 5, 13, 1040654) It is not as if only Englishmen knew or discovered that ones health improves by staying in the Himalayas.
('28', 455, 5, 14, 1040760) The reader will like to read the translation 1 that a friend has sent me of the verses in praise of the Himalayas to be found in Ayurveda, in order to show that their greatness has also been recorded in our ancient books.
('28', 455, 5, 15, 1040982) While reading this who would not feel that such ancient statements go to show that the lives of our ancestors must have been full of poetry?
('28', 455, 5, 16, 1041123) A very simple thing has been adorned with figures of speech and rendered sweet.
('28', 455, 5, 17, 1041203) They could do that because the people then were contented.
('28', 455, 5, 18, 1041262) India was, comparatively speaking, happy.
('28', 455, 5, 19, 1041304) Even the poorest did not starve.
('28', 455, 5, 20, 1041337) The land of Bharat was independent.
('28', 455, 5, 21, 1041373) Will not such an age come again?
('28', 455, 5, 22, 1041406) The vaids 2 proved to be true; that age will return only when we prove ourselves to be true.
('28', 455, 5, 23, 1041499) The vaids should themselves go to the Himalayas and get refreshed, acquire honesty of purpose, discover medicines and give their benefit to us so that they
('28', 455, 6, 24, 1041655) 1 Not translated here
('28', 455, 7, 25, 1041677) 2 Physicians practising Ayurvedic system of medicine
('28', 456, 0, 1, 1041730) VOL.28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15 AUGUST, 1924 457
('28', 456, 1, 2, 1041772) may earn spiritual merit.
('28', 456, 1, 3, 1041798) Today the vaids are intent on demanding a rupee for service worth a pie; they have nothing of the research spirit of the West, but imitate the Wests greed for money, learn by rote old verses and dispense medicines and add to the number of diseases instead of reducing it.
('28', 456, 1, 4, 1042070) They tempt the disease stricken by their various advertisements in newspapers and make us perpetual slaves to them and their medicines.
('28', 456, 1, 5, 1042206) If, however, they would stay in the Himalayas and make researches, and also attempt to make us self controlled they would promote their own welfare as well as ours.
('28', 456, 1, 6, 1042371) We may learn from them of one medicine which can do what a hundred may not.
('28', 456, 1, 7, 1042447) Today the mountains are fit resorts only for the rich or the ascetics.
('28', 456, 1, 8, 1042518) The middle classes have to lead their lives somehow by imbibing endless medicines.
('28', 456, 2, 9, 1042601) ACCIDENT IN A MILL
('28', 456, 3, 10, 1042620) A Government committee is investigating at the moment the causes of the accident which occurred when a mill collapsed.
('28', 456, 3, 11, 1042739) The terms of reference are very limited in scope.
('28', 456, 3, 12, 1042789) The duty ofthe owner of the mill is much larger than this; that of the Mill owners Association is larger still and that of the Mill workers Union is in a way the largest of all.
('28', 456, 3, 13, 1042967) The Government committee may do what it likes, but it is the clear duty of the owner of the mill to support to the full the families rendered helpless.
('28', 456, 3, 14, 1043119) Whatever may have been the cause of the accident, the poor workers had no hand in it at all.
('28', 456, 3, 15, 1043212) In such circumstances, whether law enjoins it or not, the mill owners are in duty bound to support the helpless families, to provide medical treatment to the wounded and hereafter to take greater precautions in regard to the sound condition of the building.
('28', 456, 3, 16, 1043470) It is the duty of the Mill owners Association to maintain the good name of every mill owner.
('28', 456, 3, 17, 1043563) It is bound to maintain and be answerable for the condition of the buildings of all mills.
('28', 456, 3, 18, 1043654) It should call some impartial building expert, get him to inspect mill buildings and obtain his certificate in respect of every building of the mills, get removed whatever defects may have been pointed out by him and should ascertain whether or not the mill owners concerned have made proper provision for the medical treatment of injured mill workers and for the maintenance of helpless families.
('28', 456, 3, 19, 1044052) The responsibility devolving on the workers union is both heavy and delicate.
('28', 456, 3, 20, 1044130) It is its especial duty to safeguard the interests of
('28', 457, 0, 1, 1044184) 458 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 457, 1, 2, 1044226) workers.
('28', 457, 1, 3, 1044235) There is constant apprehension that the mill owners may regard this as a breach of the unions obligations.
('28', 457, 1, 4, 1044342) Nevertheless, the union ought to take such steps as are necessary to protect the life of workers.
('28', 457, 1, 5, 1044440) It is the natural and first step to get this ensured through the mill owners.
('28', 457, 1, 6, 1044518) If no help is forthcoming from the mill owners, adequate steps ought surely to be taken independently of them.
('28', 457, 1, 7, 1044629) I wish, however, to give my detailed idea about this through the Majoor Sandesh only; hence I do not take up space for it in Navajivan.
('28', 457, 1, 8, 1044765) But I shall merely say that the mill owners should not put the labour union into an awkward position and they should realize that the union leaders do not wish ill to them, but wish them well.
('28', 457, 1, 9, 1044958) Moreover, keeping this in mind, they should assist the labour union in its work as the workers guardian and take from it the help they require.
('28', 457, 2, 10, 1045102) AAVKAR LAYAK KE DAYAK?
('28', 457, 3, 11, 1045125) Simlanivasi asks me whether just as I accepted a correction concerning the word talleen, I would not correct the phrase aavkar dayak.
('28', 457, 3, 12, 1045259) I have already introduced that correction in the article itself.
('28', 457, 3, 13, 1045324) Dayak means that which gives, layak means fit.
('28', 457, 3, 14, 1045371) In thissense, we should consider Governments tyranny as aavkarlayak, not aavka rdayak.
('28', 457, 3, 15, 1045458) Who knows how many such mistakes are being committed?
('28', 457, 3, 16, 1045512) Hence I should like to make the pleasant suggestion that every educated reader of Navajivan should correct such errors himself when he reads the paper.
