('28', 458, 1, 2, 1046099) 258. SOME OBJECTIONS ANSWERED 1
('28', 458, 2, 3, 1046131) (A correspondent to Navajivan sends a formidable letter where in he objects to most of my propositions and generally my way of life.
('28', 458, 2, 4, 1046264) A friend has translated my reply to it for the benefit of the readers of Young India.
('28', 458, 2, 5, 1046350) Translation of the letter is not given as the reply itself enables the reader to know the objections.) 2
('28', 458, 3, 6, 1046455) Right conduct is not like Euclids right line.
('28', 458, 3, 7, 1046501) It is like a beautiful tree, not one of whose millions of leaves is like any other.
('28', 458, 3, 8, 1046585) Though, therefore, they are from one seed and belong to the same tree, there is none of the uniformity of a geometrical figure about any part of a tree.
('28', 458, 3, 9, 1046738) And yet we know that the seed, the branches and the leaves are one and the same.
('28', 458, 3, 10, 1046819) We know, too, that no geometrical figure can bear comparison with a full blossomed tree in point of beauty and gran deur.
('28', 458, 3, 11, 1046941) Therefore, where the correspondent sees inconsistency, I see neither contradiction nor insanity in my life.
('28', 458, 3, 12, 1047049) It is true that, as a man cannot see his back, so can he not see his errors or insanity But the sages have often likened a man of religion to a lunatic.
('28', 458, 3, 13, 1047202) I, therefore, hug the belief that I may not be insane and may be truly religious.
('28', 458, 3, 14, 1047284) Which of the two I am in truth can only be decided after my death.
('28', 458, 3, 15, 1047351) I never asked my audience to substitute the spinning wheel for the rosary.
('28', 458, 3, 16, 1047426) I only suggested that they could go on spinning taking the name of Narayana simultaneously.
('28', 458, 3, 17, 1047518) And whilst today the whole country is on fire, I think it behoves us all to fill the buckets of the spinning wheel with the water of yarn, and extinguish the fire with the name of Narayana on our lips.
('28', 458, 3, 18, 1047720) I want to see the spinning wheel everywhere, because I see pauperism everywhere.
('28', 458, 3, 19, 1047801) Not until and unless we have fed and clothed the skeletons of India will religion have any meaning for them.
('28', 458, 3, 20, 1047910) They are living the cattle life today and we are responsible for it.
('28', 458, 3, 21, 1047979) The spinning wheel is, therefore, a penance for us.
('28', 458, 3, 22, 1048031) Religion is service of the helpless.
('28', 458, 3, 23, 1048068) God manifests Himself to us in the form of the helpless and the stricken.
('28', 458, 3, 24, 1048142) But we, in spite of our forehead marks, take no notice of them, i.e., of God.
('28', 458, 3, 25, 1048220) God is and is not in the Vedas.
('28', 458, 4, 26, 1048252) 1 The original of this article was written in Gujarati and published in Navajivan, 10 8 1924, under the title Rosary or the Spinning Wheel.
('28', 458, 5, 27, 1048392) 2 This prefatory paragraph was published, along with the translation, in Young India, 14 8 1924.
('28', 459, 0, 1, 1048489) 460 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 459, 1, 2, 1048531) reads the spirit of the Vedas sees God therein.
('28', 459, 1, 3, 1048579) He who clings to the letter of the Vedas is a Vediaa literalist.
('28', 459, 1, 4, 1048644) Narasinha Mehta does indeed sing the praise of the rosary, and the praise is well merited where it is given.
('28', 459, 1, 5, 1048753) But the same Narasinha has sung:
('28', 459, 2, 6, 1048786) Of what avail is the tilaka and the tulsi, of what avail is the rosary and the
('28', 459, 3, 7, 1048865) muttering of the Name, what avail is the grammatical interpretation of the Veda, what avail is the mastery of the letters?
('28', 459, 3, 8, 1048988) All these are devices to fill the belly and nothing worth without their helping to a realization of the Para Brahma.
('28', 459, 3, 9, 1049105) The Mussalman does count the beads of his tasbih and the Christian of the rosary.
('28', 459, 3, 10, 1049187) But both would think themselves fallen from religion if their tasbih and rosary prevented them from running to the succour of one who, for instance, was lying stricken with a snake bite.
('28', 459, 3, 11, 1049374) Mere knowledge of the Vedas cannot make our Brahmins spiritual preceptors.
('28', 459, 3, 12, 1049449) If it did, Max Muller would have become one.
('28', 459, 3, 13, 1049494) The Brahmin who has understood the religion of today will certainly give Vedic learning a secondary place and propagate the religion of the spinning wheel, relieve the hunger of the millions of his starving countrymen and only then, and not until then, lose himself in Vedic studies.
('28', 459, 3, 14, 1049778) I have certainly regarded spinning superior to the practice of denominational religions.
('28', 459, 3, 15, 1049867) But that does not mean that the latter should be given up.
('28', 459, 3, 16, 1049926) I only mean that a dharma which has to be observed by the followers of all religions transcends them, and hence I say that a Brahmin is a better Brahmin, a Mussalman a better Mussalman, a Vaishnava a better Vaishnava, if he turns the wheel in the spirit of service.
('28', 459, 3, 17, 1050192) I certainly did not repeat the divine word Rama, nor count the beads on account of a feeling that my end was near.
('28', 459, 3, 18, 1050307) But I was too weak then to turn the wheel.
('28', 459, 3, 19, 1050350) I do count the rosary whenever it helps me in concentrating on Rama.
('28', 459, 3, 20, 1050419) When, however, I rise to a pitch of concentration where the rosary is more a hindrance than a help, I drop it.
('28', 459, 3, 21, 1050530) If it was possible for me to turn the wheel in my bed, and if I felt that it would help me in concentrating my mind on God, I would cer tainly leave the rosary aside and turn the wheel.
('28', 459, 3, 22, 1050716) If I am strong enough to turn the wheel, and I have to make a choice between coun ting beads or turning the wheel, I would certainly decide in favour of the wheel, making it my rosary so long as I found poverty and starvation stalking the land.
('28', 459, 3, 23, 1050961) I do look forward to a time when even repeating the
('28', 460, 0, 1, 1051013) VOL.28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15 AUGUST, 1924 461
('28', 460, 1, 2, 1051055) name of Rama will become a hindrance.
('28', 460, 1, 3, 1051093) When I have realized that Rama transcends even speech, I shall have no need to repeat the name.
('28', 460, 1, 4, 1051189) The spinning wheel, the rosary and the Ramanam are all the same to me.
('28', 460, 1, 5, 1051260) They subserve the same end, they teach me the religion of service.
('28', 460, 1, 6, 1051327) I cannot practise ahimsa without practising the religion of service, and I cannot find the truth without practising the religion of ahimsa.
('28', 460, 1, 7, 1051467) And there is no religion other than Truth.
('28', 460, 1, 8, 1051510) Truth is Rama, Narayana, Ish wara, Khuda, Allah, God.
('28', 460, 1, 9, 1051564) As Narasinha says, The different shapes into which gold is beaten gives rise to different names and forms; but ultimately it is all gold. I have nothing to withdraw from what I have said about mach ines in the Indian Home Rule, and a reference will show that I have included the printing press in the machines.
('28', 460, 1, 10, 1051875) It must be remembered that it is not Indian Home Rule depicted in that book that I am placing before India.
('28', 460, 1, 11, 1051983) I am placing before the nation parliamentary, i.e., democratic swaraj.
('28', 460, 1, 12, 1052054) I do not suggest today a destruction of all the machines, but I am making the spinning wheel the master machine.
('28', 460, 1, 13, 1052167) The Indian Home Rule depicts an ideal State.
('28', 460, 1, 14, 1052212) The fact that I cannot come up to the ideal condition of things laid down therein is to be attributed to my weakness.
('28', 460, 1, 15, 1052330) I believe that there is no religion greater than ahimsa, and yet I cannot escape the himsa which is inevitably involved in the processes of eating and drinking.
('28', 460, 1, 16, 1052491) The ideal of ahimsa is, however, ever before me; therefore, even in these processes, I do endeavour to restrain myself: I am striving every moment to reduce even those functions to a minimum.
('28', 460, 1, 17, 1052683) What I have said about hospitals is also true.
('28', 460, 1, 18, 1052730) And yet I suppose I shall resort to the few medicines I hold lawful, so long as I retain the least attachment for my body.
('28', 460, 1, 19, 1052853) I went to the hospital as a prisoner.
('28', 460, 1, 20, 1052891) I did not run away from it immediately on my release, because I thought it my duty to remain under the care of those who had treated me with courtesy and kindness.
('28', 460, 1, 21, 1053055) I am, however, ashamed at the very fact of my illness, inasmuch as I believe that a man should never fall ill.
('28', 460, 1, 22, 1053166) It is humiliating for me to take any medicine, and the more so that it was at all necessary to take me to the hospital.
('28', 460, 1, 23, 1053286) I have never preferred killing a dacoit to winning him over with love.
('28', 460, 1, 24, 1053357) But he who is not equal to that love, who cannot master all the love that the act demands, has the right to protect his proteges and his property even by killing the dacoit.
('28', 461, 0, 1, 1053531) 462 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 461, 1, 2, 1053573) It is a gross error to liken the Englishmen to dacoits.
('28', 461, 1, 3, 1053629) The dacoits loot you by sheer violence, the Englishmen do so chiefly by seducing us.
('28', 461, 1, 4, 1053714) There is thus a great difference of method in the two.
('28', 461, 1, 5, 1053769) A liquor vendor also robs me of my soul by selling his liquor.
('28', 461, 1, 6, 1053832) Should I suggest killing him, or non co operating with him?
('28', 461, 1, 7, 1053892) But if an Englishman brutally assaults you, or a liquorvendor forcibly tries to pour liquor down your throat, and if you will not win both over by love, then it is open to you to engage them in an armed combat.
('28', 461, 1, 8, 1054103) It would make no difference if the aggressors in the case were one or many, weak or strong.
('28', 461, 2, 9, 1054195) I have ventured to give a reply to the above letter, but I have a doubt whether it was proper to do so.
('28', 461, 2, 10, 1054299) I have assumed the correspondents object to be pure; hence only I took the trouble to reply to him.
('28', 461, 2, 11, 1054399) But I think it can be seen from my reply that usually a great deal of erroneous thinking is found in such correspondence.
('28', 461, 2, 12, 1054521) It seems the life of many educated people has become devoid of thought.
('28', 461, 2, 13, 1054593) As long as one cannot deduce a corollary from a principle, one can be held to have no knowledge of the principle at all.
('28', 461, 2, 14, 1054714) If the correspondent had gone deep into the subject and thought profoun dly over it, he himself could have deduced all the answers that I have given.
('28', 461, 2, 15, 1054864) Truly speaking, all these replies are already there in my earlier writings.
('28', 461, 2, 16, 1054940) But I find from the letters I receive that correspondents lazy thinking is a common fault and hence I have to give this reply.
('28', 461, 2, 17, 1055067) But I advise every reader and correspondent that they should think deeply on every subject, because by doing so they will save themselves from many misconceptions .
('28', 461, 2, 18, 1055232) Reading without reflection is fruitless.

('28', 475, 10, 16, 1073719) From the Hindi original: C.W. 4860. Courtesy: Chandragupta Vidyalankar
('28', 475, 11, 17, 1073790) 282. PERTINENT QUESTIONS
('28', 475, 12, 18, 1073815) A correspondent asks:
('28', 475, 13, 19, 1073837) Are you in favour of the introduction of compulsory primary education system in India?
('28', 475, 13, 20, 1073924) Is it unjust or unnecessary to make this education compul sory?
('28', 475, 13, 21, 1073988) If we get swarajya, in the present condition of our country, will you
('28', 475, 14, 22, 1074058) 1 One whose celibacy is inviolate 2 The postmark bears this date.
('28', 476, 0, 1, 1074124) VOL.28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15 AUGUST, 1924 477
('28', 476, 1, 2, 1074166) make primary education compulsory throughout the whole of India?
('28', 476, 1, 3, 1074231) I fear I must answer the main question in the negative.
('28', 476, 1, 4, 1074287) I am not quite sure that I would not oppose compulsory education at all times.
('28', 476, 1, 5, 1074366) All compulsion is hateful to me.
('28', 476, 1, 6, 1074399) I would no more have the nation become educated by compulsion than I would have it become sober by such questionable means.
('28', 476, 1, 7, 1074523) But just as I would discourage drink by refusing to open drink shops and closing existing ones, so would I discourage illiteracy by removing obstacles in the path and opening free schools and making them responsive to the peoples needs.
('28', 476, 1, 8, 1074760) But, at the present moment, we have not even tried on any large scale the experiment of free education.
('28', 476, 1, 9, 1074864) We have offered the parents no induce ments.
('28', 476, 1, 10, 1074909) We have not even sufficiently or at all advertised the value of literacy.
('28', 476, 1, 11, 1074983) We have not the proper schoolmasters for the training.
('28', 476, 1, 12, 1075038) In my opinion therefore, it is altogether too early to think of compulsion.
('28', 476, 1, 13, 1075114) I am not even sure that the experiment in compulsory education.
('28', 476, 1, 14, 1075178) has been uniformly successful wherever it has been tried.
('28', 476, 1, 15, 1075236) If the majority wants education, compulsion is wholly unnecessary.
('28', 476, 1, 16, 1075303) If it does not, compulsion would be most harmful.
('28', 476, 1, 17, 1075353) Only a despotic Government passes laws in the teeth of the opposition of a majority.
('28', 476, 1, 18, 1075438) Has the Government afforded full facilities for education to the children of the majority?
('28', 476, 1, 19, 1075529) We have been compulsion ridden for the past hundred years or more.
('28', 476, 1, 20, 1075596) The State rules our life in its manifold details without our previous sanction.
('28', 476, 1, 21, 1075676) It is time to use the nation to voluntary methods even though, for the time being, there may be no response to prayers, petitions and advice addressed to the nation.
('28', 476, 1, 22, 1075842) It has had little response to its prayers.
('28', 476, 1, 23, 1075885) Nothing is more detrimental to the true growth of society than for it to be habituated to the belief that no reform can be achieved by voluntary effort.
('28', 476, 1, 24, 1076038) A people so trained become wholly unfit for swaraj.
('28', 476, 1, 25, 1076090) It follows from what I have said above that, if we got swaraj today, I should resist compulsory education at least till every effort at voluntary primary education has been honestly made and failed.
('28', 476, 1, 26, 1076289) Let the reader not forget that there is more illiteracy in India today than there was fifty years ago, not because the parents are less willing, but because the facilities they had before have disappeared under a system so foreign and unnatural for the country.
('28', 476, 1, 27, 1076551) The same thing is happening today in Burma.
('28', 476, 1, 28, 1076595) The writers other question is:
('28', 476, 2, 29, 1076626) Are you in favour of primary education being compulsory by the
('28', 477, 0, 1, 1076689) 478 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 477, 1, 2, 1076731) municipal and local bodies, by taking advantage of the present Compulsory Primary Education Act, specially when it is possible to do so by the hearty support of members of all shades of opinion?
('28', 477, 1, 3, 1076926) This question has reference to Non co operators.
('28', 477, 1, 4, 1076975) I am of opinion that it is not inconsistent with the Congress resolution to take advantage of the Act if the councillors wish to do so.
('28', 477, 1, 5, 1077111) But for the reasons mentioned, I should hesitate straightway to adopt compul sion.

('28', 485, 8, 16, 1097500) kha work in the Ashram.
('28', 485, 8, 17, 1097524) Almost all the volunteers know to spin well and the
('28', 485, 9, 18, 1097576) charkhas are being sent to the barricades except during heavy showers.
('28', 485, 10, 19, 1097647) the number have learnt to card and I am making it compulsory that the
('28', 485, 11, 20, 1097717) spinners must use their own carded cotton.
('28', 485, 11, 21, 1097760) Tape making is also going on.
('28', 485, 12, 22, 1097790) long we will set up a loom.
('28', 485, 12, 23, 1097818) I must respectfully refuse to believe that cultured young men doing such honest work in the faith that it purifies them and helps them in their struggle against passion and prejudice can possibly deceive the public or me.
('28', 485, 12, 24, 1098040) They have no interest in so doing.
('28', 485, 12, 25, 1098075) For their faith is in their work.
('28', 485, 13, 26, 1098109) IT MELTS STONES
('28', 485, 14, 27, 1098125) But the president of the meeting in his letter says, You seem to think that satyagraha, when offered to a brother will gradually melt away the opposition of the latter and win him over to the side of the satyagrahi.
('28', 485, 14, 28, 1098341) This is not our experience here. I do not wonder that the hearts of the orthodox have not yet been touched by the sufferings of the satyagrahis.
('28', 485, 14, 29, 1098486) They have not suffered long enough yet nor intensely
('28', 486, 0, 1, 1098539) VOL.28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15 AUGUST, 1924 487
('28', 486, 1, 2, 1098581) enough.
('28', 486, 1, 3, 1098589) Even suffering cannot be manufactured.
('28', 486, 1, 4, 1098628) They must take whatever God may have in store for them.
('28', 486, 1, 5, 1098684) If He wants them to have to linger away in suffering, they must Submit to it cheerfully.
('28', 486, 1, 6, 1098773) They dare not shirk the severest trial nor may they dare stage play suffer ing.
('28', 486, 1, 7, 1098853) That was one of my reasons against the Sikh friends resis ting arrests and inviting fire.
('28', 486, 1, 8, 1098943) My uniform experience is that true suffering melts the stoniest hearts.
('28', 486, 1, 9, 1099015) With my own eldest brother, it took fully thirteen years.
('28', 486, 1, 10, 1099073) I do not reproduce all the letters I received from English friends.
('28', 486, 1, 11, 1099141) But some of them are humble recognitions of the evil done (true enough in ignorance) by the English rulers.
('28', 486, 1, 12, 1099249) What are these recognitions if they are not in conscious response to suffering?
('28', 486, 1, 13, 1099329) Nothing can shake me from the conviction that given a good cause, suffering for its sake advances it as nothing else has ever done.
('28', 486, 1, 14, 1099461) To the orthodox Hindus I need net point out the sovereign efficacy of tapasya.
('28', 486, 1, 15, 1099540) And satyagraha is nothing but tapasya for Truth.
('28', 486, 2, 16, 1099589) A DISTURBING ITEM
('28', 486, 3, 17, 1099607) There is however in the presidents letter a disturbing item.
('28', 486, 3, 18, 1099668) I must give it in his own words as follows:
('28', 486, 4, 19, 1099712) I bring to your notice an incident that took place at Chenganur under the auspices of the adherents of the Congress party on 6 th July, 1924. This was a savarna meeting announced to be held at the place.
('28', 486, 4, 20, 1099916) A representative of our
('28', 486, 5, 21, 1099940) committee was also invited to attend.
('28', 486, 5, 22, 1099978) By the machinations of a mischie vous clique, the meeting was subjected to a set of resolutions which were quite contrary to the propositions adopted for presentation at the meeting.
('28', 486, 5, 23, 1100161) Our representative and several other savarna members immediately left the hall
('28', 486, 6, 24, 1100240) and called up another meeting composed of very respectable caste Hindus at the residence of the Vanjipozhey chief, the premier landlord of Chenganur.
('28', 486, 6, 25, 1100390) Leave this alone, however gruesome and treacherous the tactics be.
('28', 486, 6, 26, 1100457) What we painfully deplore is that an organized attempt was made to vilify and hoot him and to lay hands on him if possible.
('28', 486, 6, 27, 1100581) He had to come away from the place without giving scent of his departure.
('28', 486, 6, 28, 1100655) This incident I refer to you just to bring to your notice the manner in which Congress propagandism is pursued in Travancore now.
('28', 486, 6, 29, 1100785) I ask conductors of the campaign to send me an explanation which I shall gladly print.
('28', 486, 6, 30, 1100872) They will not, I trust, hesitate to admit the error if any has been committed.
('28', 486, 7, 31, 1100951) REPORTERS BEWARE !
('28', 486, 8, 32, 1100970) The A.P. reporter in Ahmedabad lost me (temporarily I hope)
('28', 487, 0, 1, 1101030) 488 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 487, 1, 2, 1101072) all the reputation for humanity that I had built up through painful toil.
('28', 487, 1, 3, 1101146) For he reported me as saying that the only message I could send to afflicted Malabar was that those who were rendered naked and hungry and homeless should spin of Mr. Painter may receive Rs. I5,000 for damage to his reputation, I think I should receive at least Rs. 1,50,000 for damage done to mine.
('28', 487, 1, 4, 1101446) And if I could receive that sum, I should retrieve somewhat my lost reputation and make over the sum without deduction to the Malabar sufferers.
('28', 487, 1, 5, 1101591) But unlike Mr. Painter, I acquit both the reporter and the agency from all blame.
('28', 487, 1, 6, 1101673) The local reporter tells me he was not present at the meeting.
('28', 487, 1, 7, 1101736) The people who attended the meeting heard little, but the listeners thought I had said something about spinning.
('28', 487, 1, 8, 1101849) What would be more natural for me than that I should ask the Malabar suffers to Spill for food, clothing and lodging?
('28', 487, 1, 9, 1101967) Was not the great Acharya Ray doing the same thing?
('28', 487, 1, 10, 1102019) The poor reporter forgot that Dr. Ray was doing it after the people had settled down.
('28', 487, 1, 11, 1102105) However, the awful slip is a lesson for the reporters and the public.
('28', 487, 1, 12, 1102175) The reporters hold the reputation of public men in the hollow of their hands.
('28', 487, 1, 13, 1102253) It is not a light thing to misreport public mens speeches and acts.
('28', 487, 1, 14, 1102321) The public have to be equally careful about believing every report.
('28', 487, 1, 15, 1102389) a., gospel truth.
('28', 487, 1, 16, 1102407) So far as I am concerned, I must continue to warn the public and all concerned against believing what may be reported of me unless it .
('28', 487, 1, 17, 1102543) is certified by me as correct.
('28', 487, 1, 18, 1102574) I am in no hurry to have every word oft mine reported The reporters would, therefore, dome a favour, if they would not report me at all when they cannot get their notes confirmed by me.
('28', 487, 1, 19, 1102760) I am obliged to say all this because I have many painful memories of misreporting.
('28', 487, 1, 20, 1102843) In I896 I published in India a pamphlet covering 30 pages or more on British Indians in South Africa 1. A five line summary was cabled by Reuter to Natal 2. It was wholly contrary to the gist of my pamphlet.
('28', 487, 1, 21, 1103051) This very incorrect report inflamed the Natal colonists.
('28', 487, 1, 22, 1103108) I was nearly lynched to death by an infuriated crowd on my return to Natal.
('28', 487, 1, 23, 1103184) Lawyer friends pressed me to bring a suit for damages.
('28', 487, 1, 24, 1103239) But I was a non resister even then.
('28', 487, 1, 25, 1103275) I refused to sue.
('28', 487, 1, 26, 1103293) 3 I lost nothing by not suing.
('28', 487, 1, 27, 1103324) When the colonist perceived that I was not a bad sort.
('28', 487, 1, 28, 1103379) and that they had cruelly misjudged me, they
('28', 487, 2, 29, 1103424) 1 Vide The credentials, 14 8 1896 to Notes on the Grievances of the British Indians in South Africa, 22 09 1896 2 Vide Memorial to Secretary of States for the Colonies, 15 03 1897

('28', 488, 1, 2, 1103654) regretted the error.
('28', 488, 1, 3, 1103675) I therefore, in the end lost nothing by self res traint.
('28', 488, 1, 4, 1103732) But I have no desire to court another such experience even though it may bring me added glory.
('28', 488, 1, 5, 1103827) I want to put in more work, if God so wills it.
('28', 488, 1, 6, 1103875) I must, therefore, ask the reporters to spare me yet a while.
('28', 488, 1, 7, 1103937) HELP TO MALABAR I have not written the foregoing lines merely be put reporters and the public on their guard.
('28', 488, 1, 8, 1104047) Under the best of circumstances suchmistakes will occur.
('28', 488, 1, 9, 1104104) I am satisfied that there was no wilful neglect either in Ahmedabad or at the headquarters.
('28', 488, 1, 10, 1104196) But I wish to utilize the occasion for getting more money for the sufferers.
('28', 488, 1, 11, 1104273) I invite all those who were indignant over my supposed callousness to send me as much as they can towards helping the sufferers.
('28', 488, 1, 12, 1104402) I have invited the readers of Navajivan not merely to give me out of their savings, but even out of their necessaries, to share their clothes and food With the sufferers.
('28', 488, 1, 13, 1104573) The response has been quick and generous.
('28', 488, 1, 14, 1104615) The students of the Mahavidyalaya have, after the style of Shraddhhanandjis Pupils of the Gurukul during the South African campaign, been doing manual work at labourers wages on the very premises that are being built for them.
('28', 488, 1, 15, 1104842) The possibilities of such effort are immense.
('28', 488, 1, 16, 1104888) Boys and girls even under 12 have given up milk for a number of days, the savings to be devoted to the relief fund.
('28', 488, 1, 17, 1105004) This means in some cases 3 annas per day.
('28', 488, 1, 18, 1105046) Adults are denying themselves one meal per day.
('28', 488, 1, 19, 1105094) Boys and girls are giving up their clothes, retaining for them selves the veriest minimum.
('28', 488, 1, 20, 1105185) A girl has given up her silver anklets.
('28', 488, 1, 21, 1105225) A boy has given up his valued gold ear rings.
('28', 488, 1, 22, 1105271) 4 sister has sent in her four heavy gold bangles, another her heavy gold necklace.
('28', 488, 1, 23, 1105354) These are not exhaustive but typical instances.
('28', 488, 1, 24, 1105402) A little girl brought out all the coppers she had stolen.
('28', 488, 1, 25, 1105460) The National College students and others have given me heaps of yarn they have already spun.
('28', 488, 1, 26, 1105553) Others propose to spin for a certain period daily on behalf of the sufferers.
('28', 488, 1, 27, 1105631) These to me are more precious than the donations in the next column, generous as they are in several cases.
('28', 488, 1, 28, 1105739) May these offerings, but especially the little offerings and self denials of the little ones, give comfort to the homeless, hungry and naked men, women and children of the afflicted areas.
('28', 488, 1, 29, 1105928) I invite the readers of Young India who have not paid elsewhere to the fund to send their quota.
('28', 488, 1, 30, 1106025) Telegrams before me tell me that clothing will be just as welcome as money.
('28', 488, 1, 31, 1106101) The poorest must identify themselves with their countrymen in Malabar by some act of self denial.

('28', 489, 1, 2, 1106241) CLOTHING
('28', 489, 2, 3, 1106250) With reference to clothing being received in abundance, I wish to inform readers that no distinction is being made as to handspun or other clothing.
('28', 489, 2, 4, 1106399) Those who haste still got mill or foreign clothes may send these.
('28', 489, 2, 5, 1106465) Inquiry has been made in Bombay as to where clothing should be delivered.
('28', 489, 2, 6, 1106539) I suggest arrangements being made with the Provincial Congress Committee.
('28', 489, 2, 7, 1106613) Pending such arrangements, delivery may be made at the Navajivan depot in the Princess Street, Bombay.
('28', 489, 2, 8, 1106716) Donors will however please note the following instructions: 1. Dirty clothes should be washed and folded.
('28', 489, 2, 9, 1106822) 2. Torn clothes should be mended and folded.
('28', 489, 2, 10, 1106867) 3. All clothing should be well packed and tied in parcels with list of clothing and name of donor attached.
('28', 489, 2, 11, 1106975) These will not be acknowledged separately in these columns.
('28', 489, 2, 12, 1107035) But donors will do well not to deliver anything without a receipt being obtained at the office of delivery.
('28', 489, 2, 13, 1107143) I would warn donors from paying or giving any article to anyone without taking a full receipt and know ing the collectors.
('28', 489, 2, 14, 1107266) Whilst it flatters my pride to receive monies and jewellery and clothing at the Navajivan and Young India offices, I would ask the readers not to worry where they make their donations.
('28', 489, 2, 15, 1107451) They may pay wherever they like.
('28', 489, 2, 16, 1107484) It is enough 50 long as they pay.
('28', 489, 2, 17, 1107518) In a calamity of such magnitude as that through which the South is passings there should be no distinction between co operators and non co operators.
('28', 489, 2, 18, 1107668) As for the funds being sent to me, I am conferring with Mr. Vallabh bhai as to the best method of distribution.
('28', 489, 2, 19, 1107780) I am in correspondence with Mr. Rajagopalachari regarding the disposal, but if those who have been sending me wires will kindly send their suggestions I shall be grateful for them.

('28', 493, 5, 16, 1112372) Miss Sonja Schlesin served me as confidential secretary in South Africa for nearly seven years and during a most important part of my public life.
('28', 493, 5, 17, 1112519) She was entrusted with heavy responsibilities including account keeping, involving transactions extending to four figures at a time.
('28', 493, 5, 18, 1112652) She came in touch with hundreds of people belonging to different races and nationalities.
('28', 493, 5, 19, 1112742) During my last incarceration in South Africa, she was in sole charge of my affairs.
('28', 493, 5, 20, 1112826) I never once had reason to doubt her integrity or ability.
('28', 493, 5, 21, 1112885) Indeed, she did not work for the sake of pay but for the sake of the work itself which she loved.
('28', 493, 5, 22, 1112983) Her services were available to me at all times of the day.
('28', 493, 5, 23, 1113042) Her knowledge of shorthand and literary talents were of great assistance to me.
('28', 493, 5, 24, 1113122) I could not wish for a better secretary.
('28', 493, 5, 25, 1113163) I should like to hear that she was entrusted with a post requiring close attention, strictest honesty and ability.

('28', 494, 1, 2, 1113518) 293. LETTER TO K. NATARAJAN
('28', 494, 2, 3, 1113546) SABARMATI, August, 15, 1924
('28', 494, 3, 4, 1113574) DEAR MR. NATRAJAN, Before I went to jail I wrote to Mr. Petit asking if Pandit Benarasidas could be paid out of the I. C. A. 1 funds in connection with his work regarding Indians overseas.
('28', 494, 3, 5, 1113763) I was given to understand in the jail that Mr. Petit was prepared to recommend half the amount asked.
('28', 494, 3, 6, 1113865) Mr. Petit however has no recollection of this.
('28', 494, 3, 7, 1113912) Pandit Benarasi das gives to the Gujarat National College during College months about two hours per day for teaching Hindi.
('28', 494, 3, 8, 1114036) The rest of his time including the long vacations of four months he devotes wholly to the work for Indians overseas.
('28', 494, 3, 9, 1114153) He has made this cause his own and has become an expert in these matters.
('28', 494, 3, 10, 1114227) Mr. Petit admits the value of the Pandits services, but says he should be in Bombay.
('28', 494, 3, 11, 1114312) Pandit Benarasi das is a quiet man of a retiring disposition.
('28', 494, 3, 12, 1114374) He is essentially a student.
('28', 494, 3, 13, 1114403) I have placed at his disposal rooms at the Ashram where he is staying.
('28', 494, 3, 14, 1114474) I do not think that his work will be more valuable for his stay in Bombay.
('28', 494, 3, 15, 1114549) Of course, he can go to Bombay whenever his presence is required.
('28', 494, 3, 16, 1114615) The Pandit is at present being paid Rs. 130 per month, on my recommendation, by the Gujarat Vidyapith.
('28', 494, 3, 17, 1114718) His co worker, Totaramji of Fiji, who is also living at the Ashram is being paid Rs. 50 out of Ashram funds.
('28', 494, 3, 18, 1114827) Rs. 50 are paid for the expenses on postage, wires, etc., incurred by the Pandit.
('28', 494, 3, 19, 1114909) But I feel that it is not right to saddle the College or the Ashram with the expenses when the largest part of his time is given to the overseas work.
('28', 494, 3, 20, 1115060) I therefore feel that the Association should pay at least of the past expenses, and in future _ of the Rs. 230 disbursed monthly by the College and Ashram.
('28', 494, 3, 21, 1115216) Will you please let me know if my proposal appeals to you?
('28', 494, 4, 22, 1115275) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI From a photostat of the typewritten office copy: S.N. 9989

('28', 496, 2, 3, 1116598) APPENDIX I
('28', 496, 3, 4, 1116609) SWARAJISTS STATEMENT ON COUNCIL ENTRY1
('28', 496, 4, 5, 1116648) May 22, 1924
('28', 496, 5, 6, 1116661) We are obliged to Mahatma Gandhi for the trouble he has taken to discuss with us the various points involved in the question of Council entry and are indebted to his courtesy for the opportunity we have had of seeing an advance copy of the statement he has issued to the Press.
('28', 496, 5, 7, 1116939) The views expressed by him in the course of con versation and those embodied in the Press statement have all been considered by us with care and attention due to his great personality, but with all the reverence we entertain for him and his opinions, we remain unconvinced by his reasoning.
('28', 496, 6, 8, 1117230) We regret we have not been able to convince Mahatma Gandhi of the sound ness of the Swarajist position regarding Council entry.
('28', 496, 6, 9, 1117358) We fail to understand how such entry can be regarded as inconsistent with the doctrine of the Non co operation resolution of the Nagpur Congress.
('28', 496, 7, 10, 1117504) But if non co operation is more a matter of mental attitude than of the appli cation of a living principle to the existing facts of our national life with special refe rence to the varying attitudes of the bureaucratic Government which rules that life, we conceive it to be our duty to sacrifice even non co operation to serve the real interests of the country.
('28', 496, 8, 11, 1117866) In our view this principle includes self reliance in all activities which make for the healthy growth of the nation and resistance to the bureaucracy as it impedes our pro gress towards swaraj.
('28', 496, 8, 12, 1118060) We are, however, anxious to end this fruitless verbal discussion making it clear, however, that Council entry is and can be thoroughly consistent with the principle of non co operation as we understand that principle to be.
('28', 496, 9, 13, 1118284) We desire further to make it clear that we have not used in our programme the word obstruction in the technical sense of English Parliamentary history.
('28', 496, 9, 14, 1118436) Obstruc tion in that sense is impossible in subordinate and limited Legislative bodies, such as the Legislative Assembly and Provincial Legislatures under the Reforms Act undou btedly are.
('28', 496, 9, 15, 1118625) Possibly another word should have been found to convey our rneaning.
('28', 496, 9, 16, 1118694) We may state, however, that our position is really not so much of obstruction in the Parliamentary sense as that of resistance to the obstruction placed in our path to
('28', 496, 10, 17, 1118862) 1 This was issued jointly by C. R. Das and Motilal Nehru on behalf of the Swaraj Party.
('28', 497, 0, 1, 1118950) 498 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 497, 1, 2, 1118992) swaraj by the bureaucratic Government.
('28', 497, 1, 3, 1119031) It is this resistance which we meant to imply when we used the word obstruction.
('28', 497, 1, 4, 1119112) This was clearly indicated in the way we defined and described non co operation in the preamble to the constitution of the Swaraj Party.
('28', 497, 1, 5, 1119249) It is the removal of such bureaucratic obstruction which we feel we must emphasize.
('28', 497, 1, 6, 1119333) This is the policy which we have hitherto followed in the Legis lative bodies and it is this policy which must in future be more and more effectively directed to the varying needs and problems of our national life.
('28', 497, 2, 7, 1119548) Here again we are anxious to end all verbal discussion as to whether this can be aptly described as a policy of uniform, continuous and consistent obstruction.
('28', 497, 2, 8, 1119708) We are content to detail our policy and then leave it to our friends to give it a more appro priate name, should they so desire.
('28', 497, 3, 9, 1119837) In the light of this principle and policy, we would here state our future pro gramme of action within and outside the Legislative bodies.
('28', 497, 4, 10, 1119975) Within the Legislative bodies we must continue:
('28', 497, 5, 11, 1120023) (1) To threw out budgets unless and until the system of Government is altered in recognition of our rights or as a matter of settlement between the Parliament and the people of this country.
('28', 497, 5, 12, 1120214) In justification of this step, all that we need point out are a few salient facts connected with the budget in the Central Government, which are more or less true of Provincial budgets also.
('28', 497, 5, 13, 1120405) Out of a total of 131 crores (excluding Railways), only 16 crores are votable.
('28', 497, 5, 14, 1120484) Further, out of the non votable amount, as much as 67 crores, i.e., more than half the amount of the budget, is for military expenditure.
('28', 497, 5, 15, 1120622) It is thus clear that the people of this country have a right to vote only on less than one eighth of the total amount of the budget, and even the exercise of this limited right is subject to the power of restoration in the Governor General.
('28', 497, 6, 16, 1120864) is, therefore, clear that the people have neither any voice in the framing of the budget nor any control over those who frame it.
('28', 497, 6, 17, 1120994) They have no power either over the raising of the revenue or its expenditure.
('28', 497, 6, 18, 1121072) On what principle then, may we ask, is it our duty to pass such a budget and take the responsibility of being a party to it?
('28', 497, 6, 19, 1121197) We have no doubt the support of many self respecting men in the country in holding, as we do, that it is, our clear duty to throw out such budget in all Legislative bodies, unless and until this vicious system is changed.
('28', 497, 7, 20, 1121419) (2) To throw out all proposals for legislative enactments by which the burearcracy proposes to consolidate its power.
('28', 497, 7, 21, 1121537) It is conceivable that some good may incidentally result from a few of such measures but we are clearly of opinion that in the larger interests of the country it is better to temporarily sacrifice such little benefit rather than add an iota to the powers of the bureaucracy which already irresistible.
('28', 497, 8, 22, 1121839) 1 Section 67 A of the Government of India Act empowered the Governor General in Council to restore cuts if that course was considered necessary.
('28', 498, 0, 1, 1121984) VOL.28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15 AUGUST, 1924 499
('28', 498, 1, 2, 1122026) (3) To introduce all resolutions, measures and bills which are necessary for the healthy growth of our national life and the consequent displacement of the bureau cracy.
('28', 498, 1, 3, 1122196) We heartily accept the suggestion made by Mahatma Gandhi in his statement and we think that the resolution mentioned by him in support of the cons tructive programme of the Congress should certainly be accepted by the Swaraj Party.
('28', 498, 1, 4, 1122428) The principle of self reliance and resistance to the bureaucratic obstructions upon which we have hitherto acted, calls for their adoption, and if the constructive work of the Congress comes within the principle of non co operation, no less do these resolutions although they represent constructive activity within the Legislative bodies
('28', 498, 2, 5, 1122766) (4) To follow a definite effective policy based on the same principle to prevent the drain of public wealth from India by checking all activities leading to exploitation.
('28', 498, 3, 6, 1122937) To make this policy effective we should take and occupy every place which is open to the members of the Central and Provincial Legislatures by election.
('28', 498, 3, 7, 1123090) In our opinion we should not only fill elective posts, but serve on every committee when it is possible to invite the attention of the members of our party to this important question and we call upon them to decide this matter as soon as possible.
('28', 498, 4, 8, 1123338) Our policy outside the Legislative bodies should be as follows:
('28', 498, 5, 9, 1123402) In the first place, we should give our whole hearted support to the cinstructive programme of Mahatma Gandhi and work that programme unitedly through the Congress organizations.
('28', 498, 5, 10, 1123580) We are decidedly of opinion that our Council work must necessarily lose much of its strength without the backing of the outside constructive work; for it is not inside but outside The legislatures that we must look her the sanction without which the effective carding out of our Council policy is impossible.
('28', 498, 5, 11, 1123889) Indeed in the matter of constructive work the mutual support of both inside and outside activity must, in our opinion, give strength to the very sanction upon which we rely.
('28', 498, 5, 12, 1124063) In this connections we un hestiatingly accept the suggestion of Mahatma Gandhi regarding civil disobedience.
('28', 498, 5, 13, 1124172) We can assure him that the moment we find that it is impossible to meet the selfish obstinancy of the bureaucracy without civil disobedience, we will retire from the Legislative bodies and help him to prepare the country for such civil disobedience, if by that time the country has not already become prepared, and we will then unreservedly place ourselves under his guidance and work through the Congress organization under his banner in order that we may unitedly work out a substantial programme of civil disobedience.
('28', 498, 6, 14, 1124694) In the second place, we must supplement the work of the Congress by helping labour and peasant organizations throughout the country.
('28', 498, 6, 15, 1124827) The problem of labour is always a difficult problem to solve in every country, but in India the difficulties are greater.
('28', 498, 6, 16, 1124949) On the one hand we must find out a way of organization by which we can
('28', 499, 0, 1, 1125020) 500 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('28', 499, 1, 2, 1125062) prevent exploitation of labour by capitalists or by landlords, but on the other hand we must be on our guard to see that those very organizations may not themselves be the source of oppression by nursing extravagant and unreasonable demands.
('28', 499, 1, 3, 1125304) Labour undoubtedly requires protection, but so do industrial enterprises.
('28', 499, 1, 4, 1125378) Our organization must protect both from exploitation and the Trade Union Congress must be so organized as to be able to serve this useful purpose.
('28', 499, 1, 5, 1125525) We bold that in the long run the real interests of both and the country at large are identical.
('28', 499, 2, 6, 1125621) We feel happy that we have had this opportunity of putting our views before the country side by side with Mahatma Gandhis opinion, for we feel certain that the perusal will make it obvious that, notwithstanding some differences of view, there is an abiding and fundamental unity amongst both parties of the Indian National Congress.
('28', 499, 2, 7, 1125954) Both parties feel the necessity of working the constructive programme whether within or outside the Legislative bodies.
('28', 499, 2, 8, 1126074) In this direction, we feel confident, lies the germ of a fruitful alliance between Mahatma Gandhi and the Swaraj Party.
('28', 499, 2, 9, 1126194) Our joint effort in the same or different directions will furnish a fitting answer to the bureaucracy unwilling to recognize the rights and liberty of the Indian people, and we emphatically assert that, in our determination to work with the same object in the same or different spheres is expressed the determination of the Indian nation to bring the struggle for swaraj to a successful issue.
('28', 499, 2, 10, 1126588) The Voice of Freedom, pp.

('28', 499, 4, 12, 1126626) LETTER FROM BHAGWAN DAS
('28', 499, 5, 13, 1126650) BANARAS, June 5, 1924 TO THE EDITOR, YOUNG INDIA
('28', 499, 6, 14, 1126699) DEAR SIR,
('28', 499, 7, 15, 1126709) I have read, as many thousands of others must have read, with anxious care and deep attention, your weighty pronouncement on Hindu Muslim Tension: Its Cause and Cure, in Young India for 29 5 1924. The many fairly well known (but not equally well realized) truths which it puts plainly, frankly, freely, in admirable
('28', 499, 8, 16, 1127025) language, will now be brought home to millions (through translations), by the autho rity of your profoundly trusted sincerity, as they were not before.
('28', 499, 8, 17, 1127177) Yet it seems to me that a deeper diagnosis of the Cause and a more radical prescription for the Cure are needed.
('28', 499, 8, 18, 1127290) I, therefore, in compliance with your own footnote, submit a few questions with respect to some of your statements, in the hope of further elucidation.
('28', 499, 9, 19, 1127442) (I) You say, at p.
('28', 499, 9, 20, 1127461) 176 1: My own experience but confirms the opinion that the
('28', 499, 10, 21, 1127520) 1 The page numbers cited are those of Young India.

('28', 500, 1, 2, 1127613) Mussalman as a rule is a bully, and the Hindu as a rule is a coward. Is it really always and everywhere so, as a rule?
('28', 500, 1, 3, 1127732) If always so, or only sometimes so, why is it so?
('28', 500, 2, 4, 1127782) Without the full answer to these questions, the mere advice to the Hindus to be brave, either non violently, or violently, will remain ineffectual.
('28', 500, 3, 5, 1127930) Are the Mussalmans and the Hindus of India two different races, two different ethnic stocks?
('28', 500, 3, 6, 1128023) Most patently not.
('28', 500, 3, 7, 1128042) Ninety nine per cent of the Mussalmans are descended from Hindu ancestors or are recent converts in their own persons.
('28', 500, 4, 8, 1128161) Is the record of the Hindu soldiers, Sikhs, Gurkhas, Dogras, Rajputs, Jats, Baiswaras, Mahrattas, Ahirs, Nayars, Telingas, of even the non combatant stretcher bearer Kahars, worse than that of any Mussalman soldiers, or any Christian soldiers, European or any other?
('28', 500, 4, 9, 1128428) Undisputedly not, again.
('28', 500, 5, 10, 1128453) How then are we to interpret your statement that in the majority of quarrels, the Hindus come out second best?

('28', 500, 6, 13, 1128937) difference of race or ancestry between them, when there is no inherent bravery (or bullyness, which is a very different thing) in the one or inherent cowardice in the otherwhy is it that the Hindu behaves as a coward in these petty quarrels and rowdinesses, and tempts and evokes the bravery or the bullyness in the Mussalman?
('28', 500, 7, 14, 1129264) Is it something in take present condition of the two religions as such which makes the Hindu such a coward and the Mussalman such a brave?
('28', 500, 7, 15, 1129403) Can it be this miserable touch me not business, this awful hypocrisy of self centred selfishness and conceited and sanctimonious self righteousness born of the notion of hereditary superior and inferior casteswhich, killing all mutual sympathy, prevents Hindu from helping Hindu in such quarrels, and therefore makes each one a coward, because of the sense of helplessness, while the Mussalmans democractic religion ensures him help and makes him brave
('28', 500, 8, 16, 1129856) It is not only the so called depressed classes that are untouchables; all the castes and sub castes and sub sub castes of Hindus are all mutually untouchables, more or less, in this, that or the other respect!
('28', 500, 8, 17, 1130066) A religion which has come to this pass of mutual touch me not and therefore antipathy and distrust must necessarily breed cowards who must necessarily be eaten up by the braves whom they must nece ssarily bring into being by providing the temptation.
('28', 500, 8, 18, 1130317) Islam, also degenerate as it is today, is yet distinctly better in some respects than the degenerate Hinduism of today.
('28', 500, 8, 19, 1130437) If it had only less slaughter and more philosophy, it would be as good as any of the higher forms of Hinduism, and far better than most of the lower ones.

('28', 505, 4, 6, 1141431) SOONITA, RIDGE ROAD, MALABAR HILL, July 28, 1924
('28', 505, 5, 7, 1141480) DEAR MAHATMAJI,
('28', 505, 6, 8, 1141496) Thanks for your letter answering some of the questions I put to Maulana Mahomed Ali.
('28', 505, 7, 9, 1141581) After I sent you my last letter enclosing a copy of the questions, I read in the papers that you had lost considerable weight and were suffering from headache and occasional fever.
('28', 505, 7, 10, 1141762) Please pardon me for troubling you with the questions in your present state of health.
('28', 505, 7, 11, 1141849) I would not have done so had I seen the papers before writing.
('28', 505, 8, 12, 1141912) I am now getting very anxious about your health.
('28', 505, 8, 13, 1141961) The most obvious thing to do is to stop all work at once and take complete rest.
('28', 505, 8, 14, 1142042) But the misfortune is that you will not do this.
('28', 505, 8, 15, 1142091) All great men have their weaknesses and sometimes they are more than those of ordinary men.
('28', 505, 8, 16, 1142183) Specially in matters concerning the care of their own persons.
('28', 505, 8, 17, 1142246) You recognize the fact that you are not physically fit for the work you have undertaken and yet will not do the one thing which everybody including yourself knows has to be done to restore you to your normal state of health !
('28', 505, 8, 18, 1142472) I do not know any name for that other than national misfortune.
('28', 505, 9, 19, 1142536) I shall be perfectly frank with you even at the risk of offending you.
('28', 505, 9, 20, 1142607) Let me tell you plainly that the kind of work you are doing at present can very well wait and that the nation will not be in the least poorer if it is not done at all and if in its place we have our Gandhi restored to health and vigour at the end of say a month or even two months.
('28', 505, 9, 21, 1142889) I should cut you off from all communication with India for a time and send you out in the open sea for a fairly long cruise without any land being in sight for six weeks.
('28', 505, 9, 22, 1143060) The least that you can do is to take a trip to see Ceylon where you will have an entire change of surroundings.
('28', 505, 9, 23, 1143172) Your dak should await you at the Ashram
('28', 506, 0, 1, 1143212) VOL.28 : 22 MAY, 1924 15 AUGUST, 1924 507
('28', 506, 1, 2, 1143254) during your absence.
('28', 506, 1, 3, 1143275) But it is useless to go on writing in this strain.
('28', 506, 1, 4, 1143326) I am afraid I can make no impression on you and there is nothing for us but to resign ourselves to whatever the future has in store for us.
('28', 506, 1, 5, 1143466) I have however made up my mind about one thing and that is that I will not be a particeps criminis in the suicide you are
('28', 506, 2, 6, 1143588) committing by troubling you with any further correspondence or talk about any work however urgent it may be until you have very considerably improved your health.
('28', 506, 3, 7, 1143751) Your postcard 1 must be awaiting my return to Allahabad.
('28', 506, 3, 8, 1143808) I am going back day after tomorrow night.
('28', 506, 3, 9, 1143850) I should have run up to Sabarmati for a day if 1 thought I could be of any use whatever.
('28', 506, 3, 10, 1143939) But I expect no good to come out of my visit and have therefore given up the idea.
('28', 506, 3, 11, 1144022) Let me however ask you a question.
('28', 506, 3, 12, 1144057) Would you put me down as mad if I were to ask you to spend a few weeks on the bank of the Ganges some five miles out of Allahabad at a garden house belonging to a friend of mine which is at my entire disposal?
('28', 506, 3, 13, 1144267) This is the only alternative to your going out to sea that I can think of for the benefit of your health.
('28', 506, 4, 14, 1144373) Yours sincerely,
('28', 506, 5, 15, 1144390) MOTILAL NEHRU
